title: A Comprehensive Methodology for Detecting Demagnetization and Initial Rotor Position in SM-PMSMs
authors: Mohammad Rastegar, Milad Bahrami-Fard, Mohammad Hassan Ghaderi, Behnam Mohammadian Mosammam, Poras T. Balsara, Babak Fahimi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Estimating the initial rotor position is critical for the proper startup, efficient torque production, and reliable operation of permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs), as well as for preventing demagnetization. This article presents a comprehensive method for detecting the rotor position under standstill and flying shaft (i.e., no stator excitation) conditions in a surface-mounted permanent magnet synchronous motor (SM-PMSM). Initial rotor position detection in SM-PMSMs is challenging due to weak magnetic saliency, nonlinearities, and parameter variations. Even small inaccuracies can significantly affect motor efficiency, performance, and longevity, particularly in applications involving varying speeds or loads. In this work, a series of voltage pulses using basis space vectors are applied to the stator windings of a three-phase SM-PMSM. The positive and negative current values are evaluated, alongside the recorded differences between their absolute peak values. These differences, influenced by the permanent magnets, are leveraged to detect the rotor position without direct access to the rotor. A numerical model of a four-pole SM-PMSM is developed using Maxwell 2-D to validate the magnetic circuit changes. The proposed method's performance in early detection of demagnetization is also introduced and validated numerically and experimentally. Finally, the method's efficacy is experimentally assessed under standstill and flying shaft conditions, along with its impact on synchronous startup in sensorless control of SM-PMSMs and its effectiveness in early demagnetization detection.

title: Huygens Metasurface-Enabled Holographic Communication: Huygens Channel and Effective Degrees of Freedom
authors: Lv Ye, Yunchao Song, Chen Liu, Bo Li, Yang Bao, Yusong Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Huygens metasurfaces (HMS) formed by Huygens sources can flexibly control electromagnetic waves to generate any desired radiation pattern. This capability is precisely what holographic multiple-input multiple-output (HMIMO) communications seek to achieve. Therefore, deploying HMS at the base station provides an attractive solution for next-generation wireless communication systems. Against this background, this study establishes an electromagnetic channel model to analyze the effective degree of freedom (EDoF) of HMS systems, in which EDoF directly characterizes the spatial multiplexing capability of HMS systems. This aspect has not been addressed in previous research. Specifically, we first model the channel of HMS using the electric and magnetic dyadic Green’s functions in electromagnetic theory. Since the channel is unique to HMS, it is specially called the Huygens channel. Then, we analyze the EDoF of the Huygens channel. Finally, by comparing with existing EDoFe studies based on the electric dyadic Green’s Function (EDGF) channel, the results demonstrate that the Huygens channel exhibits a larger EDoF in the near-field region. This provides important insights for the design and optimization of future communication systems, such as the HMIMO communications system.

title: Leveraging Network Structure to Emulate Quantum Memory
authors: Hilal Sultan Duranoglu Tunc, Joy Halder, Riccardo Bassoli, Gerhard P. Fettweis, Frank H. P. Fitzek
publish: IEEE Network
abstract: Quantum memories, which play a critical role in various aspects of quantum networks—such as timing synchronization, fidelity preservation, network performance continuity, and efficient resource management—are not well-suited for practical deployment due to their high cost and complex implementation requirements. For this reason, in our study, we propose a low-cost and easy-to-implement alternative method called soft memory, which does not require any physical quantum memory hardware and is based on a delay-aware routing strategy. Under varying threshold and request time window values, we evaluate two key performance metrics—mean time difference and request success rate—across three types of quantum networks: (i) memoryless quantum networks, (ii) quantum networks equipped with fixed qubit storage time, and (iii) the proposed soft memory architecture. Despite requiring no additional physical hardware, the soft memory approach achieves a request success rate nearly equivalent to that of a quantum memory with 0.15-second storage time, while providing a lower mean time difference.

title: Incremental Learning Strategy With Multi-View Deep Learning for Disease-Related miRNAs/lncRNAs Identification
authors: Ning Ai, Haoliang Yuan, Zhonghua Lu, Yong Liang, Qi Hong Lai, Loi Lei Lai, Hongmin Cai, Dong Ouyang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: The identification of new biomarkers for various disease-related microRNAs (miRNAs) and long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) is an issue of critical biological significance. Computational identification for miRNA/lncRNA-disease associations is of great practical significance, which can substantially save the cost of traditional experimental detection. With the continuous development of sequencing technology, different multi-omics data have exploded. The existing computational methods identify disease-related miRNAs and lncRNAs by inputting all data resources. However, with the explosive growth of data, it is hard to treat new data as supplementary input to continue training former models trained by static data, which is a limitation in biology, medicine, and other fields. To address this challenge, we propose the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\mathit{I}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>ncremental <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\mathit{L}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>earning <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\mathit{S}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>trategy for disease-related miRNAs/lncRNAs identification via <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\mathit{M}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>ulti-view <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\mathit{D}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>eep <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\mathit{L}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>earning (ILSMDL). Firstly, ILSMDL applies masking contrastive learning (MCL) strategy to enhance the generalization capability of itself. Secondly, this framework leverages graph transformer (GT) to encode node positional information for similarity networks (homogeneous graphs), and channel attention (CA) mechanism to improve representation by explicitly assigning adaptive weights to different masked and unmasked similarities. Thirdly, ILSMDL performs a deep matrix factorization (DMF) based on the reconstruction to reduce the false negatives and identify the latent miRNAs and lncRNAs associated with diseases. Finally, the incremental multi-view training pattern is devised to face this challenge. We consider these different similarity networks can be incrementally trained by our framework. In comparative experiments, ILSMDL demonstrates impressive capability across two datasets. Moreover, case studies further validate ILSMDL predictive reliability, underscoring its effectiveness in discovering new associations.

title: Coastal Aquaculture Pond Recognition via Scale and Boundary Dynamic Awareness Network in Remote Sensing Imagery
authors: Zhanchao Huang, Junchao Cai, Wenjun Hong, Weiwang Guan, Jiajun Zhou, Hua Su, Shou Feng, Ran Tao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Coastal aquaculture ponds, vital to marine aquaculture, are widely distributed along coastlines and hold significant economic and ecological value. Accurately mapping their distribution and types is essential for optimizing marine spatial resources and protecting coastal ecosystems. While deep learning has improved detection from remote sensing imagery, precise recognition still faces challenges such as large scale and shape variations, blurred boundaries in dense areas, and a lack of high-resolution fine-grained datasets. To this end, a Scale and Boundary Dynamic Awareness Network (BDA-Net) is proposed in this paper. Specifically, A Taylor-optimized Scale-adaptive Feature Interaction (TSFI) structure is designed to achieve efficient multi-scale feature adaptation for diverse pond sizes and shapes, overcoming fixed-scale Transformer limitations while preserving accuracy with lower computation via Taylor approximation. Moreover, a Frequency-guided Adaptive Boundary Convolution (FABC) is developed to resolve boundary confusion and detail loss by adaptively fusing multi-directional frequency features, enhancing contour-aligned sampling for improved fine-grained discrimination and recognition performance. Additionally, a high-resolution fine-grained dataset is constructed to fill the gap in low spatial resolution and coarse category subdivision of existing aquaculture pond datasets. Extensive experiments on this dataset and public benchmarks demonstrate that the proposed BDA-Net achieves an mIoU of 85.71%, outperforming the existing methods by over 5.45%.

title: Efficient Attention-Based Learning Network for Object-Task Affordance Graph Generation in Robotic Manipulation Cognition
authors: Zhongli Wang, Jiake Lu, Shijie Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems
abstract: Cognitive abilities in robotic manipulation are crucial for advancing robotic intelligence. In complex environments with diverse objects, a robot must understand task affordances between objects to enhance its cognitive manipulation abilities. Task affordances represent potential manipulation relationships between objects. Leveraging the representation and reasoning power of knowledge graphs, we model task affordances in the form of <subject, relation, object =, where subjects and objects are nodes, and relations are edges. The paper proposes an attention-based object-task affordance graph generation network for robotic manipulation cognition. The proposed network effectively extracts subject, relation, and object features and combines them through multi-scale channel attention mechanisms to identify task relations and generate object-task affordance graphs. To train the network, we construct a novel objecttask affordance dataset that includes labeled task affordances across various scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that our method significantly improves the accuracy of object-task affordance graphs and endnotes the robot with manipulation cognitive capabilities during task execution.

title: Compact Broadband Circularly Polarized Filtering Patch Antenna With Multi-Element Coupling Structure
authors: Xianjing Lin, Wenyong Liu, Zuhao Jiang, Weichao Kuang
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents a compact broadband circularly polarized (CP) filtering patch antenna with multi-element coupling structure. The antenna consists of two substrate layers. The upper substrate layer incorporates a main radiating patch with an etched rectangular slot, a pair of unequal-sized L-shaped parasitic stubs placed along the +45∘ diagonal of the main patch, and surrounding microstrip patches. The lower substrate features a ground plane etched with an asymmetric U-shaped slot on its top surface and a microstrip feedline on the bottom. The signal enters the port, propagates along the microstrip feedline, and couples to the main radiating patch through the asymmetric U-shaped slot, generating CP radiation. Further coupling between the main patch and the surrounding microstrip patches produces two additional CP modes, enabling wideband CP operation. Without the need for additional filtering circuits, the antenna achieves bandpass filtering characteristics by introducing two controllable radiation nulls near 2.0 GHz and its second harmonic at 4.0 GHz through the unequal L-shaped parasitic stubs. A third radiation null near 3.6 GHz is generated by the rectangular slot etched on the main patch. The proposed design maintains a compact profile (0.54λ0 × 0.54λ0 × 0.07λ0, where λ0 corresponds to the lowest operating frequency) while realizing integrated wideband CP and filtering performance. The measured results demonstrate an impedance bandwidth of 23.1% (2.64–3.33 GHz), an axial ratio (AR) bandwidth of 11% (2.8–3.125 GHz) and a stable in-band gain of approximately 7 dB. The out-of-band suppression levels reach 17 dB and 24 dB in the lower and upper stopbands, respectively, confirming good CP filtering performance.

title: DeepFingerNet Predicts Finger Trajectory from ECoG Measurements_supp1-3644562.docx
authors: Feng Wan
publish: N/A
abstract: Decoding fine motor movements, such as finger trajectories, from brain signals poses a critical challenge for brain-computer interface (BCI) systems, particularly when employing electrocorticography (ECoG) because of its inherent signal complexity and inter-subject variability. Although traditional machine learning and deep learning methods have advanced coarse motor control, they often fall short in capturing and generalizing. To address these limitations, we propose DeepFingerNet– a novel architecture based on nested U-Nets designed specifically for ECoG-based finger trajectory prediction. DeepFingerNet enhances feature extraction and fusion by leveraging nested skip connections, which effectively integrate low-level spatial details with high-level abstract representations. We employ a hybrid loss function, combining cosine similarity and mean squared error, to optimize the direction and magnitude of the decoded trajectories. Evaluations on two publicly available ECoG datasets demonstrate the model’s effectiveness, achieving correlation coefficients of 0.69 (a 17% improvement over baseline methods) on BCI Competition IV Dataset 4 and 0.54 (a 5% improvement) on the Stanford University dataset, respectively. These results underscore DeepFingerNet’s potential to significantly improve the reliability and precision of fine finger predictions from ECoG measurements, thereby supporting advanced applications in neuroprosthetics and human-machine interaction.

title: High-Precision Motion Control of a Robotic Arm Using the Manifold Deformation Design Scheme
authors: Chao-Chung Liu, Ming-Nan Chen, Chao-Shu Liu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study focuses on the application of the Manifold Deformation Design Scheme (MDDS) as an advanced control strategy for a custom-built robotic arm, aiming to achieve precise, stable, and efficient motion control under complex and dynamic working conditions. MDDS offers a novel approach to nonlinear system control by deforming the system’s dynamic manifold to conform to desired performance objectives. Through this transformation, it effectively simplifies controller design, reduces the dependence on gain scheduling, and enhances the system’s ability to cope with model uncertainties and external disturbances. To comprehensively evaluate the performance of MDDS, simulation experiments are conducted along three representative trajectories: linear, circular, and workpiece paths. The results demonstrate that the MDDS-based control system achieves significantly smaller position errors, faster convergence speeds, and superior stability compared with the traditional Proportional Integral Derivative (PID) control method. To validate the simulation findings, experimental tests are performed on a physical prototype of the robotic arm following the same trajectory profiles. The experimental outcomes closely match the simulation results, confirming that MDDS maintains lower error levels across all motion axes and ensures smoother and more precise motion responses. Overall, both simulation and experimental analyses verify that MDDS provides a robust, accurate, and efficient control solution for robotic arms, offering substantial improvements in motion precision, adaptability, and system stability over conventional control techniques.

title: Expression of Concern for: Multi Label Classification for Emotion Analysis of Autism Spectrum Disorder Children using Deep Neural Networks
authors: T. Lakshmi Praveena, N.V.Muthu Lakshmi
publish: 2021 Third International Conference on Inventive Research in Computing Applications (ICIRCA)
abstract: Emotion recognition and analysis is the process of identifying emotions and feelings of a person. Emotion analysis process is accurate in identifying expression in normal people in a single attempt. Emotion analysis is difficult in case of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) children which are suffering with communication problems and speech problems. This paper proposed an optimized deep learning model with multi label classification for predicting ASD and NoASD with emotion analysis in children of age group 1 to 10 years. The kaggle dataset [1] of 1857 ASD children and 1850 Typically Developed (TD) children are used in this paper. Proposed model performance is tested on Yale Expression Dataset [2], CAFÉ children dataset [3] and also tested on social media dataset of autism parents group. The model is implemented by extracting face landmarks and is used to predict ASD and NoASD as first classification label and emotion is detected based on landmarks by computing internal and external distances by feature wise. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) is used to work with extracted face landmarks by using optimization methods, dropout, batch normalization and parameter updating. The proposed model is applied to predict 6 emotions irrespective of 4 general emotions with better accuracy.

title: Reducing Energy Consumption in Robotic Processes Using a Single-DOF Bennett Mechanism
authors: Tomáš Poštulka, Daniel Huczala, Grzegorz Orzechowski, Aki Mikkola, Zdenko Bobovský, Róbert Huňady
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper explores the energy-saving potential of a spatial, single-degree-of-freedom (1-DOF) Bennett mechanism in industrial pick-and-place tasks. In comparison to conventional robotic arms with multiple actuators, Bennett’s mechanism uses a closed kinematic structure and a single actuator to realize complicated spatial trajectories. Through both simulation and experimental comparison with a commercial UR3e collaborative robot, the mechatronic prototype of the Bennett mechanism demonstrated a reduction in energy consumption of up to 92% for identical tasks. The results confirm that closed loop mechanisms can be an energy-efficient option for tasks with simple, repetitive motion. While the Bennett mechanism is limited to predefined trajectories, its simplicity, low energy footprint, and suitability for repetitive tasks make it a promising alternative for dedicated automation scenarios. This study underscores the value of low-redundancy kinematic designs in future industrial robotics.

title: AI in Gastrointestinal Endoscopy: Enhancing Accuracy and Speed in Disease Detection
authors: Masrufa Akter Muni, Mustafizur Rahman, Rahat Hasan, Md Mohaimin Rashid, Rakibul Islam, Khandakar Rabbi Ahmed
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The use of artificial intelligence (AI) in gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy has demonstrated enormous promise for increasing procedural efficiency and diagnostic precision. In order to increase polyp segmentation performance, this research suggests PolypTransNet, a deep learning (DL) technique that combines the power of Transformer-based attention mechanisms and convolutional neural networks (CNNs). With the Kvasir-SEG dataset, the model achieves a Dice accuracy of 91.42%, an IoU of 84.88%, and an inference speed of 22 FPS, surpassing current benchmarks such as U-Net, ResUNet++, and PraNet. The network incorporates EfficientN etBO as a lightweight encoder and self-attention blocks for global context modeling, which facilitates both precise boundary definition and real-time deployment through ONNX optimization. Experimental outcomes validate that PolypTransNet presents a practical and reliable solution for AI-assisted colonoscopy, with excellent potential for clinical use in the early detection of colorectal cancer.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Approach for Advanced Detection of GAN-Generated Images
authors: Sara A. Al-Khazraji, Khalid Shaker
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The rapid advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies, particularly generative AI, it raises serious concerns regarding misuse. One of the most prominent issues is the increasing difficulty in distinguishing between real and AI-generated images, which can lead to misinformation, and loss of trust in digital content. As a result, there is a growing need for reliable detection methods capable of identifying synthetic content. In this study, we introduce a robust and generalizable model designed to accurately differentiate between real and generated images. Our approach utilizes a hybrid architecture that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for local feature extraction with Vision Transformers (ViTs) to performing classification. The model trained on Pro-Gan only, to perform binary classification between authentic and synthetic images. It achieved a high training accuracy of 99%. To evaluate its generalization capability, the model was tested on images from unseen generators Cycle-Gan and Style-Gan achieving accuracies of 89% and 81%, respectively. These results confirm the model’s strong performance .

title: Research on Sentiment Classification of Online Reviews Based on Deep Semantic Analysis
authors: Heping Gou, Yongxia Jing, Qiang Han
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Systems (ICCS)
abstract: Sentiment in reviews is often embedded in complex inter-word or inter-sentence relationships. Traditional sentiment classification models struggle to effectively capture global semantics, and sentiment polarity may be reversed due to negation words, modifiers, or contextual cues. To comprehensively analyze global semantics and local features, this paper proposes a Chinese text sentiment classification model that integrates BERTand BiLSTM, adopting focal loss to dynamically adjust the weights of classification samples. The BERT pre-trained model is employed to obtain context-aware word embeddings, BiLSTM is utilized to capture long-range dependencies in text sequences, and the use of dynamically adjusted classification sample weights helps modulate the influence of salient emotional words on text classification. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed model effectively captures long-distance dependencies in text sequences, emphasizes local key sentiment features, enhances contextual comprehension, and significantly improves the accuracy of text sentiment classification.

title: Optimizing Emotion Recognition from EEG Signals Using Deep Learning
authors: Xinru Liu, Xueya Zhang, Ruiqiang Feng, Jingxu Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Recognizing emotions using electroencephalogram (EEG) signals is an important research direction in affective computing.This paper proposes a novel deep learning framework combining Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (BiGRU) and Self-Attention Mechanism (SAM) for automatic feature extraction and emotion classification. First, the raw EEG signals are segmented and subjected to dimensionality reduction using a one-dimensional CNN. Subsequently, Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT) is used to generate two-dimensional scalograms, realizing the joint representation of temporal and spatial features. Then, two-dimensional CNN, BiGRU and SAM are jointly trained on the scalograms to capture discriminative features from spatial, local, temporal and global levels. Finally, the fused features are used for multi-emotion state classification of EEG signals. Using the SEED dataset, the proposed model was evaluated on the classification task with three target classes (positive, neutral, and negative). Based on the comprehensive experimental results, the proposed method achieved an emotion detection accuracy of 93.1%, which effectively improved the accuracy of emotion recognition.

title: Detection of Chilli Leaf Diseases Using Vision Transformers and Attention Mechanisms
authors: Thrishul K V, Bhaskar C, M S Srividya
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Timely and precise identification of plant diseases plays a crucial role in minimizing agricultural losses and improving crop yield. While convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have shown effectiveness in automating the detection of plant infections, they often fail to interpret the overall image context because of their limited receptive scope. This shortcoming affects their ability to handle tasks that require detailed visual understanding. To address this, the present work introduces ChilliLeaf-ViT, a Vision Transformer (ViT)-based deep learning framework designed for accurate diagnosis of diseases in chilli plant leaves. The method makes use of a ViT model that was trained on ImageNet and is adjusted using a proprietary dataset that comprises six illness classes: White Spot, Curl Virus, Bacterial Spot, Cercospora Leaf Spot, Healthy, and Nutrition Deficiency. Unlike CNNs, the ViT architecture tokenizes images into fixed patches and employs a self-attention mechanism to learn relationships between them, enabling a more effective detection of subtle visual cues. During training, data augmentation and transfer learning approaches were used to enhance generalization. The proposed model attains an accuracy of 99.38%, outperforming standard CNN-based approaches in classifying leaf diseases. In addition, a Flask-powered web application has been developed to enable real-time disease prediction through image uploads, ensuring practical usability for field deployment. Overall, this research presents a reliable and efficient framework for automated detection of plant leaf diseases and highlights the effectiveness of transformer-driven architectures in advancing precision agriculture.

title: Design of an IIoT Edge-Based Sensor and Control Network with Ovation DCS Integration via Modbus TCP
authors: Jeremy Perschon, Steve C. Chiu, Hesham A. Sakr, Mostafa M. Fouda, Ahmed F. Ashour
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) sensing technologies provide more operational data for effective decisionmaking and analytics. Such systems are typically implemented using wireless communications to facilitate simple deployment. Edge control and signal processing reduce response time and distribute computational burden away from the industrial control system (ICS). Application of IIoT and edge systems requires the integration of the established ICS. This integration is simplified by ensuring that the IIoT system can interface with application layer protocols such as Modbus TCP. This research implements a wireless sensor and control network, together with a Modbus gateway that offers additional physical security features, including remote latching, motion detection, and door detection. The gateway uses LoRa and WiFi to collect sensor data from the nodes and send supervisory commands. Moreover, the gateway exchanges data with the Ovation distributed control system (DCS) with Modbus TCP. The nodes perform edge signal processing and control.

title: Extracting Dark Data from Synthetic Blood Cancer EHR: An Integrated Ensemble and NLP Framework for Structured and Unstructured Clinical Intelligence
authors: Jeevan E G, Kalp Jain, Pranav P Kulkarni, Sonam V Maju
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Electronic Health Records (EHRs) offer a digital alternative to conventional record-keeping by storing essential patient information that comprises demographics, medical history, medications, and diagnostic results. Nevertheless, a considerable amount of this data is still considered as dark data which is the term used for data that is either unstored unwritable, left unused or not available for data mining and the same is not subject to clinical insights or analysis hence it takes up valuable storage area. In this work, we propose a comprehensive strategy that merges machine learning (ML) and natural language processing (NLP) methodologies in order to recover and interpret the dark data generated from synthetic generated EHRs of blood cancer patients. The ensemble classifiers were used to model the structured data consisting of patient demographics and treatment parameters for prediction of treatment outcomes, and at the same time, unstructured physicians' notes were passed through ScispaCy biomedical model en_ner_bc5cdr_md, to detect medical entities and describe their relationships in context. The resulting insights were encapsulated in a single JSON framework that interlinked structured and unstructured data. The experimental results demonstrated that the Bagging Classifier reached the highest accuracy (0.82) surpassing other models like XGBoost (0.72) and Stacking Classifier (0.70). The proposed approach demonstrates a method for dark data extraction and highlights the potential of multimodal data fusion to enhance precision oncology research.

title: D-Axis and Zero-Axis Current Equal Zero Ampere Control in Discontinuous Current Vector Control of SR Motor
authors: Keitaro Kawarazaki, Nobukazu Hoshi
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This paper proposes a simplified discontinuous current vector control (DCVC) method for switched reluctance motors (SRMs), referred to as the $i_{\mathrm{d}}=i_{0}=0 \mathbf{A}$ control. The proposed method simplifies the torque model of DCVC while maintaining the vector-control framework of conventional continuous current vector control (CCVC), thereby reducing implementation complexity. Theoretical analysis shows that the root-mean-square (RMS) phase current is reduced by $11.4 \%$ compared to CCVC, resulting in a $21.4 \%$ reduction in copper and converter conduction losses. The operating range analysis clarifies that the proposed method is effective in the low-output range, where linear PWM operation is maintained. In contrast, CCVC performs better in the high-output range with higher voltage utilization. Experimental verification confirms that the proposed method achieves a smooth transition between the two control modes without torque fluctuation and improves system efficiency across all operating ranges, achieving a maximum improvement of 7.32 percentage points compared with CCVC. Although a slight increase in torque ripple and acoustic noise is observed due to the trade-off between the torque-per-ampere ratio and torque ripple inherent in DCVC, the proposed $i_{\mathrm{d}}=i_{0}=0 \mathbf{A}$ control is experimentally demonstrated to be a highly efficient and easily implementable control strategy suitable for low-output SRM operation.

title: Robust Linear Programming Optimization of Grid-Connected PV Microgrids
authors: Kobena Badu Enyam, Benjamin Aidoo, Princess Elorm Sepah, Lily Akosua Afriyie Kyei-Baffour, Joshua Nti, Emmanuel Otibu Darko Korankye
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: This paper presents a robust, real-time linear programming (LP) energy management system (EMS) for gridconnected photovoltaic (PV) microgrids with battery storage and flexible loads. The method uses a fully linear, scenario-based formulation that captures piecewise-linear battery degradation, dynamic tariff schedules, shiftable electric-vehicle (EV) charging, and ramp-rate constraints-avoiding the latency of mixed-integer and heuristic controllers. Forecast uncertainty in PV and demand is handled via multi-scenario stochastic optimization with Latin hypercube sampling while preserving linear tractability. On a representative 500 kW PV and 400 $\mathrm{kW} / 2.5 \mathrm{MWh}$ battery system in Accra, Ghana, the EMS outperforms benchmark MILP and PSO approaches, delivering $\sim 7 \%$ and 11% cost savings, respectively, with $\lt1$ s solve times on low-cost hardware. Voltage regulation and battery state-of-charge remain within tight bounds under uncertainty. The results demonstrate a practical, scalable EMS that integrates economic and operational constraints, enabling real-time dispatch for microgrids confronting growing renewable variability. It enables resilient, cost-effective operations..

title: A Real-Time System for Portfolio Optimization Using Markov Chain Steady-State Analysis
authors: D S S Mohan, Chakresh K V S, K Sahit Reddy, Sailaja Y
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Markov chains and their asymptotic behavior provide a useful paradigm for capturing the long-run dynamics of random systems. This article examines the use of Markov chain steady states in financial markets, employing Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) to identify and forecast market regimes from real stock data. We describe a real-time, interactive system that retrieves past and current price data, trains HMMs to learn underlying market states, and infers transition matrices for predicting short-run behavior and calculating long-run steadystate probabilities. These steady states shed light on the long-run tendencies of financial assets, enabling strategic decision-making. Steady-state analysis is combined with portfolio optimization within the system, which dynamically optimizes asset weights to achieve maximum risk-adjusted return. Through the union of theoretical soundness and effective application, this book brings into focus how steady-state Markov analysis can be utilized effectively in real-time finance forecasting and investment planning.

title: Real-Time Onboard UAV Target Detection and Localization for Swarms in Denied Environments
authors: Shuaiqing Zhang, Huahui Yi, Zhengtian Yang, Yayao Zhao
publish: 2025 Low-Altitude Economy Forum &amp; International Conference on Low-Altitude Flight Technology and Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Application (LEF &amp; ICLU)
abstract: This paper presents a real-time onboard UAV detection and localization system designed for swarm operations in GNSS- and communication-denied environments. The system integrates a lightweight YOLOv5-Ghost detector with an RGB-D camera to achieve accurate 3D position estimation of neighboring UAVs without external infrastructure. Extensive indoor experiments with two UAV types demonstrate that the system provides reliable localization and real-time performance in close-range scenarios. The method enables practical swarm collision avoidance and formation control. However, when targets are farther from the camera, distance estimation becomes less reliable and missed detections are more likely. This limitation, along with challenges from adverse lighting and occlusion, constrains the effective operating range of the system. The approach supports robust multi-UAV operations under denied environments, and future work will address autonomous navigation, large-scale field deployment, and adaptation to more diverse scenarios.

title: Evaluating LSTM Performance Across Varying Historical Data Sequences for Weather Forecasting in Virtual Power Plant Optimization
authors: Omaira Jajbhay, Mohamed F. Khan, Andrew G. Swanson
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: The operation of Virtual Power Plants (VPPs), integrating renewable sources like wind and solar, relies on accurate weather forecasting. Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks are widely used for time series forecasting in this context. This study investigates the effect of varying historical data lengths on LSTM performance using hourly weather data spanning 6, 11, and 21 years. Forecasting accuracy is evaluated by comparing predicted outputs to actual observations, focusing on solar irradiance. Results show that LSTM models trained with mid-range sequences (11 years) achieved the highest accuracy, with a Mean Absolute Percentage Error of 1.9669%. These findings challenge the assumption that longer or shorter datasets automatically yield superior forecasts, highlighting the importance of context-driven data selection. Optimizing historical data length can enhance forecasting reliability, supporting more efficient energy production and storage in VPPs while contributing to resilient smart grid operations.

title: Blitz: A Student Life Goal Assistant Smartphone Application with Talent Hunt Program, Higher Study, Research, and Job Preparation Help Features
authors: Mahfuzulhoq Chowdhury, Mehreen Rahman, Nourin Noushrat Noushin, Md. Yeasin, Rehena Sultana, Md. Minhazul Islam Minar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: For students to improve their professional chances and personal development, they must pursue higher education, participate in a talent hunt program, and prepare for the workforce. No automated ICT-based mobile or web application for students was provided by the earlier literary works with features such as job profile suitability check, higher study eligibility check, coaching center search, scholarship news, job circular, talent hunt fraud detection, and job preparation help. To reduce the previous shortcomings, this paper presents a student life goal assistant Smartphone application that offers features such as fake talent hunt detection, job and higher study eligibility checking, coaching center search, English test center, and visa application center search, talent hunt program search, job circular search, scholarship news, job preparation help, higher study tips, and research collaboration help. According to the app essentiality and suppleness evaluation, over 56% of app users provided highly satisfying remarks with the proposed app.

title: Research on Large-Scale Data Processing Method for Intelligent Computing and Deep Learning Supported by Computer Storage System Optimization
authors: Lin Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: To address bottlenecks such as insufficient I/O throughput, high access latency, and inefficient data scheduling in computer storage systems during large-scale deep learning data processing, this paper proposes a collaborative processing method integrating storage system optimization and intelligent computing. First, we design a hardware optimization scheme based on a hierarchical storage architecture, reducing storage access latency through dynamic ratio allocation between NVMe SSDs and HDDs. Second, we introduce an intelligent computing model combining reinforcement learning (Q-Learning) and gradient boosting decision trees (XGBoost) to achieve adaptive decision-making for data cache replacement and prefetching scheduling. To clarify the sources of performance improvements, experiments were conducted with three comparison objects: a traditional pure hard disk (HDD) + least recently used (LRU) cache benchmark system, a static hierarchical storage system without intelligent scheduling (Scheme A), and the proposed method (Scheme B). Validation was performed on large-scale datasets such as ImageNet and CIFAR-100 using deep learning models including ResNet-50 and BERT. Experimental results show that:Compared with the traditional pure HDD+LRU benchmark system, Scheme B improves I/O throughput by 47.2%-61.5%, reduces data access latency by 38.9%-52.3%, and shortens deep learning model training time by 29.4%-36.7%. Compared with Scheme A without intelligent scheduling, Scheme B further improves I/O throughput by 36.4%-38.8% (e.g., from 324.5 MB/s to 442.6 MB/s on the ImageNet dataset), reduces data access latency by 40.6%-46.9% (from 3.2 ms to 1.9 ms), shortens training time by 25.5%-28.8% (from 178.4 minutes to 132.8 minutes), and increases cache hit rate from 71.5% to 89.2%.These results demonstrate that the proposed method not only improves basic storage performance through the hierarchical hardware architecture but also breaks through performance bottlenecks relying on intelligent components consisting of Q-Learning cache optimization and XGBoost prefetching scheduling, providing efficient storage support for large-scale deep learning data processing.

title: Enhancing Retail Automation with OCR-Based Barcode and Date Detection
authors: Rishita Bansal, Mohd. Nazim, Anurag Kumar, Atul Kumar Roy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: This research presents an efficient vision-based system that employs optical character recognition (OCR) to retrieve expiration dates, manufacturing dates, and decode barcodes, thereby advancing retail automation. The primary objective is to overcome the limitations of traditional barcode scanners, which frequently encounter issues in challenging conditions such as glare, inadequate lighting, and misaligned orientations. The suggested system employs a multi-step image processing workflow to improve the visibility of barcodes. It starts with converting to greyscale and assessing the histogram, and then moves on to adaptive thresholding and dynamic re-binarization. Once a barcode is successfully identified, the system breaks it down into its components and decodes them using recognized symbology standards such as Code128. For extracting text, EasyOCR is used, ensuring precise recognition of printed date information and serial numbers. The system achieved a text detection accuracy ranging from 92% to 94% and recognized expiration and manufacturing dates with an accuracy of 85% to 90% when evaluated on 6,000 real-world product images. The recognition accuracy for both barcodes and expiration dates significantly improved due to the utilization of a large dataset. Using image enhancement methods, issues like glare and motion blur associated with the surroundings were reduced. The results demonstrate that the system operates consistently in different retail environments and provides a cost-effective, portable solution compared to traditional scanning techniques. This study establishes a basis for scalable implementation in retail spaces that interact with customers and manage inventory.

title: Machine Learning-Based HVAC Optimization for Energy-Efficient Air Conditioning in Office Buildings: A Data-Driven Study of HVAC Energy Prediction Using Ensemble and Boosting Regression Models
authors: Ashraf M. Zaki, Huanxin Chen, Luai M. Alhems
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Thirty percent or more of China’s primary energy comes from buildings. Future sustainable development will need to lower building energy use through increased energy efficiency and the application of innovative technology. To estimate energy usage in office buildings, this research compares two machine learning regression models: Multilayer Perceptron and K-nearest Neighbor. The study uses meteorological information, building attributes, and historical data on energy use as input elements for model training. The performance of both models is evaluated using metrics such as Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), and coefficient of determination (R-squared). The study also looks at how different elements like building location, size, and occupancy patterns affect each model’s ability to forecast the future. This study evaluates four regression tree models: Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBR), Extra Trees Regressor (ETR), CatBoost Regressor (CatBR), and Voting Hybrid Regression (VHR) using two years of real meteorological and office building data. Model performance was assessed through multiple statistical indicators. Results show strong predictive accuracy: XGBR ($\mathrm{R}^{2}=0.9868$), ETR (0.9934), CatBR (0.9923), and VHR (0.9925). VHR achieved RMSE $=46.73$, MAE $=4.84$, and MRE $=0.0897$. ETR demonstrated the best overall performance for HVAC energy forecasting.

title: A Framework for Enhancing IoT Data Integration with ERP Systems Using Oracle PeopleSoft Integration Broker Event Services
authors: Tirumala Rao Chimpiri
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Integrating Internet of Things (IoT) data streams into enterprise resource planning (ERP) applications is critical for real-time operational situational awareness and agile decision making. Conventional ERP systems such as Oracle PeopleSoft are built for batch, transactional workload applications. These systems are not inherently designed to ingest continuous and high-velocity IoT stream data. This paper proposes a framework that leverages Oracle PeopleSoft Integration Broker Event Services to enable secure, scalable, event-driven updates from an edge gateway to core ERP modules. Conceptual analysis indicates that integration latency can be reduced from 12–24 hours to approximately 5–10 seconds, supporting immediate work-order creation, stock-level corrections, and policy-driven automation in maintenance and inventory modules. By connecting physical IoT environments with enterprise ERP systems, the model opens the new opportunities for smarter, and more flexible business processes. The current work presents a conceptual architecture and simulated evaluation; future work will involve implementing and assessing a live prototype under production conditions.

title: Patient Record Protection Protocols for Confidentiality Within Intelligent Health Information Frameworks
authors: Ammar Abdulhassan Muhammed, Mohammed Saeb Nahi, Hayder Rageh Abdulsada, Mustafa Abdulirees Jebur, Ihsan Alwan Muhsin, Estabraq Rasheed Ibrahim
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Patient record protection protocols are critical in intelligent health information frameworks, where vast data exchanges occur across interconnected systems. Ensuring confidentiality in such environments is crucial to maintaining trust and meeting ethical and legal standards. Existing methods often face challenges in controlling data access granularly, leading to potential breaches and unauthorized exposure of sensitive patient information. These issues arise from limited access control measures and ineffective management of user roles within complex health information systems. To address these concerns, this study proposes the implementation of a Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) framework. RBAC categorizes users based on roles and assigns specific permissions, enabling precise control over who can access different types of patient records. The proposed method ensures that healthcare professionals access only the information necessary for their role, thereby preserving confidentiality and enhancing security. Findings reveal that RBAC significantly reduces unauthorized data access and ensures better compliance with privacy regulations such as HIPAA. By dynamically managing user roles and privileges, this framework enhances patient record protection while facilitating efficient data sharing within intelligent health information systems.

title: Beyond Signature Validity: Behavioral Fingerprinting for Fake Device Detection in Post-Quantum IoT Networks
authors: Dhruti Upadhyaya, Neha J C, Venugopal K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Traditional cryptographic techniques, including emerging post-quantum algorithms, focus primarily on ensuring message integrity and authenticity in Internet of Things (IoT) deployments. However, these approaches overlook whether the device generating valid signatures is itself genuine or compromised. In scenarios where attackers can clone devices or capture private keys, valid signatures become insufficient indicators of trust. This paper introduces a comprehensive framework that combines post-quantum-style signature emulation with behav-ioral fingerprinting to detect fake or spoofed IoT devices. We simulate a network of ten devices where one adversarial node continually broadcasts repetitive, low-entropy sensor readings. By extracting behavioral metrics such as the proportion of repeated messages, the randomness of message content, and the variability in message timing, and applying an unsupervised anomaly detection model (Isolation Forest), we achieve perfect detection of the spoofed device and maintain a low rate of false positives. To strengthen auditability, we integrate a blockchain-inspired, hash-linked logging mechanism that records each verified interaction. Our results demonstrate that layering behavioral analysis onto cryptographic verification significantly enhances device-level trust in IoT networks.

title: E-CRM Effectiveness in Expanding Market Share Among Beauty Centers
authors: Jassim Algasawneh, Adel M. Qatawneh, Nada Alkhawajah, Mohammed Abdul Halim Wriekat, Gaith Abu Alfalayeh, Mohammad Alqsass, Zeid Alqatawneh
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This article investigated the impact of electronic customer relationship management on market share. It consisted of three hypotheses. After analyzing the data consisting of 497 questionnaires through a data analysis program, it was found that electronic customer relationship management has an impact on market share. This means that following up with customers and recording their data leads to gaining customer satisfaction and thus maintaining or increasing market share.

title: A Comprehensive Approach for Phishing Detection and URL Blocking Using Browser Extensions and Mobile Applications
authors: Hemanth S Savanth, Arun Praskash Pattar, Arun Rajaram Hegde, Chinmahesh C, Sushma D, Arnab Tah
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Phishing attempts remain a persistent threat and often lead to the compromise of consumers' personal data. This study proposes a browser extension and a mobile applicationas as components of a comprehensive phishing detection and prevention strategy. The browser extension uses heuristic-based domain name and keyword analysis, along with cross-verification from the Google Safe Browsing API. Users can manually validate URLs with a related Flutter-built mobile application. Both solutions are built around a similar detection engine to ensure consistent security across all scenarios. Through experimental evaluation, a low false positive rate and good accuracy in real-time phishing attempt detection are shown. Index terms include URL validation, mobile apps, browser extensions, Safe Browsing API, cybersecurity, and phishing detection.

title: Smart Voice Assistant Using Tiny ML on Cortex-M55
authors: Niharika CL, Ranjani G
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The advancement of edge computing and Tiny Machine Learning (Tiny ML) has opened new possibilities for deploying intelligent applications on resource-constrained microcontrollers. This paper presents a smart voice assistant designed for fully offline operation using Tiny ML on the ARM CortexM55 platform. Unlike traditional cloud-based voice assistants, our system ensures reduced latency, improved data privacy, and no dependence on internet connectivity. The approach involves selecting predefined voice commands, extracting Mel Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) features, training a lightweight Neural Network model, and deploying it using the TensorFlow Lite for Microcontrollers (TFLM) framework. The model is tested using simulation tools such as Arm Virtual Hardware (AVH) and Keil Studio Cloud, eliminating the need for physical hardware during development. Experimental results show that the model achieves accuracy with minimal memory usage, making it suitable for low-power embedded devices. This study demonstrates a complete pipeline for developing and simulating voice recognition systems for edge applications.

title: Deep Learning Based Fusion of Visual and Thermal Images for Legacy Systems
authors: Bollupalle Sree Sai Jayanth, Aniruddha N Bayari, Darshan Kashyap N, Aditya Ravi, Dadam Rishikesh Reddy, Praveena T
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The fusion of RGB and infrared (IR) images plays a crucial role in enhancing scene perception, particularly in low-light or adverse conditions. RGB images provide rich color and structural details, while IR images capture thermal information, making them valuable for applications such as surveillance, autonomous navigation, and industrial inspection. This paper presents a deep learning-based image fusion approach using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), trained on the FLIR dataset. The proposed model extracts and integrates complementary features from RGB and IR images to generate a high-quality fused output. The model is developed using PyTorch, converted to the Open Neural Network Exchange (ONNX) format, and further optimized for deployment in C environments for real-time applications. Experimental results demonstrate superior image fusion quality, evaluated using Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) and Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM). The findings indicate that the proposed method effectively enhances image clarity, object detection, and situational awareness, making it suitable for real-world applications requiring robust multi-modal image integration.

title: Optimizing Asynchronous Communication Flows in Microservices Using Event-Driven Architecture
authors: Vasudeva Chemuru, Supraja Chinthala, Udaya Veeramreddygari
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Good asynchronous communication and microservice coordination are the keys to achieving today's distributed systems fault tolerance and scalability. Decoupling services as asynchronous passing of messages leads to reduced latency, better throughput, and greater fault tolerance due to Event-Driven Architecture (EDA). Asynchronous communication flow best practices of scalable microsystem systems utilizing EDA models are presented here. It examines to what extent event sourcing, message queues, and broker-based systems can mitigate bottlenecks of synchronous inter-service communication. The study adopts a mixed-method research design that includes architectural simulation and performance benchmarking through throughput, latency, and resource usage. Through the strict experimentation and assessment, findings show the improved scalability of event-based systems when subjected to varied workloads. Findings confirm that EDA-based coordination does have a measurable impact on performance via decoupling coupling and real-time response. The experiment also recognizes issues in EDA deployment, including event schema design and data consistency. The solution plan aims at service boundary modularization, resilience, and efficiency at operation levels. The article concludes by implementing scaled microservices deployment best practices through architecting asynchronous workflows. These are used to direct cloud-native service-oriented software development practice and theoretical models of cloud-native service-oriented architecture.

title: Blockchain-Based Secure and Robust Mechanism for Collaborative Manufacturing in Industry 4.0
authors: Yogi Patel, Rajesh Gupta, Sudeep Tanwar, Jitendra Bhatia, Hossein Shahinzadeh, Amirafshin Zamani
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: The rapid advancement of Industry 4.0 has paved the way for decentralized and collaborative manufacturing systems. In such systems, ensuring the smooth operation of machines and efficient task management is c ritical. This paper presents a blockchain-based framework for collaborative manufacturing that integrates machine management, task assignment, fault detection, and reward distribution. Using Ethereum smart contracts, the framework guarantees transparency, security, and traceability of machine activities and tasks. The system comprises three key layers: the Data Synchronization Layer, the Fault Management Layer, and the Security and Compliance Layer, which together facilitate seamless operation and data flow a cross the manufacturing ecosystem. We evaluate the performance of the proposed framework through comprehensive metrics, including gas consumption, transaction execution time, and transaction costs. The results show the framework's efficiency i n terms of transaction execution, with minimal gas consumption per operation. However, for large-scale deployments, optimization techniques such as off-chain data storage and layer-2 solutions are recommended to mitigate gas costs and improve scalability. This paper provides a robust solution for secure and efficient machine and task management in collaborative manufacturing, addressing both operational and economic challenges.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for High-Frequency Trading with Market Impact Modeling
authors: Ishta Rani, Hina Gandhi, Ramesh Kumar, Nithya Marannan, Na Kyung Kim, Tejaswini Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: High-frequency and dynamic decision-making is required in high-frequency and dynamic trading in financial markets to capture market impact - the effect that a trade itself has on asset prices. Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) is talked about in a market impact sensitive way in the context of optimal trade execution in a high-frequency setting, in this context the market impact model is directly part of the action. The proposed solution leverages a DRL agent customized with deep neural networks to estimate the intricate trends in market data of high dimensionality, (e.g. order book status, trading volumes, and price dynamics). The agent is given an incentive to maximise the cumulative returns when they are subjected to execution costs and when they are subjected to the adverse effects on the market and, there are policies that adjust the type of order and the quantity of orders depending on the market dynamics are learnt. The types simulated in the reward function of the agent are transient and permanent market impact. The adaptability and robustness of the agent is extensively tested with simulated and historical limit order book information. It has also been demonstrated that the DRL agent has a superior balance of profitability and slippage reduction in some regimes of channeled markets compared to the traditional rule-based agents and optimization agents. We are optimistic that these DRL frameworks augmented with realistic market impact models can make new steps and come up with new designs that form a new paradigm of efficient and cost sensitive trade execution in high-frequency modern day trading systems.
