title: Unsymmetrical Fault Prediction and Fault Level Evaluation for Inverter Systems in the South African Power Distribution Network
authors: Abdul Asis Abdlahi, Ahmed Ali, Peter O. Olukami
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This study addresses the challenges of fault level contributions from wind turbine generators in South Africa’s distribution grid compared with the Synchronous generator, mainly focusing on the limited fault contribution from inverter-based systems during grid faults. In this study, ANN and SVM models are developed to classify network faults with synchronous generators and Type 1 wind turbines. Improving fault level understanding with these models aids in reliable grid planning, making fault detection more precise and efficient than traditional calculation-based methods. Machine learning models like ANN and SVM are expected to outperform conventional symmetrical component analysis, especially in complex fault scenarios with a penetration of renewable plants.

title: Unfair Trading Detection System-A Hybrid Approach
authors: Savitha Hiremath, S Gowthami, NB Jahnavi, Kushala Reddy B P, Kusum Kumari
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Financial markets are prone to unethical trading strategies that can distort market equity and investor confidence, such as insider trading, market manipulation, and fake trades. Both private investors and the integrity of the financial system suffer from these practices. These methods remain widespread and still disturb the balance of equal market competition despite the Securities Exchange Commission and other legal frameworks being established. To revitalize investor confidence and promote a fairer financial market structure, this paper argues in favor of a stronger and more adaptable framework that can better respond to evolving threats. To support this, the study employs a statistical approach and machine learning models developed using RapidMiner and PyCaret, combined with sentiment analysis techniques, to detect patterns of unethical behavior and assess their impact on market dynamics. These tools provide actionable insights for regulatory bodies and stakeholders, enhancing proactive monitoring and early intervention capabilities.

title: SE-Oriented Distributed User Association in Satellite-UAV Collaborative Communications
authors: Cui-Qin Dai, Baifan Cheng, Youbing Liu, Rongpeng Liao
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Satellite-unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) collaborative communications integrated with cell-free (CF) architecture have emerged as a pivotal enabler for 6G due to global connectivity and enhanced spectral efficiency (SE). However, prolonged propagation delay and constrained fronthaul capacity may result in the centralized decision problem. In this paper, a SE-oriented distributed user association with bilateral matching (SEO-DUABM) scheme is proposed to enable real-time association decisions and improve SE performance. Firstly, a satellite-UAV network model with CF architecture is established with the low earth orbit satellite, UAVs, and ground users. Then, the average SE is derived by introducing a two-phase signal combining method, and an optimization problem is formulated to maximize the average SE by designing the user association matrix. Following that, a distributed user association with bilateral matching is given to achieve stable association and enhance SE. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme can maintain superiority under varying UAV antenna configurations.

title: CRT-NTT: A CRT-Optimized NTT Hardware Architecture for Non-Prime Modular Multiplication in Raccoon
authors: Tenglong Xiao, Junjie Zhong, Bei Wang, Fei Lyu, Chenghua Wang, Weiqiang Liu, Yijun Cui
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Raccoon is an additional digital signature scheme currently under evaluation in the NIST Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) standardization process. Its security relies on standard lattice assumptions and is specifically designed for application scenarios resistant to side-channel attacks. In Raccoon, the modulus q of the Number Theory Transform (NTT) is a 49-bit non-prime number, rendering existing hardware designs relying on prime modulus reduction algorithms ineffective. This paper presents the first hardware design of a non-prime modular multiplication leveraging the Chinese Remainder Theorem (CRT), decomposes the non-prime modulus q=q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>×q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. It includes three sub-modules: a parallel modular multiplication module to maximize the parallelism of DSPs, a prime modular reduction module that integrates the K-RED algorithm and congruence relation properties for the prime moduli q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf> and q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, and a restoration module that utilizes the improved Barrett algorithm to obtain the correct result for the non-prime modulus q. Moreover, the hardware implementation of the pipelined NTT concluding the proposed modular multiplication is presented to verify functional correctness and enable benchmarking against state-of-the-art solutions. Evaluated on the Xilinx Artix-7 platform, the proposed NTT architecture utilizes 35678 LUTs, 15946 FFs, 48 DSPs, and 1.5 BRAMs, achieving an operating frequency of 98 MHz with a total latency of 6.59 μs. This represents a 4× speedup over the official software implementation.

title: AI Controlled Automated Hydroponic Farming System
authors: Preetham N, Hithesh M P, K Preethi, Syed Nadeem, Shivakumar Gadeda, Sufiyan Khan, S Anupama Kumar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The increasing demand for environmentally sus-tainable agriculture and efficient crop management systems has positioned hydroponics as a vital alternative to traditional farming. Its ability to conserve water and utilize limited space makes it especially suitable for urban and resource-constrained regions. However, most existing hydroponic systems still lack intelligent automation and real-time disease diagnosis, resulting in operational inefficiencies and unpredictable crop health out-comes. The proposed system leverages an ESP32 microcontroller to monitor and control key environmental metrics—such as ambient temperature, humidity, water temperature, nutrient concentration (TDS), moisture level, and water availability. Based on preset threshold conditions, the system autonomously triggers actuators like inlet/exhaust fans and nutrient pumps to maintain optimal plant growth conditions. In parallel, an AI-based plant disease detection module was implemented using a lightweight VGG-16 convolutional neural network, fine-tuned on a large dataset of plant leaf images. The model analyzes images captured from the hydroponic setup and classifies them into healthy or diseased categories, enabling early intervention. The system was tested using Arduino IDE for embedded firmware, TensorFlow and OpenCV for AI model training and deployment, and Blynk for real-time IoT -based visualization. The VGG-16 model achieved a classification accuracy of 95.16%. The results validated the system's ability to autonomously manage environmental conditions and detect diseases in real- time, demonstrating its potential for deployment in smart, resource-efficient, and scalable agricultural environments.

title: Integration of Artificial Intelligence in Thrust Vector Control for Model Rockets
authors: Aditi A, Dhriti Bhatt, Divya Vijay, Kushagra Chaturvedi, M Sai Anirudh, Siddharth Satish, Sowmyarani C N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Thrust Vector Control (TVC) plays a critical role in guiding rockets and launch vehicles by manipulating the direction of thrust to maintain desired flight trajectories. While conventional Proportional- Integral- Derivative (PID) controllers remain the industry standard for TV C due to their simplicity and reliability, they struggle to adapt under nonlinear and time- varying flight conditions common in solid-propelled vehicles. This paper presents an interdisciplinary approach that integrates classical PID control with reinforcement learning (RL) for adaptive thrust vectoring in model rocketry. A dual-axis gimballed TV C system was designed and fabricated using plastic gear servos and an ESP32 microcontroller, with real-time orientation feedback from an onboard MPU-6050 IMU. A closed-loop PID algorithm demonstrated stable pitch and yaw stabilization under static thrust tests. In parallel, a custom Gym-based simulation environment trained a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) agent to benchmark intelligent control strategies under realistic nonlinear dynamics. Comparative results indicate that the RL controller achieved faster settling times and superior disturbance rejection compared to the baseline PID system. These findings highlight the feasibility of hybrid intelligent control architectures for small-scale rockets and serve as a practical foundation for future work involving embedded RL deployment, hybrid fallback strategies, and fully autonomous SRAD rocket systems.

title: Design and Development of Smart Battery Health Assessment Model Using Digital Twin
authors: Aryan, Jadhavrao Ruturaj Ajitrao, Yash Aryan, Sarvagya Kumar, Shourya Anand, Shubham Garg, Sushmita Sarkar, Raja Vidya
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: With the rapid rise of electric vehicles, renewable energy systems, and portable electronics, battery performance and reliability have become crucial. Key parameters such as State of Charge (SOC) and State of Health (SOH) are essential for monitoring battery status. This paper presents a smart battery health assessment model using a digital twin framework, integrating Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) with MATLAB-based real-time diagnostics. The digital twin enables accurate simulation, monitoring, and prediction of battery behavior, enhancing adaptive energy management and reliability.

title: Optimizing Predictive Maintenance Based on Digital Twins Using Artificial Intelligence Tools
authors: Mahyar Manzelati, Massoud Reza Hashemi, Aref Karimiafshar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: Predictive Maintenance (PdM) is a key industrial technique, yet traditional methods often lack the required accuracy and scalability. To address this, we propose a novel three-layer framework for Digital Twin-based Predictive Maintenance (PdMDT). The architecture integrates real-time data collection, a hybrid (data-driven and physics-based) digital twin for simulation, and an intelligent decision-making layer. It is built on novel learning methods such as CNN-LSTM and RF-LSTM in its decision-making layer. We validated the framework on an industrial water pump with 51 sensors, predicting faults with a 10-minute lead time. We developed two models: a CNN-LSTM with an attention mechanism (98.29% F1 score) that identifies key sensor contributions, and a lightweight RF-LSTM (98.91% F1 score) suitable for edge devices. The proposed PdMDT framework provides a scalable and interpretable solution applicable to real-world industrial environments. By enabling precise fault prediction and root cause analysis, it significantly reduces downtime and maintenance costs, advancing the implementation of smart manufacturing. While validated on a real industrial dataset, future work will extend the framework to live plant deployments to assess scalability and robustness in production environments.

title: Rainfall Forecasting of Multi-Area Using Hybrid Convolutional Neural Networks and Temporal Neural Networks
authors: Rachmawati Ade Ningsih, Esmeralda Contessa Djamal
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Rainfall forecasting is essential for supporting farming activities, such as irrigation planning and disaster risk mitigation in the event of floods or droughts. Since agricultural operations often span multiple areas, reliable rainfall forecasting that captures both spatial and temporal patterns is needed to ensure effective planning and risk prevention. This research involved three close weather stations throughout the Bandung area: Bandung Geophysics Station, Citeko Meteorology Station, and West Java Climatology Station. The 2D Convolutional Neural Networks and Temporal Neural Network methods were proposed to extract spatial-temporal features from climate data from the said multi-stations. The results show that when handling multi-area data, the proposed model achieved an accuracy improvement of approximately 11.24% to 93.88% compared to single-station data. Furthermore, it outperformed the feature selection method based on GMM-ARI, with an increase in accuracy of up to 11.47%, indicating a reduced necessity for feature selection. Compared to previous studies, the model achieved a 6.92% accuracy improvement over the 2D CNN-LSTM and a 17.05% overall improvement compared to the 1D CNN architecture. The findings also demonstrate that using TCN with dilated convolutions effectively overcomes the long dependency limitations found in RNN-based models and 2D CNN models, which capture spatial dependencies and regional interactions between adjacent weather stations, leading to improved forecasting accuracy.

title: Human Activity Recognition with FMCW Radar Using Few-Shot Learning on Raspberry Pi
authors: Rajani Katiyar, Ashwin B Nayak
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This study introduces a deep-learning framework for Human Activity Recognition (HAR) using spectrogram representations of FMCW radar data. Leveraging a publicly accessible dataset (DOI: 10.21227/pfzr-g090), eight distinct activities are classified through a ResNet50 transfer-learning model. Training and validation are carried out on preprocessed time-frequency images in a Kaggle environment equipped with an NVIDIA Tesla T4 GPU, yielding a test accuracy of 94.5%. The trained network is then ported to a Raspberry Pi 3B+ to assess its performance under embedded conditions. Although only offline radar samples are used, the edge device achieves inference times below 10 ms per frame with CPU utilization under 20%, demonstrating its feasibility for low-power deployments. In relation to performance ranges summarized in recent survey articles [2], [10], the achieved 94.5% accuracy places the proposed system among the higher-performing embedded-oriented radar HAR solutions, albeit slightly below the 98% reported for the current state-of-the-art few-shot ProtoNet. Additional comparisons with a shallow CNN baseline and the compact tinyRadar LSTM model show that the ResNet50-based approach provides the most favorable balance of recognition accuracy and computational efficiency. These findings highlight the viability of radar-driven HAR with few-shot learning concepts for real-time operation on resource-limited platforms.

title: Data-Driven Diamond Pricing: Leveraging Machine Learning for Precise Cost Estimation
authors: Yashika Chauhan, Mudita Uppal, Deepali Gupta, Sapna Juneja, Punit Gupta, Ghanshyam Raghuvanshi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Diamonds are a form of crystallized carbon and are one of the most coveted gemstones in the world with their prices varying depending on various factors such as weight and carat, cut, color, clarity and size. It is not an easy job to predict diamond prices precisely with the interaction of these attributes. ML is applied in this research to develop a model for prediction of diamond prices using Support Vector Regression, Linear Regression, XGBoost and Random Forest algorithms. Through carrying out extensive exploratory data analysis (EDA), feature transformation, and principal component analysis (PCA), the data were preprocessed for training. Each model's accuracy was measured against primary parameters of Mean Absolute Error (MAE), R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score and Mean Squared Error (MSE). Experimental results shows the fact that XGBoost model was the most precise in prediction with greater performance compared to other models with the lowest error rates and highest <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> score. The accuracy of the model developed was also high with minimum error as the model gave an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> of 0.9897 and a MAE of 0.0328 and MSE of 0.0020. This study is very applicable to the diamond industry since it presents a reality-based method of price estimation that allows stakeholders to make logical decisions.

title: Sustainable Steel Production in the Desert: Economic and Technical Assessment of a Hydrogen-Powered Steel Plant in Mauritania
authors: Julius Uhl, Marco Schamel, Anton Achhammer, Michael Sterner
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: The global steel industry is a major contributor to climate change and faces challenges in achieving a carbon-neutral production, hinging on the availability of cost-effective hydrogen produced by renewable energy. Mauritania, with its exceptional solar and wind resources, offers some of the most competitive conditions globally for hydrogen production. Instead of focusing on hydrogen exports, this study explores the technical feasibility and economic viability of establishing a renewable-powered steel plant in Mauritania, utilizing the country’s abundant iron ore reserves. The findings suggest that sustainably produced steel in Mauritania could be cost-competitive with current European prices. With ongoing declines in investment costs for emerging renewable technologies, Mauritania has the potential to become one of the world’s most cost-effective steel producers.

title: Smart Valuation of Pre-Owned Cars Using Computing System
authors: J Joshua Daniel Raj, Sreejith S, Manoj P, Poornima, Sneha
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Accurately determining the market value of pre-owned vehicles is essential for improving transparency in automobile transactions. Vehicle pricing depends on several parameters including details like the brand, model, year of manufacture, mileage, and mainly the overall condition. This study presents a data-driven approach that employs a gradient boosting regression model-Cat Boost Regressor-to estimate the prices of used cars. The dataset, sourced from publicly available Indian automotive listings, was preprocessed to handle categorical and numerical attributes efficiently. Cat Boost was selected because of it's capability to natively process categorical variables and capture complex non-linear interactions without extensive feature encoding. The proposed system includes exploratory data analysis and also structured feature engineering to produce interpretable results. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the model achieves consistent predictive performance across diverse brands and segments, offering an effective framework for intelligent price estimation at the car market.

title: Predicting Cardiovascular Disease Risk Using Transformer Networks and Electronic Health Records
authors: Dilli Ganesh V, Nandhini T J, Prashant Johri, Mahmoud Mahfuri
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: cardiovascular disease (CVD) is one of the biggest killers globally, and it is crucial to predict CVD risk at the initial stage to reduce the mortality rate and morbidity of the disease. Thus, this research develops a deep learning approach based on the transformer architecture to predict CVD risk by analyzing EHRs. It is worth noting that conventional models are somewhat challenged with increased amounts and chronological characteristics inherent in-patient data. To cope with this challenge, we utilize transformer models that can model dependencies in the data for EHR and capture complex patterns. Further, the proposed approach converts structured and unstructured data, such as patient demographics, laboratory tests, prescriptions, and notes from electronic health records, into a risk assessment model. The transformer network successfully captures numerous dependencies of the features encountered in the medical field and trends in the medical history compared to traditional models like logistic regression or recurrent neural networks. Based on experimental results, the proposed framework exhibits better predictive performance, reliability, and interpretability to be a useful scientific tool for usage in clinical decision-making. By using deep learning with EHR analytics, this framework helps in early risk prediction for disease diagnosis, which has a positive impact on disease management. It also advances accuracy, extendibility, and flexibility, which paves the way for new AI-facilitated models in the healthcare environment. The future groundwork will entail improving the efficiency of the model and confirming its effectiveness in various populations as well as real-life practice.

title: Method for the Automated Evaluation of Energy Flexibility in Industrial Energy Systems
authors: Kerim Torolsan, Alexander Mutz, Manuel Schmalzried, Alexander Sauer
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Industrial energy systems account for Germany’s most significant share of electricity consumption and offer substantial potential for temporal load shifting. Nevertheless, investments in energy flexibility remain limited due to low transparency, high complexity, and uncertain economic benefits. Existing approaches often require detailed process knowledge and costly audits. This paper introduces a method for the automated evaluation of energy flexibility in industrial energy systems. The method applies linear optimisation to historical load data and market parameters, combining a model-based potential analysis with a systematic assignment of suitable energy flexibility measures. The approach is designed for low-threshold applicability without detailed process information. The method was applied in two real-world case applications. Results showed reductions in peak load, network charges, and day-ahead market procurement costs. While maximum technical cost reductions were achieved at higher flexibility levels, economic feasibility depended on storage sizing. The method provides a transparent, data-driven basis for linking quantified flexibility potential with practical measures, thereby supporting informed investment decisions.

title: Energy Storage and Management in Battery-free Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Bernardo Yaser León Ávila, Carlos Alberto García Vázquez, Osmel Pérez Baluja, Luis Alberto Quintero Domínguez, Daniel Tudor Cotfas, Petru Adrian Cotfas
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The growing demand for self-sustaining IoT deployments is driving interest in energy harvesting (EH) and advanced energy storage solutions, particularly for battery-free wireless sensor networks (BF-WSNs). This survey synthesizes recent advances in storage technologies and power management strategies that enable the perpetual operation of WSNs in industrial, environmental, and smart infrastructure applications. Supercapacitors emerge as a cornerstone technology due to their high power density, long cycle life, and low environmental impact, making them well-suited for intermittently available ambient energy sources. We begin by reviewing energy management mechanisms in WSNs and then present the key considerations for integrating supercapacitors as the sole energy storage element in BF-WSNs. This work supports future research and applications by outlining critical design trade-offs and identifying open challenges for developing sustainable and reliable BF-WSN systems.

title: Impact of Flexibility Services on Power Grid Adequacy: A Case Study of Senegal’s 2025 Grid
authors: Thiaw Aminata, Henneaux Pierre, Niang Ababacar, Toure Sellé, Traore Papa Silly
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: The global energy transition toward renewable energy sources (RES) poses major challenges for power system operators, especially regarding grid reliability. This study analyzes the technical and economic impacts of flexibility services on system adequacy using the open-source Antares Simulator. Adequacy is assessed through Expected Energy Not Supplied (EENS) and Loss of Load Expectation (LOLE). Senegal’s 2025 grid serves as the case study. Four scenarios are simulated to evaluate the role of flexibility services, including energy storage and Demand Side Response (DSR), in mitigating supply-demand imbalances. Results show that integrating either service reduces EENS by 94% and LOLE by 93%. Flexibility also lowers total system costs and reduces marginal prices by at least 0.9% and 17%, respectively. This techno-economic analysis underscores the critical role of flexibility in enhancing adequacy, supporting RES integration, and ensuring a more reliable and stable power grid.

title: Intelligent Video Monitoring for Classroom Management
authors: Rajkumar Panchal, Sushma Nandgaonkar, Manoj Shelar, Pradip Paithane
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Manual classroom monitoring to ensure student attentiveness and teacher accountability is often impractical and unreliable, especially in institutions managing multiple classrooms simultaneously. It requires continuous human supervision, which is resource-intensive, prone to bias, and infeasible for large-scale or real-time analysis. To address these limitations, we propose an automated, real-time classroom monitoring framework using Real-Time Detection Transformer (RT-DETR) for object detection and Deep Simple Online and Realtime Tracking (DeepSORT) for identity tracking. Our system is trained on publicly available datasets labeled with various student behaviors-such as using a phone, reading, sleeping, writing, etc.-and teacher presence. RT-DETR enables high-accuracy detection, while DeepSORT assigns consistent IDs to individuals across frames, allowing for accurate behavior reporting per student rather than per frame. The system achieves a mean average precision (mAP) above 95 % and runs at 24 FPS, with detailed evaluation metrics including precision, recall, F1-score, MOTA, and MOTP.

title: Improving Financial Decision-Making with Hybrid AI Models: A Case Study in Financial Information Systems
authors: Md Borhan Uddin, Sabrina Shamim Moushi, Md Anwar Hosen, Suny Md Ashraf Khan, Arafat Hossain, Khandakar Rabbi Ahmed
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Enhancing decision-making accuracy and inter-pretability is a critical issue in the current financial information systems environment. This study proposes FiT-XGSHAP, a novel hybrid AI structure with a Financial Transformer for high-dimensional sequence learning, XGBoost for structured learning, and SHAP for post-hoc interpretability. The ‘Give Me Some Credit’ dataset, which comprises over 150,000 real credit records with a range of financial characteristics, including DebtRatio and Monthly Income, is used to train and test the algorithm. Predicting two-year severe delinquency-a binary classification challenge at the core of financial risk prediction-is the goal. FiT-XGSHAP is 96.74% accurate. precision = 96.00%, recall = 97.00%, F1-score = 96.00%, AUC = 0.98, particularly outstanding to the conventional single-model approaches. The experiments demonstrate the power and usefulness of hybrid architectures for financial predictive tasks, presenting high performance and interpretability. The study supports advancing intelligent support systems for financial decision-making by integrating the power of ensemble learning with the explainability of explainable AI.

title: Sustainable Operations Management: Role of Technology in Environmental Conservation
authors: T. Nirmala, Jayashree Hareesh, Debabrata Baral, Krishna Murthy Inumula, Deepali Pulekar, Rekha Verma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Businesses are responsible for severe environmental damage due to the overuse of natural resources, excessive waste generation, and poor dumping of toxic substances. Small and medium-sized businesses (SMEs) play a critical role in mitigating the worldwide ecological impact, which has become a growing aspect of the business plan over the past twenty years. Supply chain management (SCM) is among the industries most ready for transformation. Sustainable SCM (SSCM) incorporates ecological operations throughout the supply chain. SSCM enables organizations to minimize their ecological impact by changing their purchases, manufacturing, dispersion, usage, and material recycling practices. This research examines how digital technology can enhance urban waste management in smart cities by addressing structural issues. A comparative analysis of Enterprise A and Retailer B's demandside supply chain identifies important waste sources such as oversupply, stock mismanagement, and delays in shipping and advertising. The study employs an integrated method that includes empirical evaluation of operational statistics, cuttingedge statistical approaches, and Artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms. The findings demonstrate that by improving SC cooperation, streamlining transportation, and improving stock management, IoT and AI technology significantly reduced waste. By using fewer resources and producing fewer pollutants, these digital innovations also follow the guidelines of the circular economy, so aiding overall sustainable operational management and resilience targets in urban contexts. The report emphasizes the need to incorporate digital technologies into waste management plans to develop more SSCM. This investigation highlights the power of digital technology for encouraging sustainable operational management and environmental conservation in smart cities by connecting conceptual models with real-world uses.

title: Meta-Learning-Based Adaptive AI Tutors for Personalized Instruction in Smart Education Platforms
authors: Aya Ali Jemha, Haider Abd Alrazaq, Feruza Umarova, Najmitdinov Akhadkhon Khamitdkhanovich, Saida Shakirova, Bhuneshwari Dewangan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Smart education platforms are revolutionizing modern learning by leveraging artificial intelligence to deliver personalized instruction tailored to individual students. Meta- learning, as an emerging AI paradigm, enhances this personalization by enabling rapid adaptation to diverse learner needs. However, existing intelligent tutoring systems often suffer from limitations in generalization and adaptability, requiring large amounts of labeled data and struggling to personalize instruction for new or atypical learners in real-time. To address these challenges, this paper proposes MAPLE (Meta-Adaptive Personalized Learning Engine). This novel framework integrates Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) into AI tutors, enabling fast and efficient adaptation using limited learner data. MAPLE is designed to pre-train on a diverse range of student profiles and fine-tune rapidly to new learners with minimal interaction, thereby enhancing the precision of feedback and instructional relevance. MAPLE operates within innovative education platforms to deliver real-time personalized feedback, adaptive content sequencing, and learner-specific strategy recommendations. It dynamically models each student's learning style, pace, and cognitive gaps, making instruction more responsive and engaging. The experimental evaluation of MAPLE demonstrates superior performance in adaptability and personalization compared to traditional machine learning-based tutoring systems. Key outcomes include a significant increase in learning retention, faster convergence to learner proficiency, and higher student satisfaction scores. By minimizing the need for extensive retraining and maximizing instructional relevance, MAPLE provides a scalable and efficient solution for personalized education.

title: Early Success Prediction for Online Learners: A Semisupervised and Self-Training Approach
authors: Jia Hao, Jiatian Mei, Jianhou Gan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: The accurate and early prediction of online learners’ final success significantly aids administrators in providing timely assistance, thereby enhancing the retention rate for online educational platforms. However, a primary challenge lies in the fact that most learners’ behaviors remain unlabeled until the end of semester, hindering researchers from utilizing traditional supervised learning methods to forecast their final success in the initial weeks. To address these challenges, we introduce a framework called data augmentation-based semisupervised and self-training method for early success prediction (DSSP). Specifically, DSSP initially gathers labeled datasets with a limited number of instances from completed online courses and then employs a generative adversarial network (GAN)-based approach to augment an auxiliary dataset, which maintains the same mixed Gaussian distributions as the labeled set. Furthermore, we apply a self-training method to capture the latent behavior pattern from unlabeled learners’ dataset and then train a multilayer perceptron (MLP)-based semisupervised predictor via consistency loss till convergence, so that the model can predict the online learners’ final success when given their behavior at the first few weeks of the semester. The extensive experiments on the public dataset OULAD (<uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://analyse.kmi.open.ac.uk/opendataset</uri>) demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed methods.

title: High-Gain Nonisolated DC–DC Converter with Zero Input Current Ripple for Fuel Cell Electric Vehicles
authors: Sudeep Shetty, Subhasis Mishra, U. Vinatha
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: This paper presents a novel single-switch, common-ground high-gain DC–DC converter for vehicular applications, integrating a Current Mirror Ripple Cancellation Circuit (CMRCC) to achieve a continuous input current with negligible ripple. The proposed power stage incorporates one switched inductor–capacitor (SLC) cell and one switched capacitor (SC) cell, along with a clamping circuit to reduce voltage stress on the switching device, thereby enhancing efficiency and reliability. This configuration delivers high voltage gain while maintaining control simplicity through a single-switch design and minimizing electromagnetic interference via the common-ground structure. A comprehensive theoretical analysis is provided, covering voltage gain, efficiency, component stress, and open-loop stability. A 48 V/400 V, 350 W laboratory prototype was developed to validate the proposed design under dynamic load and source variations, achieving a peak efficiency of 94.4%, an input current ripple below 1%, and a transient deviation of less than 10% under 30% load and 20% source step changes. These results confirm that the proposed integrated approach offers a compact, high-performance, and application-ready solution for electric vehicle powertrains and renewable energy systems.

title: Lightweight Semantic Feature Extraction Model With Direction Awareness for Aerial Traffic Object Detection
authors: Jiaquan Shen, Ningzhong Liu, Han Sun, Shang Wu, Zongzheng Liang, Lulu Han, Yongxin Zhang, Deguang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The detection of traffic objects in aerial scenes holds significant application potential in both military and civilian sectors. However, current aerial traffic object detection techniques based on computer vision face challenges including limited awareness of object direction, a heavy computational burden on the feature extraction backbone network, and inadequate capacity to learn crucial semantic information. In this paper, our focus is on investigating the mechanisms for predicting the directional perception of traffic objects in aerial scenes, achieving backbone network lightness, and exploring methods for extracting key semantic information from objects. Firstly, to tackle the challenge of poor perception of traffic object direction and angle in aerial scenes, we utilize techniques like equivariant vector field convolution, multi-task anchor-free prediction, and adaptive loss to develop a precise mechanism for recognizing and predicting object directions. Secondly, given the presence of small-sized and numerous objects in aerial scenes, we propose the adoption of a lightweight backbone network employing channel stacking to decrease the model’s computational burden. Additionally, we establish a theoretical framework and methodology for optimizing and compressing this backbone network, aimed at enhancing feature extraction and propagation for aerial traffic objects. Furthermore, to address the issue of inadequate learning of key semantic information features, we incorporate saliency attention and multi-scale contextual information to capture the essential semantic characteristics of the objects. We also establish a method for extracting semantic features specifically for aerial traffic objects. The approach presented in this paper broadens the applicability of aerial object detection algorithms and offers novel methodologies and theoretical foundations for object detection in intricate scenarios.

title: From the Editor
authors: Tony Lujia Chen
publish: IEEE Electrical Insulation Magazine
abstract: This issue includes three articles, the first titled “New Categories for Phase-Resolved Partial Discharge Pattern Classification,” by Contin, Piccolo, and Cavallini. It presents a refined framework for analyzing phase-resolved partial discharge (PRPD) patterns in insulation diagnostics. The study questions the traditional one-to-one link between PRPD shapes and defect types, proposing three new categories: voltage-dependent, multiple, and ambiguous patterns. This is to better represent the changing nature of discharge phenomena. By testing insulation systems rated between 4 and 18 kV, including porous tape insulation and four-layer mica tapes, the authors show how PRPD patterns develop under different voltage levels, aging conditions, and stress factors. Examples include distributed micro-void discharges that change from “rabbit-ear” to rounded shapes, symmetric in polarity and phase. The article emphasizes the limitations of relying only on pattern shape for diagnosis and recommends additional localization techniques such as antenna probes and ultrasound detectors. This work is especially valuable for those seeking to improve the reliability of insulation evaluation and develop more advanced pattern-recognition systems for rotating electrical machines.

title: WESA: A Wavelet-Enhanced Spatial-Agnostic Framework for Hyperspectral Image Classification Under Spatial Fragmentation
authors: Zhen Yang, Huihui Li, Tao Zhang, Jinsheng Ji, Feiming Wei, Heng-Chao Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) contain a rich spectrum of bands, enabling a nuanced understanding of observed scenes. As one primary goal, HSI classification mainly involves identifying subtle material variations pixel-wise using the spectral information. This paper addresses the critical challenge of HSI classification under spatial fragmentation, a scenario where conventional methods that rely on fixed spatial arrangements often fail. In brief, we first introduce the Patch-Level Spatial Perturbation (PLSP) strategy to fragment the HSI data. Then, we propose WESA, a novel Wavelet-Enhanced Spatial-Agnostic Framework, which is designed to be inherently robust to spatial disorder by integrating two key components: Wavelet Multi-Scale Analysis (WMSA) and Frequency-Spatial Aware Knowledge Distillation (FSA-KD). WMSA enhances discriminative feature learning by decomposing inputs into multi-frequency subbands, capturing stable features that are less dependent on spatial location. FSA-KD bridges the domain gap between spatially fragmented and intact data via knowledge distillation, enabling the model to recover crucial spatial-spectral insights. Evaluated on four diverse datasets, WESA demonstrates exceptional robustness. For instance, on the Indian Pines dataset, WESA provides an average OA improvement of 14.88% over baseline models under extreme <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1\times 1$</tex-math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$5\times 5$</tex-math></inline-formula> patch fragmentation. Ultimately, this work offers a powerful spatial-agnostic solution for HSI classification in disordered environments, with practical implications for agricultural monitoring, urban mapping, and dynamic land cover analysis following sudden natural disasters.

title: Strategies for Efficient Interrogation of Multimode Fiber Bragg Gratings
authors: Ivan Chapalo, Andreas Ioannou, Vasilios Sarakatsianos, Kyriacos Kalli, Stavros Pissadakis
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Practical use of fiber Bragg gratings (FBGs) inscribed in multimode fibers (MMFs), especially in step-index (SI-) MMFs, is limited due to their unstable reflection spectra (RS). In this work, the physical mechanisms for RS instabilities occurring in Bragg reflectors inscribed in MMFs are considered theoretically, and methods to ensure RS stabilization are proposed and evaluated. They are based on mechanical modulation of MMF and on the use of long lengths of intermediate MMFs. These stabilization methods are experimentally investigated for FBGs inscribed in standard 50/125 and 105/125 SI-MMFs. Reduction of relative standard deviation of reflection peaks' amplitudes from 30-80% down to 1-4% is demonstrated. The efficiency of stabilized interrogation of SI-MMF FBGs is further confirmed by applying a strain test. Effective RS stabilization is also demonstrated for Bragg reflectors inscribed in specialty MMFs including those of no-core polypropylene light guide, silica graded-index MMF and polymer perfluorinated CYTOP graded-index fiber.

title: Controllable Generation with Text-to-Image Diffusion Models: a Survey
authors: Pu Cao, Feng Zhou, Qing Song, Lu Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: In the rapidly advancing realm of visual generation, diffusion models have revolutionized the landscape, marking a significant shift in capabilities with their impressive text-guided generative functions. However, relying solely on text for conditioning these models does not fully cater to the varied and complex requirements of different applications and scenarios. Acknowledging this shortfall, a variety of studies aim to control pre-trained text-to-image (T2I) models to support novel conditions. In this survey, we undertake a thorough review of the literature on controllable generation with T2I diffusion models, covering both the theoretical foundations and practical advancements in this domain. Our review begins with a brief introduction to the basics of denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) and widely used T2I diffusion models. Additionally, we provide a detailed overview of research in this area, categorizing it from the condition perspective into three directions: generation with specific conditions, generation with multiple conditions, and universal controllable generation. For each category, we analyze the underlying control mechanisms and review representative methods based on their core techniques. For an exhaustive list of the controllable generation literature surveyed, please refer to our curated repository at https://github.com/PRIV-Creation/Awesome-Controllable-T2I-Diffusion-Models.

title: Out-of-Distribution Detection through Transformation Rectified Activation
authors: Maozhen Li, Yu Liang, Man Qi, Guanjun Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Rectified activation is a highly effective post-hoc method for out-of-distribution (OOD) detection, designed to enhance the robustness of Deep Neural Networks (DNNs). It operates by truncating high neuron activations to prevent over-confident predictions on unfamiliar data. However, this approach has two key limitations: it only truncates outlier activations without optimizing the post-truncation relationship between in-distribution (ID) and OOD data, and its performance is often unstable due to the manual selection of the rectification threshold. In this paper, we introduce Transformation Rectified Activation (Trans-ReAct), a novel method that addresses these issues. Trans-ReAct leverages two core innovations: (1) it applies mathematical transformations to strategically amplify the activation differentiation between ID and OOD data, and (2) it introduces a dynamic threshold anchor that automatically adapts the rectification threshold to the ID data, ensuring stable performance. Evaluated on three benchmark datasets, Trans-ReAct significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, reducing the false positive rate at 95% true positive rate (FPR95) by up to 9.76% and increasing the Area Under the ROC Curve (AUROC) by up to 2.04%.

title: Space-O-RAN: Enabling Intelligent, Open, and Interoperable Non Terrestrial Networks in 6G
authors: Eduardo Baena, Paolo Testolina, Michele Polese, Dimitrios Koutsonikolas, Josep Jornet, Tommaso Melodia
publish: IEEE Communications Magazine
abstract: Satellite networks are rapidly evolving, yet most Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTNs) remain isolated from terrestrial orchestration frameworks. Their control architectures are typically monolithic and static, limiting their adaptability to dynamic traffic, topology changes, and mission requirements. These constraints lead to inefficient spectrum use and underutilized network capacity. Although Artificial Intelligence (AI) promises automation, its deployment in orbit is limited by computing, energy, and connectivity limitations. This article introduces Space-O-RAN, a distributed control architecture that extends Open RAN principles into satellite constellations through hierarchical, closed-loop control. Lightweight dApps operate onboard satellites, enabling real-time functions like scheduling and beam steering without relying on continuous ground access. Cluster-level coordination is managed via Space RAN Intelligent Controllers (Space-RICs), which leverage low-latency Inter-Satellite Links (ISLs) for autonomous decisions in orbit. Strategic tasks, including AI training and policy updates, are transferred to terrestrial platforms Service Management and Orchestrations (SMO) using digital twins and feeder links. A key enabler is the dynamic mapping of the O-RAN interfaces to satellite links, supporting adaptive signaling under varying conditions. Simulations using the Starlink topology validate the latency bounds that inform this architectural split, demonstrating both feasibility and scalability for autonomous satellite RAN operations.

title: Implementation of Direct Digital Control in Modular Multilevel Converters for Hot-Swap Capability via Distributed Module Controllers
authors: Tzu-Chieh Chou, Chun-Wei Huang, Chien-Chih Hung
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper presents implementation of direct digital control in modular multilevel converters (MMCs) for hot-swap capability via distributed module controllers, which in turn can achieve a fault-tolerance mechanism. Adopting the module distributed controllers is to realize an extension of cell-module (CM) number, increase MMC stability and reliability, and simplify the complexity of fault-tolerance mechanism. The proposed direct digital control can take into account wide filter-inductance variation and source-voltage harmonics, and help achieve seamless hot-swap features with low distortion on output currents and less interference to grid voltages. In this paper, the module-distributed controllers are introduced first, and then the fault-tolerance mechanism for either CM unplugging or plugging is presented in detail. Experimental and simulated results obtained from an MMC operated in power-injection and with a hot-swap feature have verified the analysis and discussion.

title: Using Auxiliary Mirrors for Improved Surface Coverage in Depth Scanning
authors: Jakub Chlebek, Jan Maslowski, Jakub Krejčí, Zdenko Bobovský, Michael Hofbaur, Tomáš Kot
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Depth cameras have become an integral part of a wide range of applications, including industrial inspection, reverse engineering, human–robot collaboration, and biomechanical analysis. Their practical use, however, is limited by a narrow field of view and self-occlusions, which often prevent complete surface coverage of the scanned object. This paper introduces a methodology for systematically determining the optimal placement of a depth camera and an auxiliary planar mirror to maximize surface visibility. To this end, a simulation tool was developed that models camera rays, their reflections from the mirror, and their intersections with objects. The proposed method combines geometric visibility analysis with an optimization procedure that searches for configurations with maximum coverage. Validation was performed on a set of twenty objects ranging from simple geometric primitives to complex reference models. While a standalone camera achieved an average coverage of 51.68 %, the addition of a single planar mirror increased this value to 85.46 %, with complete coverage achieved for several objects. A complementary user study demonstrated that manually chosen configurations exhibit high variability and do not outperform the algorithmic design. The results confirm that the use of mirrors provides a cost-effective solution for overcoming occlusion-related limitations without resorting to multi-camera systems, and that the proposed methodology delivers consistent performance across diverse object geometries. The approach is particularly applicable in industrial inspection, robotic vision, and other domains where complete geometric information is essential.

title: A Sampling-Neighborhood-Regularized Latent Factorization of Tensor for Dynamic QoS Estimation
authors: Xiuqin Xu, Mingwei Lin, Zeshui Xu, Xin Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Since similar users frequently exhibit similar Quality of Service (QoS) when accessing similar services, effectively capturing neighborhood information hidden in QoS data becomes critical for latent factorization of tensor (LFT)-based QoS estimators. Current LFT models either calculate the complete set of neighborhoods or do not consider neighborhoods, resulting in a rapid rise in model complexity and poor estimation accuracy. Moreover, not every neighbor in the neighborhood set is beneficial to the user/service entity. To address these limitations, this study proposes a sampling-neighborhood-regularized latent factorization of tensor (SNLFT) model with three key ideas: 1) extracting primal latent factors (LFs), which are obtained to express related entities on the basis of high-dimensional and incomplete QoS data; 2) constructing the sampling-neighborhood set, which is acquired using the Gibbs sampling to reflect the similarities between the primal LF vectors of entities over time; 3) developing a sampling-neighborhood-regularized LFT model, where all the sampling neighborhoods of entities and L2-norm of desirable LFs are employed to regularize the objective function. Extensive experiments on eight dynamic QoS datasets demonstrate that SNLFT significantly outperforms state-of-the-art models in both estimation accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Development of Planning and Tracking Logic for Perpendicular Parking Trajectories in Narrow Spaces Considering Rear-Wheel Steering
authors: Beomhyuk Park, Sang-Ho Lee, Jee-Yoon Suh, Wanki Cho, Seung-Han You
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Parking in modern urban environments has become increasingly challenging as available spaces grow narrower and vehicles continue to increase in size. Although various automated parking technologies have been developed to address this issue, most production-level approaches are designed for relatively wide spaces and rely on simplified single-stage trajectories to ensure real-time feasibility. As a result, their applicability to narrow environments requiring multiple maneuvers remains limited. To overcome these challenges, this paper proposes a trajectory generation and tracking control logic for perpendicular parking in narrow spaces. The proposed logic emulates the way human drivers adjust their vehicle position through forward and backward movements, enabling effective parking even in narrow environments. The trajectory generation is based on a kinematic model and incorporates rear-wheel steering using a virtual wheelbase concept, allowing the existing logic to be applied without modification. To enhance robustness of tracking control, a disturbance observer is employed to compensate for road slopes and external disturbances, while a feedforward-based control strategy reduces the dependence on sensor feedback in lateral motion tracking. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through CARSIM simulations and real vehicle experiments, confirming its robustness and feasibility in achieving stable, collision-free perpendicular parking.

title: Expression of Concern for: Prediction of Autism Spectrum Disorder Using Efficient Net
authors: Mohana Sree Venkata Sai Krishna Narala, Sandeep Vemuri, Chandrika Kattula
publish: 2023 9th International Conference on Advanced Computing and Communication Systems (ICACCS)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder is a neurodevelopmental condition that can have a lasting impact on a person's ability to communicate, learn language, interact socially, and process information.Early detection of this disorder in children helps to improve their intellectual ability. This model helps to detect autism spectrum disorder. So, to predict whether the person is either autistic or a typically developing child is done using facial images. Our findings facilitate the distinction between children diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder and those who are typically developing by analyzing their facial characteristics. Autism Image data dataset is used which consists of 2530 facial images in training set, 300 facial images are present in the test set which are used for evolution of model. The Efficient Net convolutional neural network was utilized to build this model, which achieved a accuracy level of 88.

title: Wearable Health Monitoring for Senior Citizens with Mobile App Access for Caregivers and Family Members
authors: Khandaker Waliur Rahman, Ishtiaque Asad, Sharif Md. Rakibul Raihan, Md. Ataur Rahman, Shipra Banik, Mahady Hasan
publish: 2025 IEEE Region 10 Symposium (TENSYMP)
abstract: The paper introduces a system called ElderSense wearable device, which is a smart health monitoring system that addresses the needs of the elderly citizen and their caregivers by using various vital monitors such as heart rate, emergency alerts etc to provide a better care for the loving ones. In these papers, we conducted three surveys. In our first survey, we wanted to find out whether the ElderSense wearable wristband and mobile app were actually needed by older people or their caregivers. After developing a UI design, we can again conduct another user satisfaction survey to understand how well it worked and what could be improved. Based on their feedback, we made some changes and then conducted a third survey with UI/UX professionals, including healthcare experts and technology specialists. Their insights helped us refine the design further, reliable, and easy to use for both elderly users and caregivers.

title: An IoT-Based Real-Time Elevator Health Monitoring System Using LSTM Autoencoder
authors: Autoencoder Yogendra Kumar, Mohammad Arif Khan, Avishek Adhikary
publish: IEEE Sensors Letters
abstract: Elevators play an essential role for safe and efficient vertical transportation in modern buildings. However, traditional maintenance strategies based on scheduled inspections often fail to detect faults that appear between inspection intervals, this leads to unplanned downtime. This paper presents an IoT-based Elevator Health Monitoring System (EHMS) that integrates vibration sensing, wireless communication, and machine learning to enable real-time condition monitoring. The system utilizes an accelerometer sensor interfaced with an microcontroller to capture elevator vibration and motion data. The collected data is transmitted to a cloud server, where a Long Short-Term Memory based autoencoder is used for anomaly detection by calculating threshold based on reconstruction error. The proposed system detects real-time fault data with 98.33% accuracy and 100% recall, validated through four-month experimental study.

title: FO-ESDE: A Sparse Antenna Array Design Scheme From Enhanced Sum-Difference Co-Array Perspective
authors: Lang Zhou, Gongjian Zhou
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: In this letter, we first investigate a shift strategy for enhancing the length of the consecutive segment in the sum and difference co-array (SDCA). Then, a fourth-order sparse antenna array design scheme, entitled fourth-order enhanced sum-difference expansion (FO-ESDE), is proposed for direction of arrival (DOA) estimation, based on enhanced SDCA and fourth-order expansion co-array (FO-ECA). Both the sensor locations and uniform degrees of freedom (uDOFs) of this scheme can be expressed in closed-form expressions. Numerical simulation results indicate that the FO-ESDE exhibits enhanced uDOFs and inherits the superior mutual coupling (MC) performance of the first subarray's generator array. In addition, the estimation performance of FO-ESDE surpasses that of competing second-order and fourth-order sparse antenna arrays.

title: Multiset Combinatorial Gray Codes with Application to Proximity Sensor Networks
authors: Chung Shue Chen, Wing Shing Wong, Yuan-Hsun Lo, Tsai-Lien Wong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Theory
abstract: We investigate coding schemes that map source symbols into multisets of an alphabet. Such a formulation of source coding is an alternative approach to the traditional framework and is inspired by an object tracking problem over proximity sensor networks. We define a multiset combinatorial Gray code as a mulitset code with fixed multiset cardinality that possesses combinatorial Gray code characteristic. For source codes that are organized as a grid, namely an integer lattice, we propose a solution by first constructing a mapping from the grid to the set of symbols, which we referred to as colors. The codes are then defined as the images of rectangular blocks in the grid of fixed dimensions. We refer to the mapping as a color mapping and the code as a color multiset code. We propose the idea of product multiset code that enables us to construct codes for high dimensional grids based on 1-dimensional (1D) grids. We provide a detailed analysis of color multiset codes on 1D grids, focusing on codes that require the minimal number of colors. To illustrate the application of such a coding scheme, we consider an object tracking problem on 2D grids and show its efficiency, which comes from exploiting transmission parallelism. Some numerical results are presented to conclude the paper.

title: Research on the Impact of Laser Simulation Accuracy under Ultra-High Dose Rate X-rays
authors: Jingrui Liu, Ge Tang, Tao Yi, Zhiyong Chen, Bo Yu, Shubo Cheng, Jianbin Zhou, Mo Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: Laser simulation technology, owing to its high temporal and spatial resolution, excellent controllability, and strong repeatability, has become a vital auxiliary method for investigating dose rate effects in semiconductor devices. However, due to the limitations of large-scale ground-based simulation facilities, the equivalent dose rate achievable through laser simulation has long been constrained to approximately 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">12</sup> rad(Si)/s. In this study, ultra-high dose rate X-ray irradiation—up to the order of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">14</sup> rad(Si)/s—was generated via laser-target interactions to systematically investigate the influence of nonlinear physical processes on the accuracy of laser simulation under extreme dose rate conditions. Experimental results show that, after converting the laser dose rate using a Conversion Factor (CF) of 1.5 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> rad(Si)·s<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>/W·cm⁻², the simulated results exhibit good agreement with the measured X-ray-induced peak responses, confirming the applicability of this equivalence factor under ultra-high dose rate conditions. In addition, the comparison between the laser and X-ray data indicates that the relative errors of the peak responses for the silicon-based devices are 4.77%, 2.41%, and 6.63%, respectively. A characteristic dual-peak response phenomenon was also observed in the experiments, and further analysis indicates that it primarily originates from spatial variations in the X-ray incidence position causing non-uniform energy deposition.

title: AI-Driven Environmental, Social, and Governance Score Predictions: A Machine Learning Approach Using SDG Indicators
authors: Anmol Jain, Divyansh Agarwal, Dhairya Jain, Manoj Kumar, Nishant Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Sustainability has become a crucial priority for global development, specifically Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) scores that serve as criteria for judging ethical and sustainable behavior. Machine learning models are applied to predict ESG scores with respect to Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) indicators which lead us to a primary discussion of some challenges faced in ESG analytics, namely data sparsity, indicator interdependencies, and non-linear relationship. Through the Gradient Boosting methodology, PCA, and advanced feature engineering, we showcase a robust predictive framework that outperforms traditional statistical methods with respect to performance. This is a novel approach combining multi-source SDG data with advanced preprocessing techniques to deal with missing values and multicollinearity issues. The proposed model is significantly more accurate when compared to baseline methods and offers unique insights regarding feature importance within the environment, society, and governance domains. The present study highlights the importance of ESG metrics in sustainable development, the model performance is evaluated using various metrics, and the actionable implications for decision-makers are considered. Such interpretability is enhanced for practitioners, affirmed by the visual representation of results using feature importance plot, predicted vs actual score graph, and statistical comparison of models.

title: Quantitative Comparison between Diesel Generator and ESSs
authors: Abdullah Aldabbous
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The replacement of emergency generator with Energy Storage Systems (ESSs) will reduce GHG emissions. This paper quantitatively compares DGs and six energy storage systems (ESSs)-lead-acid, Li-ion, and nickel-cadmium batteries; Flywheel (FESS); Compressed Air (CAES); and supercapacitors-for emergency power in offshore oil/gas facilities. Offshore environments pose unique challenges: space/weight constraints and logistical limitations. The study evaluates systems against seven design criteria derived from NFPA 110, API RP 14F, and author experience: space, weight, self-discharge, fuel autonomy, power transfer time, short-circuit capability, and loading flexibility. The study reveals DGs outperform ESSs in volumetric/gravimetric energy density However, ESSs offer critical advantages: faster response times, eliminating UPS needs for critical loads, renewable energy integration potential, solving offshore refueling challenges, reduced environmental impact.

title: Telehealth Solutions in Nursing: Evaluating the Impact of Remote Patient Monitoring on Chronic Disease Management
authors: Ray Suresh, Supriya Pottal Ray, Monita Thokchom, Sushila Devi, Ramesh Bidari, Nikhil Ingawale
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Telehealth technologies are behind the modern healthcare revolution, especially helping nurses care for chronic illnesses. How RPM influences the care of diabetes, hypertension, and heart failure is measured in this study. With RPM, nurses can spot warning signs quickly, respond promptly, and make sure patients are part of their care plan using fresh data. The study looks at recent research and case studies to see how healthcare results, patient satisfaction, and workflow have advanced. The findings demonstrate that RPM helps patients follow their treatments, visit the hospital less often, and experience a better quality of life. As a result, nurses can be more comfortable giving more active and suited care when RPM is utilized in their work. RPM is a useful tool for managing chronic diseases, according to the evidence, despite issues with data security and technology uptake. Its long-term viability depends on ongoing investments in nurse education and the telemedicine structure.

title: A Multi-Stage Hybrid Image Denoising Approach: A Comparative Study with Wavelet Transform and Edge Preservation
authors: Shreya, R Chithra, Sanchitha Y M, Avik Banerjee
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Digital image denoising is a significant challenge in image processing. It affects visual quality and the tasks that follow. This paper introduces a new multi-stage hybrid image denoising method. We compare it with the Enhanced Discrete Wavelet Transform (EDWT) method by Tuba and Zivkovic. Our approach starts with spatial filtering, then uses ensemble wavelet denoising, follows with residual refinement, and ends with edgeaware blending. We carried out experiments on standard images that were corrupted by both Gaussian and Salt & Pepper noise at different levels. We evaluated performance using Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM), and Mean Squared Error (MSE), among other quality metrics. The results show that our multi-stage hybrid method consistently performs better in denoising. Specifically, it achieves an average PSNR of over 41 dB. It maintains an average SSIM of over 98% compared to the original image. Additionally, it reduces the MSE by more than 98% across all tested images and noise conditions. This method effectively preserves image details and structural integrity.

title: MetaRookies: An AI-Powered Platform for Intelligent Fitness, Nutrition, and Real-Time Posture Correction
authors: Preetham N, Nandeesh C M, K Preethi, Roopa Iranna Bagalkoti, Somesh Nandi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents MetaRookies, an intelligent and interactive fitness platform that integrates advanced artificial intelligence techniques to support users in achieving sustainable health and wellness goals. The system offers a comprehensive solution encompassing real-time posture correction, personalized workout planning, nutritional evaluation, and adaptive goal tracking. By leveraging MediaPipe for pose estimation, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for motion analysis, and YOLO (You Only Look Once) for object detection, MetaRookies delivers immediate and accurate feedback during physical exercises, helping users maintain proper form and prevent injuries. In addition to exercise guidance, the platform generates tailored workout routines based on individual profiles, fitness levels, and progression history. The system continuously adapts to users' evolving needs through machine learning-based personalization. A dedicated nutrition module further enhances the platform by analyzing meal inputs using image processing and estimating nutritional content, thereby encouraging healthier dietary decisions. The MetaRookies application is integrated with a Flask-based interactive dashboard that visualizes progress, monitors health metrics, and utilizes a streak-based motivational system to foster long-term user engagement. Designed with a strong emphasis on accessibility and user-centric personalization, the system caters to both novice users and experienced fitness enthusiasts. Overall, MetaRookies combines AI-driven analysis, adaptive planning, and user engagement strategies into a unified platform, offering a holistic approach to fitness and well-being.

title: Multi-Parametric Dynamic Performance Evaluation of Si IGBT and SiC MOSFETs for High-Frequency DC-DC Converter Applications
authors: Jamlick M. Kinyua, Mutsumi Aoki
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: In applications where power density and efficiency are critical, the choice between Si IGBTs and SiC MOSFETs is crucial. SiC MOSFETs, with their high critical electric field, superior thermal conductivity, and wide band gap, represent a transformative innovation. This work provides a comprehensive, simulation-driven analysis comparing both technologies across multi-parametric dimensions (voltage, current, gate resistance). Switching transitions, device stress, various losses, and efficiency are compared under identical setups. The results demonstrate SiC MOSFETs’ superior characteristics over Si IGBTs, enabling significant performance improvements, higher efficiency, and more compact designs. This study addresses a current lack of systematic investigation by presenting a conclusive comparative evaluation of switching losses, conduction losses, and efficiency under varied operating conditions, providing validated conclusions for designing advanced WBG converters

title: Development of a Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Predicting Epileptic Seizures Using EEG Signal Analysis
authors: MS Sathwik, S Suma
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Epilepsy affects over 65 million people worldwide, with many cases resistant to medication and surgery. Early seizure prediction can offer a critical opportunity for therapeutic response and improved quality of life. This paper proposes a hybrid deep learning framework to predict seizures by analyzing EEG signal patterns. The proposed method consists of pre-processing the scalp EEG signals, extracting features using CNN and classifying the features with SVM Across multiple model configurations, individual classifiers such as CNN, LSTM, ANN, and SqueezeNet achieved accuracies in the range of 90-96%, while the hybrid ensemble framework attained peak performance with an accuracy of up to 98.14%. To enhance robustness, an ensemble architecture combining CNN, LSTM, SqueezeNet, and ANN is introduced. This is supported by advanced preprocessing techniques like bandpass filtering, ICA, and Z-score normalization. The system supports multi-class prediction and is designed for integration with telehealth platforms.

title: Sentiment Analysis Using Natural Language Processing
authors: Rajashree Shettar, Ramya V
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Social media platforms, especially Twitter, have become powerful channels for users to express opinions on diverse topics ranging from products and politics to social issues. Valuable insights could be derived from the extracted unstructured information and analyzed by applying sentiment analysis techniques. In this paper, a comprehensive study on Twitter reviews is done by categorizing user sentiments into three classes: positive, neutral, and negative. This work is divided into two experimental segments. In the first segment, dataset comprising of 27,453 tweets is evaluated and three techniques are applied, namely, a rule-based method (VADER), a traditional machine learning pipeline using TF-IDF with Logistic Regression, and a deep learning model based on the transformer architecture, RoBERTa. Among these, RoBERTa achieved the highest accuracy of 72.13%, outperforming VADER (63.13%) and TF-IDF + Logistic Regression (69.14%), demonstrating the effectiveness of transformer-based contextual embeddings for sentiment classification. In the second segment, experiment is conducted with a reduced dataset of 5,000 tweets to simulate a low-resource environment. A comparison of Logistic Regression, Support Vector Classifier (SVC), Random Forest (RF), and Gradient Boosting (GB) performance is explored. Logistic Regression and Random Forest achieved the highest accuracy of 75.8% and 75.9% respectively, highlighting their robustness even on limited data. The results show the effectiveness of both transformer-based and classical models, depending on the dataset size and complexity.
