title: CCTV Data Recovery by Using Fast Forward Motion Picture Experts Group (FFMPEG)
authors: Badri Bin Azni, Fakariah Hani Binti Haji Mohd Ali, Nurul Huda Binti Nik Zulkifli
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Closed-circuit television (CCTV) is a dominant device at the moment, which is a necessity and a supporting factor in the aspect of asset security and personal protection. With a wide range of types and capabilities, CCTV plays a role in recording events that occur within a predetermined field of view (FOV). Various methods have been invented to store recording files, whether in the built-in storage inside the CCTV itself, memory cards, stored in the hard disk of a Digital Video Recorder (DVR), or via cloud-based storage as the latest and most recent method. However, on the other hand, problems often occur when technical problems occur, especially with the power supply, the process of recording cannot be completed, and finally, the file created by the system cannot be played back and remains as a temporary file in the storage. Fast Forward Moving Picture Experts Group (FFMPEG) is the key to starting the data recovery process, where the unplayable temporary files can be recovered and perhaps played. FFMPEG is a great open-source tool for transcoding, muxing, filtering, and playing back any recording made by humans or computers. It also supports various types of legacy formats created by various standards committees, communities, or corporations. In this study, FFMPEG will be used to rearrange the coding and to ensure that the broken video recording file can be played back, and provide an overview of what happened until the last moment of the recording was successfully recorded.

title: Generation of Sound from Silent Videos
authors: Daksh Goyal, Shubham Upadhyay, Prajwal Patgar, Jeevith P, B. Roja Reddy, Kavitha SN, Praful Mathur, Roopa Sheshadri
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Synthesizing realistic audio for silent videos is a challenging cross-modal generation task with broad applications in video editing and multimedia content creation. To address this, we implemented a Contrastive Video-Audio encoder (CVAP) framework that generates high-fidelity audio synchronized with silent video. The CVAP model integrates a deep video encoder to extract spatiotemporal visual features, a Variational Audio Autoencoder (VAE) for compact audio representation, and a Transformerbased temporal alignment module that learns the correspondence between visual events and sound patterns over time. A BigVGAN vocoder then converts the generated audio spectrogram latent representation into a waveform, ensuring high audio quality. At its front end, CVAP employs the MAViL visual encoder, whose masked-audio-video pretraining yields rich spatiotemporal features aligned with auditory semantics. These features enter a shared latent space formed by a mel-spectrogram variational autoencoder: video cues are projected into the same representation that the audio decoder will later reconstruct, ensuring that sight and sound speak a common language. The proposed approach is novel in its combination of advanced components and offers practical implications, such as automating effect generation for films and videos and enhancing multimedia experiences by adding contextually appropriate sound to silent video content. As validated by our experimental evaluations (Tables 1, 2, and 3), the proposed CVAP framework achieves superior audio synthesis quality, with significant improvements in Fréchet Audio Distance (FAD) and related metrics, thus providing a new pathway for more immersive and accessible audiovisual media experiences.

title: Weather Prediction Using Machine Learning: A Data-Driven Approach to Reliable Forecasting
authors: Tejashwini P S, Prathik K, Jeevan K, S Mohammed Hasnain, Puvvadi Venkata Tanay
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Weather prediction is essential across various domains, including agriculture, transportation, and disaster management, as it facilitates informed decision-making through reliable forecasts. Traditional approaches, such as Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP), are computationally demanding and often struggle to accurately model the complex, non-linear relationships inherent in weather data. To address these challenges, this study employs machine learning techniques to analyze historical weather datasets. Advanced data preprocessing techniques, including normalization and feature engineering, were applied to manage missing values and inconsistencies within the dataset. Several machine learning models–Linear Regression, Decision Tree, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machines (SVM)–were implemented and evaluated using performance metrics such as Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> Score. Among these, an ensemble approach integrating Random Forest and SVM demonstrated superior performance, exhibiting enhanced accuracy and robustness. These findings underscore the efficacy of data-driven methodologies in overcoming the limitations of traditional forecasting techniques, providing a scalable and reliable solution for modern weather prediction systems.

title: Face Sketch to Image Generation Using Pix2Pix GAN
authors: Arthik Shetty, Sachidanand C G, M S Srividya
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This work presents an automated image synthesis method from hand-drawn sketches using adversarial networks. Conventional translation approaches enforce rigid constraints forcing outputs to match input sketch edges exactly, producing unrealistic results when sketches are imperfect. Our technique utilizes sketches as soft guidance instead of hard constraints, generating more natural images. We introduce a joint completion framework treating sketches as contextual cues for image synthesis. A contextual GAN learns unified sketch-image distributions through shared representation. Key advantages include: (1) joint representation simplifies learning in common sketch-image space, avoiding cross-domain complexities; (2) outputs maintain semantic relation to inputs while exhibiting visual flexibility unlike strict conditional GANs; (3) identical architecture enables bidirectional sketch-image conversion. Experiments on benchmark datasets show improved performance over existing conditional methods, especially for poor-quality sketches, with strong generalization. The method achieves realistic results through context-guided completion rather than direct mapping.

title: AI-Powered Brain Tumor Classification: Optimizing Accuracy and Speed with PHOG, SCHF and Machine Learning Models
authors: Radhika Sethuraman, Gururama Senthilvel P
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Detection together with classification of brain tumors holds essential importance in medical imaging since it supports early diagnosis and treatment preparation. The investigation determines the performance capabilities of various machine learning models which use both PHOG and SCHF to extract features for analysis. The research consisted of Decision Stump alongside Decision Tree while IBK (Instance-Based Learning) served as the third tested classifier. The study evaluated model performances through accuracy tests together with precision, recall measurements as well as ROC (Receiver Operating Characteristic) analysis PRC (Precision-Recall Curve) evaluation and execution time assessment. SCHF + IBK produced the best brain tumor classification accuracy at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{9 2. 9 8 \%}$</tex> which established it as the optimal identifying method. SCHF + Decision Stump method produced similar results to PHOG + Decision Tree method as both achieved 92.02 % accuracy in the classification process. Reliability of classification extends from the PHOG + IBK model since it achieved 91.11 % accuracy alongside a precision level of 0.93. The combination of SCHF and Decision Tree resulted in the least effective yet most inefficient tumor prediction model with 81.01 % accuracy and weak ROC of 0.83 and recall at 0.81. The extremely fast execution time of 0.14 seconds for PHOG + Decision Stump makes this model the best choice for live applications due to its exceptional computational speed. SCHF + IBK produced the longest execution time of 1.16 seconds even though it achieved good classification outcomes. The examination reveals that IBK-based methods achieve top classification results but Decision Stumps execute the fastest compared to other models. The SCHF + Decision Tree classifier proved to be ineffective thus making it an unfit solution for tumor classification problems.

title: Implementation of Multi-Mode Thyristor Rectifier Phase Controller
authors: Chen Luo, Lin Chai
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Thyristor-based phase-controlled rectifier is widely used in industrial applications where high power regulated DC power supply is needed, and digitally controlled thyristor trigger controller is used to regulate the firing timing of thyristors, thus controlling the rectifier's output. In different industrial applications, the rectifier circuit configurations are varied and need different control logics. In this paper the software control logic of a DSP-based thyristor trigger controller which supports 4 different rectifier circuit configurations is implemented, including single 6-pulse rectifier, double individual 6-pulse rectifiers, 12 pulse rectifier with single current feedback, and 12 pulse rectifier with double current feedback. Compared to conventional rectifier trigger controller designs, this design enables the controller to adapt to more types of applications, which offers broader applicability across different scenarios.

title: A Hybrid GNN-CNN Framework for Drug-Target Binding Affinity Prediction with Quantified Uncertainty
authors: H R Sankhya, Jagadeeshwari V Gogga, Vijayshree V M, Sailaja Y
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Predicting binding affinity between drug molecules and target proteins is an essential and labor-intensive hurdle in the drug discovery workflow. This paper presents a new deep learning framework to help overcome this hurdle, designed around a Graph Neural Network (GNN) representing the drug molecules and a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) based representation of a protein sequence. To increase the reliability of the predictions obtained from the model, Monte Carlo Dropout (MCD) was implemented to quantify uncertainty, associated with each prediction. The framework integrates the benefits of both the GNN and CNN hybrid architecture, achieving state-of-the-art results on the publicly available benchmark Davis dataset with a training Mean Squared Error (MSE) of 0.1387, Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 0.3724, and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.3672. These results underscore the model's superior predictive accuracy and its ability to provide confidence- aware predictions, which is crucial for rational decision-making in high-throughput virtual screening and guiding experimental validation in drug discovery.

title: Maximum Power Point Tracking in Photovoltaic Systems Using the Snake Optimization Algorithm
authors: Nursultan Koshkarbay, Karam Khairullah Mohammed, Saad Mekhilef, Nurzhigit Kuttybay, Nurdaulet Kalassov, Ahmet Saymbetov, Madiyar Nurgaliyev
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Renewable energy, particularly solar power, is increasingly important as non-renewable sources decline, but its efficiency is often reduced by weather and shading. Implementing a Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) system ensures that solar panels consistently operate at their optimal power output, even under partial shading conditions. This study presents a snake optimization (SO) method designed to increase the rate of convergence to the maximum power point under different partial shading conditions (PSCs). The results demonstrate that the proposed SO method performed exceptionally well, achieving an average tracking time of 0.875 seconds across different weather conditions and an efficiency of $98.82 \%$.

title: An Intelligent Multi-Module Financial Assistant for Personalized Budgeting, Risk Alerts, and Adaptive Investment Advisory
authors: Pavithra Ganta, Gourav Agarwal, Rajshekhar Jha, Kalyan Nagaraj
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Managing personal finances in today's fragmented fintech landscape presents significant challenges due to the absence of integrated, user-aware systems. This work proposes a unified, intelligent finance management framework that automates budgeting, credit recommendation, risk detection, and interactive advisory services. The system combines modular components-namely, a fraud detection engine using XGBoost, a personalized credit card ranker powered by learning-to-rank models, and a finance chatbot built on LLM with intent and context detection pipelines. Key innovations include categoryaware document embeddings, semantic user profiling, and rulebased behavior mapping for spending trends. Evaluation results demonstrate effective fraud classification, accurate credit matching, and scalable document-grounded advisory generation. The platform is designed for young professionals, freelancers, and digital users, and emphasizes scalability, explainability, and contextual intelligence across financial tasks.

title: Spiking Neural Networks for Real-Time Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality Systems
authors: Chilukuri Bala Venkata Subbarayudu, Hassan M. Al-Jawahry, Jajimoggala Sravanthi, U.Esakkiammal, V. Dinesh Babu, Zainb Hussain Ali, Amir M Khalaf, Sajad Ali Zearah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Gesture recognition is an important part of Virtual Reality (VR) systems because it lets users interact with the VR easily. But it's hard to do real-time processing because most deep learning models, like neural networks, need much power and computing power. This Paper investigates Spiking Neural Networks (SNN) as a superior virtual reality gesture detection method in real-time. SNN saves energy and go faster since it uses spikes to process data, much like the brain. Following an SNN-based model, the proposed approach trained it on a motion recognition dataset utilizing certain learning techniques like Spike-Timing-dependent Plasticity (STDP). This Paper assessed the model's energy usage, speed, and accuracy on neuromorphic devices. Although SNN uses less energy and reacts faster than other deep learning models, the findings imply that it can correctly detect motions. Therefore, VR apps are quite suitable, especially on phones and connected devices. This Paper encourages the generation of smarter, more energy-efficient artificial intelligence for virtual reality systems and increases real-time motion recognition.

title: Design and Implementation of a Transformer-Less Dual Active Half Bridge Converter for Lighting Applications
authors: Ignacio M. Alvarez Diaz, Guirguis Z. Abdelmessih, J. Marcos Alonso
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: Through this article, a bidirectional Transformer-Less Dual Active Half Bridge converter (T-LDAHB) is used to integrate a battery, a PV panel and an LED load. The innovation presented in this work lies in the detailed mathematical analysis of this relatively unexplored DC/DC converter, combined with the implementation of Phase Shift Modulation (PSM), improving efficiency compared to conventional alternatives. The prototype presented is an autonomous off-grid system, ideal for rural areas or third world countries where access to grid is complicated or very difficult to reach. The prototype designed has been analysed with simulations and experimentations under maximum power of 120 W, reaching a peak efficiency of 96%.

title: Effects of Permanent Magnet Faults in the Direct Drive PMSG for Offshore WECS
authors: Merve Cömert, Hüseyin Tayyer Canseven, Abdurrahman Ünsal
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The increasing reliance on multi-megawatt DirectDrive Permanent Magnet Synchronous Generators (DD-PMSGs) for offshore wind energy conversion systems (OWECS) places a critical emphasis on their operational reliability. While DDPMSGs eliminate the failure-prone gearbox, their performance is fundamentally dependent on the health of their permanent magnets (PMs), which are susceptible to demagnetization and mechanical damage. This paper presents a detailed investigation on the electromagnetic signatures of common PM faults using high-fidelity Finite Element Analysis (FEA). A comprehensive 2D model of the $15-\mathrm{MW}$ reference wind turbine generator, defined by the International Energy Agency (IEA), is used as a benchmark. The study systematically analyzes the effects of uniform and localized demagnetization, as well as broken magnet, on key performance indicators. The results demonstrate that each fault type generates distinct and quantifiable changes in the electromagnetic torque, three-phase back-electromotive force (back-EMF), and air-gap flux density distribution. By characterizing these unique fault signatures, this work provides a foundational understanding necessary for the development of advanced condition monitoring and fault diagnosis algorithms, ultimately contributing to the enhanced reliability and reduced operational costs of OWECS.

title: Investigation of Combustion and Emission Performance in Ammonia-Diesel Dual-Fuel Engines
authors: Rahim Karami, Mohammad G. Rasul, Marzyeh Hosseinpour, Behad Moghtaderi
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The growing interest in ammonia as a zero-carbon fuel for internal combustion engines has highlighted its potential, particularly in large-displacement engines. Despite its environmental advantages, the use of ammonia introduces considerable challenges in terms of combustion dynamics and pollutant formation. This research uses computational fluid dynamics (CFD) modeling through CONVERGE software to evaluate how varying the share of ammonia, diesel injection duration, and injection timing affects engine behavior under high-load conditions. The findings reveal that introducing a 10% ammonia blend results in peak pressures surpassing those of conventional diesel combustion. While ammonia tends to delay ignition and reduce the heat release rate, optimizing injection timing and shortening injection duration improves premixed combustion characteristics. Notably, nitrogen oxide (NO) emissions are substantially decreased by as much as 92%, with higher ammonia content, likely due to thermal DeNOx reactions. However, shortening injection at higher ammonia levels elevates NO output, and advancing injection timing has limited impact on this trend.

title: Quality Systems for Pharma: CAPA Optimisation and Leadership in Compliance
authors: Vamsi Krishna Gottipati, Saideep Nakka, Pankaj Kumar, Mirjalol Ismoilov Ruziboy Ugli, Bobur Mirzayev
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Corrective and Preventive Action (CAPM) systems form the foundation of the pharmaceutical quality because they ensure compliance, product integrity, and safety of patients. The strategic CAPA integration revealed in this review pertains to the leadership accountability, digital transformation, and organizational culture. Systemic changes are needed in problems that are chronic such as ineffective root cause analysis, slow closure and half hearted correction actions. The effective CAPA links quality data, decision tools and corrections in-process and the leadership and good quality culture is important enablers. It is complemented by AI-powered prediction analytics, globalized CAPM standards, and culture-based performance indicators, making CAPM become more of a quality excellence and source of innovation throughout the lifecycle of the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Fabrication and Evaluation of Flow-Directional Graded Catalyst Layers in PEMFCs Using Electrospray Deposition
authors: Eiji Yoshida, Hikaru Arai, Noboru Katayama

title: ML-Driven Loan Approval: Evaluating Predictive Models and Real-Time Deployment on the Cloud
authors: Abir Saha, Xiao Pu, Ihsan Ali, Junaid Shuja
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Loan approval plays a central role in banking operations and directly affects the organization’s profit and risk exposure. With increasing loan applications and the limitations of traditional manual evaluation methods, financial institutions are turning to machine learning to improve decision-making processes. This study evaluates four machine learning models to predict loan approval status using a comparatively large and numerically focused data set. Logistic regression, Random Forest, XGBoost, and ANN were implemented and compared under a consistent experimental setup. The data set used in this study contains structured financial data with features such as installment amount, annual income, debt-to-income ratio, FICO score, and revolving balance, relevant to real-world loan prediction scenarios. Among the models tested, XGBoost achieved the highest accuracy. The best model was also deployed using AWS SageMaker with API Gateway and Lambda for real-time inference, demonstrating the potential for use in production environments. The results highlight the effectiveness of different machine learning techniques in loan assessment and underscore the importance of using relevant numerical features for realworld applicability.

title: Music Genre Classification Using Multilayer Perceptron: A Machine Learning Approach
authors: Praveena Kumari M K, Premitha Kamath, Varun K, Varadraj D Ganiga, Shilpa K A
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Music genre classification is an important task in digital library organization, and is beneficial to recommender systems. In this work, we explore the possible use of a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) to solve genre classification tasks using audio features as input, such as MFCCs, chroma features, and spectral contrast, among others, and signal processing approaches such as STFT, Mel spectrograms, and spectral rolloff. The proposed model also outperformed the traditional classifiers such as KNN, SVM, and Random Forest when tested on the GTZAN dataset with a test accuracy of 92.19% and a validation accuracy of 92.22%. Experiments demonstrate that the lightweight neural models, such as MLP, can achieve comparable performance with deeper CNN/RNN architectures and have computational advantages in scenarios of real-world applications, e.g., automated genre tagging, personalized recommendations, and content curation in music streaming platforms.

title: Advanced Detection of Helmet Usage and Number Plates in Riders
authors: P. Jayadharshini, Muthuraman Saminathan, Lalitha Krishnasamy, P. Nithya, T. Sathya, N. Abinaya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Most critically, enforcing road safety laws and reducing roadway fatalities from traffic accidents will rely heavily on accurately detecting helmet use and motorcycle riders' number plates. Conventional methods of enforcement rely heavily on human observation and labour-intensive methods, and are problematic as they can be subject to human error under specific conditions (for example, poor weather and lighting). To demonstrate an automated system that could potentially mitigate some of these constraints, we developed a novel automated system by combining cutting-edge object detection models (You Only Look Once, Nano version (YOLOv8n), Faster R-CNN) and EasyOCR (optical character recognition) to assist law enforcement. YOLOv8n has been praised for its speed and accuracy; when developing and training the model, we sourced a dataset with images of riders wearing helmets and other images of riders without helmets, as well as the number plate images to ensure that during training, the model was able to learn both tasks as it related to the helmet use detection and number plates. EasyOCR is an excellent resource for extracting textual data from detected number plates, so combining YOLOv8n with EasyOCR allows for real-time data collection from the detected number plates. This unified platform is a big step ahead in roadway security technology. It offers an easily expandable yet successful way to keep an eye on helmet use and identify and punish drivers who don't wear them, all of which will help reduce traffic accidents and save lives.

title: A Review of Smart Building Management Systems: CPS Applications for Energy-Efficient Monitoring and Control
authors: Rhana Elsayed, Mohamed I. Ismail, Ahmed F. Ashour, Hesham A. Sakr, Mohamed I. Ibrahem, Mostafa M. Fouda
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Cyber-physical Systems (CPS) are increasingly utilized by Smart Building Management Systems (SBMS) to achieve intelligent, energy-efficient operations. The significant energy footprint of buildings (approximately 40% of worldwide energy use) and the desire to improve sustainability without compromising occupant comfort are the primary drivers of this movement. However, complicated cybersecurity issues are also brought about by the close integration of Internet of Things (IoT) sensors, automated controls, and networked management. In this study, we provide a comprehensive examination of CPS-based smart building monitoring and control technologies, exploring how state-of-the-art sensors, data analytics, and Artificial Intelligence (AI)-powered decision engines are utilized to enhance responsiveness and energy efficiency. We present a comparison between contemporary CPS-enabled SBMS and conventional building management systems, emphasizing the enhancements in security, flexibility, and energy efficiency. A thorough analysis of energy optimization processes demonstrates how machine learning algorithms and feedback loops may dynamically strike a balance between efficiency and comfort. We also examine new security models being developed to defend these cyber-physical infrastructures against attacks. This survey is unique because it comprehensively covers recent CPS developments and identifies emerging trends that will influence next-generation smart building management, including blockchain, Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO)based decentralized management architectures, and federated learning for collaborative optimization. In addition to outlining substantial obstacles and future research opportunities, our findings highlight the crucial role that CPS plays in enabling safe, self-sufficient, and sustainable buildings.

title: Pneumonia Detection and Severity Grading Using YOLOv8
authors: K. Praveen Kumar, Addanki Praveen, Ancha Jai Ranganath, Anjikesava Nomula
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Pneumonia remains a global health issue, especially in resource-limited settings where timely and accurate diagnosis is lacking. In this paper, we introduce a computer-aided pneumonia detection and severity grading system using a deep learning strategy based on the YOLOv8 classification model. The system was trained on a public chest X-ray dataset comprising Normal and Pneumonia classes and achieved a Top-1 classification accuracy of 94.7 %, demonstrating its capability to distinguish pathological cases from normal scans. Additionally, a severity grading module was integrated using prediction confidence scores to categorize cases as mild, moderate, or severe, enabling related precautionary guidance and treatment suggestions. A web interface was also developed using Flask to support real-time image uploads, diagnostic inference, and personalized clinical feedback. The proposed system offers a rapid, interpretable, and deployable solution to support radiologists and healthcare professionals, especially in underserved regions.

title: Developing a Graphical User Interface for linking the Backscattering Sensor (BB3) to acquire real-time data
authors: K. Martin Sagayam, S. Dhanasekar, D. Narain Ponraj, Tony Jose, Ahmed Hammad, Aghiad Khedr Suleiman
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Backscattering sensor BB3 is an essential device to measure the spectral reflection, attenuation, and illumination conditions in seawater. The device is equipped with an optical sensor for sensing the conditions. This paper presents a method for measuring the backscattered light from a BB3 sensor at three different wavelengths: 630 nm (red), 488 nm (blue), and 532 nm (green). Designing a Graphical User Interface is a description of the actions that a device can perform. Interfaces are even more conceptual than abstract classes. The designed interface is updated such that the system time is synchronized with the sensor time. This is to identify the time lag between the scatterings at different depths. The experiment shows prominent results from the proposed method in terms of performance metrics.

title: An Efficient Design of Serial ORBGRAND Decoder
authors: Sheng Lei, Zhanhua Liang, Jing Tian, Yangcan Zhou
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Since its introduction, guessing random additive noise decoding (GRAND) has received extensive attention due to its simplicity, high parallelism, and good decoding performance. Among the different decoder architectures, the serial architecture demonstrates significant advantage in power consumption. However, there remains substantial potential for reducing decoding latency. Thus, an improved serial ordered reliability bits GRAND (ORBGRAND) decoder with low latency is proposed in this work. Apart from the parity constraint of Hamming weight (HW) which is considered to reduce the error pattern (EP) query times, two improvement measures are further proposed: 1) The serial sorter is optimized to further reduce the latency and area overhead; 2) High-frequency EPs storage module is added for lower latency with slight overhead increase. Implementation results for a (128, 104) cyclic-redundancy-check (CRC) code and a (128, 106) extended Bose-Chaudhuri-Hocquenghem (eBCH) code indicate that the proposed decoder achieves a throughput of 27.7 Gbps with 264.5% growth compared with state-of-the-art serial ORBGRAND decoder. The area efficiency is 115.4 Gbps/mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and is improved by 123.6%.

title: Data Center Developments for Flexible Generation Dispatch, Advanced Infrastructure, and Ultra-Fast Digital Twins
authors: Grant M. Fischer, Rosemary E. Alden, Donovin D. Lewis, Aron Patrick, Dan M. Ionel
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The rapid advancement and widespread integration of artificial intelligence (AI) is driving demand for unprecedented deployment of power-intensive computational infrastructure, including multi-megawatt data centers with the potential for facilities with gigawatt-scale capacity in the near future. In this paper, load growth projections for the US are reviewed, and an example energy dispatch solution considering a mixed energy portfolio with flexible, renewable, distributed, and load-based generation is employed. The brief technology review included in the paper covers aspects of electric power, cooling, and computational infrastructures. The concept of a data center digital twin for transient load, grid interaction, and hybrid energy dispatch studies is described and proposed for implementation using a power hardware-in-the-loop test bench. For the transients associated with the typical data center loads, a generative adversarial neural (GAN) model is proposed and employed to synthetically produce GPU load profiles at the rack level, which are aggregated to emulate large-scale data center behavior.

title: Renewable Energy Investments in Rural Areas: Socio-Economic Impacts, Governance, and Migration Dynamics
authors: Murat Akil, Hafize Nurgul Durmus Senyapar, Ramazan Bayindir
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Renewable energy investments in rural areas extend far beyond environmental or technical outcomes, generating transformative socio-economic impacts. This study examines the impact of renewable energy initiatives on rural development, livelihoods, and migration dynamics, employing a qualitative exploratory design and document analysis, supported by MAXQDA-based thematic coding. Drawing on peer-reviewed literature, international development reports, and policy documents, the analysis identifies five critical impact domains: economic development and income gains, gender and social inclusion, rural attractiveness and migration dynamics, land use and equity risks, and institutional design for local value creation. Evidence from Africa, Latin America, and Europe illustrates that decentralized solar mini-grids and community wind projects can quadruple household incomes, stimulate small business growth, and empower women entrepreneurs, while also reducing outmigration when implemented inclusively. Conversely, poorly governed large-scale projects-such as the Lake Turkana wind initiative-have triggered displacement, “green grabbing,” and community resistance. The findings emphasize that governance models, participatory planning, and fair benefit-sharing are decisive in shaping whether renewable energy stabilizes rural populations or exacerbates inequalities. To achieve just and resilient rural futures, integrated policy frameworks must link energy justice, migration-sensitive strategies, and local ownership. By positioning renewable energy as a catalyst for rural transformation, this study provides actionable insights for policymakers, practitioners, and researchers engaged in sustainable energy transitions.

title: Lightweight Cryptographic Protocol for Secure Microtransactions in Mobile Applications
authors: Tushita Agarwal, Ali Q Saeed, Taher M. Ghazal
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: In mobile FinTech applications, secure microtransactions are crucial for safeguarding user privacy and fostering trust in low-value, high-frequency digital payments. Traditional cryptographic mechanisms often impose computational burdens on mobile and IoT devices, limiting scalability and real-time efficiency. Existing methods, such as RSA or TLS, suffer from large key sizes, high latency, and energy consumption, making them unsuitable for lightweight financial operations in constrained environments. To address these challenges, this study proposes a Lightweight Cryptographic Protocol based on the Elliptic Curve Integrated Encryption Scheme (ECIES) combined with a Hash-Based Message Authentication Code (HMAC). ECIES enables efficient asymmetric encryption using compact key structures, while HMAC ensures data integrity and authentication with minimal processing overhead. Together, the ECIES-HMAC framework secures microtransactions by encrypting payment data and verifying message authenticity, all while maintaining optimal performance. This protocol is deployed in mobile FinTech platforms to protect peer-to-peer payments, QR-based transfers, and digital wallet operations. It supports real-time transaction processing with strong resistance to replay, spoofing, and man-in-the-middle attacks. Performance evaluations show a 45% reduction in cryptographic latency and 30% lower energy usage compared to legacy.

title: Understanding Students’ Behavioral Intention to Use AI-Powered E-Learning Platforms Based on the Theory of Planned Behavior
authors: Fadhia Nova Adelia, Ono Supriadi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: AI-powered e-learning platforms are increasingly used by university students, however, their adoption rate depends not only on access to technology, but also on users' psychological readiness. Amid the acceleration of digitalization of education in Indonesia, it is important to comprehend aspects that impact students' decisions to use these kinds of platforms. This study examines students' behavioral intention by advancing the theory of planned behavior framework through two external constructs, namely e-learning AI literacy and AI e-learning exposure. A total of 280 students were selected using purposive sampling, and SmartPLS version 4 software with the Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM) approach was employed for data analysis. The findings reveal that e-learning AI literacy and AI e-learning exposure have a substantial impact on attitude toward behavior, subjective norms, and perceived behavioral control, all of which affect students' behavioral intentions directly and indirectly. The finding highlights the necessity of enhancing students' understanding and direct experience as part of a digital education strategy. This finding shows that students' good understanding and first-hand experience of the platform are key factors that encourage conscious and engaged use.

title: Unraveling the Efficacy of Machine Learning: A Critical Analysis of Contemporary Performance Trends and Their Applications Across Diverse Fields
authors: Meenakshi, Poonam Sharma, Gulbir Singh, Kiran Dhiman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Effectiveness and applicability across various domains become essential and crucial for the evaluation of machine learning algorithms. Contemporary performance trends lay more emphasis on data-driven decision-making backed by advancements in computational capabilities and the exponential growth of data availability. In recent studies more emphasis is placed on methodological rigor while evaluating performance evaluation by applying metrices as precision, recall, Fl-scare, accuracy to assess algorithmic performance in real-world applications. This review studies important machine learning methodologies- supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement learning and see their impact on fields as healthcare, finance, education and robotics. Besides, this paper sheds light on challenges connected with computational efficiency, ethical considerations and scalability. The findings emphasize the transformative potential of machine learning along with laying stress on robust evaluation frameworks in societal benefits. Automatic learning algorithms are mainly divided into three main types: Supervised learning, non-Supervised learning and reinforcement Learning.

title: Financial Bot Attack Detection In Trading Platforms Using Transformer-Based Sequence Classification(T-BERT)
authors: G.B.Santhi, Sarvaree Bano, Montader M. Hasan, Nagaraju Krishna Chythanya, S. Gopinath
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Financial platforms have grown exposed to advanced bot assaults as algorithmic trading has become more common. Finding these bots using the procedures is challenging since they can mimic real trading activity while affecting the market and generating data breaches. This paper describes a Transformer-based sequence classification model called T-BERT. This model aims to spot fraudulent trading activity when examining data about trades occurring over time. A fine-tuned BERT model trained on labeled datasets, including individuals and bot activity, processes trade events. The result implies tokenization and temporal embedding augmentation of the trading events. Through contextual learning, T-BERT can detect behavioral patterns not immediately clear throughout the experience. T-BERT maintains a low false-positive rate and achieves a detection accuracy of 96.3% compared to the performance of traditional machine learning models. They represent a notable advancement in the performance of machines. Furthermore, the attention methods of the model improve the data’s interpretability by highlighting possibly fraudulent transaction sequences and simplifying the process of understanding bot behavior. The research results indicate that transformer-based designs successfully spot bot-driven financial threats. The T-BERT solution aims to improve the integrity and security of real-time trading platforms by offering a solution that is additionally scalable and interpretable.

title: Dynamic Load Balancing in Cloud Computing Using Improved Firefly Optimization Algorithm (IFOA)
authors: Srikanth Yerra, Middae Vijaya Lakshmi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Load balancing is critical for efficient task scheduling and resource utilization in cloud computing environments. Traditional load balancing strategies often struggle with dynamic workloads and heterogeneous environments. With the change in technology and inclusion of various automated tools, this task has become increasingly complex due to dynamic resource demands and the proliferation of automation tools. This paper presents an improved Firefly Optimization Algorithm (IFOA) that dynamically balances cloud workloads by simulating the natural flashing behavior of fireflies. The IFOA incorporates adaptive parameters and a multi-metric fitness function considering makespan, load deviation, and throughput. Experimental results demonstrate that IFOA outperforms traditional algorithms such as Round Robin, GA, PSO, and ACO in terms of faster convergence, lower makespan, and improved throughput.

title: Automating Project Management Systems with Hybrid AI: Leveraging Deep Learning and Graph Analytics for Resource Optimization
authors: Rakibul Islam, Md Anwar Hosen, Md Borhan Uddin, Saima Tasnim, Sabrina Shamim Moushi, Suny Md Ashraf Khan, Khandakar Rabbi Ahmed
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Innovation in project management requires advanced analysis techniques that can model multiple unrelated project attributes and their interdependencies. Traditional project management techniques cannot represent the nonlinear interactions among attributes and relational project attributes within portfolios. In this work, we discuss HPGNet, a novel hybrid artificial intelligence system comprising Multilayer Perceptron MLP and Graph Convolutional Network GCN for learning high-dimensional tabular project information and graph-structured relational information in parallel. Using an openly available dataset of IT and construction projects, HPGNet constructs similarity graphs to capture relationships between projects and integrates them with dense feature embeddings to accurately predict multi-class risks and optimally allocate resources. Our approach outperforms single-modality baselines by a landslide, achieving 98.83% accuracy and a Macro-F1 of 0.988. We also utilize interpretability techniques such as SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) and permutation importance to provide crystal-clear insight into model decisions, thereby instilling trust amongst stakeholders. The hybrid approach is a reliable system for project management automation that supports data-driven, adaptive resource optimization and risk management.

title: Multimodal NLP for Embedded Psychological Text Analysis
authors: Nima Esmi, Fatemeh Borhani, Maryam NezhadMoghaddam, Mina Mohammadi Parsa, Asadollah Shahbahrami, Georgi Gaydadjiev
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: Accurate psychological text analysis on embedded devices is essential for privacy-preserving mental health monitoring; however, deploying transformer-based models in such constrained environments remains challenging due to limited memory, computational power, and energy budgets. We present a multimodal framework that integrates a lightweight Transformer (DistilBERT) with a CNN-based image branch (ResNet-50) accelerated by the Hailo-8L edge AI board. Text inputs are processed both as sequences and as two-dimensional image-like representations, enabling robust handling of noisy, informal text containing emojis and misspellings. Evaluations on the Depression Twitter dataset and the SST-2 benchmark demonstrate that the fusion model consistently outperforms text-only and image-only baselines, achieving up to 91.6% accuracy while remaining feasible for deployment on a Raspberry Pi 5. Overall, the proposed design offers a practical balance between efficiency and accuracy, enabling real-world, privacy-aware psychological monitoring directly on personal embedded devices.

title: Solar Tracking Fresnel CSP - PV Hybrid System
authors: Evren Meltem Toygar, Tufan Bayram, Berke Can Uğuroğlu, Mert Ali Becerikçi, Beren Şahutoğlu
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The Solar Tracking Fresnel CSP-PV Hybrid System based on concentrated solar power (CSP) technology was designed, and a small-scale model was fabricated. The system was developed to enhance efficiency and reduce the return-oninvestment period by delivering cost-effective performance. A key innovation is its ability to dynamically adjust the ratio of thermal and electrical energy output in response to real-time user demand. This enables flexible energy allocation, thereby improving the system’s efficiency and adaptability across different operating conditions. The system design was carried out using SolidWorks, and mechanical analyses were performed in ANSYS. To verify the system’s operability, a 1:10 scale prototype was produced using 3D printing technology and PLA filament, providing a rapid, costeffective means of producing complex geometries.

title: Developing a Predictive Model for Oncology Patient Drop-off in Treatment Pathways
authors: Hemanth Dandu
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: The discontinuation of patients in oncology treatment is a critical issue impacting clinical outcome and the use of healthcare resources. This study offers an integrated predictive model to model patients with high risk for treatment discontinuation through machine learning techniques. The research considered a sample of 7,500 oncology patients based on 15 clinical and socioeconomic factors. Highest predictive accuracy was obtained by Support Vector Machine at 97.0% (precision: 96.8%, recall: 97.2%, F1-score: 97.0%), and then by K-Nearest Neighbors at 96.6% (precision: 96.2%, recall: 96.9%, F1-score: 96.5%). Feature importance analysis revealed insurance status as the most influential predictor (24% contribution), followed by income level (19%), and hospital distance $(16 \%)$. Poorly insured patients were 3.2 times more likely to discontinue treatment (OR=3.2, 95% CI: 2.8-3.7). This predictive model allows for pre-emptive intervention strategies in order to limit patient attrition and enhance treatment outcomes.

title: AI-Powered IT Governance and Compliance: A Hybrid Model for Ensuring Security and Regulatory Adherence
authors: Md Farhad Kabir, Sharmin Sultana, Arafat Rohan, Mir Araf Hossain Rivin, Areyfin Mohammed Yoshi, Khandakar Rabbi Ahmed
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper suggests a novel AI-based hybrid model based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for risk identification and regulatory compliance in order to address the growing problems of IT governance and compliance. Spatial and temporal feature learning are used in model training based on the UNSWNB15 dataset to achieve the best classification accuracy in identifying patterns of non-compliance behavior and cyberattacks. With a classification accuracy of 99% and an AUC of 0.95, the engineered hybrid solution's improved performance is confirmed by comparative performance evaluation utilizing baseline CNN, LSTM, and RF models. Additionally, the model validates the performance problems that result from dealing with class imbalance and offers suggestions to guarantee that AI systems are developed in a compliance-friendly setting. The results demonstrate how well AI-based models work to enable automated monitoring and decision-making for enterprise IT governance systems in realtime. This study improves regulatory risk assessment in dynamic IT environments in a scalable and interpretable way.

title: IoT and AI-Enhanced Autonomous Fire-Fighting Robot with Real-Time Hazard Monitoring
authors: Akila P, S. Ravindran, S.Shunmuga Sundaram, Faiz Mohammad Karobari, Kavitha E, Mahesh K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Fire incidents pose severe threats to human life, property, and the environment, demanding rapid and efficient intervention. Traditional firefighting methods expose personnel to extreme hazards, including high temperatures, toxic gases, and structural collapses. This paper presents an IoT and AI-enhanced autonomous fire-fighting robot, designed to detect, navigate, and extinguish fires with minimal human involvement. The proposed system integrates flame, temperature, and gas sensors with an Arduino-based control unit and an AI-assisted flame classification model to minimize false alarms. Real-time environmental data is transmitted via IoT to a remote monitoring station, enabling both autonomous and manual override modes. The navigation system employs ultrasonic sensors and obstacle avoidance algorithms, while the fire suppression mechanism uses a servo-controlled water or CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-based extinguisher. Experimental results demonstrate a detection accuracy of 96.5% and a fire extinguishing time under 25 seconds in controlled environments. The proposed solution significantly enhances firefighting efficiency, reduces human risk, and offers scalable applications for industrial, commercial, and residential safety systems.

title: Line-of-Sight Probability Through Trees for LEO Satellites Terrestrial Network Communications
authors: Jiachi Zhang, Dongmei Liu, Yifan Wang, Jianan Jiang, Liu Liu
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite networks provide global coverage with reduced latency, emerging as a promising complementary solution to ensure seamless connectivity world-wide. The recent development of direct-to-satellite smartphone connectivity through 5G Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTN) demonstrates particularly significant potential. This paper proposes a novel Monte Carlo method for calculating vegetation-induced blockage probability in satellite-to-ground line-of-sight (LoS) links. First, we present a physical tree modeling approach based on fractal geometry theory, capable of simulating diverse vegetation structures through parameter adjustments including recursion depth, branching ratio, and angle. We then develop an innovative computational framework that evaluates LoS probability by establishing Monte Carlo links with randomized angles through the tree models and analyzing their blockage status. The proposed method statistically determines LoS probability by quantifying unblocked links. Comprehensive simulations assess the impact of various tree parameters, demonstrating that increased recursion depth and branching angles substantially degrade LoS probability.

title: Addressing Fundamental Knowledge Gaps in Underground Hydrogen Storage
authors: Eleonora Parente, Steffen Berg, Evren Unsal
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Global energy scenarios have been progressively shifting toward renewable sources, driven by climate goals and policy mandates. However, the intermittent nature of renewables, such as solar and wind, necessitates scalable and flexible energy storage solutions. Green hydrogen has emerged as a promising carbon-neutral energy carrier, that can be used as a substitute vector in those sectors where electrification cannot yet succeed, such as hard-to-abate sectors and long-term large-scale energy storage applications. Underground Hydrogen Storage, UHS, in saline aquifers is considered a viable pathway to storing large volumes of hydrogen, enabling seasonal and backup energy supply, and creating necessary buffer for wider utilization of renewables worldwide. Reservoir simulation is used to assess the feasibility and optimization of such geological storage systems. Key input data includes petrophysical properties such as porosity and permeability but as relative permeability saturation functions. Due to the scarcity and inconsistency of hydrogen-specific data in the literature, this study proposed a new consistent and repeatable procedure for obtaining relative permeability. The key question addressed is whether hydrogen relative permeability is similar as other gases like nitrogen and methane where more data is readily available for relevant rock types. The novel protocol is tested across these gases, combining $\mu \mathrm{CT}$ imaging and pore-scale flow simulations to derive relative permeability curves over a broader saturation range, providing a final comparison between the obtained results. The comparative findings support the hypothesis of similar behavior between the different gases, justifying the use of model gases for early-stage UHS design, ultimately facilitating the development of such technology and the integration of hydrogen into renewable energy sy stems.

title: Application Of Advanced Data Analysis In Government Tourism Marketing Activities: Strategy Optimization and Effect Evaluation
authors: Jie Yu, Chongwen Ma
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: In recent years, local governments have continuously invested in local tourism marketing, but failed to achieve the desired effect, and problems frequently occur, so there is a need for a marketing plan optimization and effect evaluation method to promote the development of tourism economy in various places. The purpose of this paper is to optimize the application of government tourism through advanced data analysis technology and marketing solutions, so as to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of government tourism marketing activities. First, this paper uses big data analysis methods in advanced data analysis to identify important influencing factors such as advertising volume, social media engagement, and weather conditions. Then, this paper uses the local resource government to optimize the allocation of advertising resources, and uses relevant algorithms to find the optimal combination of marketing solutions. Subsequently, the data results are obtained from the case application. The results show that after optimization, the government in this study has led to a significant increase in the number of tourists in Scenic Area B, with a growth rate of up to 25%, and at the same time, a 4.67-fold increase in the return on investment of the government's tourism marketing activities. Therefore, this shows that scientific advanced data analysis and marketing solutions can greatly improve the effectiveness of government tourism marketing activities. Based on this, this method has the potential to be promoted and applied in other cities, and can help many local government departments to improve the overall efficiency of their tourism industry.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning-Based on Energy Management of a Hydrogen Power Supply System for an H-bike
authors: Mamoru Otsuka, Masami Sumita, Koki Harano, Tomoya Ezawa, Noboru Katayama, Kiyoshi Dowaki
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The practical application of fuel cell-powered electric assist bicycles using metal hydride requires optimization of power distribution in hybrid power sources combining fuel cell and lithium-ion batteries (LiB). In this study, deep reinforcement learning (DRL) was used to control hydrogen flow and LiB state of charge (SoC), aiming to achieve both flow stabilization and suppression of SoC fluctuations. As a result, we successfully reduced hydrogen flow fluctuations by $2.1 \%$ and suppressed SoC variation by $46.6 \%$. This improved power allocation stability and confirmed enhanced control performance compared to conventional PI control. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of deep reinforcement learning in fuel cell hybrid power systems.

title: Ensuring Greenhouse Security Using AES Encryption
authors: Kiran V, Karthik Sriram, Gagandeep S Cholaki, Gaurav R, K S Sudip Aniruddh, Nithin Mammen Joy
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents a secure and energy efficient IoT-based greenhouse monitoring system which emphasizes affordable and clean energy. The proposed framework employs an ESP32 microcontroller interfaced with environmental sensors to monitor temperature, humidity, and soil moisture in real time. Data transmission is enabled through LoRa (Long Range) communication to ensure low-power, long-distance connectivity. To address security concerns in remote deployments, AES-128, a 128-bit encryption which is implemented for secure data transfer across the network. Real-time monitoring and control are facilitated via the Blynk cloud interface, accessible through mobile devices. Experimental results demonstrate the system's effectiveness in providing secure, scalable, and energy sustainable automation for remote greenhouse applications. The LoRa modules provided reliable communication over a distance of 450 meters (LOS), and the AES-128 encryption introduced a negligible overhead of 2.5 ms per transmission, with zero packet loss or breach attempts observed during continuous operation.

title: A Fault Tolerant Model Predictive Control with SelfAdaption for the Three-phase T-Type Inverter
authors: Joaquim Monteiro, J. Fernando Silva, Sónia Pinto, V. Fernão Pires
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Multilevel inverters with three-level T-Type topology are widely recognized as a highly recommended solution for applications that require reliability and fault tolerance. However, achieving a fault tolerant operation system typically requires the implementation of fault detection algorithms along with modulator or control system. This paper proposes a different approach by introducing a self-adaptive control system designed to ensure fault-tolerant operation under open-switch fault conditions. The proposed control system is based on Model Predictive Control (MPC). The proposed controller intrinsically detects deviations from the desired setpoint and automatically cancels the usage of the faulty voltage vectors. Furthermore, the proposed control ensures capacitor voltage balancing, even under fault-tolerant conditions. The effectiveness of the proposed faulttolerant MPC method is demonstrated through several simulation tests. The results obtained confirm the validity and feasibility of the proposed approach.

title: Evaluating Phi-4: A Benchmark Against Small Language Models in Education
authors: Stephane Maillard
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Recent years have seen a transformational educational environment due to the growing usage of artificial intelligence. It has evolved from a technological niche to a revolutionary solution that redefines teaching, learning and assessment. The motivation of this paper is to explore the capacities of small language models, which lack sufficient research in educational contexts, especially Phi-4. The main contribution of this study is to offer a benchmark of Phi-4 alongside a range of both small and large language models, such as Mistral, Falcon, Qwen and DeepSeek, across various school subjects. The goal is to evaluate differences in performance, adaptability, and potential integration into educational environments. In the pursuit of developing a comprehensive benchmark for Phi-4 in education, the methodology is characterized by the building of a custom dataset with question and answer pairs covering different subjects to allow an evaluation of different small and large language models. When evaluating the models with a ROUGE score for all subjects combined, it shows that Phi- 3.5 -mini-instruct leads in recall for ROUGE-1 and ROUGE-L and Falcon-7b-instruct shows the best score regarding the precision and F1 score across both ROUGE-1 and ROUGE-L as well as speed. Phi-4-mini-instruct reaches the second best score for all metrics except precision and F1 score for ROUGE-L where it ended in third place. Regarding the evaluation per subject, Falcon-7b-instruct gets the best scores for geography, medical and science. Phi-3-medium-128k-instruct gets the best score for math. Despite some limitations in the size of the custom dataset and number of subjects evaluated, this study can provide educators, researchers, and policymakers with insights into the strengths and limitations of emerging AI technologies. It can also lay the groundwork for a more inclusive understanding of AI in education, since the AI revolution will reshape how knowledge is communicated and acquired in the coming years.

title: Research on the Application and Influence of Artificial Intelligence in Digital Printing Technology : and Discuss the Sustainable Development Ideas of Digital Printing Technology
authors: Xiaoxi Zhao
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: As the fashion industry evolves, digital printing technology requires greater diversification and personalization. Traditional garment pattern design processes are time-consuming and fail to adapt to dynamic market demands. This study employs artificial intelligence (AI), particularly Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), to enhance design efficiency and quality. We propose an AI-driven system integrating pattern generation, optimization, and user feedback modules. A case study demonstrates the system’s ability to produce diverse patterns (e.g., floral, geometric motifs) and refine designs through user interaction. Results show 97% satisfaction for optimized patterns and a projected 22% sales growth, underscoring AI’s capacity to improve market competitiveness. The research highlights AI’s role in streamlining digital printing workflows, enhancing user satisfaction, and bridging creativity with industrial scalability. These findings offer actionable insights for integrating AI into textile technology, advancing innovation in fashion design.

title: A Hybrid Transformer – Classifier Technique for Guitar Play Recognition
authors: N Aishwarya, P Devisowjanya, Ajay K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Automatic identification of guitar-playing technique is important for music analysis, identification of performers, and interactive learning. This paper presents a hybrid Transformer-classifier model that utilizes sophisticated spectrogram-based feature extraction techniques to improve classification accuracy. Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT), Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC), Constant-Q Transform (CQT), Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT), and Gammatone spectrograms are used in order to extract the fine-grained frequency and time-domain features of the guitar sound. These spectrograms are processed through Vision Transformers (ViTs) and Swin Transformers, which extract spatial and temporal features in an efficient manner. These extracted features are subsequently classified through ML classifiers. The experimental demonstrates that the MFCC delivers the highest classification accuracy when coupled with Vision Transformer and Swin Transformer. More precisely, with SVM and MLP classifiers, both models record an accuracy of 97 %. In the case of Linear SVM, Vision Transformer outperforms marginally with a 98 % accuracy, and Swin Transformer records 97 %. These findings highlight the high performance of hybrid Transformer-classifier models in guitar technique recognition without compromising computational efficiency.

title: Expression of Concern for: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) Detection from Facial Images using MobileNet
authors: Shubham Dodia, Vidula Meshram, Janai Kasle, Shrirang Gomase, Harshal Amrit, Renuka Sarse
publish: 2024 IEEE 9th International Conference for Convergence in Technology (I2CT)
abstract: A developmental disability linked to brain development, autism spectrum disorder (ASD) results in difficulties with behavior, socialization, and communication. Children with autism exhibit significant morphological alterations to their faces that distinguish them from normally developing (TD) children. Our aim is to assist psychiatrists by identifying children with ASD at an early age, which will lessen their symptoms and enhance their cognitive functioning. In this research study, we deploy a neural network-based binary classifier on a pre-trained model of MobileNet to a publically available data set named Autism_Image_Data that we obtained from Kaggle to present a functional model using a facial imaging for autism detection. The dataset contains 2540 training images with 300 test images. This model achieves an accuracy of 89.58% on the dataset that was trained using pre-trained MobileNet architecture model through transfer learning.

title: Dynamic Source-Aware Transfer Learning for Vehicular Platoon Predictive Control
authors: Yanhong Wu, Zhiqiang Zuo, Yijing Wang, Defeng He, Ji Li, Quan Zhou, Hongming Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The allocation of computational resources in the vehicular platoon is susceptible to communication topology, particularly under complex scenarios, such as off-ramps. This article proposes a dynamic source-aware transferable data-driven control (DSTDC) strategy to optimize computing resource allocation under the off-ramps scenario. A data-driven predictor is established to characterize the powertrain structure of vehicular platoon. To improve the computational efficiency of platoon control algorithm, a transfer learning method is constructed. Specifically, the knowledge of vehicle in the source domain is transferred to vehicles in the target domain, and the latter just should update the knowledge in terms of the individual dynamic characteristics and tasks. Furthermore, an adaptive domain switching mechanism is developed to address the issue of source domain vehicle departure in the off-ramps scenario. Here, the source domain vehicle will be subject to reevaluation in terms of the computing performance, data accumulation and driving stability. Finally, a platoon experiment platform is conducted, and the results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed DSTDC strategy.

title: On the Fixed-Length-Burst Levenshtein Ball with Unit Radius
authors: Yuanxiao Xi, Yubo Sun, Gennian Ge
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Theory
abstract: Consider a length-n sequence x over a q-ary alphabet. The fixed-length Levenshtein ball Lt(x) of radius t contains all length-n q-ary sequences that can be derived from x by performing t deletions followed by t insertions. Recent studies have successfully characterized fixed-length Levenshtein balls in the context of radius t = 1. These works have derived explicit formulas for various quantities, including the exact size of the balls, extremal bounds (minimum and maximum sizes), as well as expected sizes and their concentration properties. However, the general case involving an arbitrary number of t deletions and t insertions (t > 1) remains largely uninvestigated. This work systematically examines fixed-length Levenshtein balls with multiple deletions and insertions, focusing specifically on fixed-length burst Levenshtein balls, where deletions occur consecutively, as do insertions. We provide solutions for explicit cardinality formulas, extremal bounds (minimum and maximum sizes), expected size, and concentration properties surrounding the expected value.

title: Beyond Vital Signs: Emotion-Aware Remote Patient Monitoring
authors: Mai Ali, Bilal Taha, Dimitrios Hatzinakos, Deepa Kundur
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Remote Patient Monitoring systems (RPMs) are becoming increasingly important as the aging population struggles to manage chronic illnesses and secure consistent healthcare access. While these systems excel in tracking physical metrics, integrating emotion recognition can bridge the often-overlooked connection between emotional and physical well-being. By identifying emotional responses such as discomfort, distress, or contentment, RPM systems can provide immediate feedback for care adjustments and reveal long-term trends. Subtle shifts in emotional patterns may act as early indicators of mental health conditions linked to chronic diseases or transient emotional stress. Expanding RPMs to include emotion awareness makes care more adaptive and holistic. This review explores how emotion recognition can enhance RPM systems by addressing both physical and emotional health. It examines methods that leverage physiological and behavioral responses to capture emotional states, assessing the advantages, limitations, and applicability of these modalities in RPM settings. By incorporating emotion-aware tools, RPMs have the potential to deliver more comprehensive, responsive, and personalized care, revolutionizing healthcare delivery for diverse patient groups.

title: Double-Layer Coordinated Yaw Control for Offshore Wind Farm Considering Dynamic Wind Direction
authors: Yang Fu, Shijing Yang, Lirong Deng, Yang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy
abstract: To mitigate the impact of frequent wind fluctuations on power generation and fatigue loads in offshore wind farms, this study proposes a double-layer coordinated yaw control strategy that explicitly considers dynamic wind direction. The strategy features a hierarchical framework: the upper field-level control, executed centrally, maximizes total farm power generation by employing gradient descent combined with serial refinement to determine optimal yaw angles for various wind conditions. A novel Gaussian-Curl Energy-Conserving model is constructed to address strongly asymmetric wake interactions in large-scale wind farms. The lower unit-level control applies model predictive control over a continuous time horizon to track these field-level yaw references, featuring the dual objectives of minimizing tracking error and mitigating fatigue loads. Furthermore, a disturbance observer is incorporated for real-time compensation of systematic measurement errors. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed control framework significantly enhances the wind farm power generation and reduces fatigue loads under stochastic wind environments, which exhibit strong applicability for large-scale offshore wind farm operations.

title: Exploring 3D Unsteady Flow Using 6D Observer Space Interactions_supp2-3642506.mp4
authors: Xingdi Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Visualizing and analyzing 3D unsteady flow fields is a very challenging task. We approach this problem by leveraging the mathematical foundations of 3D observer fields to explore and analyze 3D flows in reference frames that are more suitable to visual analysis than the input reference frame. We design novel interactive tools for determining, filtering, and combining reference frames for observer-aware 3D unsteady flow visualization. We represent the space of reference frame motions in a 3D spatial domain via a 6Dparameter space, in which every observer is a time-dependent curve. Our framework supports operations in this 6D observer space by separately focusing on two 3D subspaces, for 3D translations, and 3D rotations, respectively. We show that this approach facilitates a variety of interactions with 3D flow fields. Building on the interactive selection of observers, we furthermore introduce novel techniques such as observer-aware streamline- and pathline-filtering as well as observer-aware iso surface animations of scalar fluid properties for the enhanced visualization and analysis of 3D unsteady flows. We discuss the theoretical underpinnings as well as practical implementation considerations of our approach, and demonstrate the benefits of its 6+1D observer-based methodology on several 3D unsteady flow datasets.

title: Exploring KV Cache Quantization in Multimodal Large Language Model Inference
authors: Hyesung Ahn, Ranggi Hwang, Minsoo Rhu
publish: IEEE Computer Architecture Letters
abstract: Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) have demonstrated strong performance across modalities, such as image, video, and audio understanding, by leveraging large language models (LLMs) as a backbone. However, a critical challenge in MLLM inference is the large memory capacity required for the key–value (KV) cache, particularly when processing high-resolution images. This pressure often forces heterogeneous CPU–GPU systems to offload the KV cache to CPU memory, introducing substantial transfer latency. KV cache quantization is a promising way to reduce this memory demand, yet it remains underexplored for MLLM inference. In this work, we characterize MLLM inference and present a text-centric KV cache quantization method that retains only 10% of tokens in high precision while quantizing the rest. Our method reduces Time-To-First-Token (TTFT) by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.7\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> and Time-Per-Output-Token (TPOT) by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4.3\times$</tex-math></inline-formula>, with negligible accuracy loss.

title: Jamming Scheduling and Resource Allocation for Secure Communication in Massive LEO Satellite-Empowered IoT Network
authors: Yongpeng Shi, Qian Luo, Shubin Zhang, Jiadai Wang, Jiajia Liu
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: The massive low earth orbit (LEO) satellite-empowered Internet of Things (MLS-IoT) network has many advantages including high capacity, low latency, large network coverage, and high reliability. However, the openness and broadcasting on satellite communication links pose huge challenges to protect the security of data delivery, especially to defend against eavesdropping. Leveraging the density of LEO satellite deployment and developing efficient secure communication schemes with the aid of physical layer security (PLS) technique deserve further exploration. To the best of our knowledge, it is an almost untouched issue to employ satellites to transmit jamming signal in MLS-IoT systems since lots of available researches in this line mainly considered cooperative jamming only on ground networks. For this purpose, we propose in this paper a PLS based secure communication enhancement scheme in MLS-IoT network. A jamming scheduling and resource allocation problem is presented for the secrecy rate maximization by dynamically switching the roles of satellites on sub-channels for transmitting private information or jamming signal. An iterative strategy is devised to jointly optimizing jamming scheduling, device association, channel assignment, and power allocation. Numerical results validate that our presented optimization approach could significantly improve the system secrecy rate and achieve the optimal jamming scheduling and resource allocation decisions.

title: DCSV-Krylov Exploration for Control Allocation in Multitime Scale Systems
authors: C. A. Peña Fernández
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
abstract: Control allocation is essential for managing MIMO dynamic systems, such as autonomous vehicles and robotics, which operate across varying temporal scales, posing challenges in optimizing control actions. A common approach involves traditional solvers for overdetermined systems---most notably the singular value decomposition (SVD), the least squares QR algorithm (LSQR), and Arnoldi-type methods---, which, while effective for homogeneous temporal scales, struggle to handle mixed dynamics. Their inability to explicitly account for temporal variations and uncertainties often results in suboptimal performance and high computational costs. To address these challenges, this work introduces a novel combination of the Dynamic Confined Space of Velocities (DCSV) method with Krylov subspace exploration, significantly enhancing control allocation in mixed-temporal-scale systems. The DCSV method generates optimized initial estimates, which are iteratively refined using Krylov methods, achieving precise control with reduced computational costs. Comparative analysis against traditional solvers demonstrates that DCSV consistently outperforms these methods, achieving higher accuracy with fewer computational resources, particularly in systems with mixed dynamic scales. Since LSQR is closely related to quadratic programming (QP) and linear programming (LP) through its cost function, and SVD directly computes generalized inverses, their evaluation provides a basis for comparison with conventional control allocation strategies. The proposed method surpasses these approaches by achieving a better balance between computational efficiency and control precision. In addition, the uncertainty principle embedded in the DCSV framework establishes theoretical limits that ensure robustness in the allocation process, supported by a structured sequential exploration process formulated via pseudocode. By optimizing initial estimates through DCSV, fewer refinement iterations are needed, leading to faster and more accurate control allocation, as confirmed by formal analysis. This methodology offers a robust and efficient solution to the challenges posed by mixed temporal scales, with enhanced adaptability for real-world applications in dynamic and computationally constrained environments.
