title: Analyzing the Impact of the Internet of Things on Clinical Psychology and Mental Health: A Systematic Review
authors: Marwan Ibrahim Salameh, Abdallah M. A. Al-Tarawneh, Loai Al Olimat, Reman Mi’Ari, Khadija Katbi, Suzan Almasoud, Nawwash Alanazi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This study aimed to analyze the impact of the Internet of Things (IoT) on clinical psychology and mental health. Studies published between 2022 and 2025 were reviewed from databases such as Scopus, Springer, Wiley, Elsevier, and Google Scholar. A total of 50 research papers were identified, from which 27 were selected based on specific inclusion/exclusion criteria. Researchers utilized Spider-Net, a PRISMA flowchart, and VOSviewer. The main findings indicated that human samples covered all segments of society, with the least representation among children and the elderly. Qualitative studies and review papers were more frequently used. The most cited studies focused on early diagnosis and psychological monitoring. Weaknesses included a lack of comparative studies and limited research on the use of digital programs in psychotherapy.

title: Expression of Concern for: Leveraging Convolutional Neural Networks for Precise Diagnosis of Autism Through Transfer Learning and Ensemble Model
authors: Pronab Sarker, Anirudh Atmakuru, Subrata Chakraborty, Manoranjan Paul, Prabal Datta Barua, Biswajeet Pradhan
publish: 2024 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Autism is a neurodevelopmental condition that can make social interaction and communication challenging. It is known for repetitive behaviors and difficulties in understanding nonverbal communication cues. The growing interest in autism, fueled by advances in global health expertise, has resulted in increased efforts to enable early detection and intervention. The fundamental purpose of early detection is to provide personalized behavioral development treatment programs, easing the integration of autistic people into the society. In this research, we investigate the efficacy of deep learning models for autism detection, by developing an ensemble of high-performing Convolutional Neural Network(CNN)-based models. We perform a comparative study of five deep learning models, Xception, InceptionV3, MobileNetV2, DenseNet201, ResNet50V2 to analyze images of autistic and non-autistic children. To enhance the predictive performance and robustness, we create an ensemble model combining the three top-performing deep learning models, achieving a state-of-the-art 91.7% accuracy. We further improve our performance to 93.33% by performing histogram equalization on the images. The use of automatic hyperparameter tuning has helped explore alternative model configurations effectively and resulted in a highly optimized CNN architecture for autism diagnosis in children. Our ensemble model achieved state-of-the-art results using a publicly available dataset, which includes 2 classes and comprises a total of 2940 images for training, validation, and testing. Our research showcases the immense potential of deep learning and ensemble model in advancing autism detection and early intervention.

title: Blockchain Driven Holistic Healthcare Systems for Secure Data Management
authors: Dipti Jaiswal, Abha Choubey, Manuraj Jaiswal, Siddhartha Choubey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: A blockchain-based method for managing private healthcare data prioritizes security, privacy, and accountability. The recommended framework protects patient data with strong user identity, role-based access control, and enhanced encryption. This addresses the essential requirement for healthcare data security. The review demonstrates that the system consistently outperforms competing healthcare data management choices in critical areas including data safety, accuracy, growth, and user satisfaction. The blockchain system's decentralized nature and cryptography prevent patient record changes. Real-time validation and data tracking are possible. This capacity helps secure electronic health records and develop confidence with users and partners. Legal compliance and cost effectiveness top the method's considerations. This makes it a viable alternative for contemporary healthcare companies with data management issues. Blockchain technology makes private healthcare data safer and more dependable, as well as the healthcare system more efficient and trustworthy. This study expands blockchain healthcare re-search. It illustrates how it may enhance patient outcomes in a digital healthcare system by changing data management.

title: Fault Diagnosis Method for Wireless Access Points in Substations Based on Graph Neural Network
authors: Wei Wang, Yanan Zhu, Zihao Zhang, Shitong Zhou, Yinsong Gao, Yao Yu
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Wireless Access Points (APs) in substations pose significant challenges for fault diagnosis due to their complex operating environments, multidimensional performance indicators, and dynamic signal characteristics. Substation networks typically adopt an Access Controller + APs architecture, where APs lack direct communication, resulting in no inherent topology for modeling inter-node relationships. To address these challenges, in this paper we propose a Random Forest-assisted Graph Learning Convolutional Neural Network (RF-GLCN) method. First, an initial correlation graph is constructed to reflect device operational states based on similarities between pre-diagnosis results and multidimensional performance indicators. Employing graph convolutions to aggregate features from each node and its neighbors. Additionally, a dynamic graph optimization mechanism adaptively evolves the graph structure based on node features and model feedback. The proposed method is evaluated on a simulated substation dataset, with experimental results demonstrating superior accuracy and reliability in fault diagnosis compared to baseline methods.

title: AutoML-Driven Architecture Optimization for Efficient and Scalable Neural Network Design
authors: Zainab Kadum Jabber, Tholfiqar Z. Ismail, Nigora Yokubova, Ibragimov Ulmas Rakhmanovich, Kakhramon Khakberdiev, Moniza Nurez Khan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: AutoML-Driven Architecture Optimization is an emerging approach that automates the design of neural networks to improve efficiency, accuracy, and scalability across a wide range of applications. By reducing manual intervention, it enables rapid deployment of optimized models suited for different computational environments. However, traditional architecture design methods often involve extensive trial and error, are time-consuming, and fail to adapt well to varying resource constraints, leading to inefficient and inflexible models. To overcome these limitations, this paper introduces a framework based on Reinforcement Learning-based Neural Architecture Search (RL-NAS), which explores and identifies optimal architectures through a reward-driven search process. The proposed RL-NAS method is applied to optimize neural networks for image classification tasks across both edge and cloud platforms, striking a balance between model accuracy, latency, and resource usage. The experimental evaluation shows that RL-NAS generates architectures that significantly outperform manually designed baselines in terms of performance and computational efficiency. Furthermore, the method demonstrates robust adaptability to diverse deployment scenarios, confirming its effectiveness in scalable neural network design.

title: Gesture Recognition Based on ZFNet with Integrated Attention Mechanism
authors: Congcong Wang, Baoquan Ge, Lanlan Chen, Yang Zuo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: With the rapid development of wireless sensing technology in intelligent interaction, gesture recognition based on Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) has become a research hotspot due to its non-contact nature and strong environmental adaptability. However, in fine-grained gesture classification tasks, existing methods often suffer from insufficient recognition accuracy and lack of lightweight design, which hinders real-time deployment. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a lightweight gesture recognition framework based on ZFNet with integrated channel attention. Specifically, the Markov Transition Field (MTF) is employed to map RFID phase sequences into two-dimensional feature images, thereby representing both local and global temporal patterns in a form suitable for convolutional processing. Furthermore, Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) modules are embedded into the intermediate convolutional blocks (Conv2-Conv4) of ZFNet to adaptively recalibrate channel responses, enhancing the representation of critical fine-grained features and improving discriminative ability. Finally, traditional fully connected layers are replaced with 1×1 convolutions combined with global average pooling, which significantly reduces parameter size and enhances generalization performance. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared with the original ZFNet, the proposed model reduces the number of parameters by approximately 93% while achieving an average recognition accuracy exceeding 97%. These findings indicate that the proposed framework effectively balances accuracy and efficiency, exhibits strong cross-scenario adaptability, and provides a feasible solution for deploying fine-grained gesture recognition in real-time interactive applications.

title: Unsupervised Learning Approaches for Online Purchase Prediction: A Performance Comparison
authors: Veena Parihar, Ayasha Malik, Sapna Juneja, Punit Gupta, Reshma R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: With the advent of growing usage of internet globally, the volume of data is also increasing with similar rate. This trend has also revolutionized the way of purchase of customers from visiting physical stores to online purchase. Now a days, the web is full of consumers' data which can reflect the online behaviour of consumers. Thus, such impactful methods are needed that can effectively identify the behavioural patterns out this online consumers' data. The prediction of buying behavioural patterns is essential for taking decisions for e-commerce businesses for improving the customer experience and for taking necessary actions to provide customized recommendations for improving the overall revenue. The online clickstream data can be analysed to predict purchase patterns of consumers in advance rather than analyzing the static data. This paper aims to present insight from online shopping data and selection of best machine learning algorithm among various applicable techniques. The techniques considered here are unsupervised machine learning techniques such as k-Means Clustering (KMC), mean shift, Hierarchical Agglomerative Clustering (HAC) etc. with the application of hyperparameter tuning for improved performance. A comparative analysis is presented for all the algorithms among which the KMC has provided better results for internal evaluation as well as external validation in comparison with others. Experimental outcomes present that the application of hyperparameter tuning has also improves the scores of all the techniques.

title: Adaptive Gamification Framework for Computer Science Education Using Machine Learning-Based Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment
authors: Sumit Ramswami Punam, Muntather Almusawi, M. Anjaneyulu, Jansirani D, R. Velmurugan, Ali Usama Al-Hayaly, Ahmed Sedeeq Baker
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The Science of Educational Computing struggles to support student motivation in the face of different previous knowledge, divergent learning rates and rigid instructional styles. Existing gamification methods, although strong in increasing motivation, cannot incorporate adaptive processes to adapt the learning paths into a student’s unique progress. Current adaptive learning systems depend highly dependent on predefined rules or simplistic student profiles and therefore struggle to dynamically adapt to the performance of the live student. This study proposes an adaptive gamification structure that uses machine learning algorithms to constantly assess student motivation, problem solving ability and learning trajectory. The main innovation is a dynamic dynamic adjustment model (DDA), based on Machine, based on reinforcement learning and predictive analysis. This model continually observes student interactions and performance standards to adapt adaptively the difficulty of the challenge and the difficulty of the task gamified to maximize cognitive stimulation. In contrast to static gamification methods, this adaptive system establishes a closed feedback loop, allowing personalized real -time learning. Experimental tests with undergraduate students in Computer Science have shown that adaptive structure increased by 31%engagement rates, retention of refined concept by 24%and increased accuracy of problem solving by 18%compared to non -adaptive approaches. Statistical significance (p <0.01) established the robustness of these findings. The AI adaptive gamification platform provides a scalable, personalized and student -centered learning environment, filling critical gaps in the teaching of conventional computer science. Outside the academy, this technology has the potential to apply to professional technical training, uppart corporate initiatives and on -line learning platforms, supporting intelligent educational ecosystems that continually adapt to student requirements.

title: Graph Contrastive Learning-based Heterogeneous Network Node Classification
authors: Yiling Zou, Jian Shu, Linlan Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Node classification in heterogeneous networks holds significant importance in fields such as recommendation systems and paper classification. However, existing methods overlook the information of intermediate nodes in meta-paths and fail to address the degree bias problem in networks. To solve the above problems, this paper proposes a heterogeneous network node classification method (GCL-NC) based on graph contrastive learning, which uses meta-path view and augmented view to obtain comprehensive and effective node embeddings. Specifically, in the meta-path view, the intermediate nodes of the meta-path are introduced as virtual nodes, the features of all nodes in the subgraph are reconstructed by averaging neighbor features, and then node features are learned by using an encoder. In the augmented view, different augmentation strategies are applied to low-degree nodes and high-degree nodes respectively; subsequently, the augmented view is fed into the encoder for feature learning. Finally, contrastive learning is performed on the embedding vectors of the two views, and a classifier is employed to complete the classification task. Experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms existing approaches.

title: AI-Based Security Engineering for Fintech and Regulated Industries
authors: Ilakiya Ulaganathan, FNU Antara, Santhosh Chitraju Gopal Varma, Zokir Mamadiyarov, Ziyadulla Turayev
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Fintech and other highly regulated sectors that face growing cyber threats, compounding compliance requirements and even faster digital change are now dependent on AI-based security engineering. The more basic enabling technologies, including machine learning algorithms, systems design, and automated compliance integration, are discussed in this review, and how AI can be used to detect threats, score risk, and react to incidents where false positives and latency are the key elements. It provides a comparison between classical and deep learning architecture, describing the architectures that adopt a mixture of CNNs, LSTMs, and other technologies to provide accuracy and robustness in intrusion detection. It proposes a novel multi-tier security model, which dwells upon the feedbackbased learning, regulation compliance, and adversarial resistance. The key research gaps such as explainable AI, federated learning in order to maintain privacy and policy-conscious response to threats are described. The article unites both theoretical and experimental results, along with the solutions to the technological and regulatory problems.

title: Novel Full Converter Topology for Variable Speed Wind Generators
authors: Taiga Yamaguchi, Kenta Koiwa, Kang-Zhi Liu
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel back-to-back converter and its control method for variable speed wind generators. The proposed system consists of active rectifiers, $\mathbf{Z}$-source, and gridconnected inverter. The adoption of an active rectifier enables current control of the generator, facilitating the use of a highefficiency generator, specifically an interior permanent magnet synchronous generator. The Z-source is resistant to short-circuit operation caused by switching element false turn-on, enabling an increase in the switching frequency of the inverter and allowing for a smaller DC link capacitor. Moreover, the Z-source provides two controllable voltages to the DC link, enabling them to be controlled separately in a shoot-through mode. It enables the power converter system to operate at maximum efficiency. The effectiveness of the proposed system is validated through simulations.

title: Multi-Voltage Performance Analysis and Quality Index Development for DC EV Charging Systems using Ripple Measurement
authors: K Jeykishan Kumar
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This study introduces a novel Charging Quality Performance Index (CQPI) for evaluating DC fast charging systems across multiple voltage levels (375V, 440V, 500V). Through experimental analysis of a 30kW electric vehicle supply equipment (EVSE), a weighted correlation was established between ripple characteristics and efficiency, developing voltage-specific coefficients for performance evaluation. The correlation analysis yielded distinct weight factors at each voltage level (375V: 0.9617/0.0383, 440V: 0.5672/0.4328, 500V: 0.9621/0.0379 for current ripple (CR)/voltage ripple (VR) respectively). The experimental results demonstrate optimal charging performance at moderate state of charge (SOC) levels with high load conditions, achieving a peak power conversion efficiency (PCE) of $96.3 \%$, and a $1 \%$ reduction in the current ripple corresponds to approximately $1.45 \%$ PCE improvement. This index provides a quantitative framework for evaluating and optimizing DC Charging system performance.

title: Machine Learning Techniques Based Risk Detection in Digital Banking and Investment Channels
authors: Rana T. Shwayyea, Ahmed Imran Fattah, Saif Saad Hameed, Wisam Ali Hasan, Ali Jaafar Dakhil, Saad Jader Mutlak
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Machine learning techniques have become crucial tools for enhancing risk detection in digital banking and investment channels, where vast amounts of transactional data flow daily. These technologies provide advanced capabilities for identifying suspicious activities, thereby enhancing security and fostering customer trust. However, existing methods often rely on static, rule-based systems that struggle to adapt to evolving fraud patterns and are limited by their dependence on labeled fraudulent data, which is typically scarce and limited in quantity. This paper proposes a framework titled Fraudulent Transaction Detection using Deep Learning (FTD-DL), which leverages an autoencoder-based deep learning approach to learn standard transaction patterns and detect anomalies without requiring explicit fraud labels. The FTD-DL framework addresses the limitations of existing methods by utilizing unsupervised learning to identify subtle, previously unseen fraudulent behaviors in real-time. The proposed method enhances fraud detection efficiency by calculating reconstruction errors for each transaction and flagging those with high deviation for further investigation or automated action. Findings from the implementation demonstrate improved detection of novel fraud patterns, reduced false positives, and scalable adaptability across different banking environments. This study highlights the potential of deep learning to revolutionize digital banking security, providing a robust and adaptive risk detection mechanism.

title: Analysis of Methods for Diagnosing Mechanical Fault of Power Transformer Winding
authors: Abdullaev Abduvokhid Abdugaffor Ugli, Khaqiqov Anvarbek Umidjon Ugli, Bakhodirov Islomjon Abdulaziz Ugli, Ibrokhimjonov Ahliddin Bakhtiyorjon Ugli
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Power transformers are important parts of electrical systems. If they fail, it can cause big problems. One common reason for failure is mechanical damage to the windings, often caused by short circuits or aging. Detecting such faults early is very important but not always easy. This paper compares different methods used to find these problems, including Frequency Response Analysis (FRA), Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA), Polarization-Depolarization Current (PDC), and ShortCircuit Impedance (SCI). Each method has its strengths and weaknesses. The study shows that using a combination of methods gives better results. FRA is good for finding winding deformation, DGA helps assess insulation condition, and SCI is fast but less sensitive. The paper explains that combining different techniques gives more accurate and reliable diagnosis. In the future, these methods could be connected to online systems for real-time monitoring of transformers.

title: Intelligent Drive-Based Optimization of Trajectory Tracking for the Deployment Mechanism of Fengyun Satellites
authors: Hongting Zhang, Yu Zhou, Zhiliang Yu, Qingping Huang, Yanfen Wang, Guiru Jing
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Systems (ICCS)
abstract: To address the trajectory tracking issues in deployment mechanism caused by external disturbances, an adaptive control strategy combining radial basis function (RBF) neural networks and sliding mode control (SMC) is proposed. Firstly, external disturbances are estimated using an adaptive RBF neural network, and the estimated values are fed into the control system for compensation. Subsequently, a rapid convergence sliding mode controller is designed based on tracking errors to enhance the response speed and tracking accuracy of the system. Finally, the stability of the control method is proven theoretically through Lyapunov function analysis, and verified by simulation and experimental results performed in the MATLAB/Simulink environment. Results confirm the proposed method's superior disturbance rejection capability and high control accuracy. Additional exploration is conducted into robustness analysis, energy efficiency, payload adaptability, and potential aerospace applications.

title: Secure and Reliable File Transmission Using Stop-and-Wait ARQ with Hybrid Encryption Mechanisms
authors: Anand Rathod, Anirudh R Sharma, Ashishkumar G Uppin, Pratibha K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a Secure Stop-and-Wait File Transfer Protocol, aimed at ensuring both reliable and secure data transmission in modern communication systems. The protocol enhances the traditional Stop-and-Wait Automatic Repeat Request (ARQ) mechanism by incorporating cryptographic features such as Advanced En-cryption Standard (AES) for data confidentiality, Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) for secure key exchange, and digital signatures to ensure data integrity and authenticity. Reliability is achieved through mechanisms like frame acknowledgment, timeouts, and retransmissions. Developed in Python, the system provides a user-friendly graphical user interface (GUI) that allows users to initiate, monitor, and manage secure file transfers. It also includes real-time logging of Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) layer operations and visualization of performance metrics, offering comprehensive insights into protocol behavior across layers. This project demonstrates how a simple ARQ-based protocol can be transformed into a secure communication system that balances simplicity, efficiency, and robust security features.

title: Modern Web Technologies in Financial Applications: A Performance-Driven Approach
authors: Shreya Mahajan, Adinath Jain
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Modern financial systems are increasingly relying on web-based platforms to deliver fast, secure, and scalable services. This paper explores the integration of modern web technologies such as Angular, Spring Boot, and RESTful APIs in the development of financial applications. The focus lies on the performance, responsiveness, and maintainability of full-stack architectures. A generic full-stack financial application has been implemented to demonstrate the effectiveness of combining component-based frontend design with modular backend APIs to handle loanrelated operations efficiently. Tools such as Postman and Swagger were employed to test and validate API interactions, while development followed Behavior-Driven and Test-Driven Development practices to ensure code reliability. Performance evaluation revealed that the chosen stack significantly reduced latency and improved user experience. The findings demonstrate that modern web technologies can effectively meet the growing demands of digital financial services in terms of speed, flexibility, and scalability.

title: The Digital Drain: Predictive Analytics of Smartphone Impact on Health
authors: Rakshitha M, Mansi H L, Karthik S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: In the last decade, smartphones have been progressively integrated into everyday life. It also raises the issue concerning the possible risks linked with its use with respect to one's socio-emotional and physical health. The goal of this paper is to forecast the potential negative effect of smartphone usage. Most of the existing works have focussed on using the smartphone sensor data or behavioral profiling for detecting depression and anxiety. In this proposed research, we aim to address the ill effects of smartphone usage in a multi-dimensional perspective. The proposed research finds the correlation between the smartphone usage and various factors such as sleep issues, eyesight problems, anxiety, social media addiction, or incapacity to effectively interact socially. In contrast to existing works that focussed on one dimensional analysis, this research applies a holistic approach to perform risk assessments through predictive analytics. The proposed model attained 92.50 % accuracy with Random Forest. The classifier was validated with test runs and was adjusted for class imbalance, using the SMOTE method. This adjustment aided in reaching 93.71 % accuracy. further confirming the strong statistical relationship between smartphone usage and mental health. The outcomes advise that mobile phone usage has a statistically significant impact on an individual's mental health and this research will prove to be essential to understand the ill effects of smart phone usage.

title: Genetic Algorithm-Driven Portfolio Optimization Across Equities, Cryptocurrencies, and ESG Assets
authors: Hemanth Medhahal, Rohit Suresh, Pramath KP, Sailaja Y
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents a study on the use of genetic algorithms (GAs) for portfolio optimization across diverse assets, including equities, cryptocurrencies, and ESG-focused instruments. The optimization framework incorporates real-world constraints such as full capital allocation, cardinality limits, and diversification bounds, with objectives centered on maximizing risk-adjusted returns like the Sharpe Ratio. The GA methodology is outlined with details on portfolio encoding, fitness evaluation, and genetic operators. Performance is compared against traditional mean-variance optimization and meta-heuristics like Particle Swarm Optimization and Ant Colony Optimization using historical market data. Results show that GAs consistently achieve superior risk-adjusted returns and demonstrate greater robustness under complex constraints, particularly in portfolios adhering to ESG criteria.

title: Biowaste Based Electrode for Supercapacitor Application Using Coconut Oil Cake
authors: Rohan S, Rishab Rajesh Nayak, Ananya K R, Shwetha K.P., Sudha Kamath M.K., S Girish Kumar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The rising demand for ecofriendly, durable and efficient energy capture solutions has intensified interest in ecofriendly supercapacitor materials. In this study, coconut oil cake, an abundant agricultural by-product, was utilized as renewable substrate for activated carbon production. The biomass was purified, powdered, carbonized at high temperature, and chemically activated using potassium hydroxide <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{KOH})$</tex>. The resulting activated carbon demonstrated partial graphitization, an amorphous and porous structure. Electrochemical characterization revealed a specific capacitance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$48.78 \text{Fg}^{-1}$</tex>, demonstrating its potential for energy storage applications. These results highlight coconut oil cake as a cut-price, renewable, and steady feedstock for producing efficient activated carbon electrodes, offering an environmentally responsible route for supercapacitor fabrication.

title: Deep Learning Based Multi-Task Model for Fruit Type and Freshness Detection
authors: Shamshuddin Shaik, V Padmapriya, S Uma
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: As the demand for improved food quality and reduced wastage post-harvest continues to grow, automated fruit classification and freshness detection have become crucial in the agricultural sector. This paper introduces a deep learning-based Multi-Task Learning (MTL) model that performs simultaneous fruit type classification, like apple, banana, and guava, and freshness assessment (fresh or rotten). The architecture utilizes a shared Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) backbone to extract high-level visual features, followed by dedicated task-specific branches for predicting the fruit type and freshness. Additionally, independent CNN-BiLSTM models were trained per fruit type to enhance freshness detection based on temporal patterns. The experimental results on a well-structured image dataset indicate that the proposed method outperforms existing techniques in terms of accuracy and effectiveness, with accuracies of 98.33% for fruit type and 99.78% for freshness classification. These results highlight the model's potential in supporting intelligent supply chain systems and reducing food waste.

title: Highly Efficient On-Device Diabetic Retinopathy Screening Using Quantized EfficientNet-Lite Models on Retinal Fundus Images
authors: Aous Hani Nief, Satar Jabbar Rahi Algraittee, Hussain Ali Hussain, Anas Ramaid Mohammad Karaghool, Sazan Kamal Sulaiman, Mohammed Abdul Jaleel Maktoof, Kahtan Mohammed Adnan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research proposes a highly efficient, quantized convolutional neural network framework for on-device diabetic retinopathy (DR) screening, integrating lightweight EfficientNet-Lite models, lesion-preserving image preprocessing, and INT8 quantization for real-time edge deployment. Using EfficientNet-Lite0 as the architectural backbone and applying adaptive histogram equalization and vessel segmentation, the system was benchmarked across clinical-grade fundus image datasets including EyePACS, APTOS 2019, and Messidor-2. The model consistently achieved DR detection accuracies up to 91.3%, with F1-scores reaching 0.859 and inference times below 130ms on ARM-based mobile processors, validating its diagnostic precision under resource constraints. Compared to unquantized baselines and mobile CNNs, the proposed framework demonstrated a 4.7–5.2% increase in accuracy and a 45% reduction in memory footprint, with no significant loss in classification performance due to quantization. TensorFlow Lite optimization and lesion-centric preprocessing enabled consistent screening performance under low-light and noisy imaging environments. With the compressed model size of ~4.2MB and readiness for deployment onto real-world smartphone and embedded systems, the proposed pipeline facilitates scalable, privacy-friendly, and accurate DR screening in remote or underserved locations.

title: Cross-Chain Integration Using Oracles
authors: Posam Harshitha, Manasa D N, Madhubala M, Lavanya M, Deepika Dash, Anala M R
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The heterogeneous blockchain ecosystem remains fragmented, limiting the composability and scalability required for decentralized applications (DApps). The purpose of cross-chain integration is to eliminate this challenge by enabling secure data and asset transfer across asymmetrical blockchains. Oracle off-chain data providers are expected to play an important role in bridging different blockchain networks. This paper provides a comprehensive survey of cross-chain communication techniques, analyzes the ability and limitations of oracle-based solutions, and identifies promising research directions to enhance the performance, safety, and credibility of such systems.

title: An Adaptive Drone Navigation in Dynamic Terrains Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Pradeep Kumar Muthukamatchi, Manoj Varthan Velumani, M Kasiselvanathan, K Sangeetha, Hameed Nida Hameed, Hasanin Alshamri, Basheer Husamaldeen Alhayaly
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Autonomous drone navigation in dynamic environments, an important challenge in robotics, requires real-time adaptive decision-making. This work aims to offer a deep reinforcement learning system (DRL), thus allowing drones to avoid obstacles effectively, sailing in complex and chaotic settings. Using a Deep Q Network (DQN), it has improved with reward modeling techniques and policy optimization. The proposed method improves the efficiency and lifetime of learning. After being trained in a simulated environment with dynamic obstacles, the model is assessed for generalization ability in real-world situations. Experimental results show the DRL-based navigation system beats traditional path planning methods by achieving higher success rates and reducing the likelihood of collision. The approach also demonstrates a quick reaction to environmental changes, hence enhancing dependability in actual applications. Finally, this article underlines the potential of DRL in autonomous training to negotiate in more efficient dynamic contexts free from risk.

title: A Lightweight Deep Learning-Based DDoS Attacks Detection for IoT
authors: Dawit Dejene Bikila, Jan Ćapek, Zeru Kifle Kebede, Petr Hajek
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) connects heterogeneous devices and systems, which brings major benefits to various industries. However, its use in critical areas poses vulnerability to threats like Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. These attacks can congest the networks, disrupt services, and compromise sensitive data, leading to delays, threatening operations, and causing serious financial or reputational harm. To overcome these threats, an intelligent attack detection method needs to be developed. This motivates the current work to propose a lightweight Deep Learning (DL) based DDoS attack detection for IoT. Our model employs an Autoencoder (AE) for learning a reduced latent space representation of features from the CICIoT2023 dataset. A lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is fed an image representation of the encoded features for classifying DDoS attacks. Additionally, we have used the focal loss function to handle minority class (rare attack types) detection, which contributes to the enhanced overall detection. Our experimental results indicate that the proposed model achieved a comparatively higher performance than the state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Techno-Economic Performance of Renewable-Powered Hydrogen Systems for Residential Electricity Supply
authors: Mohamed Elsheikh, Pieter David Boom, B.S. Awad Alquaity
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This study presents a techno-economic analysis of green hydrogen production using photovoltaic (PV) and wind energy integrated with proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolysis in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. The renewable systems supply DC power to the electrolyzer, converting water into hydrogen, which is stored and used to fuel a gas turbine for electricity generation to power 400 homes. Weather data, technical and financial parameters, and NREL’s SAM simulations are used to estimate plant performance, levelized cost of electricity (LCOE), hydrogen production potential, and levelized cost of hydrogen (LCOH). Results show that the LCOE for PV and wind plants is 4.57 and 4.28 ¢ /kWh, respectively, whereas levelized cost of creating hydrogen (LCOH) is 6.5 and 8.2 ${\$}$/kg for PV and wind plants, respectively. Net present value (NPV) analysis indicates that PV projects become profitable after 9.5 years, reaching 17.78 M${\$}$ by year 20, while wind projects achieve profitability earlier, after 7 years, and reach 34.79 M${\$}$ by year 20. These findings demonstrate the economic viability of integrating renewable energy into hydrogen production for a sustainable, low-carbon electricity supply in the region.

title: Performance Optimization in Networks Through SDN Integration
authors: Sai Priya T. S, Mounika R, K. Saraswathi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The rapid growth of modern networks has improved data rates and connectivity but continues to face challenges in scalability, flexibility, and efficient traffic management. Traditional decentralized controllers lack global optimization, making them inefficient for complex 5G environments. To address this gap, this paper investigates a Software-Defined Networking (SDN) architecture with centralized control to enable dynamic load balancing and resource allocation. However, SDN faces critical security challenges due to its centralized network architecture, where the controller becomes a single point of failure and an attractive target for diverse attacks. To address this, the novelty of this work lies in integrating OpenFlow with SSL/TLS encryption and SHA-based authentication, thereby establishing secure communication channels that ensure confidentiality, integrity, and authentication. The proposed framework is implemented on an OpenFlow-based SDN using Mininet for simulation and Wireshark for traffic analysis. The performance is further evaluated using metrics such as throughput and latency across two different scenarios.

title: Decarbonization of the civil sector through utility-scale PV and related grid improvements: assessment of economic and carbon impact in an Italian case study
authors: Elena Benedetti, Francesco Castellani, Cecilia Servi, Federico Santi, Maria Carmen Falvo
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This study investigates the economic and environmental implications of deploying utility-scale photovoltaic systems to support the decarbonization of the civil sector in the Tuscany Region, Italy. By combining regional data, policy targets, and technical simulations, this paper compares the BAU scenario with two contrasting scenarios: one based on traditional fossil generation, and one supported by the adoption of utility-scale PV and battery energy storage systems. The analysis integrates electricity demand projections from full electrification of heating in residential and tertiary sectors, assesses photovoltaic potential using updated GIS and legislative data, and evaluates impacts on the regional transmission grid as defined by the Italian Transmission System Operator. The study concludes that investment in utility-scale PV and BESS infrastructure is a strategic and sustainable pathway for achieving regional decarbonization goals, even if CAPEX is still more expensive than providing electricity to the civil sector using fossil sources, due to lower capacity factors and higher generation and grid costs.

title: GeezNet: Comparative Study of Deep Architectures for Geez Numeral Recognition
authors: Oli Gurmessa, Pakeeza Akram
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: The Ge’ez script is one of the ancient writing systems. It is underrepresented in modern OCR research due to its complex numeral shapes and the absence of standardized datasets. This paper presents GeezNet, a deep learning framework optimized for Ge’ez numeral recognition. We also introduce a curated, open-access dataset containing 10,000 labeled images across 20 numeral classes. Several GeezNet variants—baseline, depthwise separable, residual, and Vision Transformer (ViT) hybrid-are compared with transfer learning models such as ResNet-50 and Inception-V3. The optimized 15-layer GeezNet achieves 97.8% accuracy on an independent test set. It reduces computational cost compared to larger generic architectures, enabling deployment on mobile and archival digitization systems. Misclassification analysis shows difficulties with visually similar numerals. These insights inform future work on robustness to noise and handwriting variability. This study provides a benchmark model, a comprehensive architecture comparison, and a public dataset to advance OCR for underrepresented scripts in low-resource settings.

title: Anomaly Detection in Wearable Health Devices Using Autoencoders with Sparse Representation
authors: Priti Sharma, Layth Hussein, Gummagatta Vybhavi Yajaman, S Jeyanthi, K. Yuvaraj, Elaf Hussein Hadi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The fast adoption of wearable health devices has resulted in massive volumes of physiological data, which is crucial to have a quick anomaly detection system to ensure that appropriate medical treatments are provided. Standard rule-based systems often fail the test of adapting to individual variation and the complicated temporal patterns natural in biological signals. Biosignals are naturally complex and offer a unique anomaly detection system using sparse representation autoencoders. This methodology aims to find anomalies in multivariate time-series health data. The suggested method directs autoencoders to get compact latent representations by training them on conventional physiological patterns using the advised technique. This approach also ensures that the sparsity is preserved to improve feature discrimination. Reconstruction error thresholds help identify anomalies, while sparsity ensures the system is resilient to noise and redundant data. Experiments managed on publicly available datasets, including ECG and PPG signals, have revealed that the model may considerably enhance its accuracy and recall. The findings of these tests suggest that the model outperforms the traditional baseline deep learning settings. As seen in the results, the inclusion of sparsity in autoencoders contributes to an increase in their ability to identify minor anomalies. This approach may be beneficial for real-time health monitoring systems, as it is highly sensitive and reduces the number of false alarms.

title: Beyond Passive Listening: Leveraging AI and Bloom's Taxonomy to Cultivate Deeper Student Participation
authors: Lokesh Suryawanshi, Tanishq Kaul, Riddhima Sharma, Preeti Agarwal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Conventional classroom teaching methods struggle to keep students engaged and provide real-time pedagogical feedback to the professor delivering the lecture. Our research implements an AI-driven classroom engagement model. It employs live transcription, semantic summarization, and computergraded formative assessment based on Bloom's Taxonomy. This transforms passive learning into an interactive experience. The system generates dynamic quizzes through live lecture recording and its translation into structured insights. The model is being empirically tested at NMIMS, Navi Mumbai. Our study aims to illustrate how integrating intelligent systems in classrooms can enhance student engagement and improve understanding through increased attentiveness, and it also comes with a leaderboard for students to see the ranks of their peers, which adds gamification and eventually creates a sense of competition.

title: Lightweight Remote Sensing Image Detection Algorithm Improved YOLOv8
authors: Jialiang Ji, Shujun Pei
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Addressing the issues of false positives and missed targets that mainstream object target algorithms encounter when working with remote sensing images featuring heterogeneous backgrounds and multi-scale objects, the present work presents a modified YOLOv8n for lightweight detection of remote sensing imagery. The method introduces the C2f-SC module, replacing the C2f Bottleneck with a novel SCBottleneck, enhancing feature extraction capabilities and background suppression, thereby improving performance in small object detection. In the Neck section, the SimAM attention mechanism is incorporated, which enhances the recognition accuracy of key regions while keeping the model's parameter count unchanged. Furthermore, the TDAD-Head detection head is proposed, utilizing shared convolutions to decrease the parameter count and optimize the interaction between classification and localization tasks, thus enhancing detection performance. Additionally, the Slide Loss function is refined using the Exponential Moving Average (EXPMA) concept, resulting in the ES Loss function that dynamically adjusts sample weights to effectively address class imbalance issues. Empirical results reveal that, versus the baseline YOLOv8n, the improved algorithm achieves a 2.1% increase in mAP, while the parameter count and calculation are reduced by 29% and 25% respectively, and FPS is increased by about 24%, which realizes the balance between detection performance and lightweight.

title: Energy Optimized AI Based O-Ring Defect Detection for Sustainable Manufacturing
authors: Sahana S, Prajwal M, Yashwanth R, Hemanth B S, Neha Chandramohan, Paridhi Sudarshan, Ramavenkateswaran N, Mekhala Purohit
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: O-rings, vital in aerospace, automotive, and manufacturing, require precise defect detection, as even minor imperfections can cause failure. Traditional methods like manual checks often fall short. This project aims to create an automated, real-time O-ring defect detection system. The system integrates mechanical automation, computer vision, and embedded electronics. A Waveshare OV5693 5MP camera, mounted around a rotary fixture, provides 360° inspection. CAD models were created in SolidWorks/Fusion 360, with the setup built on a 3Dprinted <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T$</tex>-slot structure. A machine learning pipeline, combining ResNet-18 and Autoencoder models, was trained on custom and Roboflow datasets. Image processing used OpenCV, TensorFlow, and PyTorch, with Streamlit for real-time defect visualization. The ResNet-18 model achieved 97% accuracy, while the autoencoder showed low reconstruction loss. The combined ensemble model reached 93% accuracy, with the system achieving 92.3% accuracy and sub-second latency under real-time conditions. This solution provides a scalable, energy-efficient, and interpretable alternative to traditional inspection, advancing AI-driven quality assurance in industry.

title: CFA-DETR: A Lightweight End-to-End Cross-Scale Feature Aggregation Network for Metal Defect
authors: Amei Du, Ruijun Lan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: To address the challenges posed by irregular deformations and densely distributed defects on flat metal surfaces, this study proposes a lightweight Cross-scale Feature Aggregation Detection Transformer (CFA-DETR) specifically designed for industrial applications. The model incorporates a Context-guided Attention Aggregation RepBlock (CAA-RepBlock) that mitigates information loss during multi-scale defect feature extraction. This design enables accurate localization of critical features within complex textural backgrounds while simultaneously reducing network complexity. To enhance recognition and localization of key regions, a deformable attention mechanism is integrated, improving robustness against distorted defects and enhancing feature separability. Additionally, a multi-level Dilated Reparameterized Block with Enhanced Local Attention Network (DRBELAN) is developed to facilitate efficient cross-scale feature fusion. This module enhances comprehensive semantic information representation for dense defects while accelerating inference through reparameterization strategies. On the benchmark NEU-DET dataset, CFA-DETR achieves 81.1% detection accuracy with only 8.23M parameters. Experimental results demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed model in detecting both distorted and densely distributed surface defects across diverse industrial scenarios.

title: Detection of Complex Patterns and Anomalies in Power System Data
authors: Ahmed Hadi Ali AL-Jumaili, Ashraf Thaker Mahmood Almukhtar, Huda Mohammed Lateef, Hameed Allawi Shanyoor AL-Jumaili, Mohammed À. Al-Shibly, Omar Salah F. Shareef, Omar D. Madeeh, Yaseen Hadi Ali
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Since the data in power systems is growing more complex and large, advanced tools are needed to watch and detect any anomalies as they arise. Often, standard data analysis does not do a great job at finding the changing, irregular parts of big energy consumption data. The study explains how Apache Mahout, Spark, and Storm were added to K-Means and Canopy to make the CKMA framework for anomaly detection. CKMA is low-variance anomaly detection since it uses Canopy to create quick first clusters and then refines them using K-Means. LMR together with PCA is used to spot slight changes in the stability of the power grid. Seeing the results of tests, it becomes clear that the CKMA algorithm enhances processing speed and detection accuracy much more when integrated into distributed systems than traditional ones. With such a unified system, finding changes in power usage patterns is more reliable, adaptable, and up to date, so it is useful for managing smart grids and forecasting energy usage.

title: Automated Railway Track Inspection with Real-Time Defect Detection
authors: Anurag Tiwari, Pregati Ranjan, Samay Sagar, Vipul Kumar Mishra
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Today's Indian Railways is one of the biggest railway networks in the world and serves as a crucial part of the nation's transportation system. But how do you maintain safe, reliable tracks when the system relies on manual inspections and periodic maintenance that strain resources, take time, and can be prone to human error? The current study focuses on overcoming these obstacles by utilizing Artificial Intelligence(AI) to automate defect identification and incorporate predictive maintenance of railway tracks. Major contribution of the paper are first creating railway track images dataset with different faults, Second developing an object detection model to detect missing/broken fasteners and surface flaws, for predictive maintenance operations. The results showed notable advancements with this YOLO based system when it comes to better accuracy in fault detection, low manual intervention, and fault detection in real time. This study aspires that AI technologies if correctly integrated into the Indian Railways' maintenance system, have the potential to revolutionize the system and ensure safety and reliability. The proposed system presents a powerful, scalable, and efficient means of leveraging AI to revolutionize track monitoring, and ultimately build a more secure and resilient railway network in India.

title: Multi-Dimensional Priority-Driven Scheduling for Real-Time Applications on Heterogeneous Systems
authors: Pratibha Kantanavar, Shreyas Gowda BN, Shrinidhi Kanmas
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: As industrial systems evolve toward greater automation, adaptability, and intelligence, the demand for real-time processing on heterogeneous multi-dimensional platforms has intensified. These platforms, which combine general-purpose CPUs with specialized accelerators such as FPGAs, enable parallel execution and high performance. However, achieving real-time guarantees in such environments is complex due to heterogeneous processing capabilities, resource contention, and inter-task communication delays. This paper proposes two novel scheduling algorithms that are tailored for real-time execution in heterogeneous industrial computing environments. The Real-Time Priority-driven Algorithm (ReTPA) dynamically assigns tasks by considering both priority and processing unit availability, enhancing workload distribution and meeting tight deadline constraints. Extending this, the Communication-aware Real-Time Priority-driven Algorithm (CRETPA) introduces communication-aware scheduling decisions to mitigate inter-core latency and improve coordination among diverse processing units. In addition, the proposed framework explores the integration of Dynamic Partial Reconfiguration (DPR) for reconfigurable hardware modules, analyzing its impact on scheduling feasibility under real-time constraints. Experimental results on industrial benchmarks reveal that ReTPA and CRETPA significantly reduce execution time, improve deadline adherence, and increase throughput compared to traditional scheduling approaches. These findings validate the suitability of the proposed methods for deployment in embedded control systems, smart manufacturing, and industrial automation infrastructures that require predictable and efficient real-time performance.

authors: Mattewos Tefferi

abstract: When I was appointed as chair of the DEIS Young Professionals (YP) Committee in early 2023, I outlined several priorities in my editorial in IEEE Electrical Insulation Magazine [1]. Looking back now, as my term comes to an end, I am proud of what the YP Committee has accomplished over the past three years.

title: Dynamic Action Execution Evaluation of Functional Movement Screening Based on Computer Vision and Deep Learning
authors: Yuting Chen, Sheng Lu, Wenting Zhou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Functional Movement Screening (FMS) is an approach for fundamental human movement function assessment and sports injury prevention. However, traditional manual assessment suffers from issues such as subjectivity and low efficiency. The dynamic action execution evaluation is a difficult problem in FMS tests. In this paper, an intelligent assessment pure vision based method is proposed to evaluating body sway in two dynamic FMS movements. YOLO and ResNet techniques are employed to construct the torso tilt detection model. The degree of body sway during the completion of FMS movements is assessed based on the detected angle changes of the testers’ torsos. The experimental results showed that our approach can correctly judge the body sway of the FMS dynamic action execution.

title: A Secure Cloud Orchestration Layer for Scalable and Efficient Teleoperation
authors: Awwal Ishiaku
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Teleoperation systems face significant challenges in scalability, security, and session isolation, particularly in cloud-based and multi-tenant environments. This work proposes the Secure Cloud Orchestration Layer (SCOL), a conceptual framework designed to address these challenges. SCOL leverages software-defined networking (SDN) and network slicing to isolate teleoperation sessions and dynamically allocate resources. It incorporates ephemeral session keys, role-based access control (RBAC), and immutable logging to enhance security and accountability. Additionally, SCOL integrates blockchain and smart contracts to provide tamper-resistant authentication and consent mechanisms. By combining these technologies with a modular, containerized microservices architecture, SCOL offers a scalable and secure framework for teleoperation systems, enabling their application in domains such as healthcare, robotics, and industrial automation.

title: Energy-Efficient RIS-Assisted NOMA Networks with IoT Gateways Under PSSWIPT for Simultaneous Communication and Energy Harvesting
authors: Sima Sobhi-Givi, Mousa Abdollahvand
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: This paper investigates a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) enabled massive machine-type communication (mMTC) network, where Internet of Things (IoT) gateways employ a power-splitting simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (PSSWIPT) architecture to enable concurrent energy harvesting (EH) and information decoding (ID). We formulate a joint optimization problem that maximizes the overall energy efficiency (EE) of the network while satisfying quality-of-service (QoS) requirements and ensuring a minimum harvested energy level for each gateway. The optimization variables include the transmit power allocation, beamforming vectors, RIS phase shift matrix, and power-splitting ratios at the gateways. To tackle the resulting high-dimensional and non-convex problem, we develop a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO)-based reinforcement learning (RL) framework. Simulation results show that the proposed PPO-based approach significantly outperforms benchmark methods, achieving higher EE while guaranteeing the energy sustainability of low-power IoT devices. These findings highlight the potential of integrating RIS, NOMA, and advanced learning-based optimization in future energy-constrained mMTC networks.

title: Evolutionary AI for Morphological and Locomotor Design of Resilient Exploration Robots
authors: Raghab Singh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: We present an AI-driven evolutionary framework that co-designs morphology and locomotion for compliant (soft) robots intended for extraterrestrial terrains. Using CPPN-NEAT with novelty-guided search, our approach explores diverse body plans and gaits across Earth, Martian, and lunar gravity. In an ablation against direct encodings, CPPN-based robots achieved <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.78 \times$</tex> greater mean displacement under Earth gravity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 4. 3 ~ c m}$</tex> vs. 8.0 cm), while also exhibiting higher morphology-diversity scores (0.87 vs. 0.41), indicating improved exploration of the design space. Novelty search further enriched behavior-space coverage and yielded robust gaits under low gravity. Results highlight that diversity-centric, generative encodings can surface unconventional yet effective designs often overlooked by purely fitness-driven optimization.
