This article, part of the “A Day in the Life of a ____ Laboratory” series, highlights the laboratory's unique role in live-line maintenance, encompassing the education of future professionals and development of innovative technologies.

title: Noisy Iris Segmentation Using Modified Circular Hough Transform (MCHT)
authors: Suzwani Ismail, Fakariah Hani Mohd Ali
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Noisy iris images that consist various forms of noise such as occlusions of eyelids, glasses, hair, and eyelashes caused segmentation errors on iris boundary, as well as exhibit problem in selecting and extracting iris features. These factors exhibited poor accuracy performance for iris recognition system. Many segmentation methods had been proposed in order to accurately segment the noisy iris. Some of them used segmentation method with the help of noise removal method, and there are also previous works which utilized ROI of iris image. Nevertheless, there are still limitation in terms of segmentation error. Thus, the problems of segmentation error become the motivation of this study to design an enhanced segmentation method to reduce segmentation error of noisy iris image, which lead to enhancement in accuracy performance of noisy iris recognition system. This research aimed to propose a new iris recognition system based on Modified Circular Hough Transform (MCHT), which comprises of two stages; MCHT I and MCHT II, to accurately segment noisy iris Image. 20000 right and left iris images from CASIA Iris Thousand database had been utilized to evaluate the proposed work. Empirical results of MCHT have demonstrated a 97.02% segmentation accuracy compared to 73.38% segmentation accuracy of existing segmentation method.

title: AI-Driven Optimization of Plaster Manufacturing Using Design of Experiments and Machine Learning
authors: Prasert Aengchuan, Attasit Wiangkham
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Systems (ICCS)
abstract: This paper presents a two-stage framework for optimizing process control in plaster manufacturing under uncertain operating conditions, integrating Design of Experiments (DoE) and Machine Learning (ML) techniques. In the first stage, a full factorial 2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">k</sup> DoE was employed to evaluate four input parameters—roller mill current (M), blower hot air flow (F), classifier speed (S) and temperature (T)—with combined water (CW) as the system output. The analysis identified temperature as the most influential factor, while several multi-factor interactions also significantly impacted system behavior. In the second stage, three ML models—Decision Tree (DT), Support Vector Regression (SVR) and Gaussian Process Regression (GPR)—were implemented to predict CW. All models achieved strong predictive accuracy (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> > 0.8), with mean absolute error (MAE) values ranging from 0.0860 to 0.0906. While SVR achieved the highest training R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> (0.862), GPR demonstrated the most consistent performance and lowest overall error. These results support a hybrid control strategy that leverages DoE for initial feature screening and ML for robust data-driven prediction. GPR was identified as the most suitable model among those tested for applications requiring high precision and reliability, due to its superior generalization and integrated uncertainty quantification.

title: Hybrid Deep Neural Architecture for Alzheimer's Stage Prediction Using MRI and Attention-Based Temporal Modeling
authors: R M R Shamija Sherryl, S. Jone Rosy, Mithra C, P. Jesu Jayarin, D Beulah David
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is a chronic neurological disease that significantly impairs cognitive ability. Early diagnosis is crucial for efficient care and timely action. In this study, we introduce a hybrid deep learning model that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (-CNN) and The bidirectional short-term memory (BiLSTM) networks to reliably classify Alzheimer's disease symptoms from structural MRI images.and readability. pipeline effectively distinguises between Alzheimer's disease (AD), mild cognitive impairment (MCI), and normal controls (NC) by integrating spatial and temporal data. The suggested model outperforms conventional CNN and LSTM models with a classification accuracy of 94 %. Grad-CAM visualization improves interpretability by highlighting brain regions important to the condition. With its progressively neurodegenerative. nature that significantly impairs cognitive functioning, Alzheimer's disease (AD) poses a serious healthcare concern. For intervention measures to be effective, early and correct diagnosis is still essential. In order to more accurately and interpretably categorize Alzheimer's disease from structural MRI scans, this study investigates a novel hybrid deep learning architecture that blends 3D Convolutional Neural Networks (3D-CNNs) with Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) networks. Novelity of this work is creation of a hybrid architecture for AD forecasting that combines CNN and BiLSTM.PCA is used to reduce dimensionality in order to enhance generalization. Grad-CAM visualization is integrated for interpretability. outperformed conventional CNN or LSTM models with an accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 4 \%}$</tex>. It is useful for real-world screening because it is applicable to single-timepoint MRI.

title: Impact of Ambient Temperature on Reversible Capacity Loss and Electrochemical Behavior of Commercial Lithium-Ion Battery Chemistries
authors: Hayder Ali, Atif Alzahrani, Muhammad Khalid
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are vital to modern energy systems, with nickel manganese cobalt oxide (NMC), lithium iron phosphate (LFP), and nickel cobalt aluminum oxide (NCA) chemistries accounting for $\sim 90 \%$ of the market due to their trade-offs in performance, cost, safety, and sustainability. Although these chemistries are well studied for irreversible capacity loss (permanent aging) under extreme conditions, reversible capacity loss remains comparatively underexplored across real-world temperature ranges. This form of loss is a temporary reduction in usable capacity caused by environmental factors such as temperature fluctuations, with capacity often recoverable once optimal conditions are restored. While not permanent, it reduces performance, impairs state-of-charge and state-of-health estimation, and limits battery management system effectiveness, particularly in applications subject to daily or seasonal temperature variations. This study addresses these gaps by evaluating reversible capacity loss and AC/DC internal resistance growth in NMC, LFP, and NCA. Electrochemical behavior is characterized using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) across five controlled ambient temperatures ($10{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to 45°C) under standardized charge–discharge conditions. The findings establish benchmarks for reversible capacity loss in these chemistries and provide guidance for selecting LIBs suited to temperature-sensitive applications in grid storage, electric vehicles, and portable electronics.

title: Inertia Monitoring and Forecasting With Deep Penetration of Photovoltaic Source. A case Study of the Republic of Mauritius Power Grid
authors: Abdul Ahad Jhumka, Maria Vahdati, Mehdi Shahrestani, Omid Shariati
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: This paper aims at monitoring and forecasting the system inertia for the Republic of Mauritius power grid based on a novel stochastic dynamic grid model under an extreme weather event. As the island has set the target of connecting $60 \%$ of photovoltaic source to the network by 2030 as a measure to reduce carbon emissions, it is expected that the grid inertia to reduce, leading to unstable conditions. Accordingly, we use the Auto Regressive Integrated Moving Average forecasting method to study the inertia behavior. We demonstrate this method by using an IEEE 9-bus for our study. The percentage of penetration of the photovoltaic source is set at $\mathbf{6 0 \%}$ and we forecast the inertia for a period of 5 hours under a rainy period. Our findings establish a minimum power generation to maintain stability, below which operators are required to connect other generating sources in the mix to avoid peak shaving. With this research, utilities can anticipate future disturbances.

title: A Preliminary Investigation of Occupancy Estimation Using Environmental Sensors for Future Application in Japanese Nursing Facilities
authors: Takuya Miura, Yuji Mizuno, Jiyoung Choi, Nobumasa Matsui
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This paper proposes a privacy-preserving occupancy detection method that estimates room occupancy without using cameras or other imaging devices, relying solely on environmental sensor data such as temperature, humidity, and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> concentration. While video cameras provide the advantage of high-precision, real-time behavior detection, concerns are raised regarding potential privacy infringements resulting from their continuous video recording. The model employs a Long ShortTerm Memory (LSTM) network to capture temporal dependencies in the data. First, threshold optimization is performed to maximize the F1 score based on the model’s output probabilities. Next, three categories of supplementary featurestemporal, dynamic, and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-related-are incorporated in addition to the baseline inputs to evaluate their contribution to occupancy estimation performance. Using permutation importance for feature selection, the performance of three configurations is compared: a baseline model, a featureaugmented model, and a feature-selected model. The baseline model achieves an F1 score of 0.86, while the feature-selected model achieves the best performance with $\mathbf{F 1}=\mathbf{0 . 9 3}$, Accuracy $=$ 0.92, and $M C C=0.84$. The permutation importance analysis indicates that diurnal periodicity and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> variation patterns are the most influential factors for occupancy estimation. These results demonstrate that high-accuracy occupancy detection can be achieved using only environmental sensors while preserving privacy. The proposed approach has potential applications in elderly monitoring support and energy-saving control systems.

title: Building Trust in AI: A Hybrid Approach to Combating Fake News and Misinformation
authors: Piyush Verma, Manoj Kumar S, Harsh Deep, Kumar Chinmay
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The increasing spread of fake news in the digital world has become very concerning with respect to information authenticity and public trust. This paper proposes a comprehensive automated fake news detection system based on Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to automate content verification. The system utilizes an integrated approach combining language comprehension and dynamic knowledge retrieval for evaluating news headlines and articles. Real-time verification is done through a web interface which displays confidence scores, the evidence used for retrieval, and insight on the content retrieval patterns. The model achieves approximately 92.5% accuracy with an 8% false-positive rate on benchmark datasets. Its modular architecture allows for external API integration, enabling scalability for use in newsrooms, educational institutions, and as monitoring tools for social media. In alignment with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 16, this system-defines, and seeks to solve the issue of misinformation while promoting digital media literacy and explains the gap that exists between AI understanding and communication, where trust is essential.

title: Active Smart Surface-Assisted Energy Efficiency Optimisation for Multi-User Communication Networks
authors: Zhao Zhanwei, He Xiaoli, Xie Wei
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: A MU-MISO network system based on sub-connect ed active RIS assistance is investigated for the dual-path loss in t he RIS cascade channel. By analyzing the relationship between sy stem power consumption, RIS phase matrix and amplitude factor under multi-user, the optimisation problem of maximising energ y efficiency with the constraints of maximum transmit power of t he base station, RIS phase matrix and amplitude factor is establis hed for the established optimisation problem, it is decomposed int o a number of sub-problems by the quadratic transformation met hod, and then each sub-problem is transformed by using the meth ods of Lagrangian dyadic transformation and multidimensional c omplex quadratic transformation; finally, the alternating optimis ation algorithm is used to iteratively solve the optimisation proble m. Then, each subproblem is transformed using Lagrangian dyad ic transformation and multidimensional complex quadratic trans formation; finally, the problem is solved iteratively using the alter nating optimisation algorithm. The simulation results show that t he proposed scheme can improve the system's energy efficiency.

title: FEM-Based Design and Experimental Validation of a High Power Density Planar Transformer for an Active Clamp Flyback Converter
authors: Farrukh Jamshed, Reza Mounesi, Adel Nasiri
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This paper presents a validated design methodology for a 10-layer, PCB-integrated planar transformer developed for a 5 W, universal-input $\left(85-265 \mathrm{~V}_{\mathrm{AC}}\right)$ active-clamp flyback (ACF) converter. The design process integrates analytical calculations with finite-element modeling (FEM) to optimize the PCB-based magnetics for high-frequency and high-power density. A hardware prototype was fabricated and tested, and the key inductance parameters (magnetizing and leakage) differed by less than 5% from the FEM predictions. Experimental results verified the FEM-based co-simulation, confirming accurate prediction of converter behavior and successful zero-voltage switching (ZVS) across the load range. The strong agreement between analytical design, simulation, and hardware results demonstrates a repeatable process for compact, high-frequency planar magnetics in modern power adapters.

title: Research on Joint Scheduling and Joint Scheduling of Distributed Power Generation and Energy Storage Based on Hybrid Integer Linear Programming and Deep Learning
authors: Yingying Wei
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The purpose of this study is to solve the application and scheduling problem of distributed generation and energy storage joint dispatching in power joint dispatching. Due to the widespread use of renewable energy and the development of energy storage technology, it is difficult for traditional dispatching methods to meet the various requirements of the current combined power dispatching for the utilization of renewable resources, such as economy, stability, and high efficiency. Based on this, this paper introduces a hybrid integer linear programming and deep learning model to construct a reliable joint dispatch of distributed power generation and energy storage, and realizes joint scheduling, in order to achieve a more efficient and reliable scheduling strategy, so as to improve the overall performance of joint scheduling. To this end, this study uses a deep learning CNN model to predict power load and renewable energy generation. The analysis results show that the joint scheduling of distributed power generation and energy storage based on hybrid integer linear programming and deep learning model studied in this paper has obvious advantages in joint scheduling. In the normal operation scenario, the total operating cost of the joint dispatch is controlled within 250,000 yuan, and the utilization rate of renewable energy reaches 90%; In the load fluctuation scenario, its utilization rate is increased to 92%; Through practical application, the operating cost in the third month has been significantly reduced, specifically reduced to 240,000 yuan, and the utilization rate has also been improved. It can be seen that this joint dispatching has a certain economy and efficiency, and can provide intelligent dispatching solutions for its power enterprises.

title: Implementation and Analysis of a Modified High-Gain Boost Converter for Renewable Energy Integration
authors: S Krishnan, Gomathy. S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Power electronics is a significant component of current energy systems, and enables the effective conversion of energy designations in various directions, including renewable energy systems (i.e., wind, solar), electric vehicles, robotics, and high voltage DC transmission. DC-DC converters represent an inefficient component of energy systems as they can boost or buck the voltage level between power sources and power loads. The low voltage sources available (i.e., fuel cells, low voltage solar photovoltaics) are of low and variable output, which results in limited applicability and consistency while remaining economically feasible. High-gain DC-DC boost converters (BC) can ameliorate these issues by providing a step-up output voltage to the level needed to accommodate our residential and industrial consumption, while containing the input current to a near-constant potential. This paper describes the demonstration of a high-gain DC-DC BC that generates significantly greater voltage gain than other designs. By using carefully coupled inductors, capacitors, diodes, and switches, energy is efficiently transferred and converted to obtain usable voltages. The converter has a constant duty cycle and a high output voltage, making it ideal for voltage step-up applications. Simulation results validate its performance, demonstrating its ability to convert low input voltages into high output voltages while saving energy. This converter has the potential to revolutionize renewable energy systems, solar PV installations, electric vehicles, and industrial high-voltage DC technologies.

title: Deep Learning Focused Strawberry Disease Detection Ensembling Method Using YOLOv8, EfficientNetV2 & DeepLabV3+
authors: Anjum Rouf, Aman Rao, Mahima Sharma, Zeenat Zara, Amandeep Kaur, Manish Mukhia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Strawberry Disease Prediction that focused different ensemble approach where disease detection leveraged strength YOLOV8 for object detection, image classification and semantic segmentation. This Approaches aim to overcome different limitations models that combining capabilities leading accuracy and comprehensive disease analysis. For precise localization and bounding box detection areas based on visual features where it provides pixel level segmentation disease severity and spreads on strawberry plants. This resembling integrates weighted fusion or a meta-learner to achieve superior overall performance in identifying and characterizing various strawberry disease. This multi-faceted approach offers a powerful tool for early and accurate management of diseases in smart farming environments, ultimately that contribute to improving crop yield and Quality Purposes.

title: Efficiency Optimization of Dual-Axis Solar Tracking Systems Using Computational Vision Models
authors: Harshith B, M K Laxmi Narasimha, Mahima Gowda R G, Vikas J, Kushal Mandhyan, Kiran V
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents an efficiency-optimized dual-axis solar tracking system leveraging computational vision techniques to enhance photovoltaic energy capture. The proposed system uses Python-based image processing to detect the brightest region in the camera frame, indicating the sun's position. The coordinates of this region are transmitted via serial communication to an Arduino Nano, which drives two servo motors to orient the solar panel along both azimuth and elevation axes, enabling real-time sun tracking. To improve tracking precision and voltage stability, four signal filtering techniques—Kalman Filter, Savitzky–Golay Filter, Particle Filter, and Moving Average Filter—are implemented and comparatively analyzed. Experimental results demonstrate that appropriate filter selection significantly enhances tracking accuracy and power output stability. This integrated system demonstrates a low-cost, intelligent solution for solar energy optimization through a combination of computer vision, embedded control, and smart communication. To monitor energy performance, a voltage sensor connected to the solar panel measures real-time output, which is read through the serial interface and displayed in a custom graphical user interface (GUI). A mathematical model estimates the charging duration based on the voltage input, and upon timer completion, the system automatically triggers an SMS alert to a registered number using the Twilio API.

title: Optimizing Stroke Prediction in Healthcare with Neural Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Md Asif Ul Hoq Khan, Md Saidul Islam Papel, Md Hasanujjaman Milon, Istiaq Ahmed, Md Zahedul Islam, Mamunur R. Raja
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Stroke continues to rank among the top killers and a major source of lasting disability around the globe. Because of that, spotting warning signs early and calculating who is at highest risk have moved to the front lines of medical care. This paper looks at how several machine-learning models can flag future strokes by sifting through patient records and teasing out which factors matter most. Researchers feed a broad mix of data-demographics, habits, lab numbers, and history of illness-into algorithms such as logistic regression, random forests, boosting trees, and deep networks. Careful feature selection lifts forward familiar red flags-age, high blood pressure, heart trouble-while techniques such as oversampling and bagging help tame skewed class counts. Results show that the smarter models reach very high accuracy, opening the door to tailored treatment plans and on-the-spot risk alerts. In short, the study paints machine learning as a game-changing ally in stroke prevention, one able to reshape big healthcare systems through clear, evidence-driven insight.

title: Optimization of Ampacity Prediction in Distribution Networks
authors: Paula Castillo, Elvira Fernandez, Igor Albizu, Miren T. Bedialauneta, Rafael Alberdi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: The growing electricity demand and increasing penetration of Distributed Energy Resources are reshaping modern power systems, requiring more advanced strategies for network planning and operation. As grids approach their technical limits, challenges such as congestion and voltage instability become more prevalent. Accurate ampacity forecasting is essential for optimizing grid performance and facilitating efficient electricity market participation. This paper explores the application of machine learning models and neural networks to predict Dynamic Line Rating. Results show that linear regression methods outperform neural networks in terms of prediction accuracy, with Ridge and Lasso regression achieving the lowest Normalized Root Mean Squared Error. Compared to the baseline AEMET weather-based model, the proposed regression models reduce forecasting errors by nearly 50%. These findings highlight the effectiveness of statistical learning techniques in improving ampacity forecasting for enhanced grid reliability and electricity market optimization.

title: Controllable Multi-Stage Post-Processing for Answer Quality Optimizer in RAG-Based QA Systems
authors: Gongwei Fang, Jianing Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented generation (RAG), which incorporates non-parametric knowledge from external knowledge bases [1] into large language models (LLMs), has emerged as a promising approach for improving response accuracy in various tasks, such as question answering (QA). However, existing research has primarily focused on optimizing the retrieval and generation modules, while largely overlooking the critical role of answer post-processing in determining the final output quality. For instance, in the paper CRUD-RAG, the authors categorize RAG applications into four types—Create, Read, Update, and Delete (CRUD). For each type, they construct corresponding datasets and conduct extensive comparative experiments to evaluate all components of the RAG system across different application scenarios. Their evaluation examines the effects of various LLMs, embedding models, retrieval strategies, and key hyperparameters on system performance, providing practical guidance for parameter tuning in task-specific RAG systems. Nevertheless, the study reveals persistent issues with answer quality in the Read task, where generated responses frequently contain invalid information, redundant content, and other quality defects. To address these limitations, we propose a controllable answer quality optimizer. Experimental results demonstrate that our optimizer achieves significant improvements across multiple metrics.

title: Multi-Domain Deep Reinforcement Learning for Cyber-Physical Systems Security on the WDT Testbed Dataset
authors: Hamza Kaddour, Mohamed I. Ibrahem, Zubair Md Fadlullah, Mostafa M. Fouda
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) are becoming increasingly vulnerable to coordinated attacks that target both the network and physical layers. Traditional intrusion detection systems typically treat these domains separately, limiting their ability to detect complex, cross-domain threats. In this paper, we investigate the feasibility of training a unified reinforcement learning agent that can simultaneously detect anomalies in both domains. Using the publicly available Water Distribution Testbed (WDT) dataset, we evaluate and compare the performance of three Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) algo-rithms-Asynchronous Advantage Actor-Critic (A3C), Dueling Deep Q-Network (Dueling DQN), and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO). Our experiments demonstrate that Dueling DQN consistently achieves the highest reward and fastest convergence in both single-domain settings. We then develop a domainaware dual-branch Dueling DQN agent, which achieves a rolling reward of 161.99 on the unified dataset-surpassing the physicalonly model and approaching the network-only baseline. These results suggest that a shared DRL policy can generalize across domains while reducing deployment complexity in CPS security applications.

title: Chemistry, Control, and Circularity: A Cross-Disciplinary Review of Sustainable E-Mobility Systems
authors: Ajith P Arun, Niranjana Sreenivasan, Raviraj Kusanur, Jagadish H Patil, Basavaraja R J, Manjula Sarode
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) play a major role in the worldwide change to sustainable energy systems. Their rapid expansion is driven not just by environmental policies but also by technological progress and increased consumer acceptance. The growth of EVs is intricately connected to various challenges and opportunities related to energy sustainability. This review provides an interdisciplinary integration of the fundamental scientific and engineering principles supporting this transition. In chemistry, advancements in battery materials, lithium-ion efficiency, solid-state alternatives, and the hydrogen fuel cells evolving role are reshaping the energy density and longevity potential of electric vehicles. In engineering, essential components like thermal management systems, powertrain control, and lightweight vehicle design enhance performance and safety. In the end, systems integration is essential for grid compatibility, smart charging systems, vehicle-to-grid (V2G) frameworks, and energy market economics, all affect feasible scalability. This review offers a comprehensive overview of the interrelated technological ecosystems that are shaping the future of electric mobility by integrating these domains. The goal is to inform researchers and policymakers about the challenges, partnerships, and innovative methods for achieving net-zero transportation. This synthesis highlights the urgent need for collaborative efforts across disciplines to accelerate innovation and ensure ongoing energy resiliency.

title: Assessment and Prediction of House Price Using Machine Learning
authors: Deeksha B S, Vijay Kumar S, Kapilan N, Jose de Jusus Agustin Flores Cuautle
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The Assessment and Prediction of house price is a difficult area in the investigation. Traditional statistical methods are used to predict the prices, but they failed due to the complexity of real estate data and non-linear relationships among features. Various machine learning methods have become more popular for predicting home prices. because their ability to learn and solve the complex problems also relationships between the variables. The present investigation analyzes the house pricing data sets of Haryana state with two categories such as, Data collection based on parameters like, no of bedrooms, bathrooms, living area, number of floors, condition of the house, Postal Code, Number of schools nearby, Distance from the airport, based on these parameters 14000 datasets are collected, and the machine learning algorithms that are being compared are decision trees, random forests, and linear regression. Finally results reveals that, for Linear Regression the accuracy R-square obtained is 0.581, Decision Tree the accuracy R-square obtained is 0.631 and Random Forest the accuracy R-square obtained is 0.783. Random Forest is getting more accuracy than decision tree and linear regression.

title: An Analytical Approach to Social Progress: Genetic Algorithm Optimization and Statistical Assessment of Social Entrepreneurship
authors: Saurov Pandey, Swati Mishra, Amit Tiwari, Payal Bansal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Sustainable development addresses many issues within a fragmented system and promotes social value generated by activities linked to the social entrepreneurship system. Although the potential for social entrepreneurship to support inclusive growth is well recognized, very few statistically based models exist to measure its effects or guide interventions. Specifically, there are no methods for policymakers or practitioners to empirically and systematically determine how drivers such as innovation, funding, regulation, or community engagement influence sustainability outcomes in a scientific manner. This study aims to bridge that gap by developing a comprehensive analytical framework for quantitatively assessing and optimizing the role of social entrepreneurship in sustainable development. The model includes four key sustainability factors: Innovation Level (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{x}_{1}$</tex>), Community Participation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{x}_{2}$</tex>), Funding Availability (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{x}_{3}$</tex>), and Political Support (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{x}_{4}$</tex>), which are believed to influence sustainability collectively. The optimal combination of these variables is identified using GA to maximize long-term impact. The simulated results are validated through statistical methods, including ANOVA, regression analysis, model summary, and Pareto chart. The findings show a significant positive effect of Funding Availability (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{x}_{3}$</tex>) and Policy Support (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{x}_{4}$</tex>) on innovation. Additionally, Innovation Level (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$x_{1}$</tex>) and Community Participation also significantly influence innovation. The model explains a large portion of the variance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(85.57 \%; \mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}\right)$</tex>, with all predictors being significant (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<05$</tex>), indicating its robustness. This serves as an evidence-based decision support tool for social entrepreneurs, policymakers, and development organizations, integrating data from both evolutionary and statistical approaches.

title: Privacy-Preserving Deep Packet Inspection for Ethical Cybersecurity
authors: G. Vanthana, Harshitha T L, Shalini V, Sai Kruthi T, Rakshitha N K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: National cyberspace borders must be monitored vigorously as cyber threats become more sophisticated. However, this requirement often contradicts the basic entitlement to privacy. A Privacy-Preserving Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) architecture is proposed by this research to allow for the secure monitoring of network traffic while maintaining user confidentiality. By combining machine learning with metadata fingerprinting and encrypted traffic analysis, the system can identify and classify threats even when payloads are hidden. This approach emphasizes the importance of transparency and accountability by utilizing role-based access control, semantic policy enforcement, and justification-related logging. Precisely Guided Signature Matching (PGSM and Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) are employed by the system to minimize unnecessary data exposure while maintaining high throughput and detection precision. The balance between real-time monitoring, scalable rule enforcement and compliance with legal and ethical principles is achieved through this architecture, which stands in contrast to traditional DPI approaches that prioritize visibility over privacy.

title: Optimizing the Adversarial Perturbation with a Momentum-based Adaptive Matrix
authors: Wei Tao, Sheng Long, Xin Liu, Wei Li, Qing Tao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Generating adversarial examples (AEs) can be formulated as an optimization problem. Among various optimization-based attacks, the gradient-based PGD and the momentum-based MI-FGSM have garnered considerable interest. However, all these attacks use the sign function to scale their perturbations, which raises several theoretical concerns from the point of view of optimization. In this paper, we first reveal that PGD is actually a specific reformulation of the projected gradient method using only the current gradient to determine its step-size. Further, we show that when we utilize a conventional adaptive matrix with the accumulated gradients to scale the perturbation, PGD becomes AdaGrad. Motivated by this analysis, we present a novel momentum-based attack AdaMI, in which the perturbation is optimized with an interesting momentum-based adaptive matrix. AdaMI is proved to attain optimal convergence for convex problems, indicating that it addresses the non-convergence issue of MI-FGSM, thereby ensuring stability of the optimization process. The experiments demonstrate that the proposed momentum-based adaptive matrix can serve as a general and effective technique to boost adversarial transferability over the state-of-the-art methods across different networks while maintaining better stability and imperceptibility.

title: An Automatic Image-Based Framework for BRDF Measurement in Spectral Remote Sensing
authors: Shachaf Weil Zattelman, Fadi Kizel
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: The Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function (BRDF) is one of the most challenging factors in remote sensing, significantly influencing spectral measurements. Accurate BRDF measurement is crucial for understanding and correcting its impact on spectral data. However, existing approaches require specialized equipment and precise measurement setups, typically capturing data from a single point on an object’s surface. Meanwhile, advances in sensor technology have led to the development of compact and user-friendly spectral cameras, thereby reducing operational complexity. Leveraging these advancements, we propose a novel, modular framework for image-based BRDF measurement that does not require specialized instruments, such as a gonioreflectometer. Our approach begins with acquiring freehand, multiview overlapping images of materials from unknown positions on a hemisphere. We then apply computer vision techniques to estimate camera locations, automatically extract tie points between overlapping images, and establish image connectivity. This connectivity enables automatic tracking of Regions of Interest (ROIs), reflectance measurement across multiple viewing directions, and BRDF characterization. We validated our methodology using a hyperspectral dataset. The results demonstrate its effectiveness in extracting camera positions with an error of less than two degrees compared to Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) drone measurements, tracking ROIs with millimeter accuracy, and accurately measuring the BRDF of various land-cover types. This framework offers a robust, flexible, and accessible alternative for BRDF measurement in remote sensing applications.

title: Federated Semi-Supervised Learning with Annotation Heterogeneity
authors: Xinyi Shang, Gang Huang, Yang Lu, Jian Lou, Bo Han, Yiu-ming Cheung, Hanzi Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Federated Semi-Supervised Learning (FSSL) aims to learn a global model from different clients in an environment with both labeled and unlabeled data. Most of the existing FSSL work generally assumes that both types of data are available on each client. In this paper, we study a more general problem setup of FSSL with annotation heterogeneity, where each client can hold an arbitrary percentage (0%-100%) of labeled data. To this end, we propose a novel FSSL framework called Heterogeneously Annotated Semi-Supervised LEarning (HASSLE). Specifically, it employs a dual-model approach. Two models with the same architecture are trained separately: one uses labeled data only, and the other uses unlabeled data. This design enables the framework to be applied to clients with arbitrary labeling percentages. Furthermore, a mutual learning strategy called Supervised-Unsupervised Mutual Alignment (SUMA) is proposed for the dual models with global residual alignment and model proximity alignment. Subsequently, the dual models can implicitly learn from both types of data across different clients, although each dual model is only trained locally on a single type of data. Experiments verify that the dual models in HASSLE learned by SUMA can mutually learn from each other, thereby effectively utilizing the information of both types of data across different clients. Our code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/shangxinyi/HASSLE</uri>.

title: A General and Energy-Efficient Message Delivery Scheme With M3RSMA for Complex Intersections
authors: Zhenjiang Shi, Yuanyuan Sun, Jiajia Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: At complex intersections, it has become a consensus to address the perception limitations (such as blind spots, the difficulty of accurately obtaining road condition information in distant areas or under adverse weather conditions) faced by single-vehicle intelligence through vehicle-infrastructure cooperation. However, under the constraints of limited spectrum resources, the sharply rising in the number of connected vehicles, and the pressing requirement for effective utilization of electric power, there has been no study on how to design a scheme that assists roadside unit (RSU) completing roadside cooperative message delivery (RCMD) with minimal transmit power. Towards this end, this paper proposes a general and energy-efficient RCMD scheme based on multicarrier multigroup multicasting rate-splitting multiple access. We formulate a joint optimization problem involving the RSU’s transmit power, along with the power and size coefficients of each message. Then we design a deep reinforcement learning-assisted bilevel resource allocation algorithm to solve this problem. Finally, we collect extensive numerical results, using the message delivery success probability and RSU’s transmit power as performance metrics, from the proposed scheme and multiple benchmarks. Results indicate that the proposed scheme not only exhibits strong adaptability (i.e., it can be deployed at any intersection regardless of the number of lanes, vehicles, or traffic complexity), but also significantly reduces the RSU’s transmit power while maintaining high message delivery success probability.

title: Comparative Study of Stator-mounted PM Machine with Forced Liquid Cooling
authors: G. B. Zhang, G. J. Li, K. L. Li
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper investigates the thermal performance of some stator-mounted permanent magnet (PM) machines under forced liquid cooling. For reference, a conventional surface-mounted PM (SPM) machine is also analyzed. Three typical stator-mounted topologies are considered: the doubly salient PM (DSPM), flux reversal PM (FRPM), and flux switching PM (FSPM) machines. Initial evaluation with a water-jacket system demonstrates that stator-mounted machines achieve lower magnet temperatures than the rotor-mounted SPM machine. The extended modular FSPM machine further benefits from the flux gaps between the stator segments, which enhance heat dissipation and make it especially effective for liquid cooling. Several advanced cooling strategies are then proposed, showing improved performance compared with the standard water-jacket due to increased contact area. Moreover, the modular FSPM design enables semi-flooded cooling by utilizing the flux gaps between stator segments as cooling channels. Under this approach, water is shown to be significantly more effective than oil as a coolant. The results also indicate that the optimal flux gap width for maximum cooling performance depends on both coolant properties and inlet conditions.

title: Low Threshold Voltage Temperature Coefficient Due to Thermal Stress in GaN-on-Diamond HEMTs
authors: Lei Huang, Qingzhi Wu, Shuman Mao, Yuechan Kong, Tangsheng Chen, Yuehang Xu
publish: IEEE Electron Device Letters
abstract: This letter demonstrates that GaN-on-diamond HEMTs can realize an ultralow threshold voltage temperature coefficient, substantially improving the thermal stability of GaN-based devices. The GaN-on-diamond HEMTs are fabricated using transfer process, and the DC I-V characteristics are measured and analyzed at different temperatures. The measured results show that a dV<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub>/dT of -0.2 mV/K can be achieved. To provide physical insight, Raman spectroscopy measurements are employed, showing that elevated temperatures induce tensile stress in the GaN channel layer due to the thermal lattice mismatch between GaN and diamond. This thermal stress modulates the piezoelectric polarization, thereby influencing the threshold voltage. Based on these findings, a threshold voltage model accounting for thermal stress is proposed. Validation of the model demonstrates its accuracy in characterizing both the threshold voltage and DC-IV characteristics across varying temperatures. These findings will be useful for high temperature GaN electronics.

title: SPP-MIM Hybridization Meta-Film: A Biosensing Structure Uniting the Merits of SPR and LSPR
authors: Chenjia He, Xiaqing Sun, Tian Yang
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Having a flat device-solution interface is crucial for nanophotonic biosensors to achieve stable and reproducible performance, by mitigating solid-liquid-gas interfacial processes at the nanometer scale. In this aspect, the metal-insulator-metal (MIM) film presents a capable solution, by hybridizing surface plasmon polaritons (SPP) and MIM gap plasmons, which is enabled by the latter's unique dispersion characteristic and wide tunability. In this meta-film, the SPPs propagate along a flat interface, and seal the gap plasmons which can be integrated with nanostructures, e.g., a coupling grating. In addition, by tuning the gap plasmons, the SPP-MIM hybridization meta-film can be designed to achieve a significantly reduced SPP evanescent depth and a significantly improved surface sensitivity. Using gold as the plasmonic material, such improvements are theoretically predicted across a broad spectral range, from visible to near infrared. Particularly, at 1550 nm, we show that a grating-coupled meta-film device is designed to have its evanescent depth shortened from 1.4 mm to 0.16 mm, with an enhancement factor of 5.6 in its surface sensitivity, as compared with traditional grating-coupled SPR. This unique characteristic of the SPP-MIM meta-film makes it an efficient combination of propagating SPR and LSPR, by simultaneously having a flat and simple biosensing interface, a short evanescent depth and a high surface sensitivity. It provides an inspiring approach for transforming various LSPR designs into stable biosensors.

title: On-Board Implementation of the Differential Thrust-Based Lateral-Directional Model Predictive Control in the Distributed Electric Propulsion Aircraft
authors: Bohua Liang, Peng Kou, Rui Guo, Zhihao He, Yuanhang Zhang, Deliang Liang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Distributed electric propulsion (DEP) technology has demonstrated significant potential due to its advantages in reducing carbon emissions, enhancing aerodynamic efficiency, and improving takeoff and landing performance. Moreover, DEP provides a hardware-level opportunity to integrate multiple propulsors into flight control, particularly for lateral-directional control. However, achieving this capability requires a multivariable optimal control approach to effectively coordinate both the propulsors and aerodynamic control surfaces. To address this challenge, this article proposes a model predictive control (MPC) scheme for lateral-directional control. Based on a linearized DEP flight dynamics model, the proposed MPC scheme enables dynamic optimal lateral-directional control for DEP aircraft. For the first time, the scheme has been implemented in both software and hardware using Jetson Orin and unmanned aerial vehicle (CUAV) autopilot running PX4 firmware. A DEP flight platform with eight electric propulsors, a wingspan of 1.8 m, and a cruise speed of 14 m/s is developed to integrate and validate the proposed control system. Flight tests demonstrate that the proposed scheme not only achieves dynamically optimal control but also satisfies real-time requirements.

title: Expression of Concern for: A Siamese Network-Based Approach for Autism Spectrum Disorder Detection with Dual Architecture
authors: Gulsum Yigit, Muazzez Buket Darici
publish: 2023 Innovations in Intelligent Systems and Applications Conference (ASYU)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a sophisticated neuro-developmental condition impacting numerous children. Early detection of ASD is crucial to implement suitable treatments to improve the daily activities of people with ASD. This paper introduces a system for ASD detection using facial images. The proposed model presents a unique system inspired by Siamese networks. Unlike traditional Siamese networks focusing on input pairs, our model leverages architectural pairs for feature combinations. During training, we combine features learned from different or the same architectures. This enables information transfer and improves the model’s capture of comprehensive patterns. Experimental results on the 2940 facial images dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our system, which exhibits improved accuracy compared to using individual architectures. When (ResNet50, VGG16) architecture pairs are employed in the proposed approach, the highest performance is obtained with an accuracy of 78.57%. Leveraging the strengths of multiple architectures, our model provides a comprehensive and robust representation of input data, leading to improved performance.

title: Fiber-Less, Large-Scale Opto-Electrophysiology Interface for Micro-Scale Interaction of Multiple Brain Regions
authors: Sungjin Oh, Jose Roberto Lopez Ruiz, Kanghwan Kim, Nathan Slager, Eunah Ko, Mihály Vöröslakos, Hyunsoo Song, Wangbo Chen, Sung-Yun Park, Euisik Yoon
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Objective: Recent neuroscientific research craves for understanding sophisticated brain networks formed by neuron ensembles across multiple regions. An ideal way to unveil the complex connectome is bidirectionally interacting (simultaneous recording and stimulation) with neurons at high spatiotemporal resolutions. Existing CMOS recording probes cannot provide micro-scale interactions with limited stimulation capability. Although optogenetics can achieve neuron-specific stimulation, conventional methods using optic fibers illuminate a large volume of tissue, resulting in unspecific perturbations. While our previous studies demonstrated micro-LED (μLED)-based optoelectrode for localized stimulation and recording, this work advances them into a fully integrated headstage combining the optoelectrode, CMOS IC, and flexible interposer for miniaturized implementation. The proposed system enables micro-scale interactions with high spatiotemporal precision through densely packed 256-neuron-size recording and 128-soma-size fiber-less opto-stimulation across multiple brain regions. Methods: Such high resolutions yet wide coverage is achieved by (1) advanced micromachining techniques integrating recording electrodes and μLEDs, (2) micro-second, independent 384-channel interaction via a low-power, area-efficient circuit, and (3) compact and reliable polyimide-cable-based hybrid assembly. Results: A compact (23.8×28.8 mm2) and lightweight (3.5-gram) headstage achieved the highest reported channel density in area (0.56 channels/mm2) and weight (109.71 channels/gram). A single acute in vivo experiment on a transgenic mouse identified >160 isolated pyramidal neurons and narrow/wide interneurons in the dorsal hippocampus, with local and broad-range effects from focal optogenetic stimulation. Conclusion and Significance: We implemented the hybrid integrated, large-scale opto-electrophysiology interface prototype and verified its feasibility in vivo, representing the first fully integrated platform extending our μLED-based probes into a complete system.

title: A survey on Control Plane Security Approaches in Software Defined Networks
authors: Mohammed Awwal Iliyasu, Azizol Abdullah, Zurina Mohd Hanapi, Normalia Samian
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The advent of Software-Defined Networking (SDN) has greatly helped in network infrastructure and enhancing network flexibility and scalability. By separating the control plane from the data plane and centralizing network management through an SDN controller, this centralization introduces critical security threats to the control plane. Thus, this centralization inherently presents substantial security challenges to the control plane. This research systematically investigates security countermeasures for the SDN control plane through a thorough analysis of extant literature. We evaluated the merits of proposed techniques and delineate their limitations. Our methodology emphasized on two main approaches: (1) authentication/authorization and (2) secure communication. The strengths and weaknesses of the reviewed solutions are critically examined, and salient issues and challenges pertinent to these approaches are underscored. These include, but are not limited to, the paucity of real-world validation for proposed techniques, the imperative for robust strategies to secure multi-controller environments, and the necessity to accelerate transaction speeds through optimized blockchain protocols or alternative consensus models. Furthermore, this study delineates prospective research directions to foster advancements in SDN control plane security and assist researchers in discerning emergent areas within this domain.

title: AdaptiveCore: Adaptive Parallel Core Decomposition Framework
authors: Chen Zhao, Zhigao Zheng, Hao Huang, Hao Liu, Dacheng Tao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computers
abstract: Core decomposition is a widely used hierarchical analysis algorithm for large-scale graphs. It achieves this decomposition by iteratively peeling the vertices along with their adjacency edges off into different hierarchies. With the timeliness requirements of modern applications, many researchers have introduced accelerators, particularly GPUs, to improve the computational efficiency of graph algorithms. However, the empty, sparse, and numerous hierarchies in large graphs lead to inefficient computation and parallelism, not only including unnecessary searching for the hierarchy’s vertices, but also significant thread wastage when peeling off the adjacency edges of these vertices. In this paper, we propose an adaptive parallel framework for core decomposition, named AdaptiveCore. First, it improves vertex searching efficiency by adaptively skipping the empty hierarchies and reducing the search space. Moreover, it greatly improves thread utilization by adaptively allocating the available threads to peel off the adjacency edges. Comprehensive experiments show that, compared with the state-of-the-art works, the proposed framework achieves an average speedup of 7.1× on the GPU platform and up to 2.0× on the multi-core CPU platform.
