title: Clutter Suppression Based on Spatial Polarimetric Spectral Characteristics of Airborne Animals for Weather Radar
authors: Rui Wang, Chen Zhang, Kai Cui, Cheng Hu, Zimo Yang, Dongli Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Weather radar is an effective means for large-scale monitoring of airborne animals. However, both ground clutter and meteorological echoes can interfere with biological echoes, affecting the quality of monitoring data. Current frequency-domain filtering methods can only suppress ground clutter, and clutter suppression techniques based on spectral polarization can suppress both ground clutter and moving non-weather targets, but neither of these can meet the requirements for biological monitoring. To enhance the quality of biological data, this study proposes the clutter suppression method based on spatial polarimetric spectral characteristics of airborne animals for biological monitoring. For ground clutter, based on the value jumps of the spectral polarimetric observables, the clutter range in the Doppler spectrum is determined, and the clutter is suppressed. For meteorological echoes, based on the continuity differences in spectral polarimetric observables, weather suppression is achieved by using the statistical differences of the observables obtained by using a sliding window in the range-Doppler spectrogram. The results indicate that the quality of biological data has been improved after applying the proposed method to radar data collected by operational S-band weather radar. Compared to other methods, the proposed method demonstrates the best performance in suppressing non-biological clutter while preserving airborne animals.

title: CamelEval: Advancing Benchmarks for Arabic Language Models in Generative Tasks
authors: Zhaozhi Qian, Faroq Altam, Muhammad Alqurishi, Ignacio Iacobacci, Abdulmalik Aldawsari, Riad Souissi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) serve as the foundation of contemporary artificial intelligence systems. Recently, a diverse range of Arabic-centric LLMs has emerged, and with them, a variety of evaluation suites, designed to assess the alignment of LLMs with the values and preferences of Arabic speakers and address their capabilities on instruction following, open-ended question answering, and information delivery. However, the majority of these suites rely exclusively on multiple-choice questions and, thereby, fail to adequately assess the text generation capabilities of LLMs. To address this shortcoming, we propose a new automated evaluation benchmark, CamelEval. CamelEval comprises three test suites to evaluate general instruction following, factuality, and cultural alignment. Each test suite contains 805 carefully curated challenging test cases that reflect the nuances of Arabic language and culture. We envision CamelEval as a tool to guide the development of future Arabic LLMs, serving over 400 million Arabic speakers by providing LLMs that not only communicate in their language but also understand their culture.

title: 8-Channel CMOS Chip for Real-Time Control of Integrated Silicon Photonic Processors
authors: Emanuele Sacchi, Francesco Zanetto, Andres Ivan Martinez, SeyedMohammad SeyedinNavadeh, Francesco Morichetti, Andrea Melloni, Marco Sampietro, Giorgio Ferrari
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Circuits and Systems
abstract: Photonic integrated circuits (PICs) allow to implement linear operations directly in the light domain, taking advantage of the extended bandwidth, low losses and minimal cross-talk associated with optical communication. These architectures benefit from the addition of dedicated electronics that enable run-time programmability, as well as closed-loop stabilization of the working point against drifts and turbulence. This work addresses the issue of the scalability, in terms of area and power consumption, of the electronic control layer, by proposing an application-specific integrated circuit (ASIC) designed for real-time reconfiguration of programmable optical processors. The CMOS controller features 8 independent channels, each one closing a feedback control loop around an integrated photonic interferometric device. In the experiments, a pair of ASICs was connected to a 16-channel binary mesh consisting of 15 Mach-Zehnder Interferometers fabricated in a commercial Silicon Photonics platform. The resulting electronic-photonic chiplet-like system successfully established reliable free-space optical (FSO) links up to 50 Gbit/s, compensating the effect of simulated atmospheric turbulence. The inherent ability of the ASIC to drive each photonic device independently, though, makes it suitable also for applications beyond sheer working point stabilization, whenever a full reconfiguration of the PIC is needed, achieving sub-10 ms settling time when starting from a random working point. The proposed integrated design thus paves the way for the definition of compact and seamlessly scalable electronic controllers for programmable PICs.

title: Scenario-Adaptive Design of Honeycomb Structures for EMP Protection via Dynamic Weighted Time-Domain Shielding Metrics_supp1-3640611.docx
authors: Xu-Qing Liu
publish: N/A
abstract: Conventional frequency-domain shielding effectiveness (SE) metrics fail to ensure reliable electromagnetic pulses (EMP) protection by neglecting transient effects (pulse peak distortion, rising edge degradation, energy accumulation). We propose a scenario-adaptive time-domain shielding effectiveness framework, integrating peak field strength, transient field derivative, and energy density SE into a combined metric SETD_com via entropy-based dynamic weighting. This methodology unifies material preparation, parameterization, finite difference time domain simulation, and validation, reducing design cycles by 67%. The optimized metal-coated aramid paper honeycomb achieves >97% absorption in 4–18 GHz, with average SETD_com 65.99 dB. Validated in chassis shields (12 iterations), curved radomes (≤0.4 dB angular fluctuation), and satellite cabins (86.7 dB SETD_com), it resolves the trilemma of transient characterization, multidevice adaptation, and computational efficiency for high-reliability EMP protection.

title: AddrProbe: An Internet-wide Active IPv6 Address Probing System with Limited Seeds_supp1-3645923.pdf
authors: Lin He
publish: N/A
abstract: With the large-scale deployment of IPv6, it is becoming more and more important to probe active IPv6 addresses on the global Internet. However, the vast address space and the random distribution of active addresses make the probing process full of challenges, especially for the probing of IPv6 prefixes without seed addresses. Furthermore, the widespread existence of IPv6 aliased prefixes also causes significant trouble for probing. In this paper, we present AddrProbe, an active IPv6 address probing system, which dynamically probes all global routing prefixes based on learned fine-grained address patterns from limited seed addresses and quickly detects aliased prefixes during probing. The evaluation results show that AddrProbe achieves a hit rate of 23%-45% with all routing prefixes announced by the BGP system, which is 6.6-13× that of current state-of-the-art approaches (no more than 4%). Moreover, we find 1.2×1033 aliased addresses characterized by the detected aliased prefixes, covering 6,412 routing prefixes, which is a 107× and 5.9× improvement over existing methods, respectively. Finally, an IPv6 Hitlist is constructed based on the long-term probing results, which contains 562M addresses covering 190K routing prefixes and 29K ASes. These widely distributed addresses are meaningful for analyzing IPv6 address assignments and some other IPv6 measurement activities.

title: A Unified Quantum Framework for Assignment Optimization in Network Administration
authors: Yong Hun Jang, Junyoung Hwang, Wookjin Lee, Hee Soo Kim, Sang Hyun Lee
publish: IEEE Communications Magazine
abstract: Future internet networks will assume central roles in orchestrating pervasive administration missions, seamlessly integrating vast connections, heterogeneous applications, and data-driven services. Realizing this vision hinges upon computational infrastructures capable of addressing diverse key performance indicators under stringent service- specific requirements. This article presents a comprehensive quantum strategy that reframes network administration as an assignment optimization paradigm, unifying multiple objectives and resource-utilization constraints. Unlike existing quantum approaches focused on discrete quantities, the proposed framework directly incorporates continuous- valued physical parameters into quantum computing parallelism, thereby enhancing adaptability and scalability for real-world network functions. Proof-of-concept quantum implementations demonstrate their potentials in key application domains, such as access control and resource management. Further discussion explores emerging research challenges and offers insights into structural design of quantum-assisted internet infrastructures.

title: Generative Autonomous Systems Topology Generator
authors: Caio V. Dadauto, Nelson L. S. da Fonseca, Ricardo da S. Torres
publish: IEEE Communications Magazine
abstract: Accurate modeling of Internet topologies is crucial for evaluating communication protocols and traffic control strategies. However, existing topology generators often rely on rigid, structure-oriented assumptions - such as scale-free models - and fail to capture key structural properties, including betweenness centrality, clustering, and assortativity. Moreover, most current tools offer limited usability and adaptability, with outdated implementations and minimal user interfaces. In this article, we present a novel software tool, Generator of Internet Autonomous Systems Topology (Gen-AS), which implements the Deep-generative graphs for the Internet (DGGI) model - a datadriven generator for Autonomous System (AS) graphs. DGGI learns topological patterns directly from data using deep learning, enabling it to replicate complex network properties without relying on predefined structural assumptions. Designed to be flexible and user-friendly, Gen- AS features a Command Line Interface (CLI) and a Graphic User Interface (GUI), making it accessible to a wide range of users. Experimental evaluations show that Gen-AS significantly outperforms existing topology generators, achieving average improvements of 93.22% in assortativity, 94.43% in betweenness centrality, 98.87% in clustering, and 95.09% in node degree distributions. These results, measured using the Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD) metric, highlight Gen-AS's effectiveness in producing realistic Internet topologies.

title: Influence of PWM Excitation on Loss and Temperature of Flat Wire Permanent Magnet Machines for Electric Vehicles
authors: Zhongze Wu, Xueyi Yan, Zhimian Wang, Wentao Zhang, Wei Hua
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The drive system of flat wire permanent magnet (PM) machines introduces harmonics into the machine system due to pulse width modulation (PWM) excitation, resulting in additional losses and temperature rise, which is investigated in this article. First, the spatial harmonic magnetic field-circuit coupling model is applied for analyzing the current PWM harmonics, and based on which the losses can be predicted by using finite element (FE). Then, the lumped parameter thermal model (LPTM) of the flat wire PM machine is established to predict the temperature rise of the machine under sinusoidal and PWM excitation, respectively, with two cooling conditions, including natural cooling and oil cooling being considered. The proposed methodology can achieve an accurate temperature prediction for the PWM-fed flat wire PM machine, and the absolute error of temperature prediction is <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{<4.5} \boldsymbol{{}^{\circ}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>C for both natural cooling and oil cooling conditions. It is found that the additional loss caused by PWM excitation has a stronger impact on the temperature rise on the machine under natural cooling than that under oil cooling, due to the better thermal dissipation capability of the latter one. Experiments are conducted to validate the improved prediction accuracy considering PWM excitation.

title: Order Reduction Output-Feedback Positioning System With Critically Damped Performance for Servo Drives With Variable Bandwidth Mechanism
authors: Seok-Kyoon Kim, Chao Xu, Choon Ki Ahn
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The proposed order reduction (OR) technique develops a model-independent observer and a proportional–integral (PI)-type speed controller to create a variable bandwidth-based critically damped output-feedback system. This requires three nominal parameters of the servo drive model. The main contributions are threefold: 1) the OR-based model-independent speed observer diagonalizes the estimation error dynamics with a low-pass filter as a subsystem; 2) the variable bandwidth mechanism in an analytic rule continuously updates the feedback gain, while limiting it to a feasible region; and 3) the OR-based PI-type speed controller drives the speed error to zero exponentially, ensuring the desired critically damped input–output behavior. An experimental study validates the system performance using a 500-W dynamometer as a prototype servo drive, indicating at least an 18<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\%}$</tex-math></inline-formula> improvement in performance.

title: Class-Aware Diversified Augmentation for Open-Set Single Domain Generalization_supp1-3645625.pdf
authors: Jian Hu
publish: N/A
abstract: In Open-Set Single Domain Generalization (OS-SDG), one only has access to a single labeled source domain for training. It assumes that the learned model generalizes well to target samples belonging to the source label space whilst classifies target samples outside the source label space into a single “unknown” class. The current method synthesizes new samples that are semantically unrelated to known classes to simulate target unknown classes. This ignores that unknown classes actually may semantically correlated to known classes, making it difficult to discriminate samples at the margins of class decision boundaries as “unknown”. In this work, we introduce a Class-Aware Diversified Augmentation (CADA) method to overcome this problem. Our key idea is to synthesize explicitly new multiple unknown target classes with diversified semantic and learn the inherent correlation among the known and unknown classes, so to both increase the coverage of multiple target unknown classes and to optimize class margin separation. CADA is optimized by enhanced diversity maximization and class-aware minimization. The former synthesizes more novel classes by considering both semantic relationships to known classes and domain shift between the source and target domains. The latter employs class-agnostic clustering with synthesized samples to simulate class correlations among target classes, maximizing class margin separation. Theoretical analysis and experiments on five benchmarks show the efficacy of our CADA.

title: Inertia Support Strategy for Wind Turbine Based on Switched Operating Points with Equivalent Time Constant
authors: Jin Li, Ting An, Yuehong Zhou, Haiyan Zhao
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The wind Turbine adopts Virtual Synchronous Generator (VSG) control to support grid frequency by releasing their energy reserve. However, the interaction between the maximum power point tracking (MPPT) control and VSG control will weaken their inertia response capability. Therefore, this paper proposes an inertia support strategy for wind turbine based on switching operation point with equivalent time constant. Firstly, the inertia support characteristics of the wind turbine under VSG and MPPT are analyzed. Then, an equivalent time constant is employed to characterize the inertia support capability of wind turbines. In the initial stage of inertia response, the proposed method temporarily suspends MPPT control to release rotor kinetic energy as much as possible. During the inertia response period, wind turbine will change its operation state according to the curve determined by the equivalent time constant. During the recovery stage, the proposedmethod restricts the change of rotor speed to ensure that the kinetic energy recovery comes from wind energy entirely. According to the simulation results, the frequency nadir increases by 0.06Hz and the rotor speed nadir decreases by 1.21%. Besides, the rate-of-change-of-frequency has also been improved.

title: Federated Big Data Analytics for Enhancing Real-Time Business Intelligence and Optimizing Performance in Enterprises
authors: Rajkumar Bhola, Shalini Agarwal, P. Deivanai, Rohit Markan, Sajiv G, M. Karthik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Traditional centralized approaches, however, has some issues with data privacy, scalability, and latency that limit decision making and operation optimization. Traditional, centralized approaches, however, bring many problems, including data privacy, and scalability, as well as latency, for decision-making and the operation of a business. Future work can be addressed to enhance the robustness of the model and further adaption of the models besides questions regarding implementation of the models. The main use case is a way to perform aggregations across various enterprise nodes and process big data without having to centralize it. This research brings innovation into the following aspects of federated learning: manner of deployment to achieve low-latency; the state-of-the-art privacy-preserving approaches such as differential privacy, and evaluation of business cases on the introduced methodologies. A comprehensive concept level framework is designed such that the accuracy is nearly 98 % for prediction of sales, customer churn study and stock management through federated analytics. The outcome shows that the proposed system results to lower communication overhead and latency times, and offers real-time insights without compromising on the privacy of the data. by several pilot studies undertaken in real enterprises and analyzed in this thesis, it is ascertained that the proposed framework is capable of functioning in a distributed manner across the nodes and enhancing the decision-making and operating performance. In conclusion, this study aims at presenting federated learning as a tool for the modern enterprise that allows for the development of a scalable, privacy-preserving solution for real-time BI. Further work will involve improving on the above models, as well as a look on the practical aspect of the techniques that has been proposed.

title: In-Situ Determination of Battery State of Health Considering the Remaining Capacity in Electric Vehicles - A Case Study
authors: Tobias Felix Scholz, Friedbert Pautzke, Benedikt Schmuelling
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The battery pack’s capacity is a crucial factor in determining the range of an electric vehicle (EV) and significantly influences purchase decisions. Over time, battery degradation reduces this capacity, making it essential for consumers, insurance companies, and leasing providers to assess the remaining battery State of Health (SOH). This is particularly relevant for used EVs, where battery condition directly affects resale value and usability. Given the non-linear aging behavior of battery packs, influenced by environmental conditions and usage patterns, accurately determining the SOH remains a challenge. This study compares various in-situ methods for estimating SOHC using a Peugeot iOn, analyzing real-world driving and charging data over three years, and about 2850 kilometers. The findings aim to bridge the gap between laboratory-based assessments and practical, in-situ estimations of SOHc, facilitating better decision-making for stakeholders.

title: AI-Based Early Detection of Migraines Using a Fusion Machine Learning Model
authors: Yuliya Daroshka, Md Abu Sayeed
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Migraine is a neurological disorder characterized by unpredictable and often severe attacks that can seriously disrupt daily life. Although some people experience an aura as an early warning, others miss the opportunity to get timely treatment. This research investigates the potential for migraine detection from Electroencephalogram (EEG) signals recorded from temporal lobe electrodes. A novel AI-based dual-branch fusion model has been proposed that leverages a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) trained on engineered EEG features alongside a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) trained on spectrogram representations of the same signals. This hybrid model takes advantage of both structured and unstructured data modalities to improve predictive accuracy. The experimental findings indicate that the fusion model offers an accuracy of 95%, which makes it a potential candidate for biomedical applications. The proposed approach lay a foundation for future neurotechnology that is capable of identifying EEG patterns in migraine and other related neurological conditions, contributing to the advancement of AIdriven diagnostic tools in smart healthcare.

title: Research status of key technologies and challenges in Solar Array Drive Assembly
authors: Hongfei Li, Xiaoping Gao
publish: 2025 Low-Altitude Economy Forum &amp; International Conference on Low-Altitude Flight Technology and Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Application (LEF &amp; ICLU)
abstract: The Solar Array Drive Assembly (SADA) serves as the power source for spacecraft such as satellites. Its function is to ensure that the solar cell array can capture sunlight for power generation with maximum efficiency. Future satellites are trending towards lighter weight, higher integration, and greater functional density. This paper summarizes the key technologies and technical challenges in recent years, including those related to drive motors, control technologies, conductive slip rings, and mechanical transmissions. Meanwhile, it presents an outlook on the development of conductive slip rings, drive motors, and shape memory alloys in the future. It points out the highly promising development directions of permanent magnet synchronous motors, liquid metal slip rings, and shape memory alloys (SMA).

title: Metaheuristic AI-Optimized Buck-Boost Converter for Efficient V2G and G2V Power Exchange in Electric Vehicles
authors: Bachina Harish Babu, Vanama Sri Man Pavan Murari, Sri Raman Kothuri, G. Soniya Priyatharsini, M Kiran Kumar, Sudhir Kumar Sangula
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The integration of electric vehicles (EVs) into modern power systems requires efficient and reliable bidirectional power converters to support Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) and Grid-to-Vehicle (G2V) operations. This paper proposes a Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO)-based Buck-Boost converter that enhances both transient response and power quality compared to conventional PI and heuristic controllers. The GWO algorithm is employed to optimally tune control parameters, ensuring improved voltage regulation, faster dynamic response, and reduced harmonic distortion. Simulation studies demonstrate that the proposed controller achieves 96.8% efficiency, reduces current ripple by 18%, and shortens settling time by 22% relative to PI control. Furthermore, harmonic analysis confirms a significant reduction in higher-order harmonics, lowering the Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) and ensuring grid-compliant power exchange. These results establish the GWO-optimized Buck-Boost converter as a robust and practical solution for EV charging and discharging processes, while simultaneously supporting grid stability and sustainable smart grid development.

title: Advanced Mutation Testing with Zero and Few-Shot Evaluation Using GPT-V4
authors: Arshia Hemmat, Fatame Aghababaei, Mohammadreza Sharbaf, Shekoufeh Kolahdouz-Rahimi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: In the pursuit of software reliability, mutation testing plays a critical role in evaluating and enhancing the efficacy of test suites. However, a pervasive challenge in this domain is generating optimal mutations that align with the existing test cases, often resulting in inadequate coverage of the codebase. This gap leads to missed opportunities to identify potential faults and weaknesses in software, undermining the robustness of test suites. In this paper, we propose a novel approach utilizing the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) to identify a diverse array of mutations tailored to thoroughly probe different segments of the code, thereby ensuring comprehensive coverage. By leveraging LLMs, we generate mutations that are not only varied but also contextually relevant to the given code and test suites. This method facilitates the generation of mutations that are more likely to be ‘killed’ by the test suites, significantly increasing the number of detected faults. This, in turn, leads to a deeper understanding of the code's behavior and the enhancement of the overall quality of the software testing process. Our findings indicate a substantial improvement in test suite effectiveness, showcasing the power of AI in advancing software engineering practices.

title: Integrated Optimization of Demand-Side Management and Battery Storage in a Microgrid for Cost-Effective and Reliable Operation
authors: Duy C. Huynh, Hieu M. Pham, Khai H. Nguyen, Loc D. Ho, Matthew W. Dunnigan, Corina Barbalata
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: This paper proposes an integrated scheduling framework for demand-side management (DSM) and battery energy storage systems (BESS) in renewable energy-integrated microgrids to achieve cost-effective and reliable operation. A novel water wave optimization (WWO) algorithm is developed to minimize total operating cost while ensuring load satisfaction, operational constraints, and renewable variability. The optimization model simultaneously determines the optimal dispatch of DSM, BESS, grid power, and diesel generator (DG), while maintaining strict hourly power balance and zero energy not supplied (ENS). The WWO algorithm emulates the dynamic behavior of ocean waves—propagation, refraction, and breaking—to navigate complex solution spaces with rapid convergence. Simulation results over a 24-hour horizon demonstrate that the WWO-based strategy achieves superior performance compared to a genetic algorithm (GA), a non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm (NSGA-II), and a particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm, with a 25.2% cost reduction over the GA and convergence within 83 iterations. The results validate the potential of DSM-BESS coordination and metaheuristic optimization for efficient, reliable, and sustainable microgrid operations.

title: Decentralized Blockchain-Driven Urban Parking System with IOTA for Management, Reservation, and Payment Integration in Smart Cities
authors: Hala Ben Ali, Lujain Amro, Salahaldin Abukhalaf, Anastassia Gharib
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Inefficient urban parking is a major problem in modern cities, resulting in lost time, increased fuel usage, and higher pollution. Conventional parking systems, which depend on centralized databases, have drawbacks including high operating costs, single points of failure, and tampering. In order to create a safe, open, and effective solution, we propose a decentralized smart parking system that integrates the IOTA blockchain technology. Through smart contract capabilities of the IOTA Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) test network, we enable reduced fees, decentralized storage of real-time Internet of Things (IoT) sensor data, and provide tamper-proof reservations and payments. Users may see parking availability and make reservations thanks to a user-friendly interface that facilitates smooth interactions with the blockchain technology and the smart parking system. We also compare the performance of IOTA with Ethereum. For this purpose, we utilize the Ethereumbased Sepolia test network. Results demonstrate the potential of IOTA to revolutionize urban parking management by enhancing security and reducing costs, improving the overall efficiency.

title: ScriptAdaptNet: A Deep Learning Framework for Cross-Script Diacritic Error Correction in Telugu, Kannada and Devanagari Handwritten Text Recognition
authors: Triveni Banavatu, Govindaswamy Parthasarathy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: This paper presents a novel solution to the persistent challenge of unintentional Double Vattulu (diacritic duplication) errors in South Indian language document digitization. We propose ScriptAdaptNet, an end-to-end deep learning system combining vision transformers with scriptspecific attention mechanisms for accurate detection and correction of diacritic errors across Telugu, Kannada and Devanagari scripts. Our architecture features: (1) a multi-scale feature extraction module capturing script-specific diacritic patterns, (2) a hybrid CNN-Transformer network with parallel script identification, and (3) a linguistically-constrained correction module preserving valid character combinations. We introduce the Diacritic Bench dataset containing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 8, 4 2 3}$</tex> annotated word samples across three scripts, representing diverse handwriting styles and intentional duplication cases. Experimental results demonstrate state-of-the-art performance with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 6. 2 \%}$</tex> correction accuracy, reducing diacritic errors by 29.7 % compared to existing OCR systems while maintaining 98.1 % accuracy on nonduplicated characters. The system processes 31 words/second on an average, making it practical for large-scale digitization projects. Our analysis reveals significant cross-script variations in diacritic error patterns, necessitating the proposed script-adaptive approach. This study presents technical approaches and linguistic approaches for the preservation of written heritages in South Asia through accurate digitization of text in the written codes. Keywords- Diacritic error correction, Multi-script OCR, Handwritten text recognition, Double Vattulu, South Indian languages, Script adaptive deep learning, Vision transformers, Digitization of documents, Cultural heritage preservation, Indic scripts.

title: Development of a Smart Streetlight Control and Monitoring System
authors: A.S.O. Ogunjuyigbe, T.R. Ayodele, K.I. Wakeel, R O. Olarewaju, T. C Mosetlhe, A. A Yusuff
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: This paper proposes a cost-effective smart street lighting system designed to minimize power consumption and optimize energy efficiency. Street lights act as a source of light during the night to facilitate night vision, improve security and prevent accidents. The system incorporates a cloud-based platform for monitoring and controlling the streetlights remotely, enabling real-time updates and diagnostics. One of the key features of the system is its ability to dynamically adjust the brightness of streetlights based on traffic density and real-time factors such as the presence of vehicles, pedestrian activity, and environmental conditions. During hours of low traffic, the lights operate in a dimmed state to conserve energy. However, when motion is detected, whether from vehicles or pedestrians, the lights automatically increase to full brightness, ensuring optimal visibility and safety. This dynamic control mechanism not only ensures optimal lighting but also contributes to significant energy savings by reducing unnecessary illumination during periods of low activity.

title: Symbolic Sequence Frameworks for Ultra-High Fidelity with Hierarchical Representation in Multi-Stage Processing Pipelines
authors: Aarav Kannan J, R. Rajalakshmi, G. Kavitha, Gracelin Sheena, P.Sardar Maran, Beschi I S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: This outstanding research has paved a unique approach of context processing with the use of LLM in leveraging advanced characteristics of sequences. Algorithms like machine learning and other integrative tools has predominantly outlined the application of neural language processing. The feasibility measures of the model system are showcased with the help of evaluation metrics by integrating multi-stage processing pipelines. Integrative tools like T5 for sequence generation, GPT 4 for sequence creation and BERT for sequence identification are utilized. In addition, metric scores like ROUGE and METEOR scores are significantly employed for analyzing the model performance.

title: Joint Research on Partial Differential Equation Solving and Computer Simulation Technology In Electromagnetic Field Numerical Simulation
authors: Xiaolei Zhang, Zengrong Zhang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Many in the mathematical community study partial differential equations (PDEs), which are essential yet often difficult to solve analytically. Due to the lack of general analytical tools, numerical methods are widely used, though researchers continue exploring new approaches. Deep learning has recently achieved remarkable success in areas like image classification and natural language processing, and its application to PDEs is gaining attention. Deep neural networks have proven highly effective at function approximation, making them promising tools for solving PDEs. A growing interdisciplinary field is using deep learning to tackle PDEs in engineering and physics. Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) have emerged as a standard method by embedding physical laws directly into the learning process. This study presents a PINN-based framework enhanced by analytical insights and electromagnetic domain knowledge. It applies the method to electromagnetic field problems using Maxwell, wave, diffusion, and Laplace equations. PINNs accurately reproduce physical behaviors, aligning well with theoretical solutions. By incorporating PDE-based physical information as a regularizing term, PINNs improve neural network performance. This study also evaluates the wave, KdV-Burgers, and KdV equations. Experimental results confirm that PINNs are highly effective for solving PDEs and warrant further research in scientific computing.

title: Implementation of Single Shot Detector Method: Smoking Detection in No Smoking Area
authors: Andi Riansyah, Ahmad Tri Yulianto, Noorminshah A. Iahad, Muhammad Qomaruddin, Moch Taufik, Laksita Kusuma Wardhani
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Cigarettes are harmful consumer products containing over 7,000 chemicals, including at least 60 known carcinogens. Smoking is a major cause of heart disease, lung cancer, and emphysema. Although smoking rates have declined over the past 50 years, tobacco smoke exposure still affects approximately 37% of the global population and contributes to 1.3 million of the 8 million tobacco-related deaths annually. In response, governments have implemented regulations to restrict smoking by designating smoke-free zones. However, limited enforcement has resulted in frequent violations. Therefore, surveillance systems capable of detecting smoking activity are essential to support compliance with these regulations. In this study, a smoking detection model was developed using the Single Shot Detector (SSD) method with VGG16 as the feature extractor. The model was trained over 60 epochs using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.00003 and a batch size of 4. Experimental results demonstrated that at a threshold of 0.5, the model achieved outstanding performance, with 97.5% accuracy, 97.4% precision, 100% recall, and a 98.7% F1-score. While performance decreased at higher thresholds, the model maintained exceptionally high precision up to a threshold of 0.9, though recall and F1-score dropped significantly. In conclusion, the SSD-based smoking detection model with VGG16 has proven to be an effective and accurate tool for identifying smoking activity in restricted areas. With its ability to detect objects reliably under varying lighting and environmental conditions, the model holds strong potential for integration into automated surveillance systems to enhance smoke-free zone enforcement.

title: Dynamic Task Scheduling and Smart Caching in Fog-Cloud Architectures Using Advantage Actor-Critic Agents
authors: Mohammad Hassan Nataj Solhdar, Mohamad Mehdi Esnaashari
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: In this work, we introduce History-aware Scheduling and Caching with Advantage Actor-Critic (HiSC-A2C), a novel dual-agent reinforcement learning framework designed for efficient task scheduling and intelligent result caching in fog–cloud computing environments. By decoupling the decision processes for task execution and caching, our method leverages two independent Advantage Actor-Critic (A2C) agents: one selects the optimal node for executing each task, while the other determines the most suitable location for caching results, taking into account task frequency, data freshness, and user proximity. This history-aware approach enables the system to adapt dynamically to fluctuating workloads and heterogeneous network conditions, ensuring that frequently requested tasks are cached closer to end users and resources are utilized efficiently. Extensive simulation results demonstrate that HiSCA2C significantly reduces response latency and enhances computational efficiency compared to existing methods, including A3C-R2N2 and DDQN. By integrating historical task data and decoupling scheduling from caching, our framework provides a scalable and robust solution for real-time service delivery in distributed fog–cloud infrastructures.

title: Real Time Steering Angle Estimation Using Monocular Depth Profiling and 1D Free Space Analysis
authors: Aditya Ranjan, Diptanshu Kumar, Gnanendra Naidu N, Maheshkumar, B Sathish Babu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Autonomous navigation systems traditionally rely on expensive sensor arrays such as LiDAR or stereo cameras to perceive their environment and make steering decisions. We propose a novel, cost effective approach that uses a monocular camera and deep learning-based depth estimation to generate steering commands in real time. Our method employs the Depth-Anything-V2 model to create depth maps from single RGB images, followed by a computationally efficient 1D free space analysis algorithm that identifies navigable paths. By analyzing a region of interest in the lower portion of the frame and computing a 1D profile of the depth information, we determine optimal steering angles with minimal computational overhead. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach achieves comparable performance to more complex systems while operating at 10–15 frames per second on consumer hardware. The system shows particular promise for low cost autonomous vehicles, mobile robots, and advanced driver assistance systems where traditional depth sensors are impractical due to cost, size, or power constraints.

title: SentinelShield - DDoS Detection and Mitigation System
authors: Rahul R Raiker, Rishit Bist, Saarthi Bhatia, Jyoti Shetty
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks present a critical threat to online service availability, often leading to significant disruptions. Conventional defense mechanisms frequently struggle to adapt to the evolving and complex landscape of attack vectors. This paper introduces Sentinel Shield, a real-time DDoS detection and mitigation framework that leverages statistical analysis and traffic profiling to overcome these limitations. The system establishes normal traffic baselines from a simulated environment, enabling high-fidelity anomaly detection. A key contribution is an interactive dashboard for live monitoring and visualization of network threats. Experimental validation demonstrates that SentinelShield achieves a detection accuracy of over 95%, successfully identifying both volumetric and protocol-based attacks in real time. By integrating accurate detection with an intuitive visualization interface, SentinelShield offers a scalable and effective solution for modern security operations.

title: Intelligent Model-Driven Engineering for IoT: Challenges and Future Directions
authors: Delaram Nikbakht Nasrabadi, Mohammad-Sajad Kasaei, Mohammadreza Sharbaf
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: Developing complex Internet of Things (IoT) systems is challenging due to heterogeneity and scalability demands. While Model-Driven Engineering (MDE) offers abstraction and automation, Artificial Intelligence (AI) provides adaptive intelligence. Their integration, Intelligent MDE for IoT (IMDE4IoT), is emerging but fragmented. This paper presents a systematic review of 13 primary studies to consolidate research in this area. We find that machine learning is the primary AI technique used to enhance IoT design and deployment. Key challenges include integration complexity and scalability. Based on our analysis, we identify critical research gaps and propose future directions, such as developing hybrid AI techniques and standardized frameworks, to advance the field.

title: Basic consideration on Effects of Voltage and Frequency Control by Demand-side Batteries on System Stability in Urban Area
authors: Moe Iizuka, Satoshi Sakurai, Orie Sakamoto
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: In this study, the impact of demand-side batteries with voltage and frequency control on an urban distribution grid with high penetration of photovoltaic generation was analyzed. The target system is an urban grid with a scale of 28,000 households. The batteries in the detached housing area were equipped with voltage control and those in the large buildings and apartments areas were equipped frequency control. The analysis focused on time with large PV output fluctuations, and stability was evaluated using power flow analysis, eigenvalue analysis, and the voltage stability index (Sys Index). As a result, it was confirmed that the batteries for voltage control can adjust the node voltage, and that the Sys Index improved as the voltage targe value was set higher, while eigenvalue analysis indicated lower voltage target value enhance stability. In addition, the introduction of batteries for frequency control significantly reduced system frequency deviations and the effectiveness increased in proportion to the storage capacity.

title: CNN-Driven Adaptive Encryption Framework for Securing Surveillance Videos Against Evolving Threats
authors: Lalita Nayak, Asha Ambhaikar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: This This paper proposes a novel Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)-based adaptive encryption framework to secure surveillance videos, addressing the rising challenges posed by dynamic security threats such as frame tampering, synthetic content injection, and unauthorized access. The framework integrates CNNs to classify video content into risk categories (normal, sensitive, high-risk), and dynamically adjusts encryption schemes based on these classifications. Lowrisk frames are encrypted using lightweight AES-128 encryption, while high-risk frames are protected with robust RSA encryption, ensuring computational efficiency without compromising security. A frame-linked key management system is also implemented, providing strong, non-predictable keys for each session. The system is evaluated on several datasets, including the VIRAT Aerial Video Dataset and UCSD Anomaly Dataset, demonstrating high performance in terms of encryption/decryption time, classification accuracy, and resistance to various attacks. The proposed framework achieves a high level of adaptability, with significant improvements over conventional encryption methods in realtime surveillance video protection.

title: Hybrid Naval Combat Generative Adversarial Networks - XGBoost Framework for Adversary Recognition in Naval Combat Scenarios
authors: Ashok Polavarapu, Manisha Guduri, Martin Margala
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Unmanned Surface Vehicles (USVs) play a crucial role in modern naval combat, supporting applications such as environmental monitoring and enemy detection. However, building reliable machine learning (ML) models for autonomous navigation and obstacle recognition is challenged by the limited availability of diverse real-world maritime datasets, particularly in extreme weather and lighting conditions. Manual data collection is expensive and time-consuming. To overcome this, we propose Naval Combat Generative Adversarial Networks (NCGAN), a novel approach to generate realistic synthetic images for day and night scenarios. This method significantly improves the dataset size and diversity, streamlining the process of training for ML models. NCGAN performance is evaluated through generator/discriminator losses, as well as identity, adversarial, and cycle-consistency losses. Synthetic data, combined with real images, is used to train an XGBoost classifier for enemy ship detection, with a K-fold cross-validation achieving an accuracy of 0.783. This research demonstrates that GAN-generated data can effectively complement limited real-world datasets, advancing the autonomy and operational effectiveness of USVs.

title: Enhancing Neuroblastoma Diagnosis with Support Vector Machines: A Predictive Approach Using Davide Chicco's Neuroblastoma EHR Dataset
authors: Monika Singh T, K Selvakumar, Kishor Kumar Reddy C
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Neuroblastoma, a highly aggressive childhood cancer, is primarily staged based on imaging and clinical assessments. Accurate staging is crucial for determining the prognosis and treatment plan for affected children. Traditional methods for staging neuroblastoma are time-consuming, subjective, and prone to error. Limited experimental studies have evaluated deep neural networks for neuroblastoma prediction, and existing findings are inconsistent. Neuroblastoma prediction methods include clinical assessment, imaging techniques (CT, MRI, PET), genetic testing (e.g., MYCN amplification), and biomarker analysis (e.g., VMA, HVA). Artificial Intelligence(AI), Machine Learning(ML), and risk stratification models further assist in prognosis and treatment planning. This investigation employs a Support Vector Machine (SVM) model on clinical and genetic attributes from the Davide Chicco's Neuroblastoma EHR Dataset Repository facilitated through feature scaling via min-max normalization, one-hot encoding of categorical variables, label encoding for binary features, and SMOTE for class balancing. To evaluate the model, the dataset was divided into 70 % for training and 30 % for testing. The Support Vector Machine model delivered 85% accuracy, 85% precision, 81.2% recall, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$76.3 \% \mathrm{F} 1$</tex> score surpassing alternative approaches, Logistic Regression (LR), Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM), Random Forest (RF), Naive Bayes (NB), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Artificial Nearest Neighbor (ANN).

title: Empowering Schools with Artificial Intelligence and Vedic Values to Prevent Bullying in Gen Z Learners
authors: Sachin Sharma, Piyush Agarwal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Bullying affects students both mentally and emotionally and can be a widespread issue in educational settings globally. To understand this matter, the integration of innovative and social methods has recently been investigated. This research presents an innovative approach to developing an anti-bullying support system for smart schools that combines Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques with Vedic cultural principles. Through the examination and identification of bullying events in real-time utilizing various information sources, including social media, text messages, and surveillance cameras. The system can accurately categorize incidents of bullying by employing computer vision and natural language processing techniques to recognize patterns, identify aggressive behavior, and detect bullying events. Teachers, supporters, and educational organizations can intervene in real-time thanks to this monitoring, ensuring prompt action to prevent further harm.

title: A Novel Deep Learning-Based Framework for Real-Time Cyber Threat Detection and Prevention Using Network Traffic Analysis and Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Jogender Singh, Nitin Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The fast growth of internet-connected devices has made the cyber landscape more complicated and presents new challenges for security experts seeking intelligent and real-time solutions to combat these threats. Presently, this framework suggests a whole new structure for deep learning (DL) that uses analysis of network traffic, and machine learning (ML) techniques to detect and stop cyber threats. The model analyses network traffic and classifies malicious behaviour using an ensemble of models such as Random Forest, SVM, XGBoost, LSTM, and CNN-LSTM. The proposed architecture's performance is validated through extensive tests on reference datasets with a validation accuracy of 97.89% for the CNN-LSTM model. The proposed architecture's robustness is demonstrated by key metrics such as precision, recall, F1score, and ROC-AUC, and its usability as real-time approach is demonstrated by testing latency and memory requirements. The suggested structure is a dependable answer to contemporary cybersecurity issues because it also demonstrates significant resilience to adversarial attempts.

title: A Design of Octagonal Shaped Pentaband Microstrip Patch Antenna for Wireless Applications
authors: Basavaraju Y D, Kumaraswamy H V
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: An innovative and efficient method for developing a miniature five-band microstrip patch antenna for usage in wireless applications is described in this paper. Five different bands— <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.5 \text{GHz}, 5 \text{GHz}, 9 \text{GHz}, 13.5 \text{GHz}$</tex>, and 23 GHz—are used by the suggested antenna. The antenna was designed to be 37 mm long and 22 mm wide, using FR4 Epoxy Substrate material with a permittivity of 4.4 and a thickness of 1.6 mm. The antenna's radiation has been improved by a defected ground structure. To enhance the antenna performance, this antenna utilizes a slotted octagonal patch with four octagonal radiating structures. in relation to the obtained results, the suggested antenna exhibits better return loss for each of the five frequencies, which are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.5 \text{GHz}, 5 \text{GHz}, 9 \text{GHz}, 13.5 \text{GHz}$</tex>, and 23 GHz, in that order. The antenna's measured gains are 5.87 dB at 13.5 GHz, which is the highest gain attained, and an average of 4dB at other bands. The HFSS simulations shows an overall radiation efficiency of over 86%. The suggested antenna is designed to function well in five different frequency ranges: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.5 \text{GHz}, 5 \text{GHz}, 9 \text{GHz}, 13.5 \text{GHz}$</tex>, and 23 GHz. These bands, which cover applications like radar, satellite communication, and molecular spectroscopy, support important wireless standards such as S-band WiMAX technology (3.5 GHz), the C-band WLAN (5.0 GHz), X-band spectrum <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(8-12 \text{GHz})$</tex>, Lower KU band, and Middle K bands. All things taken into account, this antenna design has potential benefits in terms of weight, size, cost of fabrication, and efficiency, which qualifies it for wireless applications.

title: LiNiO2-Based Coin Cell Supercapacitor for Low-Power Sensor Applications
authors: Vedanth R Bhat, Prateeksha Praveen Kamath, Mohammad Abdul Rahman Ashraf, Shwetha K.P., Sudha Kamath M.K.
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: In this study, a lithium nickel oxide (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LiNiO}_{2}$</tex>) based coin cell supercapacitor was synthesized and integrated with a DHT11 temperature and humidity sensor powered via Arduino Uno. The active electrode material was synthesized using a solution combustion method and characterized by XRD, Raman spectroscopy, BET surface area analysis, and electrochemical techniques including <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{C V}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{C P}$</tex>. The assembled symmetric coin cell delivered a stable output voltage of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\square 1.7 ~\mathrm{V}$</tex>, and four such cells in series provided 8 V to power the sensor for approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5}-\mathbf{6}$</tex> seconds per cycle. The device demonstrated a specific capacitance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$52.5 ~\mathrm{F} / \mathrm{g}$</tex>, with an energy density of 6.24 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Wh} / \text{kg}$</tex> and power density of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$499 ~\mathrm{W} / \text{kg}$</tex>, rapid charge-discharge behavior, low internal resistance, and structural stability, confirming its suitability for compact energy storage in biomedical and environmental sensing applications.

title: Reconfigurable Scattering Patterns in Low RCS Antenna for Millimeter Wave Applications
authors: Likith S, Kumaraswamy H V, Nagaraju P
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and CST Studio Suite simulation of a 2-bit reconfigurable rectangular microstrip patch antenna with frequency agility and scattering pattern control for millimeter-wave and stealth applications. The antenna employs four PIN diodes around a rectangular slot and a defected ground structure (DGS), enabling independent control of radiation and scattering. The substrate used is Rogers RO3003 (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varepsilon r=3.0, \mathrm{h}=1.524 \text{mm}, \tan \delta=0.0013$</tex>). It operates from 3-13 GHz with distinct multi band responses for All-ON, All- OFF, and hybrid switching states. Full-wave CST simulations show S11 <−10 dB and VSWR <2 at target resonances. The All-ON state provides wideband multimode operation; the All-OFF state narrows operation to higher bands; and the hybrid states allow selective frequency allocation. The integrated DGS improves bandwidth, impedance matching, and suppresses unwanted surface waves, supporting miniaturization and low RCS performance. Radiation results from CST confirm main lobe directivity up to 7.03 dBi with side lobes below −5.2 dB, aiding RCS reduction. These features make the antenna suitable for multi-standard wireless, cognitive radio, and stealth platforms, combining reconfigurable tuning with stealth-enhancing techniques for next generation mmWave communications and defense systems.

title: Modeling of Short-Circuit Faults and Estimation of Arc Discharge Energy in Motor Drive Circuits
authors: Kengo Nagai, Koichi Shigematsu, Yota Omizu, Jun Imaoka, Masayoshi Yamamoto, Takashi Usui, Yasutaka Negishi, Tomoyuki Goto
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The electrification of vehicles has increased the operating voltage of automotive electric compressors, raising concerns about the self-decomposition of HFO refrigerants. This study models the current and voltage waveforms of arc discharges during phase-to-phase short circuits and quantitatively evaluates the resulting discharge energy. Compressor parameters obtained through teardown were incorporated into a motor drive circuit model including overcurrent protection (OCP). Shortcircuit tests conducted at 300 V and 400 V with motor speeds ranging from 850 to 3500 rpm showed that discharge energy increases with voltage but remains unaffected by motor speed. Simulation results were consistent with experimental data, confirming the validity of the model.

title: Cluster-Based Behavioral Analysis of Electric-Bus Charging Processes
authors: Mina Eskander, Amra Jahic, Maik Plenz, Edvard Avdevicius, Detlef Schulz
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Efficient management of electric-bus charging is essential for fleet operations and grid integration. This study applies a cluster-based analysis to real-world charging data, filtered to include complete sessions ranging from $\boldsymbol{\geqslant} \mathbf{8 0}$ to $\mathbf{9 8 \%}$ state of charge (SoC). It applies time-series clustering to analyze the charging behavior using Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) kmeans and OPTICS algorithms. Charging power curves aligned by state of charge (SoC) reveal distinct charging patterns, with cluster selection guided by silhouette, Calinski-Harabasz, and Davies-Bouldin indices. Statistical tests (ANOVA and KruskalWallis) identify power variability, mean power, and end-ofcharge tapering as key features distinguishing clusters. Densitybased clustering Ordering Points To Identify Clustering Structure (OPTICS-DBSCAN) additionally isolates atypical sessions as noise. Results offer insights into electric buses charging strategies and support smarter infrastructure and fleet management.

title: Enhancing AI Integration in HRM with Ethical Transparency Adaptive Models and Workforce Readiness
authors: Joel Osei-Asiamah, Vijaya Maruthi Babu Vedantam, Jillellamoodi Naga Madhuri, Narinder Kumar Bhasin, Sajiv G, B Kiran Bala
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: In the digital world nowadays, human resource management is an emerging, fast-moving discipline and has been embracing artificial intelligence in order to automate and speed up decision-making. However, the technological shift as such can bring about great apprehensions in terms of transparency, fairness, and the extent to which human workers are prepared to work effectively with the AI systems. On that concept, the proposed study presents a new ethical AI-combined framework of the HRM where the theoretical incorporation of adaptive learning frameworks, ethical auditing layers and workforce preparedness measures will facilitate a responsible and human-centered AI implementation. The primary novel thing about the study is that it is multi-layered by working the adaptive AI models in a perpetual loop using continuous HR data to generate data-based HR suggestions in recruitment, promotion and workforce planning. These recommendations are audited on compulsory ethics and have no biases at all before any decision can be implemented as a way of ensuring fairness and determining whether the legal standards are being adhered to. A parallel Workforce Readiness Assessment System explores the readiness of the workforce for the collaboration driven by AI, which capitalizes on the avenues to upskilling the human capabilities according to the AI integration. Should the suggested framework guarantee the inculcation of ethical transparency and manpower adaptability in the interaction of AIHRM, not merely a proficiency in decision-making would be maintained, but also the conservation of human values and trust. The findings helped to emphasize the necessity to establish the synergy of AI automation and ethical responsibility and human flexibility since it is only the missing link within the suite of practices employed in HR currently and the harbinger of responsible digital change of organizations.

title: AI Driven Email Classification and Phishing Attack Detection for Secure Communication
authors: Lavanya Naik, Bhargav KS, Sanket SS, Sathvik K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Phishing attacks remain a significant cybersecurity threat because they are misleading and have a broad reach across people and organizations. This project envisions an artificial intelligence-based method for detecting to catch phishing emails using sophisticated Natural Language Processing (NLP) and graph-based email classification methods. The solution is a smart classification pipeline that examines semantic content and the patterns of email communication to identify phishing attempts with precision. The NLP component handles body text of emails through transformer-based models to identify linguistic indicators of malicious intent. Simultaneously, the graph-based component represents receiver-sender relations to identify structural irregularities and suspicious behavior patterns within email networks. Collectively, the modules combine to minimize false positives, maximize detection accuracy, and offer a complete, real-time solution for phishing detection. We are developing a web-based application that will facilitate pragmatic deployment, allowing real-time monitoring, classification visualization, and alert generation. The system uses real-time email feeds and can be integrated into enterprise security tools to offer adaptive defense mechanisms. Overall, this project combines the latest AI technologies to create a scalable and proactive solution for contemporary email-based threats.

title: A Smart Monitoring Framework for Sustainable Solar Energy Harvesting Using IoT and Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Harish Reddy Gantla, Mayank Namdev, Udit Mamodiya, Indra Kishor, Gireesh Kumar, Parul Goyal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Real-time data-driven decision-making and effective system monitoring are essential for sustainable harvesting of solar energy for maximizing the energy output and environmental resilience. Standard solar energy systems are dumb and do not adjust to dynamic climatic conditions. In this paper, an intelligent IoT and machine learning (ML)-enabled monitoring system has been proposed to maximize solar energy harvesting and maximize overall system sustainability. The architecture weaves together calibrated IoT sensors (voltage, current, temperature, irradiance) on to a central cloud platform. The data is received in real time through MQTT and supervised machine learning models like Random Forest and CNN-LSTM are used for energy generation forecasting and anomaly detection. An intelligent control module offers feedback to tune panel angles and locate inefficiencies. A testbed implemented through ESP32 microcontrollers and solar panels was used for implementing the framework. The system scored 94.6 % on energy forecasting (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> score) with RMSE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.23 \text{kWh}$</tex>. The real-time monitoring latency was under 1.1 seconds. Anomaly detection sensitivity was as high as 96.3 %, allowing fault prediction in advance. Energy harvesting was improved by 17.8 % compared to a stationary system over a period of 30 days. IoT and ML integration allows smart, autonomous management of solar energy. The suggested system improves prediction accuracy, enhances fault tolerance, and boosts overall energy efficiency, thus offering a valuable solution for sustainable and intelligent energy infrastructure.

title: Detection of Rare Pediatric Tumors in Low-Resource Medical Imaging Environments Using GAN-Augmented Transfer Learning Frameworks
authors: Mohammed Thakir Mahmood, Mohammed Baqer Haleem, Hassan Ali Abood Nassrullah, Emad. N. Abdulwahab, Ahmed Slam Abod Abas, Zainab I. Mohammed, Aras Ismail Khider
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research proposes a GAN-augmented transfer learning framework for rare pediatric tumor detection in low-resource medical imaging environments, combining high-fidelity synthetic data generation, pre-trained convolutional backbones, and radiomic-deep feature fusion. Conditional GANs such as Pix2Pix and StyleGAN2 were used to generate anatomically realistic tumor instances, addressing severe class imbalance across pediatric MRI and CT datasets. The system was benchmarked on multiple rare tumor types including CNS, Wilms, Neuroblastoma, and Rhabdomyosarcoma. Models fine-tuned on both real and synthetic data consistently achieved detection accuracies above 96.3%, with F1-scores reaching 0.898 and sensitivity improvements of 5.1–6.6% over baseline CNNs. Compared to traditional oversampling and augmentation methods, the proposed framework yielded a 28–34% reduction in false negatives for minority tumor classes. The integration of weighted loss functions and radiomic-enhanced embedding’s enabled robust generalization across multi-center datasets, even under modality shifts and annotation variability. With training convergence accelerated by 2.8× and classification latency under 200ms per scan, the model offers a scalable, clinically viable solution for early-stage pediatric tumor diagnosis in constrained healthcare settings.

title: Deep Learning for Skin Cancer Detection: A CNN-Based Approach to Classifying Malignant and Benign Cancer
authors: Rohaan Farooq, Riya Chaudhary, Shilpi Harnal, Heena Sammi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The fact that skin cancer is still a major global health problem emphasises the need for accurate and timely detection to lower mortality from the disease. The dependence of traditional methods on visual analysis and dermoscopy supports their subjective and time-consuming character. This study explores DL techniques, namely CNNs, to automate the process of classifying skin lesion types as benign or malignant. This work uses the ISIC dataset to test a proprietary Sequential CNN model and several pre-trained CNN architectures, including Inception V3, ResNet, DenseNet, and VGG19. With a 90% accuracy rate, an AUC-ROC score of 0.9669, and balanced recall and precision for both benign and malignant cases, the Inception V3 model outperformed the other competing architectures. This study provides significant evidence that DL may automate the detection of skin cancer, paving the way for a novel approach to the disease's early detection and management. However, issues with computational complexity, data imbalance, and model interpretability continue to exist. Future research will concentrate on lowering dataset biases and increasing model flexibility. Utilising these tools in actual clinical settings to enhance patient outcomes and diagnostic accuracy is the ultimate objective.

title: Automated Glaucoma Detection Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Aakash Dahiya, Meenu Gupta, Rakesh Kumar, Sathvik Kanam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Glaucoma remains a major global cause of irreversible blindness, with early detection often hindered by its asymptomatic progression leading to nearly half of cases going undiagnosed. In this study, we explore a novel approach that leverages both electronic health records (EHR) and retinal imaging to enhance diagnostic accuracy using machine learning (ML) techniques. A balanced dataset of 1,652 individuals, including 826 glaucoma patients and 826 controls, was extracted from EHRs to train three distinct ML classifiers: Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and a feed-forward neural network. Separately, a convolutional neural network (CNN) utilizing transfer learning was applied to fundus images, capitalizing on imaging data's proven diagnostic value. While EHR-based models achieved moderate performance 67.5 % accuracy with Random Forest and slightly lower for the others these results align with the strengths and limitations of structured clinical data. In contrast, imaging-based models, consistent with prior studies, demonstrated superior performance, historically reaching up to 90 % accuracy. To bridge the gap between cost-effective scalability and high diagnostic precision, we developed a hybrid ensemble model that integrates predictions from both EHR and image modalities. This integrated system significantly enhanced performance, achieving 92.1% accuracy with an AUC of 0.93. Our findings underscore the potential of a multimodal machine learning approach to support early glaucoma detection, offering a promising and practical direction for scalable screening in primary care and ophthalmology settings.

title: Autonomous Indoor Rover with YOLOv5n-Based Detection for Lost-and-Found Systems
authors: Ilaqquan Rajesh Indu, Lakshmi Shrinivasan, Aruna Arunachalam, K. Keerthy Vasan, Sanvi Mishra
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Misplacement of personal items in indoor environments is a common issue, often resulting in inconvenience and lost productivity. This paper presents Findroid, an autonomous mobile robot for real-time object detection and retrieval without reliance on pre-tagged items or external infrastructure. Findroid combines a lightweight YOLOv5n object detection model with autonomous navigation enabled by a Random Mutation Hill Climbing–based SLAM algorithm, implemented via BreezySLAM and a 360° LiDAR sensor. Evaluated in the Webots simulation environment, Findroid achieves accurate indoor mapping, reliable obstacle avoidance, and real-time recognition of lost items. A Flask-based web interface enables remote monitoring and user feedback. Results demonstrate the system's effectiveness for scalable, practical lost-and-found applications in dynamic indoor settings such as public infrastructure and personal robotics.

title: Machine Learning Based Student Performance Prediction in Higher Education Using Random Forest with Gradient Boosting(BRFE) Approach
authors: Shweta Dhareshwar, Jamberi K, Hassan Baig
