title: Smart Meta-Controller: Energy Efficient Dynamic Routing for Large Language Model Inference Systems
authors: R. Jeffrey Mariaraj, Ronan Lobo, Maurya P Gowda
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The exponential growth in large language model (LLM) deployment has provided computational demands that is never seen before, resulting in significant energy consumption and CO emissions. This paper introduces the Smart Meta-controller, which is an intelligent routing system that dynamically allocates user generated queries between lightweight and computationally intensive AI agents based on the complexity of predicted tasks. Our approach employs a fine tuned DistilBERT classifier that has 97% accuracy for initial complexity assessment, brought together with a novel dynamic escalation protocol that provides robust fault tolerance against misclassification. The system implements a two stage architecture: proactive classification for immediate routing decisions and reactive escalation for error recovery when lightweight agents find tasks beyond their capabilities. Experimental results in various workloads demonstrate substantial improvements: 68% reduction in computational load, 58% decrease in GPU hour consumption, 52% reduction in average response latency, and 62% decrease in energy usage per query, while maintaining 99.1% task completion accuracy. In production environments processing over 1.2 million queries daily, the system saves approximately 2.4 MWh of energy per day, which translates to an estimated reduction of 1.2 metric tons of CO emissions annually per 10,000 daily users compared to uniform deep model routing. This work establishes a new paradigm for sustainable AI deployment through intelligent computational resource allocation, offering significant benefits in operational costs and environmental impact without compromising quality of service.

title: Implementing AI-driven Web Accessibility: WCAG 2.2 Features to Improve Usability for Users with Disabilities
authors: Muthu Selvam
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: This paper discusses the application of AI in aiding companies in web accessibility for the impaired by following the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 2.2. Recent testing approaches and tools used are mostly manual and cannot accommodate real-time accessibility problems. To address these issues, a prototype of a web-based system was developed, containing an AI-based accessibility checker, adaptive content rendering, and assistive technologies. The accessibility audit was performed, and the subsequent verification of compliance and improvement of the site’s usability involved the application of machine learning models, numerous tests involving NLP, and computer vision analysis. Consequently, the WCAG compliance scores were increased by $31 \%$, the task completion rate was increased by $33.6 \%$, and the overall user satisfaction was increased by $43.9 \%$. AI-based solutions reduced the workload significantly and enhanced the efficiency of detecting accessibility violations by $25.6 \%$ compared to traditional methods. Nonetheless, some of the challenges that next-generation ATRs are geared to face include the following ethical concerns: algorithmic bias and privacy. In this paper, the author outlines the potential of AI in making the Internet environment as accessible as possible and the need to work together on that effort towards reaching the best results in making the Internet an accessible venue. In the future, the work will focus on enhancing the AI algorithm, the weighting of materials, and significantly reducing or eliminating questionable ethical concerns that keep specific learners out.

title: Industrial Non-Intrusive Power Monitoring to Unlock the Usability of Renewable Energy Sources: A Comparative Study
authors: Giulia Tanoni, Muhammad Affan Khan, Enrik Xhani, Paolo Vitulli, Emanuele Principi
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The evolution of the smart grid ecosystem is accelerating, driven by climate challenges and rising energy demand. Distributed renewable resources play a strategic role in enhancing grid stability and reducing greenhouse emissions. Industrial plants, as major energy consumers, are particularly well-positioned to benefit from these distributed resources. NonIntrusive Load Monitoring (NILM) has emerged as a valuable technique for optimizing the use of renewable energy through the insights extracted from smart meters. However, its application in industrial environments remains partially underexplored. This research addresses this gap by presenting the first comparative study of seven state-of-the-art NILM methods in the literature. We evaluate their performance at different signal resolutions using two publicly available datasets from different industrial contexts, one of which includes energy production signals. Given the complexity of industrial systems, this study highlights the need to account for the distinct characteristics of industrial electrical loads and to carefully adapt NILM methods to these unique conditions.

title: SIGNIFY: A Bidirectional Sign Language Communication System to Real-Time Text and Voice Translation
authors: Richelle Sulit, Laud Zion Cascalla, Max Daniel De Silva, Kyla Andes
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: SIGNIFY is an innovative solution addressing communication barriers faced by the deaf and mute community through real-time translation of sign language into text and voice. Leveraging advanced computer vision and machine learning technologies, SIGNIFY enables seamless interaction between sign language users and non-users, fostering inclusivity and accessibility. Aligned with the Philippine Department of Education's (DepEd) commitment to inclusive education and Special Education (SPED) programs, SIGNIFY supports the country's efforts to integrate learners with disabilities into mainstream education. While DepEd promotes accessibility through capacity building, community engagement, and tailored programs for special needs learners, significant challenges remain in reaching all students who require support. SIGNIFY contributes to addressing these gaps by providing an effective tool for sign language communication within educational and social settings. The system demonstrates high functionality, reliability, and user satisfaction in translating sign language gestures accurately into text and speech, empowering individuals with speech and hearing impairments to participate fully in society. By integrating cutting-edge assistive technology with the Philippine inclusive education framework, SIGNIFY embodies the transformative potential of technology to foster understanding and equitable learning opportunities for all.

title: Context-Aware Search Ranking Algorithm for Enhanced E-Commerce Product Discovery
authors: Nidhi Mishra, G.Durgadevi, M. Udaypal Reddy, Zaed Balasm, M.S. Gowtham, Smaeel Abdel Qader, Fatima Ayad Abd Al Zahraa, Omar Usama Alhayaly

title: Cryptocurrency Market Oversight Strengthened by Financial Surveillance Automation Tools
authors: Saed Adnan Mustafa, Feras M. Shehada
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Cryptocurrency markets have grown rapidly, creating new challenges for regulatory bodies in overseeing financial transactions effectively. The decentralized and pseudonymous nature of blockchain technology makes it challenging to detect illicit activities such as fraud, money laundering, and market manipulation. Existing surveillance methods primarily rely on manual reviews and rule-based systems, which are often slow, inconsistent, and unable to scale with the increasing volume and complexity of cryptocurrency transactions. To address these limitations, this study proposes a Machine Learning-Based Anomaly Detection in Transaction Patterns (ML-ADTP) framework. This framework utilizes advanced machine learning algorithms to automatically analyze large-scale blockchain transaction data, identify suspicious patterns, and flag potentially fraudulent activities in real time. By combining clustering, classification, and time-series analysis techniques, the framework adapts to evolving market behaviors, thereby enhancing detection accuracy. The ML-ADTP framework enables financial regulators and exchanges to automate monitoring processes, reduce false positives, and generate timely alerts for compliance investigations. This improves overall market transparency by 98.4% and reduces the risk of illicit financial flows by 39%. Evaluation of the proposed method on real-world datasets demonstrates improved detection rates by 97.5% and faster response times by 98.2% compared to traditional methods, highlighting its effectiveness in strengthening cryptocurrency market oversight.

title: Energy Grid Trading Security-based Regulatory Policies Across Smart Supply Chains
authors: Haider Mahdi Rammoo, Mahmood Ahmed Hamdi, Rasha Saad Abdalwahid, Raghad Ali Hassan, Maytham Manfy Kadhum, Raya Majid Alsharfa
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The growing complexity of energy grid trading within smart supply chains necessitates robust security and regulatory compliance frameworks. Ensuring trust, transparency, and efficient energy exchange has become a top priority for sustainable energy ecosystems. Existing methods often suffer from centralized vulnerabilities, lack of data privacy, and limited adaptability to regulatory changes, which undermine the integrity and efficiency of energy trading systems. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Blockchain-Enabled Federated Learning (BEFL) framework that integrates decentralized machine learning with secure, immutable blockchain technologies. BEFL ensures data privacy by allowing local model training while leveraging blockchain to maintain tamper-proof, auditable energy trading records aligned with regulatory policies. This framework supports secure peer-to-peer (P2P) energy transactions, enabling dynamic pricing and decentralized decision-making while maintaining data integrity and confidentiality. The proposed method is implemented within a smart grid scenario involving distributed energy producers and consumers, where real-time compliance checks and secure trading are performed. Results demonstrate enhanced security, improved trading transparency, regulatory alignment, and reduced risks of data leakage compared to conventional systems. The proposed method gradually enhances the data privacy preservation rate by 98.43%, the transparency index by 97.64%, the regulatory compliance accuracy by 96.53%, and the security breach detection rate by 96.52%.

title: Risk2Scenario: LLM-Assisted Scenario Generation for Autonomous Driving Testing Based on Hierarchical Risk Analysis
authors: Pin Wang, Junyan Ma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Systems (ICCS)
abstract: Ensuring the safety and reliability of autonomous driving systems requires rigorous testing across diverse and safety-critical conditions. Traditional mileage-based evaluations often fail to capture rare but high-risk scenarios that lie in the long tail of real-world distributions. To address this challenge, we propose Risk2Scenario, a scenario generation framework assisted by Large Language Models (LLMs). Our approach leverages real-world traffic accident reports and employs prompt-based hierarchical analysis to extract structured risk factors, constructing a domain-specific risk factor database. These risk factors are then retrieved and integrated into the LLM, enabling the generation of semantically rich, high-risk test scenarios. To further enhance scenario diversity and coverage, we employ a genetic algorithm to explore and mutate the generated scenarios. We validate Risk2Scenario in the CARLA simulator using the Basic Agent, demonstrating its effectiveness in uncovering safety-critical situations and revealing potential vulnerabilities in autonomous driving systems.

title: Insulin Dose Recommendation System for Type-1 Diabetes Patients Using Reinforcement Learning and Continuous Glucose Monitoring Data
authors: Hadeer Mohammed, Abdul Razzaq Oleiwi Jasim, Zainab I. Mohammed, Sazan Kamal Sulaiman, Shahad M Mhmood, Shaima Ahmed
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research proposes a high-performance reinforcement learning (RL)-based insulin dose recommendation system for Type-1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM), integrating continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) data, temporal state encoding, and hybrid reward optimization. Utilizing PPO and SAC as policy backbones and incorporating LSTM-driven glucose sequence modeling, the framework was validated across synthetic and real-world datasets including UVA/Padova simulations and OhioT1DM records. The system consistently achieved Time-in-Range (TIR) performance exceeding 96.8%, with mean absolute error (MAE) reduced to 12.9 mg/dL and zero critical hypoglycemic episodes, confirming its dosing precision under variable physiological conditions. Compared to rule-based and conventional RL methods, the proposed model demonstrated a 4.5-5.6% improvement in glycemic outcomes and a 26% reduction in insulin dosing variance. The inclusion of hybrid reward shaping and noise-robust policy regularization enabled safe learning across diverse patient profiles, including meal-induced spikes and sensor noise conditions. With inference latency below 150 ms and online adaptation capability, the system is well-suited for real-time closed-loop insulin therapy applications. Its data-driven design supports deployment in intelligent artificial pancreas systems, without reliance on handcrafted dosing heuristics or fixed clinical protocols.

title: Ship Route Optimization using Genetic Algorithm on the Capacitated Multi-Vehicle Routing Problem with Pick-Up and Delivery
authors: Angelina Vanni Pazya, Tanti Octavia
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: In sea freight logistics, optimizing route scheduling is essential to improve delivery efficiency and vessel utilization. This study addresses the Capacitated Multi-Vehicle Routing Problem with Pick-Up and Delivery (CMVRPPD) using a Modified Genetic Algorithm (GA), applied to operational data from X Corp. Currently, route planning is done manually and based on historical data, resulting in low utility and inefficiencies. The novelty of this research lies in modifying the initial population generation, where the next port is selected using problem-specific heuristics rather than purely random selection. The results show that the number of operational routes can be reduced from 23 to 10, with an increase in utility by 6.58% (to 45.84%), although the total sailing distance increased by 5,538.16 nautical miles. While direct comparison with historical data is limited due to differences in assumptions—such as residual unserved demand and dual home-base usage—the proposed method offers improvements in capacity utilization and enables automated scheduling. This work contributes to the practical application of metaheuristic optimization in maritime transportation and supports decision-making in vessel routing under real-world constraints.

title: Secure Data Sharing Policies Via API Platform
authors: Monaliza Sahri, Umi Asma’ Mokhtar, Siti Norul Huda Sheikh Abdulah, Azlina Ali, Aznul Nizam Nasir, Nik Rafizal Nik Ab Rahim, Ismail Che Ani, Kamsuriah Ahmad
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Data sharing is essential in the digital era, covering various sectors. In Malaysia, implementing secure data sharing through the Government of Malaysia Central Data Exchange (MyGDX) API platform supports the Malaysian National Data Sharing Policy and the Public Sector Data Sharing Policy. However, its implementation faces various issues in data sharing policies, including policies that only encourage but do not mandate data sharing, inconsistencies in frameworks and guidelines across organizations and countries, low policy adoption and acceptance, and issues of secure data sharing. Challenges include weak policies and guidelines, weak leadership support, weak inter-agency collaboration, lack of a comprehensive policy framework, and limitations in technology infrastructure. The mandatory and practical policies and guidelines, aligned with FAIR principles, robust governance structures, and advanced and secure data sharing technologies, are listed to overcome these issues. This study identifies factors related to secure data sharing based on the CIA Triad. Further research is needed to explore the critical success factors and good data sharing governance frameworks to enhance trust and ensure secure data sharing.

title: Energy-Efficient Dadda Multiplier Using Configurable Approximation Technique
authors: Saranya L, Gunabharath K, Nandakumar J, Sri Nithi V, Srikanth KS, Mohanbabu A
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: An accuracy-adjustable, energy-efficient Dadda multiplier based on configurable addition and approximate partitioning is proposed. The structure uses the approximate width setting and voltage over scaling as approximation knobs to increase the multiplier's lifetime and dependability while also reducing energy usage. The latter can only be called at design time, but the former can be set during both design and runtime. The partial output generation is applied with voltage scaling with approximation based on accuracy. Typically, the voltage over scaled columns at lower bit significances with larger switching activities is what keeps the error within a reasonable bound. For low-overhead realization, the structure uses a small number of level shifters. Contiguous are the approximate columns that begin with the first column. The final addition in the Dadda architecture uses a power gated radix adder, which dynamically turns on and disables logical element of an adder b using the power gating approach to compute precise or approximate results. As a result, power consumption and key path latency are eliminated. LSP columns 1-4 truncation of the multiplier output is also recommended in order to increase the multiplier's efficiency even more. Xilinx ISE is used to synthesize the efficiency of the suggested Dadda structure, which is built in Verilog HDL. The evaluations indicate that, the multiplier design proposed is efficient with respect to power consumption and performance when analyzed with existing counter parts.

title: InsightX-A Smart Vision System for Human and Environmental Context Detection
authors: Hamdan Zaman Khan, Harsh Yadav, Varun Shukla, Mohammad Shoaib Khan, Anshul Kumar Mandal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: In today's rapidly advancing world of smart surveillance and automation, being able to identify people and monitor environmental conditions in real time has become increasingly important. This paper introduces InsightX, a powerful and flexible desktop application created with OpenCV and Python. InsightX is designed to handle a variety of surveillance tasks, including real-time facial recognition, counting the number of people present, detecting whether lights are on or off using visual cues, and determining if a fan is running by analyzing audio. The system also allows users to upload video files for retrospective facial recognition and data analysis. Built to be affordable and easy to expand, InsightX is well-suited for use in schools, businesses, and homes. By combining traditional surveillance with intelligent, context-aware features, InsightX lays the groundwork for more advanced automation systems in the future.

title: Mern Stack and AWS Optimization of Left CI / CD Pipeline using Docker
authors: Akshay Gupta, Mohammed A. Al-shibly, Ahmed Hadi Ali AL-Jumaili, Hameed Allawi Shanyoor AL-Jumaili, Yaseen Hadi Ali, Huda Mohammed Lateef
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: In modern software development, selecting the right Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) tools is crucial for creating efficient and reliable deployment pipelines. This study compares three widely used CI/CD tools—GitHub Actions, Jenkins, and AWS CodePipeline—in the context of deploying MERN stack applications on Amazon Web Services (AWS). A real-world job portal application was tested, with the tools evaluated based on key metrics such as build time, deployment latency, reliability, and cost-effectiveness. The results show that GitHub Actions offers the fastest deployment times but suffers from a higher failure rate in backend workflows, while Jenkins excels in flexibility but requires more manual configuration. AWS CodePipeline, though more expensive, offers seamless integration with AWS services and high reliability. This research contributes valuable insights into how different CI/CD tools perform in cloud-based MERN stack deployments and provides best practices for optimizing workflows in production environments.

title: Study of Improved Multi-Objective Genetic Algorithm on Double Taylor Spatial Frame
authors: Rongxing Yang, Jianmin Guo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: This study tackles the kinematic forward solution of the Double Taylor Spatial Frame (D-TSF) for complex fractures and multi-segment deformity correction, proposing an improved two-stage multi-objective optimization method. A complete spatial constraint model is established by defining a global coordinate system at the fixed platform center and computing all joint coordinates and rod length constraints. The coupled 12-dimensional problem is decomposed into two sequential six-dimensional subproblems, solving lower and upper rods stepwise to reduce dimensionality and complexity. A feasibility-prioritized constraint strategy and adaptive evolutionary operators are adopted, dynamically tuning crossover and mutation rates to enhance global search early and strengthen local convergence later. A local gradient refinement further improves solution precision. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed method converges reliably to optimal solutions, with rod length errors maintained within 0.6 mm, exhibiting high computational efficiency and robustness, thereby providing theoretical and technical support for D-TSF clinical applications.

title: EcoBeanAI: Predictive Modeling of Climate Effects on Coffee and Cocoa Quality and Yield
authors: Filip Dimitrievski, Sara Shaheen Khan, Kalyani Rohidas Vaidya, Rasha S. Gargees
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Climate change poses urgent threats to coffee and cocoa production by altering yield and altering sensory qualities critical to market value. Previous studies have established climate impacts on these crops, but lack predictive frameworks that integrate future climate scenarios with both yield and quality outcomes. This project addresses this gap by applying machine learning models to forecast how temperature and rainfall affect the production and sensory attributes of coffee and cocoa. Using supervised learning techniques such as GRU, LSTM, Random Forest, and XG-Boost, we built predictive models informed by historical climate data and quality scores from public datasets. Our results demonstrate that tree-based models consistently outperformed recurrent neural networks, with TabNet achieving an $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ score of 0.9579 for cocoa quality prediction and XGBoost models reaching $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ scores of approximately 0.9 for yield prediction. Feature importance analysis revealed altitude as the dominant predictor (0.34), followed by annual precipitation (0.30) and temperature change (0.26), confirming the critical role of environmental factors over processing methods. Coffee and cocoa are studied together due to their overlapping climate sensitivities and economic dependencies on quality, providing a unified framework for climate risk adaptation. The resulting models are designed to guide farmers, processors and policy makers in making informed decisions to maintain yield and maintain flavor quality amid climate variability. Our final product is an interactive tool or dashboard that offers yield and quality forecasts customized to evolving climate conditions.

title: Develop a Tool to Simulate Kruskal's Algorithm, TCP New Reno Congestion Control, Stop and Wait Protocol and RIP for Optimized Network Routing
authors: Rajat Kumar A, Rakshita Basarakod, Samarth Babu Gotrale, Kiran V
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a network simulation tool developed using Python and the Tkinter library, offering a desktop-based graphical user interface (GUI) for analyzing key network communication protocols and graph-based routing algorithms. The tool simulates Kruskal's algorithm, Routing Information Protocol (RIP), Open Shortest Path First (OSPF), TCP New Reno, and Stop-and-Wait protocols, leveraging NetworkX for network topology management and Matplotlib for real-time visualizations of routing tables, congestion windows, and transmission timelines. Users can define custom network topologies, adjust simulation parameters and evaluate performance metrics such as throughput, latency, and efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate the tool's effectiveness, alongside network throughput of 88 Mbps and 33.6 Mbps, latency of 37.81 ms and 81.14 ms, retransmission rate of 0.5% and 3% and packet loss rate of 0.25% and 1.5% respectively. Stop-and-Wait exhibited efficiencies of 93.75% and 75.00%, reflecting robust performance under varying conditions. These findings validate the tool as an educational platform for network concepts and a foundation for future enhancements like dynamic topology support.

title: Comparative Analysis of Sequence-Based Neural Networks for Human Movement Prediction: The Impact of Task Formulation and Spatial Resolution
authors: Aetandrian Widya Raharjo, Widyawan, Indriana Hidayah
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: The increasing availability of GPS trajectory data has advanced next-location prediction, yet reported accuracies vary widely due to differences in task formulation and spatial resolution. While sequence-based neural networks outperform classical statistical models few works systematically examine how task formulation and spatial granularity affect performance when using sequence-based neural networks models. This study presents a comparative analysis of three sequence-based neural models: RNN, LSTM, and Transformer, using large-scale GPS data from Yogyakarta, Indonesia. The evaluation covers both time-binned and transition-only formulations, and H3 hexagonal grids from levels 5–10. Results show that time-binned tasks and coarse grids are far easier. At H3-8, the Transformer reaches 80.2% Top-1 accuracy (F1 57.4%) for time-binned prediction but only 34.2% (F1 15.5%) for transition-only. Finer spatial resolution further reduces accuracy due to class explosion and sparsity: at H3-5, all models exceed ~95% Top-1, but at H3-10, performance falls to 52.8% (Transformer), 44.9% (LSTM), and 10.5% (RNN). Overall, the Transformer performs best, LSTM second, and RNN only strong in coarse, time-binned settings. These findings help explain performance variation in the literature, showing that next-location prediction depends not just on model architecture but also on matching task formulation and spatial granularity to the intended application.

title: Demonstration of Standalone Solar Carport Model Utilizing Fully Renewable Energy
authors: Keiichi Hirose, Takuya Goto, Kazuto Yukita
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This study introduces a standalone solar-powered carport designed to charge electric vehicles (EVs) using only renewable energy, aligning with Japan’s Green Growth Strategy and the UN’s Sustainable Development Goal 7. The system features a 4.2 kW photovoltaic array, 10 kVA power conditioning system, 15.2 kWh lead-acid battery, 3 kW EV charger, and LED lighting. Installed in Toyota City, Japan, the prototype ($5.27 \mathrm{~m} \times$ 5.26 m) was tested over one month in March 2023. Total energy demand reached 180.9 kWh, while solar generation totaled 181.6 kWh, enabling full off-grid operation. The battery charged 122.3 kWh during the day and discharged 104.2 Wh at night. A compact Battery Electric Vehicle (BEV) traveled $\mathbf{5 8 ~ k m}$, consuming $4.4 \mathrm{kWh}(115.8 \mathrm{~Wh} / \mathrm{km})$. Estimated CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions for a typical monthly distance of 480.6 km were $0.025 \mathrm{t}-\mathrm{CO}_{2}$, showing reductions of 120 kg compared to gasoline vehicles and 25 kg versus grid-powered EVs-a $79.2 \%$ decrease. The results validate the carport’s potential for clean, independent EV charging.

title: Social Life Cycle Assessment of Stationary Battery Storage Systems: A Focus on Local Communities and Workers
authors: Luis Felipe Ruiz Sanjuan, Hélène Peton, Jura Arkhangelski, Mahamadou Abdou Tankari, Gilles Lefebvre
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This study aims to identify and evaluate the socioeconomic impacts of stationary Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) from the perspectives of local communities and workers. Social Life Cycle Assessment (S-LCA) is increasingly recognized as a critical tool for achieving sustainability evaluations. Following the United Nations Environmental (UNEP) S-LCA guidelines grounded in the ISO 14040-14075 framework, this study defines the main stakeholders and subcategories, focusing on the roles of the local community and workers in the energy storage value chain. A qualitative exploratory methodology was employed, drawing on a thematic synthesis of theoretical literature, empirical research, and industry reports. This approach enabled the translation of social and economic concerns into a set of operational indicators to support informed decisionmaking processes. The selected indicators address key issues such as labor rights, local employment opportunities, community health and safety, access to energy, and transparency in supply chains. The study highlights the need for a more socially responsive evaluation of energy technologies, emphasizing in the energy storage systems life cycle. By integrating social assessment with energy system analysis, it proposes an interdisciplinary framework that facilitates the responsible deployment of battery systems.

title: Implementing Collision Detection with Exponential Backoff and Lightweight Secure Data Transmission
authors: Pavithra R, Shridhar D N, Sagar H N, Kiran V
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Efficient and secure communication in constrained environments such as IoT systems and embedded control platforms remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces a lightweight communication protocol that integrates real-time collision detection, exponential backoff for retransmission control, and minimal-overhead encryption. The system leverages high-resolution inter-packet timing to detect message collisions and mitigates repeated transmission failures through a randomized backoff algorithm. In a simulated network environment with two concurrent TCP clients, the system successfully detected collisions at timing intervals as low as 11.78 ms and 36.95 ms. Retransmissions were managed using exponentially increasing delays ranging from 25 ms to 196 ms, significantly reducing the chance of repeated collisions. To ensure confidentiality, a symmetric XOR-based encryption scheme with a rotating 32-bit key was used, offering negligible computational overhead. Experimental results demonstrated over 95% successful message delivery in high-contention scenarios within a five-retry limit, indicating the protocol's suitability for real-time, secure communication in environments such as vehicular networks, IoT clusters, and embedded systems.

title: Lightrpl-Ids: A Lightweight Machine Learning-Based Intrusion Detection Framework for RPL-Enabled IoT Networks
authors: Bharath M B, Mala B A, Pooja Shree H R, Suvika K V, Lavanya K, Chadrakala L
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has enabled widespread device interconnection over low-power and lossy networks (LLNs), commonly using the RPL routing protocol. However, RPL is vulnerable to routing attacks-such as rank manipulation, sinkholes, and selective forwarding-that can undermine network reliability and performance. Traditional intrusion detection systems (IDS) are often ill-suited for these environments because they impose high computational and energy costs on constrained devices. In this work we introduce LightRPL-IDS, a lightweight, machine-learning-based detection framework tailored to the constraints and threat model of RPL networks. By relying on a compact, carefully chosen feature set and computationally efficient classifiers, LightRPL-IDS delivers rapid and accurate detection of RPL-specific attacks while minimizing memory and energy use. Implemented and tested in the Cooja simulator, the framework achieves detection accuracies above 94 % across multiple attack types and shows substantial reductions in resource consumption. These results indicate that LightRPL-IDS is a practical, scalable security solution for resource-constrained IoT deployments.

title: Predictive Analytics for On-Time Delivery: Designing and Evaluating a Partner Data Exchange Framework
authors: Lukesh Singla, Manthan Lad
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: This research paper offers an in-depth strategy for creating a Partner Data Exchange Framework (PDEF) that uses predictive analytics to improve on-time delivery performance within supply chains. The framework combines data sharing protocols, exchange format standardization, and sophisticated predictive modeling methodologies to facilitate more effective collaboration among stakeholders throughout the supply chain. The study analyzes prevalent data exchange practices, identifies shortcomings in existing frameworks, and presents a new approach that bypasses these limitations. Five classification models were compared to predict delivery performance, of which Random Forest Classification performed best (99.44% accuracy, 98.99% recall, 99.49% F1 score). The envisioned framework performs better than conventional methods via facilitation of real-time decision-making and anticipatory risk management, thus immensely enhancing ontime delivery percentages and overall supply chain resilience. The present study adds to the growing body of literature on data-enabled supply chain management and has practical applicability for organizations interested in improving delivery performance via data collaboration and predictive analytics.

title: Interpretable CNN-LSTM Framework for Multiclass Neuromuscular Disorder Classification Using Clinically Relevant EMG Features_supp1-3639453.pdf
authors: MD. Zahid Hasan
publish: N/A
abstract: Accurate and timely diagnosis of neuromuscular disorders (NMDs), including myopathy and neuropathy, is essential for initiating effective treatment and mitigating disease progression. Despite advances in machine learning for NMD analysis, existing models often rely on datasets with limited subject diversity, focus on binary classification, and lack clinical interpretability, which limits their applicability. Classification remains challenging due to overlapping electromyographic (EMG) signal patterns, high inter-patient variability, and subjective interpretation. To address these challenges, this paper presents an interpretable deep learning framework for multiclass NMD classification using intramuscular EMG signals. A robust feature set is constructed by combining three statistical feature selection methods with clinically validated descriptors. A hybrid Convolutional Neural Network–Long Short–Term Memory (CNNLSTM) model is proposed to capture both spatial patterns and temporal dynamics in EMG data. To ensure transparency and clinical trust, the model integrates explainability techniques, including Permutation Feature Importance, SHapley Additive exPlanations, Partial Dependence Plots, and Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanations, which provide both global relevance and case-specific diagnostic reasoning. Evaluated primarily on the Mendeley dataset and further validated on the EMGLAB and a private non-invasive surface EMG cohort, the framework achieves 95.83% accuracy, 98.61% area under the curve, and strong agreement scores (Cohen’s kappa: 93.75%, Matthews Correlation Coefficient: 93.82%) with a median inference latency of 59.56 ms per sample. These findings validate the framework as a practical and interpretable tool for near real-time NMD diagnosis, enabling clinically actionable decisions in both highdemand and resource-constrained healthcare settings.

title: A Hybrid Signal and Model-Based Fault Diagnostic Strategy for Current Sensors in Six-Phase Sinusoidal Doubly Salient Electro-Magnetic Machines
authors: Xingwei Zhou, Wentao Pan, Xiang Chang, Chengjia Lu, Xu Wang, Li Zhang, Xing Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: To enhance the diagnosis capability of current sensor faults in symmetrical six-phase sinusoidal doubly salient electromagnetic machines (SDSEM) system, a hybrid signal and model-based diagnosis strategy is proposed in this paper. At first, the current sensor fault operating characteristic is investigated, and the features of z1-z2 subspace currents are analyzed in detail. Then, on the base of the currents feature, a novel phase current sensor fault diagnostic strategy is proposed, most of the faulty phase current sensor can be diagnosed according to the changes in the diagnosis signals which are constructed from z1-z2 subspace currents. In further, to distinguish the blind spot caused by the symmetrical windings with 60° phase shift, an easy-implemented model-based current observer is designed, the faulty phase current sensor can be further identified according to the difference between the sampled and observed currents. With the combined hybrid signal and model-based diagnosis strategy, accurate discriminations of phase current sensor fault are desired to be achieved. The multiple experiments validate the correctness and the feasibility of the proposed methods.

title: Whole Process Covert Attacks for Lithium-Ion Batteries in Battery Energy Storage Systems
authors: Yu Huang, Xi Sun, Tongkai Hao, Bin Lu, Hongtian Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article investigates covert attack methods for lithium-ion batteries. Effective execution of a covert attack requires both an accurate system model and the capability to restore the system to its normal state after the attack is concluded. To address these challenges, a maximum likelihood form of dual-mode H2 optimal unbiased finite impulse response (MLDMH2OUFIR) is proposed to estimate the system state. This approach mitigates the decline in attack model accuracy caused by variations in battery parameters. Furthermore, an attack exit process is incorporated to ensure that the system state reverts to its expected condition after the attack concludes, allowing the attack to be withdrawn from the target system without leaving any trace. Finally, attack simulation experiments are conducted on lithium-ion batteries. The concealment and effectiveness of the proposed scheme is verified by overcharging the SOC of the experimental batteries to 110%, 115% at different ambient temperatures without being detected.

title: Internal Model-Based Sliding Mode Control for Uncertain Nonlinear Systems With Application to PMSM Servo Systems
authors: Lu Zhang, Guangdeng Zong, Huiping Li, Xiang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article investigates the sliding mode control problem of uncertain nonlinear systems and its application in tracking periodic motion. Traditional sliding mode control fulfils perfect tracking at the cost of chattering, especially in the case of high-frequency scenarios. To address the limitations of this method, this article introduces the internal model of the reference signal in building the sliding manifold, which fully takes the advantages of two fundamental methodologies. Specifically, the internal model of the reference signal is involved in the closed-loop system dynamics after the sliding manifold is reached. Thence, all terms related to the reference signal in the tracking error can be eliminated and high-precision tracking can be achieved while reducing chattering phenomenon. Remarkably, the detailed expressions of the derivatives of the reference signal are unnecessarily required, which simplifies the controller design and implementation. It is rigorously proved mathematically that the closed-loop system is asymptotically stable. Finally, the proposed control algorithm is applied for solving the position tracking control problem for permanent magnet synchronous motor servo systems, and experimental results verify the effectiveness and superiority.

title: Online Traffic Camouflage Against Network Analyzers via Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Wenhao Li, Jie Chen, Zhaoxuan Li, Shuai Wang, Huamin Jin, Xiao-Yu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Traffic analysis plays a pivotal role in network management. However, despite the prevalence of encryption, attackers are still able to deduce privacy elements such as user behavior and OS identification through advanced learning-based methods that exploit side-channel features. Existing defense strategies, which manipulate feature distribution to evade traffic analyzers, are often hampered by the need for impractical decoder deployment across all routes in symmetric framework methods. Moreover, reversing feature distribution modifications to real-time traffic, especially through dummy packet crafting or padding, is a complex task. In response to these challenges, we propose Veil, a novel and practical defender designed to protect live connections against encrypted network traffic analyzers. Leveraging an asymmetric deployment structure, Veil is capable of reconstructing live streams at the packet-block level, thereby allowing for seamless deployment on any connection node while enforcing transmission constraints. By employing a traffic-customized DQN framework, Veil not only reverses statistical feature perturbations back to the traffic space but also directs the distribution towards a target class. Extensive experiments conducted on real-world datasets validate the efficacy of Veil in efficiently evading analyzers in both targeted and untargeted modes, outperforming existing defense mechanisms. Notably, Veil addresses the key issues of impractical decoder deployment and complex real-time traffic manipulation, offering a more viable solution for network traffic privacy protection. The source code is publicly available at https://github.com/SecTeamPolaris/Veil, facilitating further research and application in the field of network security.

title: Optimal Renewable Power Purchase Agreements for Data Centers
authors: Kekun Gao, Yuejun Yan, Yuke Zhou, Endong Liu, Zhaoyang Wang, Pengcheng You
publish: IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid
abstract: Data centers have become integral to contemporary infrastructure. However, their electricity demand significantly adds to global energy consumption, resulting in substantial electricity costs and carbon footprints. Power purchase agreements, when used as bilateral long-term contracts for procuring renewable energy, not only hedge against volatility in an electricity market to secure locked-in prices but also play a crucial role in reducing carbon emissions. This paper studies the strategy of a data center to sign such power purchase agreements, which encompasses an optimal agreement design problem (static) and an optimal signing timing problem (dynamic) to maximize long-term expected electricity cost savings. In particular, we develop a continuous-time stochastic process model for long-term market price evolution in an electricity market, alongside a power purchase agreement model comprising the starting time, contract term, contractual power supply, and locked-in price. These models enable a novel problem formulation for PPA signing, which further allows for a tractable solution via decomposition. We first fix an arbitrary starting time and explicitly analyze how to set the other three variables with the most expected total saving. We then propose a dynamic threshold policy that online identifies an optimal starting time based on real-time observations of market prices. The proposed strategy is extensively tested with simulation experiments to validate our theoretical analysis. Numerical results also provide additional insights – over 35% reduction in long-term total electricity expenditure can be made possible for data centers, as long as power purchase agreements are properly signed.

authors: N/A

With 342 delegates from 33 countries, CEIDP 2025 marked its centennial edition by fostering technical excellence, shared expertise, and a strong sense of community.

title: LPPUBR: Lightweight Privacy-Preserving Unsupervised Medical Image Bitmap Retrieval in IoT
authors: Yifan Wang, Ruizhong Du, Mingyue Li, Dongliang Xu, Chunfu Jia, Can Mei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computers
abstract: With the widespread application of Internet of Things (IoT) technology in the medical field, real-time collection and transmission of medical images become feasible. However, existing privacy-preserving image retrieval schemes often suffer from low efficiency and high communication overhead when operated in resource-constrained IoT environments due to the lack of efficient models. Thus, achieving efficient and secure medicalimage retrieval on limited-resource devices has emerged as a critical challenge. To address this, we propose LPPUBR, a lightweight, privacy-preserving, unsupervised bitmap retrieval scheme designed for IoT environments with constrained resources. LPPUBR utilizes a secure and lightweight deep learning model to extract deep feature descriptors from images and employs product quantization (PQ) to encode them into binary bitmaps, enhancing retrieval efficiency while reducing computational and storage costs. Particularly, a cross-quantization contrastive learning strategy is applied to jointly train the neural network model and PQ codewords for unsupervised learning. Furthermore, to improve interaction efficiency and reduce communication costs among multiple servers, we optimize the intermediate value recovery operation and redesign the related protocols in n-party secret sharing using a group communication strategy. A comprehensive theoretical analysis and experimental evaluation demonstrate that LPPUBR maintains retrieval accuracy comparable to the original unsupervised model while ensuring data security. Moreover, LPPUBR surpasses existing schemes in terms of computational cost, communication overhead, and retrieval efficiency.

title: Expression of Concern for: MindSpeak: An AI-Driven Mobile Application to Enhance Communication Skills for Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder
authors: Ahmed Hossam Ezzat, Ahmed Osama, Fares Abdelhamid Elsherif, Mohamed Hossam Eldin, Karim Hesham, Ahmed Mansour
publish: 2025 International Mobile, Intelligent, and Ubiquitous Computing Conference (MIUCC)
abstract: This paper presents MindSpeak, an AI-driven mobile application designed to enhance communication skills in children diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The application integrates a conversational avatar, therapeutic minigames, and real-time emotional and behavioral analysis using facial expression recognition, vocal tone detection, eye gaze tracking, and behavior monitoring. Each session is recorded, analyzed, and summarized using a large language model, specifically Generative Pre-trained Transformer 4 (GPT-4), with comprehensive reports delivered to therapists and parents. The system combines AI-based monitoring with structured, engaging therapy sessions to provide a novel, accessible platform that supports continuous, personalized intervention at home and complements traditional therapeutic approaches. Experimental evaluations demonstrate strong performance across all modules, validating the system's potential for supporting children with ASD.

title: Coupled Physics-Informed Neural Network for Multi-Physics Modeling in Additive Friction Stir Deposition
authors: Raghav Gnanasambandam, Nikhil Gotawala, Xiaofeng Wu, Benjamin Standfield, Chaoran Dou, Hang Z. Yu, Jian Yu, Zhenyu Kong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Additive Friction Stir Deposition (AFSD) is an emerging metal additive manufacturing process gaining increased attention due to its solid-state processing nature, resulting in desirable mechanical properties and the capability of fabricating large parts. To understand the multi-physics nature of the process, modeling of thermal distribution and material velocity during processing is imperative, which can be addressed by solving the related partial differential equations (PDEs). However, complex coupled PDEs entail inaccuracies and slowness in utilizing the existing numerical methods, such as the Finite Volume Method (FVM). This work proposes a neural network-based method, coupled Physics Informed Neural Network (coPINN), as a fast and accurate mesh-free solution for predicting the thermomechanical states during the AFSD process. In the case studies, the proposed coPINN accurately predicts the velocity and temperature distribution for a steady-state non-linear coupled fluid dynamics-heat transfer model of the AFSD process faster than the existing FVM. Comprehensive comparisons with residual errors show the proposed method’s trustworthiness in handling coupled physics, non-linearity, and mixed boundary conditions. In addition, the solutions of our approach show better conformance with the actual experimental data than the FVM-based solver. Overall, this work shows more efficient neural network-based solutions of a PDEs-based model than a traditional numerical method.

title: Pilot Contamination Aware Transformer for Downlink Power Control in Cell-Free Massive MIMO Networks
authors: Atchutaram K. Kocharlakota, Sergiy A. Vorobyov, Robert W. Heath
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Learning-based downlink power control in cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CFmMIMO) systems offers a promising alternative to conventional iterative optimization algorithms, which are computationally intensive due to online iterative steps. Existing learning-based methods, however, often fail to exploit the intrinsic structure of channel data and neglect pilot allocation information, leading to suboptimal performance, especially in large-scale networks with many users. This paper introduces the pilot contamination-aware power control (PAPC) transformer neural network, a novel approach that integrates pilot allocation data into the network, effectively handling pilot contamination scenarios. PAPC employs the attention mechanism with a custom masking technique to utilize structural information and pilot data. The architecture includes tailored preprocessing and post-processing stages for efficient feature extraction and adherence to power constraints. Trained in an unsupervised learning framework, PAPC is evaluated against the accelerated proximal gradient (APG) algorithm, showing comparable spectral efficiency fairness performance, while significantly improving computational efficiency. Simulations demonstrate PAPC’s superior performance over fully connected networks (FCNs) that lack pilot information, its scalability to large-scale CFmMIMO networks, and its computational efficiency improvement over APG. PAPC is further validated through ablation studies and evaluated across several representative CFmMIMO scenarios, demonstrating robustness to pilot contamination, scalability, and adaptability to varying user counts without retraining.

title: Telehealth Integrity Assurance Strategies for Confidential Virtual Consultations Across Medical Platforms
authors: Hayder Rageh Abdulsada, Mustafa Abdulirees Jebur, Ammar Abdulhassan Muhammed, Ihsan Alwan Muhsin, Estabraq Rasheed Ibrahim, Mohammed Saeb Nahi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Telehealth has emerged as a transformative solution in modern healthcare, enabling virtual consultations across multiple medical platforms. Ensuring the integrity and confidentiality of these digital interactions is crucial for protecting patient privacy and maintaining trust. Existing methods often struggle with fragmented consent processes, limited data transparency, and susceptibility to unauthorized access. This paper proposes a Blockchain-Enabled Consent Management (BECM) framework that utilizes smart contracts to securely record, verify, and manage patient consent in real-time. The BECM system ensures immutable, transparent, and auditable consent logs, enhancing data governance across telehealth platforms. By integrating BECM, healthcare providers can automate access control, reduce administrative overhead, and improve compliance with privacy regulations. The findings demonstrate that BECM significantly enhances data integrity, strengthens patient autonomy, and reduces potential security breaches during virtual consultations. This methodology offers a scalable and interoperable solution for ensuring secure and confidential telehealth services. The proposed method achieves data integrity at 98.70%, patient autonomy at 96.73%, security and privacy compliance at 97.34%, and System Scalability and interoperability at 97.84%.

title: Machine Learning-Based Threshold Voltage Estimation of Transistors Using PVT-Aware Design Inputs in the Memory Read Path
authors: Surabhi A S, Sujatha Hiremath
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Accurate prediction of threshold voltage (Vth) is vital for ensuring the reliability of transistor-level designs, particularly in the SRAM read path where even minor shifts in Vth can lead to functional errors. This work introduces a machine learning based framework to estimate the threshold voltage of individual transistors using PVT-aware input parameters such as channel length, width, supply voltage, temperature, and threshold voltage flavor. A comprehensive dataset was generated through detailed simulations of different transistors using Cadence Virtuoso and Spectre, covering a wide range of process corners and operating conditions. Several machine learning models like decision trees, support vector regression (SVR), and neural networks were trained to learn the nonlinear mapping between design inputs and Vth. Among them, the Random Forest model achieved the best performance with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.9992 and a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.000149, demonstrating high accuracy and generalization capability. A user-friendly graphical interface was developed to allow users to input design parameters and generate Vth results, significantly reducing dependency on time-consuming SPICE simulations. This methodology provides a fast and efficient tool for variation-aware design, with potential for future extension to include aging effects and support for advanced technology nodes in circuit design automation.

title: A Dual-Stage Adaptive Normalization Strategy to Compensate Resistance Drift in Flexible Sensor Smart Gloves
authors: Luyang Zhang, Ge Song, Dapeng Yu, Guangxin Zhou, Xingyu Ma, Da Chen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: With the rapid development of wearable technology, smart gloves based on flexible sensors have shown great potential in fields such as game control, human-computer interaction, and virtual reality. Resistance baseline drift poses a critical challenge in practical applications of flexible sensors, as it is strongly influenced by factors such as wearing style, environmental fluctuations, and material relaxation. This drift becomes particularly pronounced during repeated usage, leading to inconsistent data distributions that degrade the accuracy and stability of recognition models. To address this problem, this study develops a smart glove system using flexible sensors composed of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs)/iron(Fe) composites, whose performance is further optimized through plasma etching. We propose a Dual-Stage Adaptive Normalization (DSAN) algorithm based on Z-score standardization, which combines offline historical statistics with dynamic initialization at system startup to enable individualized sensor calibration. By collecting initial data under static conditions, the algorithm dynamically updates the baseline mean and standard deviation according to the current environment, effectively compensating for initial resistance offsets. In addition, a sliding window mechanism is designed to continuously track baseline drift trends, ensuring long-term stability and reliability of the sensors. Experimental results demonstrate that DSAN significantly mitigates the impact of initial resistance variation on recognition accuracy, improving performance on uncalibrated new data from 21.89% to 94.57%. This validates the algorithm’s effectiveness in compensating for sensor drift and offers strong support for the stable operation of flexible sensors under repeated wearing and complex environmental conditions, thereby promoting the long-term practical deployment of wearable devices.

title: Machine Learning-Based Risk Assessment for Pressure Ulcers in Critical Care Patients
authors: Kishore Arul
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Hospital-acquired pressure ulcers (PUs) remain a significant challenge in intensive care units (ICUs), leading to increased morbidity, extended hospital stays, and higher medical costs. Traditional risk assessment tools, such as the Braden Score, have shown limitations in accurately predicting PU development. This study explores the use of electronic health record (EHR) data and machine learning models to enhance early risk stratification for PU prevention. By analyzing ICU patient data from a large-scale dataset, predictive models incorporating demographic, clinical, and laboratory features were developed. The most effective model demonstrated superior recall compared to conventional scoring methods, highlighting the potential for automated risk prediction in clinical decision-making. These findings suggest that leveraging EHR-based predictive analytics could improve early intervention strategies and optimize resource allocation for high-risk patients.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning for Growth Analysis in Hydroponics System for Byadgi Chilli Cultivation
authors: Eshitha I, Prashanth Kambli, Prathima M N, Priyanka M R, Suresh Kumar K R
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Modern agriculture is undergoing a significant transformation with the adoption of smart technologies, particularly in controlled environments such as hydroponics. One research direction is the use of a hybrid deep learning framework for predicting plant growth stages in hydroponic systems using daily time-series data. The proposed models aim to support precision agriculture through non-invasive and real-time monitoring techniques. Two architectures were developed and evaluated: Model 1-combining CNN + BiLSTM + Attention + MLP, and Model 2based on Transformer + MLP. These models process normalized sequential features, capturing both spatial and temporal dependencies in plant growth. Model 1 achieved superior performance with a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 2.0851, Mean Squared Error (MSE) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.0156, R 2$</tex> score of 0.8625, and an approximate accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5. 5 2 \%}$</tex>. Comparative results demonstrate that the attention-augmented convolutional recurrent network (Model 1) outperforms the Transformer-based architecture (Model 2) in this domain. This study highlights the potential of hybrid deep learning systems to improve automated plant phenotyping and growth stage prediction in resource constrained soilless environments.

title: Decentralized Finance (DeFi) Risk Management Using Blockchain and AI
authors: Godwin Francis, Ch Paramaiah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Decentralized finance (DeFi) is indeed transforming the financial ecology, offering technological solutions for lending, borrowing, and trading that operate without intermediaries. However, with the rapidity of DeFi's growth comes immense risks like smart contract vulnerabilities, untypical market behavior, or scams. The objective of this study is to investigate the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Blockchain technology to efficiently manage risks in DeFi platforms. Transparency, nonrepudiation, and decentralized control are the qualities guaranteed by Blockchain, and on the other hand, predictive analytics, proactive anomaly detection, and fraud prevention are the strengths of AI. The best use of these technologies in terms of risk assessment would be to design a system based on AI and blockchain - real-time risk assessment directly from the blockchain, secure data sharing assistance, and automating the risk mitigation strategies. We developed an artificial intelligence-based risk prediction model that was trained using past DeFi transaction data and we also drew up a framework that helps smart contracts provide automated responses to cybersecurity incidents. Our framework is more accurate in comparison with existing methods through simulations and case studies when it comes to risk detection and mitigation. This study proposes a reliable and resilient approach to the DeFi ecosystem that will boost further acceptance and credibility of blockchain-based financial systems.

title: Semantic Text Representation for Improved Machine Learning in Information Retrieval
authors: Jaya Verma, R. Srilakshmi, Mandvi Singh, Sankar, B.V.N. Praveena
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Information retrieval systems require rich semantic text representations to enhance machine learning performance in search tasks. In this study, we present a novel framework that leverages advanced lexical analysis and deep neural architectures to capture complex semantic linkages within documents. By identifying subtle layers of meaning that traditional models often miss, our approach produces richer and more accurate document representations. In addition, we proposed an attention mechanism that focuses on significant sentence-level concepts during encoding which enables the model to emphasize key information and improving its discriminative power. Our experiments shows that the proposed work outperforms conventional methods in retrieval effectiveness. It achieves a classification accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${9 1. 2 5 \%}$</tex> and an overall effectiveness of 93.24 % which surpasses the performance of existing models. The proposed method achieved a precision of 92.14 % and F1 score of 90.44 % & AUC-ROC of 96.41 %. These results represents that the proposed framework's superior ability to understand and retain relevant information.

title: Venture: A Mosquito Disease Prevention Assistant Smartphone Application with Disease Symptom Checking, Specialist Support, Awareness Features
authors: Mahfuzulhoq Chowdhury, Afroza Akter, Tanjum Motin Mitul, Md. Sagor Chowdhury, Ratnajit Dhar, Ishraq Samiha
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Humans are at risk from mosquito-borne diseases since they can cause illness and even death. There was no automated mosquito disease prevention system in the earlier research works with dengue, chikungunya, and malaria detection features, finding a mosquito disease treatment specialist, finding a treatment center, scheduling an appointment, detecting mosquito breeding sites, finding a platelet donor, and providing awareness features. This paper issues a smart phone application to help combat mosquito diseases with features like dengue, malaria, and chikungunya disease detection, treatment specialist search and booking, mosquito control company search, awareness program search, mosquito breeding site detection, platelet donor search, and help request posting. The findings of the app's potency evaluation showed that over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5 8 \%}$</tex> of examiners gave very adept feedback on its features.

title: Detection of Nanoparticles with Machine Learning Technique: Evaluation of Algorithm Performance
authors: Prajwal Sanjay Pisal, Jaydeep Kishore, B.P. Joshi, Shweta Goyal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Nano-particles (NPs) are widely recognized as significant elements in a wide spectrum of goods, including aesthetics and electronics. Their application is expanding, despite the fact that their substantial financial and social possibilities has yet to be fulfilled. NPs possess distinct features that make them helpful in a range of purposes; nonetheless, their apparent toxicity increases security problems. The novelty of the study is autonomous detection of nanoparticles with improved surveillance. Advances have been done to comprehend the threats that NPs represent to human well-being and the surroundings, but further study and surveillance are required. In the past decade, Machine Learning (ML) approaches have used massive databases and computational capacity to make advancements in domains ranging from recognizing faces to genetics. In recent years, ML approaches are being used in nanotoxicology, with very promising findings. This study used ML techniques to autonomously detect NPs depending on their physical features, resulting in excellent classification accuracy. The findings show that ML algorithms are efficient in detecting nanoparticles and emphasize the requirement for more accurate characterization approaches to assure their safety in a variety of uses. The proposed ML algorithms was found to be efficient at detecting NPs, with the NN method outperforming all others with an accuracy of 0.95.

title: Transformer-Based Deep Learning Approach for Potato Leaf Disease Classification
authors: Aishwarya N, S Cheran, S Sivananda Gnaneswar, Vaisshale Rathinasamy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Accurate classification of potato Leaf diseases are essential for prompt treatment and crop management. However, the presence of imbalanced datasets often biases model predictions toward majority classes. In this work, we present a thorough comparison of transformer-based models-Vision Transformer (ViT) and Swin Transformer-for the task of potato leaf disease classification. This study also evaluates the performance of these models on a real-world, imbalanced agricultural dataset applying the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Method (SMOTE) to balance class distributions. Key evaluation metrics include test accuracy, classification report, confusion matrix, true positives (TP), Cohen's Kappa score, and ROC-AUC. For benchmarking, we also train conventional CNN architectures—VGG16, ResNet50, DenseNet121, InceptionV3, MobileNetV2, and EfficientNetV2B3-under the same conditions. Results demonstrate the superior performance of transformer models, particularly Swin Transformer, which achieved a classification accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 1. 4 \%}$</tex>, while Vision Transformer reached 87.5%.

title: Blockchain-Assisted Trust and Transparency in Cross-Border Digital Asset Management System
authors: Wisam Ali Hasan, Saif Saad Hameed, Ahmed Imran Fattah, Saad Jader Mutlak, Rana T. Shwayyea, Ali Jaafar Dakhil
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Blockchain-Assisted Trust and Transparency in Cross-Border Digital Asset Management Systems aims to apply blockchain technology in enhancing digital asset management by increasing integrity, traceability, and compliance across borders. The study explores how the decentralized and immutable nature of blockchains can address persistent issues in global asset transactions. Existing cross-border digital asset management systems encounter issues of trust, lack of interoperability, regulatory discrepancies, and inadequate transparency. These limitations hinder the immediacy of verification, increase susceptibility to fraud, and impede compliance across multiple jurisdictions. To fill these gaps, this study formulates a Blockchain-Enabled Federated Identity Management framework (B-EFIM). The methodology is characterized by the iterative design, development, and evaluation of a blockchain-based system integrating smart contracts adjustable to specific jurisdictions with a permissioned distributed ledger, empowering clear, secure, and verifiable transactions. The proposed approach enables real-time supervision of asset movements, validates automated compliance, and establishes trust through verifiable records that are accessible to all stakeholders, including regulators, financial institutions, and asset custodians. It enables seamless alignment with regulatory requirements while enhancing operational effectiveness. The B-EFIM framework significantly enhances the practitioner's ability to monitor asset tracing and compliance issues while deepening stakeholder confidence in cross-border transfers of digital assets, proving it to be an effective and scalable solution for international financial infrastructures.

title: Global Data Governance for Enhancing Compliance and Ethics Across Intelligent Financial Service Network
authors: Ali Abdulkareem Hadi Al Magsoosi, Kawther Al-Fatlawi, Aqeel H. Al-Fatlawi, Mustafa M. Abd Zaid, Orhan M. Albayati, Labeeb Saadoon Alyassri
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Global data governance has become a critical pillar for ensuring compliance and upholding ethical standards across intelligent financial service networks that rely heavily on AI, automation, and cross-border data exchange. These networks require integrated oversight mechanisms that can adapt to real-time data flows and complex regulatory environments. Existing methods often struggle with fragmented regulatory regimes, lack of interoperability between systems, and insufficient transparency in AI-driven decision-making, leading to compliance gaps and ethical concerns such as data misuse and algorithmic bias. This paper proposes a governance framework that leverages AI-powered transaction monitoring systems aligned with the COBIT 2019 methodology to enhance compliance with anti-money laundering (AML) and data protection regulations. The framework supports real-time anomaly detection, transparent audit trails, and policy-driven controls for the ethical use of AI. The proposed method enables financial institutions to automate regulatory reporting, mitigate compliance risks, and promote responsible data practices across jurisdictions. It also facilitates interoperability and consistency in data handling across intelligent financial networks. Findings indicate that the implementation of this framework improves detection accuracy, strengthens regulatory compliance, and increases stakeholder trust in AI-enabled financial ecosystems.

title: Performance of ML Models for Benign Detection in Attack-Majority IoT Traffic
authors: Morteza Taheri, Sajad Haghzad Klidbary
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: The rapid growth of the Internet of Things (IoT) increases exposure to large-scale cyberattacks. In scenarios such as peak DDoS waves or botnet outbreaks, malicious traffic can vastly outnumber benign flows. An attack-majority condition that biases detection systems toward “always attack” harming benign recall. This work investigates benign traffic detection under attack-majority conditions using the IoT-23 dataset (86.3% attack, 13.7% benign). SMOTE, ADASYN, Random Over- and Under-Sampling, no-balancing, and Class-Weighting methods were compared across classical machine-learning and deep-learning models. Evaluation was conducted in terms of overall accuracy, macro-F1, class-wise precision and recall, and training time. Results show tree-based models with class weighting or no balancing can sustain strong benign recall at lower cost, while certain oversampling (e.g., ADASYN) may reduce benign detection. These findings guide the design of efficient IoT intrusion detection for attack-dominated environments.

title: A Fast and Less Sensor Open-Circuit Fault Diagnosis for Converters in DC Microgrids
authors: Sheng Gao, Hua Han, Hongyi Liu, Xinwei Tang, Weiwei Li, Mei Su, Yangfan Ju, Xinlong Zheng, Mingxin Hu
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: A fast and fewer sensor converter open-circuit fault diagnosis method is proposed based on sharing the measurement signals of controller of single-end converter of faulty line in DC microgrid (DCMG). The negative pole grounding (NPG) and converter open-circuit faults can be accurately identified by setting threshold of the first-order derivative of bus-side power (FODP). Compared with traditional converter fault detection methods, the proposed method does not require information such as voltages and currents of insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs) inside the converter, fault line currents, and communication links, and exhibits higher accuracy, reliability, and cost-effectiveness of fault diagnosis. Simulation results verify the feasibility of the method.

title: A Predictive Famework for APT Detection in Cyber-Physical Systems Using Attack Graphs and Exploitability Metrics
authors: Nur Ilzam Che Mat, Norziana Jamil, Yunus Yusuff, Miss Laiha Mat Kiah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The rapid rise of the Internet of Things (IoT) within cyber-physical systems (CPS) has brought about transformative automation and interconnectivity across sectors such as energy, healthcare, and manufacturing. However, this expansion also introduces new vulnerabilities, particularly to Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs), which are stealthy, multistage cyberattacks designed to bypass conventional defenses. In this paper, we propose a multi-stage APT detection and prevention technique that combines correlational analysis with an enhanced attack graph model tailored for CPS environments. The proposed model integrates APT specific behavior stages with real-time system vulnerabilities, leveraging Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base and temporal scores to quantify exploitability and predict attack progression. Our approach includes a three-step pipeline: (i) attack vector detection based on event correlation, (ii) alert clustering and filtering, and (iii) attack path prediction using logistic regression on historical threat data. Simulations were conducted using datasets from SCADA-based environments, and vulnerability data from the National Vulnerability Database (NVD). The proposed detection method achieved a classification accuracy of 93.36% using a decision tree model that is able to demonstrate high precision in identifying APT patterns and their probable future stages. The significance of this study lies in its ability to bridge the gap between static vulnerability assessment and dynamic APT behavior modeling. We conclude the paper with potential future work to explore expanding the model to include scenarios with multiple adversaries and overlapping attack paths.

title: Byzantine-Resilient Federated Deep Learning for Secure and Privacy-Preserving Smart Healthcare Using Krum
authors: Inbithaq Ahmed Shakir, Wael Yahya Yaseen, Azhaar A. Shalal, Doaa S. Salman, Amjed Abbas Ahmed, Haneen Siraj Ibrahim, Alaa Sabree Awad, Zahraa Haimeed Rasool
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Federated deep learning that said, the idea of federated deep learning is to be able to train models collaboratively over decentralized data sources without revealing sensitive data. Regarding to intelligent healthcare systems, federated deep learning is critical in enabling secure use of dispersed patient data collected by wearable sensors, medical equipment and electronic health records. In this work, we study the problem of privacy-preserving federated deep learning, to enable it while preserving the privacy of the training data and designing architectures that do not centralize the data. To cope with malicious updates in federated learning, we present a Byzantine-Resilient aggregation algorithm based on Krum. The methodology overcomes model vulnerabilities, adheres to privacy standards, and enables secure collaboration among heterogeneous healthcare organizations.

title: A Comprehensive Survey of Emotion Detection in Conversational Chatbot
authors: Nupur Deochake, Mohammed Asif Zamir, Rajendra M Sonar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: This review article discusses the role of emotion detection in improving chatbot interactions, particularly through the use of emojis in text-based communication.
