As AI chatbots are used more and more in fields like customer service, online shopping, and healthcare, there is a growing need to make these systems more human-like and emotionally intelligent. While chatbots are efficient at handling basic queries and providing quick responses, they frequently fail to understand the emotions behind a user's message, which can result in boring or robotic conversations. This paper discusses the current methods for detecting emotions from text and emojis, including machine learning and deep learning approaches, and highlights some of the major challenges in this field, including sarcasm detection, understanding cultural differences in emoji use, and the lack of standard datasets for proper model comparison. Furthermore, the paper suggests potential directions for future research to develop emotionally aware chatbots that can respond in a more personalised, human-like, and engaging manner.

title: ML – Inspired Intelligent Error Detection System for TCP Communication
authors: Kiran V, Vidyashree G, Suma P
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Through sequencing, retransmission, and acknowledgements, Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) guarantees dependable data transfer. However, dynamic network conditions like noise and congestion make static error detection methods ineffective. In order to accomplish intelligent error detection and retransmission, this paper proposes a lightweight C-based simulation framework that imitates machine learning-inspired logic. The system mimics adaptive correction by simulating TCP packet flow, adding random errors, and using conditional rule-based logic. A 100% packet delivery ratio and high network efficiency were attained in the experimental results using a small-scale packet stream (50 packets, 3 induced errors). Even though this implementation isn't a complete machine learning model, it offers a modular framework for integrating actual machine learning classifiers and evaluating large networks in the future.

title: Privacy-Preserving COVID-19 Screening Using Homomorphic Encryption and Logistic Regression
authors: Mirjalol Norchayev, Toshpulat Oqboyev, Nurali Islamov, Abbos Sattorov, Malohat Yaxshiyeva, Zahraa Eisa, Mustafa Ali Alwash
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: As COVID-19 expands globally, dependable health screening systems protecting people's privacy are more important than ever. Traditional screening techniques demand the provision of sensitive health data, which raises reasonable privacy concerns. This paper utilizes Homomorphic Encryption (HE) and Logistic Regression to propose a novel architecture for reliable COVID-19 screening, thereby safeguarding patient data. Using a partially homomorphic encryption method, the proposed methodology encrypts patient characteristics, including symptoms, travel history, and exposure risk, allowing for direct logistic regression on encrypted data. The model is trained and evaluated using synthetic datasets imitating real-world screening scenarios. Experimental results show that, with almost little extra processing effort, the encrypted logistic regression model beats its plaintext counterpart (up to 93.5% accuracy). Other significant system features include meeting strict data security requirements and guaranteeing end-to-end data confidentiality. These results suggest that screening tools provided by HE might help to create a balance between data value and privacy, which is a significant consideration in developing pandemic response strategies.

title: Faithful by Design: Improving Large Language Model Rationales through Counterfactual Consistency Verification
authors: Nitin Kumar, Vipin Kataria
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Rationale generation in large language models faces critical challenges in ensuring faithfulness and interpretability, limiting their deployment in high-stakes applications requiring transparent reasoning. This study introduces a novel counterfactual verification framework designed to enhance rationale quality across diverse reasoning tasks and model architectures. We evaluate our approach using three state-of-the-art models—GPT- 4o, Claude-3.5-Sonnet, and LLaMA-3.3-70B—across benchmark datasets representing natural language inference (e-SNLI), multi-hop question answering (HotpotQA), and reading comprehension (MultiRC). The evaluation uses four metrics: counterfactual consistency scores, deletion-AUC for sufficiency analysis, perturbation robustness, and human simulatability assessments. Results show improvements in counterfactual consistency (median improvement = 0.086, p ¡ 0.001, Wilcoxon signed-rank test, N = 6,000), with effect sizes ranging from small-to-medium for computational metrics to very large for human performance measures. Human simulatability studies show a 14-point improvement in prediction accuracy (Cohen’s d = 3.50, p ¡ 0.001). Optimal rationale length is 15-35 tokens. Deletion curves indicate better information organization and sufficiency. GPT-4o outperforms other models, with Claude-3.5-Sonnet balancing efficiency and quality. Counterfactual verification enhances AI explainability by improving computational faithfulness and human comprehension, providing a reliable basis for trustworthy reasoning systems in critical applications.

title: Real-Time Gesture Recognition Algorithm Using CNN and LSTM for Secure Human-Computer Interaction
authors: Muhamed Fallahhusein, Manish Nandy, S.Senthil Kumar, Chandrakumar Vivek Kumar, D. Bhanu, Huda W. Al-Dulaimi, Haider H. Auda, Murtadha Yehya
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The need for real-time, user-friendly communication interfaces has driven gesture recognition system development. This need spurred system growth. This need has pushed Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) development forward. A hybrid deep learning architecture called GestureNet-HCI extracts spatial data using CNNs and LSTM networks to mimic temporal sequences. GestureNet-HCI integrates these neural networks. This study would benefit from our suggested structure. The technology is designed for real-time applications and accurately detects static and dynamic hand motions. The system had this feature. This was meant to streamline the procedure. It can collect and examine gesture data from depth video sources and RGB. Using video frames, the CNN module encodes visual-spatial characteristics. The LSTM, the other hand, learns motion continuity and temporal links. It is its responsibility. Resilience is attained by the model using an efficient sliding window frame sampling method and a data augmentation pipeline. You do this to become more resilient. Both elements offer the appropriate strength. With little Latency, GestureNet-HCI reaches state-of-the-art accuracy. Experiments with publicly available gesture datasets indicate that it is suitable for real-time uses. Among the pertinent data in these sets are Chalearn LAP IsoGD, NVGesture, and others. The proposed design allows for natural and effective interaction in smart surroundings, assistive technology, and virtual reality. This is a significant advancement. This allows a new standard for smart, responsive human-computer interaction (HCI) systems.

title: DCN-YOLO-Seg: A Proposed Multi-Task Framework for Large-Screen Display Defect Detection and Severity Assessment
authors: Ruchir Kakkad, Chiranjeevi C, Raj Mansuriya
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Large-screen LED/LCD display inspection requires balancing accuracy, robustness, and real-time performance. Current deep learning models struggle with irregular defects and lack integrated severity estimation. This study presents DCN-YOLO-Seg, a novel integrated framework that unifies defect detection, segmentation, and severity assessment through synergistic component integration. The architecture combines the YOLOv8 backbone enhanced with Deformable Convolutional Networks v4 (DCNv4) for adaptive feature extraction, temporal attention mechanisms for dynamic defect tracking, and specialized severity estimation with consistency regularization. The novel integration of these components enables comprehensive defect analysis within a single, cohesive architecture. Evaluation on an industrial dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4, 0 0 0}$</tex> images across six defect classes (bright pixel, color non-uniformity, dead pixel, lines, mura, scratches) achieved 94.50% accuracy, while cross-validation on benchmark datasets demonstrated superior performance on PKU-Market-Phone <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(96.50 \%)$</tex> and LCDLD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(99.69 \%)$</tex>. The system maintains <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 0}$</tex> FPS with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 5 - 3 7} \text{ms}$</tex> inference times during testing, indicating potential for high-throughput applications. DCN-YOLO-Seg establishes a practical and scalable framework for automated visual inspection in display manufacturing.

title: Scalable Microservice Architecture for Secure E-Commerce Using REST, JWT, and Kafka
authors: Smriti Prasad, Suresh C, S.G. Srivani
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents the design, development, and validation of a microservices-based e-commerce web application that prioritizes modularity, scalability, and secure transaction handling. Leveraging Spring Boot, Spring Cloud Gateway, Eureka for service discovery, and PostgreSQL for persistent storage, the architecture decomposes core functionalities—authentication, product management, and order processing-into independently deployable services. Each microservice communicates through RESTful APIs and is protected using stateless JWT-based authentication, ensuring robust access control. Kafka is incorporated to enable asynchronous, event-driven messaging for future scalability and realtime features. The Angular-based frontend interfaces with backend services exclusively via a secured API Gateway. Functional and performance validation using Postman and simulated user loads confirmed efficient API routing, strict role-based access enforcement, and low-latency service orchestration. The results demonstrate a production-ready, fault-tolerant system architecture suitable for modern e-commerce platforms, with extensibility to accommodate additional services such as payment integration, inventory management, and analytics.

title: Diabetes Prediction: Leveraging Smartphone Sensor Data in Activity Intensity and Heart Rate Monitoring Using LSTM Networks
authors: Abdul Kadar Muhammad Masum, Md Fokrul Islam Khan, Shafiqul Islam Talukder, Chanda Rani Debi, Khandaker Mohammad Mohi Uddin, Md. Maruf Hassan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: This paper presents a novel framework that integrates Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks with Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) to enable early, non invasive diabetes risk detection through smartphone sensor data. Using triaxial accelerometer and ECG signals collected over a 30 day period, the LSTM model achieved an activity recognition accuracy of 98.17% and a heart rate prediction $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ score of 0.9576. To address data scarcity and variability, GANs were employed to generate synthetic sensor data which enhanced models strength. A cosine similarity based risk estimator was used to compare experimental activity patterns with known diabetic profiles which reveals a moderate risk level (60.24%) in a target subject and stand by a 6.1% A1C test result. This framework offers a scalable, low cost solution for continuous health monitoring and early chronic disease detection using ubiquitous smartphone technology, providing significant promise for real world clinical deployment.

title: Assessing the Potential of Vehicle-to-Shelter (V2S) for Emergency Response: A Case Study of The Tokyo Metropolis
authors: Chengquan Zhang, Hiroshi Kitamura, Mika Goto
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: To enhance emergency response in urban areas, Vehicle-to-Shelter (V2S) technology—where electric vehicles (EVs) supply electricity to evacuation shelters—has emerged as a promising solution. This study focuses on the Tokyo Metropolis and proposes a multidimensional evaluation framework incorporating six indicators: earthquake probability, flood depth, population density, elderly population ratio, shelter burden, and solar panel installation coverage. Based on this framework, we calculated a V2S Need Index for all 53 administrative districts and identified significant regional disparities, with Region A emerging as the priority area for further analysis. Using Monte Carlo simulations, we developed a 72-hour emergency power demand prediction model for shelters in Region A and performed hypothetical calculations of V2S supply capacity. Results indicate that heating demand in large indoor spaces, such as school gymnasiums, strongly affects energy needs. For a shelter accommodating 1,500 people, achieving 95% coverage requires 1,123 kWh in cold conditions, 396 kWh in hot conditions, and 287 kWh in mild conditions—equivalent to 21, 8, and 6 EVs respectively (assuming 60 kWh battery capacity and 0.9 discharge efficiency). These findings demonstrate both the technical feasibility of V2S for disaster response and the importance of targeted regional deployment strategies.

title: An Optimal Route Planning for EV Shuttle Services Based on OpenStreetMap and Fundamental Geospatial Data of Japan
authors: Koki Kawaoka, Yuji Mizuno, Jiyoung Choi, Nobumasa Matsui
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This paper proposes an optimization method for shuttle routes, assuming the use of electric vehicles (EVs) for transportation services at medical facilities. With an aging population, the return of driver’s licenses and the reduction of public transportation services are progressing, while patients and other medical users increasingly require shuttle services to hospitals and nursing homes. The Japanese government has set a target of achieving $\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$ electric passenger-vehicle sales by 2035, and medical facilities are also considering switching from conventional gasoline vehicles to EVs. The proposed method constructs a three-dimensional road network by integrating elevation data provided by the Geospatial Information Authority of Japan (GSI) into the road network obtained from OpenStreetMap (OSM) using OSMnx. Route optimization is carried out in two stages. In the first step, Dijkstra’s Algorithm is used to find the optimal route between all destinations. In the second step, Simulated Annealing (SA) is used to optimize the visit order for the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP). As a result of the optimization, considering elevation increases energy consumption along the routes in this paper by approximately $\mathbf{1 8 \%}$ compared to the case without elevation. Furthermore, it shows that taking elevation into account enables the minimization of energy consumption.

title: An Intelligent Legal Consultation Service System Fusing Fine-tuning and Retrieval-Augmented Generation
authors: Guangming Chen, Kaifeng Ouyang, Hua Yin, Dan Ou, Xi Xu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Systems (ICCS)
abstract: To address the challenges of low efficiency, high cost, and poor accessibility in traditional legal services, this paper designs and implements an intelligent legal consultation service system that synergistically integrates model fine-tuning with an advanced retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) architecture. The system, based on the Qwen2-7B-Instruct model, is optimized on the DISC-Law-SFT legal dataset using the efficient LoRA algorithm, which significantly enhances its legal understanding and reasoning capabilities. To mitigate model "hallucinations" and ensure the timeliness of knowledge, we constructed a dynamically updatable legal vector knowledge base and employed a "hybrid retrieval-rerank" strategy to achieve precise citation of legal articles. Our experiments demonstrate that the system effectively alleviates factual hallucinations and significantly outperforms existing legal models in factual accuracy, logical reasoning, and citation correctness, enabling it to provide users with reliable, efficient, and accessible legal services.

title: Real-Time Brain State Reconstruction and Future Brain State Prediction
authors: Jimin Lee, Karthik Pullela, Hyunwoo Park, Jee Au Wah, Jinzhao Zhou, Chan Yeob Yeun
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a neurofeedback system capable of reconstructing and predicting brain states in real-time using EEG signals. The system addresses key challenges in EEG-based brain-computer interface (BCI) applications such as signal variability, stimulus inconsistency, and the limitations of static classifiers. We propose a pipeline that integrates rigorous preprocessing, multimodal stimuli generation, few-shot learning via NeuroGPT and reinforcement learning using GRPO. Our approach improves classification performance and enables real-time adaptation, making it suitable for applications in silent speech decoding, rehabilitation, and cognitive monitoring.

title: Log Anomaly Detection on Edge Devices Using Robust Principal Component Analysis
authors: Ruitao Yang, Fan Deng, Tao Liu, An Han
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Systems (ICCS)
abstract: The rise of IoT systems and edge computing creates an urgent need for efficient log anomaly detection on resource-constrained devices. Traditional centralized log analysis methods are unsuitable for edge deployment because of their high computational demands. This paper introduces RPCA, a lightweight framework designed for log anomaly detection on the edge that combines semantic-aware preprocessing with robust principal component analysis using an adaptive loss function. The framework uses FastText embeddings with TF-IDF weighting to produce distinctive log representations, followed by a robust PCA method that adapts to log pattern changes without requiring extensive computational resources. A cloud-edge collaborative architecture allows model updates while maintaining local processing capabilities. Experimental results show that RPCA achieves high detection accuracy on benchmark datasets and offers significant computational efficiency compared to traditional deep learning methods. Robustness testing indicates competitive performance against log variability, making RPCA suitable for dynamic IoT environments where log patterns frequently shift. The balanced trade-off between accuracy, robustness, and efficiency makes RPCA a practical solution for large-scale, edge-based log monitoring systems.

title: Particle Swarm Optimization for Dispatch Scheduling of Renewable Energy in Rwanda
authors: Chisom Ogbogu, Marion Kipsang, Jesse Thornburg
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: Rwanda faces persistent challenges of energy poverty, rising industrial demand, and increasing energy costs, prompting a reassessment of its energy development strategy. This study proposes an optimal dispatch framework for a 100 MW hybrid renewable energy system integrating solar PV, wind, proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolyzers, hydrogen fuel cells, and battery storage for reliability, affordability, and longterm resilience. Using a Particle Swarm Optimization algorithm, the model develops a least-cost dispatch strategy pursuing Rwanda’s 2050 electrification and decarbonization goals. It addresses critical issues such as intermittency, Rate of Change of Frequency, and dynamic energy storage. The optimized system reduces daily operational costs to less than one third the cost of conventional grid power alone. The integration of battery and hydrogen storage plays a central role in balancing supplydemand fluctuations, offering a techno-economically viable pathway for decentralized renewable energy systems, and advancing Rwanda’s broader energy transition as a model for sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Active Learning and Uncertainty-Driven Labeling for Improving Financial Risk Models in B2B Corporate Client
authors: Carolus Borromeus Widiyatmoko, Rahmat Gernowo, Budi Warsito
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Effective financial risk profiling of B2B corporate clients is essential for sustainable enterprise decision-making, yet is frequently challenged by data uncertainty, class imbalance, and complex real-world feature distributions. This paper proposes an integrated framework combining active learning, uncertainty-driven labeling, and stacked ensemble models to improve the robustness and balance of multi-class financial risk prediction in corporate client datasets. The approach leverages uncertainty quantification to systematically identify ambiguous instances, enabling targeted human relabeling and model retraining. Extensive experiments on real-world B2B financial data demonstrate that while XGBoost achieves the highest single-model performance, the proposed ensemble method provides more balanced results across classes, ensuring perfect recall for minority cases (Low Risk) and reducing boundary mis-classifications between Medium and High Risk. SHAP-based interpretability analysis further reveals the contribution of individual base-learners and supports explainable risk assessment. The findings validate the value of uncertainty-aware active learning and interpretable ensemble modeling in advancing robust, actionable B2B risk profiling. Future work will focus on operationalizing the active learning pipeline and expanding feature integration for even greater predictive performance.

title: Study on Reducing Electricity Consumption in Clean Rooms Air Supply System Through the Installation of Photovoltaic Solar Modules
authors: Carlos Alberto García Vázquez, Bernardo Yaser León Ávila, Darío Seguí Camacho, Osmel Pérez Baluja, Petru Adrian Cotfas, Ana Isabel González Santos, Daniel Tudor Cotfas
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This work focuses on reducing the energy consumed by the air distribution system for clean rooms in a biopharmaceutical industry through the installation of a solar panel array. For this purpose, a procedure for optimally sizing the array is proposed, which aims to minimize the number of photovoltaic solar panels (modules) needed to meet certain requirements by selecting the optimal number of strings in parallel and the optimal number of panels connected in series per string. In addition, an analysis of the influence of the tilt angle of the panels on the energy supplied by the array is conducted as a basis for the future design of a tracking system. The results show that, with the correct tilt angle, grid energy consumption can be reduced from $24.08 \%$ in winter to $28.25 \%$ in summer.

title: Dynamic Electric Vehicle Routing and Charging Optimization Using Ant Colony Algorithms and VANETs
authors: V. Surendra Reddy, P. Vasuki
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: As more and more people buy electric vehicles (EVs), we need smart routing and charging systems to make them more energy-efficient and reduce traffic jams. This paper suggests a real-time optimization framework that combines Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) with Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs) to make EV routing and charging more flexible and aware of traffic. The ACO algorithm uses a weighted graph to model the road network, taking into account things like the cost of energy, the time it takes to travel, and the delay in charging. VANET protocols allow for decentralized communication, which makes sure that everyone has the most up-to-date information about where vehicles are, where charging stations are, and how busy the network is. Using MATLAB to run simulations shows that the proposed system uses 17.3% less energy, routes 23.7% more efficiently, and waits 12.1% less time to charge than baseline models. These results show that ACO-V ANET hybrid systems are good at helping smart transportation networks support long-term EV mobility.

title: A Novel Scheme of Communication DPD based on Folding-Based Sensing Receiver in ISAC System
authors: Yan Li, Bin Wei, Jienan Chen
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: To meet high efficiency and signal quality standards, digital pre-distortion (DPD) is widely used in base stations. It effectively balances the linearity and efficiency of power amplifiers (PA). Traditional research faces two challenges: first, the added overhead of the feedback link; second, the wide dynamic range of feedback signals, which imposes high demands on the ADC of the receiving chain. If these demands are not met, it can result in saturation distortion, thereby impacting DPD calibration. This work eliminates the need for a dedicated DPD feedback structure by repurposing the ISAC sensing receiver as the DPD calibration path. This approach avoids the hardware overhead of a conventional separate feedback link through innovative component reuse .The innovation introduced in this paper is the integration of folding technology into the receiver, thus effectively preventing saturation issues in the received signal. We present an optimization of transmission and reception beamforming, enabling signal folding followed by DPD processing without the need for recovery. Theoretical analysis and simulations demonstrated in this paper to show the quantization advantages of signal folding DPD. According to the performance result, the proposed method can achieve 2dB ACLR gain with 4bit quantization.

title: Cost-Optimal Scheduling in Electric Vehicle-Enabled Microgrids Using an Improved Artificial Bee Colony Algorithm
authors: Duy C. Huynh, Hieu M. Pham, Loc D. Ho, Matthew W. Dunnigan, Corina Barbalata
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: This paper proposes a cost-optimal operation framework for grid-connected AC microgrids with integrated electric vehicles (EVs), aiming to minimize total operational costs through intelligent scheduling of distributed energy resources. The proposed system comprises solar photovoltaic (PV) generation, diesel generators (DGs), battery energy storage systems (BESS), and multiple EVs with controlled charging. A constrained optimization model is formulated, incorporating power balance, generator and storage constraints, grid exchange limits, and EV-specific charging schedules. To solve this complex scheduling problem, an improved artificial bee colony (ABC) algorithm is developed, integrating chaotic initialization and enhanced neighborhood search to accelerate convergence and improve solution quality. Comparative simulations are conducted against standard ABC, genetic algorithm (GA), particle swarm optimization (PSO), and non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm II (NSGA-II) under identical microgrid configurations. Results show that the improved ABC algorithm achieves the lowest total cost of 148.07 (USD/day), reducing costs by up to 9.66% compared to GA, while also demonstrating faster convergence. The inclusion and coordination of EVs as flexible energy assets significantly enhance operational efficiency, reduce diesel reliance, and promote better utilization of renewable energy. This research highlights the superior performance of the improved ABC algorithm and the transformative role of EVs in cost-effective and sustainable microgrid operation.

title: Low Power SRAM Optimization Using Transistor Stacking and Multi-Threshold CMOS (MTCMOS)
authors: Tejaswi Kulkarni, Vibha Vijaykumar, Vineeth Kumar, Shreyansh Arya, Kariyappa B.S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: In modern portable and embedded systems, minimizing power consumption in on-chip memory is a critical design objective. Static Random Access Memory (SRAM) plays a pivotal role in these systems, where leakage power dominates at sub-100 nm technology nodes. This paper presents a comprehensive power optimization of a 6T SRAM cell implemented using Cadence Virtuoso with gpdk45 PDK. Two key low-power techniques are investigated: Transistor Stacking, which reduces subthreshold leakage by serially connecting transistors in the pull-down path, and Multi-Threshold CMOS (MTCMOS), which employs High-Vt transistors in inverter paths and Low-Vt in access paths to balance power and performance. Simulations were performed using Spectre, and power analysis was conducted under hold conditions. The baseline SRAM consumed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$74 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>, while stacking alone reduced power to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$39 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>. MTCMOS achieved <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$43 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>, and the combined technique yielded a 66 % power reduction with only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex> average power. These results highlight the effectiveness of combined transistor-level optimization in low-power memory design.

title: Detection of Food Adulteration Using Fuzzy Logic Based Gas Sensors
authors: Munaf Ismail, Sri Arttini Dwi Prasetyowati, Eka Nuryanto Budisusila
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Meatballs are highly perishable and typically spoil within a few days, even if stored refrigerated. To extend their shelf life, some unscrupulous sellers illegally add borax, a chemical preservative known for its antimicrobial properties but banned in food due to its toxic effects on human health. Conventional borax detection methods often rely on expensive specialized equipment and trained operators, limiting their accessibility. To address these challenges, technological innovations such as the Electronic Nose (e-nose) offer a promising alternative. E-noses, which use gas sensors to mimic the human olfactory system, can evaluate food quality and detect harmful substances such as borax. In this study, the TGS 2600 and TGS 2611 gas sensors were used in the e-nose sensor array, each exhibiting distinct responses to volatile compounds released when meatballs containing borax are heated. The outputs of these sensors were analyzed using software to classify aroma patterns through simple learning and simulation. To interpret data containing uncertainty and ambiguity, the Mamdani fuzzy logic method was applied, which categorizes borax levels into three groups: safe (low borax), alert (near the threshold), and unsafe (high borax). This approach successfully translated sensor readings into comprehensive categories and achieved an accuracy rate of 91.1%, underscoring its potential as an effective tool for food safety monitoring.

title: Detecting Fake Reviews Through Feature Engineering, Statistical Analysis, and Machine Learning
authors: Rishi Manesh Nair, Malavika A Bipin, Sri Sowndariya T N, Shali S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Real online reviews highly influence purchases, whereas untrue reviews sidetrack buyers and advertise inferior products. Fake review detection aims at the creation of features that are language-specific and/or semantic or behavior based, such as punctuation use, sentiment polarity, category relevance, etc. In the present paper which is focused on the fake review detection, feature selection conducted by Welch's t-test and chisquare is enhanced with correlation-based filtering to boost robustness. Clustering algorithms identified hidden patterns that are then added into the feature set for classification through Logistic Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost, and Gradient Boosting. Cross-validation measures are taken to evaluate the models by different categories. It is observed that combining classical statistical methods with machine learning algorithms can provide a scalable and interpretable solution to improving trust in e-commerce platforms.

title: An improved CNN and Transformer hybrid method for colon polyp image segmentation
authors: Wenlei Fan, Ke Yi, Kaisheng Li, Xiaofeng Song, Yuejin Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of colorectal polyps is vital for early colorectal cancer detection. However, challenges such as low contrast and irregular shapes limit traditional methods. This paper proposes a lightweight segmentation network with a dualbranch encoder combining CNN and Transformer modules to extract both local details and global context. A Feature Fusion Module (FFM) is introduced to bridge semantic gaps between encoder and decoder. Depthwise separable convolutions are used throughout to reduce parameters and computation.Experiments on CVC-ClinicDB and Kvasir-SEG datasets show that our model outperforms state-of-the-art CNN and Transformer baselines, achieving a Dice score of 92.34% and IoU of 86.68% on CVC-ClinicDB. The model also significantly reduces FLOPs while maintaining accuracy. Ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of each component. Overall, our method balances performance and efficiency, making it suitable for real-time clinical applications.

title: Leveraging Airborne Wind Energy Systems (AWES) to Build Reliable Microgrids in Remote Regions
authors: Luca Benoit, Miyu Nakamori, Francesco De Lorenzo, Yuri R. Rodrigues
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: This paper investigates the integration of Airborne Wind Energy Systems (AWES) to develop reliable microgrids for remote regions. Wind energy holds vast untapped potential at distribution level, and recent advancements in AWES technology make it a promising distributed energy resource (DER) solution. Despite significant progress and growing demand for such resources, the potential of AWES especially when compared to traditional renewable sources remains underexplored. This work aims to evaluate the energy and power production capabilities of Pumping Kite AWES in comparison to Solar PV systems using a real-world case study based on Nome, Alaska; a region facing unique energy challenges due to its isolation. By comparing the performance of these distinct DERs technologies, the study seeks to highlight the advantages of AWES in terms of energy production, scalability, and adaptability. Obtained results provide valuable insights into the efficient deployment of AWES, demonstrating their potential applicability in small-to-medium-sized remote microgrid communities.

title: A Federated Learning Framework for Zero-Day Intrusion Detection in IoT Environments
authors: Bikrant Chhetry, Rakesh Matam, Ferdous Ahmed Barbhuiya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The increasing adoption of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has intensified the need for effective zero day attack detection, as traditional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) struggle with centralized data dependency and the requirement for labeled attack samples. We propose a Federated Learning (FL)based anomaly detection framework designed to address these limitations by training models solely on benign data distributed across IoT nodes. Leveraging the CICIoT2023 dataset, we apply Pearson's correlation-based feature selection to enhance feature relevance, reduce dimensionality, and ensure computational efficiency in resource-constrained environments. The trained model captures normal traffic patterns and identifies anomalies when evaluated on datasets containing both benign and malicious samples. The experimental results demonstrate high detection accuracy across heterogeneous clients. Additionally, the model achieves competitive performance when compared to existing FLbased techniques while maintaining privacy. By tackling data heterogeneity, reducing label dependency, and preserving data privacy, the proposed framework offers a scalable and resilient solution to safeguard IoT networks against emerging zero day threats, contributing a step forward in IoT security research.

title: Productivity Enhancement Using Generative AI in the Public Sector
authors: Jor Ji Yeoh, Ainuddin Wahid Abdul Wahab, Ahmad Zabidi Abdul Razak, Rashid Ating
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This paper examines the transformative potential of generative AI technologies—including text-to-text, text-to-image, text-to-presentation, and text-to-video systems—developed in Malaysia to boost productivity. While these innovative tools considerably improve efficiency and streamline workflow processes, current policy measures aimed at upskilling public staff have not kept pace with these technological advancements. This paper outlines the integration of generative systems in real-world applications and underscores the urgent need for accelerated upskilling initiatives to fully realize the benefits of AI-driven productivity enhancements.

title: Super-Stable Matching for Data Sharing enabled by the Secondary Data Market in Smart Grids
authors: Peizhe Xin, Zihao Fu, Jing Jiang, Rui Shi, Jing Zou, Zhiyi Chen, Zhaozheng Zhou
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: In the smart grid networks, data-intensive service becomes more and more popular. It is important to exchange data between different devices with high efficiency. The secondary data market leverages users’ bids information on monthly data usage to sell or buy leftover data caps from each other. It has been deemed as a promising third party that will satisfy different users’ data demands effectively. In this work, we introduce a new third party, DataMart. Different from the traditional data trade platforms, it can not only incentive all traders to bid users’ data demands and unit price truthfully but also permit all traders to bid heterogeneous users’ requirements, such as available time interval and data operator. Next, to guarantee the bid truthful, we design a data matching mechanism including two steps. First, we use the auction theory to determine the winner set and find a transaction price. Then to match buyers and sellers as many as possible, we divide each trader into multiple and virtual traders, and formulate a one-to-one matching game with ties. Furthermore, to solve it, a data matching algorithm based on matching theory is proposed to match buyers and sellers. Additionally, from the theory perspective, we analyze the existence, stability, truthfulness, and complexity of the data matching mechanism. Finally, the performances of the matching results are evaluated compared with the existing algorithms and demonstrating the practicability and efficiency of our proposed algorithm.

title: Prism-SQL: A Self-Judging Dual-Path Refraction Framework for Multi-Turn Text-to-SQL
authors: Le Zhou, Feng Yao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: In-context learning methods for multi-turn text-to-SQL tasks often suffer from instability due to error propagation, and their performance falls short of fine-tuned models that require significant training costs. To address this, we pro-pose Prism-SQL, a training-free framework that solves this problem by en-hancing reasoning robustness. The framework operates by generating two SQL candidates in parallel: one by incrementally editing the previous query, and the other by independently rebuilding from the entire dialogue history. Subse-quently, a critical self-judging step selects the optimal query. Experiments on SParC and CoSQL demonstrate that Prism-SQL achieves superior performance among in-context learning methods, with results that are highly competitive with SOTA fine-tuned models, thus validating the effectiveness of our dual-path generation and self-correction strategy.

title: Research on UAV Low Altitude Logistics Emergency Scheduling Mechanism for Urban Incidents
authors: Kan Yao, Yue Liu
publish: 2025 Low-Altitude Economy Forum &amp; International Conference on Low-Altitude Flight Technology and Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Application (LEF &amp; ICLU)
abstract: With the rapid expansion of the low-altitude economy, drones have become a critical component of urban logistics and emergency transportation. However, existing scheduling mechanisms often fail to provide efficient and reliable emergency response under multi-task concurrency and dynamic constraints. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a computationally optimized UAV emergency scheduling mechanism for low-altitude urban logistics. The proposed framework integrates an emergency priority determination model, multi-task fusion scheduling, and a two-level path planning algorithm. A hybrid Genetic Algorithm–Deep Reinforcement Learning (GA–DRL) optimization strategy is introduced to enhance global search and real-time decision-making efficiency, while an edge–cloud collaborative computing architecture accelerates task allocation through GPU-enabled parallel processing. Experiments based on real-world mission data from Shenzhen’s central urban area demonstrate that the proposed mechanism reduces average computation time by 38%, shortens response time by 45%, and increases task completion rate to 95.8%, significantly outperforming baseline scheduling methods. The results validate the system’s adaptability and robustness in complex urban environments. This study contributes a scalable and high-performance computational framework that advances both drone dispatch optimization and intelligent computing for urban emergency logistics.

title: Priorities for Upgrading Electric Vehicle Public Charge Points to Reduce Charging Session Duration
authors: Dinesh Chacko, Monika M. Wahi
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: In the United Kingdom (UK), electric vehicle (EV) public charge points (CPs) can have up to three connectors which charge at different speeds, from 3-7 kilowatts (kW) to over 150 kW. Charge Place Scotland (CPS) is the charging station operator (CSO) that implements and maintains the public EV charging infrastructure including all CPs in Scotland, and we used data on all of CPSs charging sessions (CSs) for eleven months in our analysis. Our research aims were to: 1) characterise factors associated with CS duration based on CS and CP attributes for EV users served by CPS, and 2) analyse whether adding more connectors at CPs could reduce CS duration on the CPS network. Using data from over one million CSs representing 6,335 CPs, we conducted a descriptive analysis, then bootstrapped the CS data into five linear regression model sets containing 1,000 models utilising datasets representing 1,000 CPs (containing at least 22,000 CSs). Average duration of CSs at rapid and ultra-rapid connectors was approximately 45 and 40 minutes respectively, while those at slow and fast connectors were over 3.5 hours. Bootstrap model sets demonstrated that number of connectors at the CP was not associated with reduced CS duration, but rapid connectors were associated with a statistically significant mean reduction in CS duration of about seven minutes. It is recommended that rather than adding additional connectors at CPs, CPS should upgrade existing connectors to rapid or ultra-rapid, and government programmes should incentivize use of these public CPs to offset the extra cost to consumers.

title: AI-Based Enquiry Chatbot Using Natural Language Processing
authors: Anshul Kumar Mandal, Varun Shukla, Harsh Yadav, Hamdan Zaman Khan, Anshika Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Educational institutions have seen the need to improve the communication to students, parents, and faculty and they need to have efficient and automated communication systems to meet the ever increasing demands. With this challenge in mind, developments of the AI based solutions have become necessary. In this paper, intelligent chatbot specifically designed for College web sites are presented. The chatbot is capable of accurately understanding and responding to the user queries using natural language, with the use of advanced Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques. It is a virtual assistant giving instant and reliable information on admissions, courses, fee structures and other institutional services. The chatbot greatly lightens up the administrative burden, makes the operation more efficient, and creates a uniform, friendly environment in the support.

title: Semantic Comment Analysis for Engagement Optimization
authors: Sahil Sharma, Mayur Waghmare, Ankita Darade, Nikhil Malusare, Jayshree Mahajan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: As the interactions continue to grow exponentially on social media sites, the content creators encounter increasing difficulties in interacting with their audience effectively. The sheer volume of user comments poses severe challenges in identifying recurring issues, providing timely feedback, and quantifying user sentiments. This paper introduces an integrated solution to problems above by combining three basic paradigms: semantic comment clustering, intelligent query matching, and sentiment analysis. Through clustering associated comments, semantic clustering helps producers respond to common questions better. Based on this as a premise, query matching identifies the most relevant previous answers to user questions and thus eliminates redundancy and speeds up responses. Finally, sentiment analysis provides an additional layer by categorizing feedback as positive, neutral, or negative, giving producers essential understanding of user sentiments. Collectively, these technologies introduce an end-to-end system that supports automated feedback management, stimulates timely engagement, and ultimately improves digital interactions for all parties involved.

title: Data-Driven Geospatial Analysis for Utility-Scale Solar PV Siting
authors: Mohamed R. Elkadeem, Ali Younes, Jakub Jurasz, Atif S. Alzahrani, Mohammad A. Abido
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The energy transition to renewable energy is essential for addressing power scarcity and environmental challenges. A key barrier to large-scale renewable energy (RE) deployment is resources assessment and the selection of optimal sites. This study introduces a data-driven methodology for evaluating land suitability and energy potential for utility-scale solar PV plants. The study integrates geographic information systems and multi-criteria decision-making to analyze spatial datasets and conflicting decision-making preferences. Key criteria include climatology, environment, location, and topography. The approach is validated with case study of Saudi Arabia’s Eastern Province. The results show that 83.6% of the region is not suitable for PV deployment due to constraints such as distance from transmission grids, transportation infrastructure, and restricted zones, including oil and gas facilities and flood-prone areas. Conversely, $16.4 \%\left(85,867 \mathrm{~km}^{2}\right)$ of the region is feasible for solar PV installation, classified into five suitability categories: $\mathbf{0. 0 4 \%}$ low, $\mathbf{0. 0 0 0 8 \%}$ moderate, 15.4% high, 0.29% very high, and 0.29% excellent. This research supports Saudi Arabia’s Vision 2030 by identifying viable solar energy sites and contributing to national energy diversification efforts. It supposed to enhance the strategic planning for large-scale solar PV deployment, providing a replicable framework for other regions aiming to optimize RE investments.

title: NFT-based Secure and Decentralized Energy Marketplace Using Blockchain
authors: Gia Ky Huynh, Ajmery Sultana
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: The energy sector faces inefficiencies, fraud, and lack of transparency, while the traditional peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading market faces challenges of trust, interoperability, and flexibility. This paper proposes an innovative solution leveraging blockchain technology to address these issues. By representing energy units as unique, verifiable Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs), our aim is to create a transparent, secure, and efficient energy marketplace. Our architecture integrates a Web3 marketplace with smart contracts to manage trading transactions, NFTs to visualize energy, and a sophisticated loyalty program to incentivize user participation. Furthermore, the platform improves user accessibility through cross-chain token bridging via the Across Protocol, enabling seamless fund transfers from Layer 1 or other Layer 2 networks to the Base network. These features collectively reduce entry barriers and expand market participation. Using blockchain technology, our solution addresses the limitations of traditional systems, offering enhanced security, user engagement, improved efficiency, and simplified access to the energy marketplace.

title: Machine Learning-Based Gesture Classification Using Hybrid EMG and MMG Signals for Upper Limb Prostheses
authors: Yasir Mohammed Ali Saeed, Mohammed Sabah Jarjees
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Muscle activity must be closely monitored in order to control prosthetic hands with extreme precision. Two significant biometric signals that represent the electrical and mechanical behavior of muscles are electromyography (EMG) and myomechanography (MMG). The system can gain a better understanding of the user's intended movements by employing multi-channel sensors to record both signals from distinct muscle regions. This method increases the prosthetic hand control's accuracy and responsiveness, making it more dependable and natural for daily use. An array of synchronized, low-noise sensors is used in this study to capture and process both electromyography (EMG) and myomechanography (MMG) signals, allowing for more detailed and responsive control signals. A root mean square (RMS) model is used for classification after real-time processing using advanced filtering and feature extraction techniques. Simulation and case study results showed improved control accuracy, reaching 95.3% for dynamic hand gestures and 93.8% for static grasps, with an average error of 4.2%. These results demonstrate the efficacy of combining EMG and MEG in a multi-channel framework to improve the accuracy and dependability of prosthetic hand systems.

title: Detecting UPI Fraud Using Machine Learning Techniques in Python
authors: Bhavana Ramesh Haleritti, Muneshwara M S, Jaymin Kania, Swetha M S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: As the digital payments in India have been rapidly increasing, the Unified Payments Interface (UPI) is one of the most sought-after methods of financial operations. Nevertheless, with this expanded usage, fraud has also grown at an alarming rate and is posing significant challenges to users and financial institutions. In this work, the author aims to identify and prevent fraudulent transactions of UPI using different machine learning methods. To maximize the reliability of the model, the dataset was subjected to a lot of preprocessing to eliminate redundant entries and normalize the feature values. A number of classification models, including Logistic Regression, K-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector Machine, Naive Bayes, Decision Tree, Random Forest and Convolutional Neural Network, were implemented and tested. The dataset was used in training the model using around 85 percent of the data and the other 15 percent was used in the validation and evaluation of the performance. Evaluation metrics that were used to gauge the efficiency of each algorithm included accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score and AUC-ROC. The Random Forest classifier was the most accurate of the models in the detection of fraudulent pattern with Decision Tree and K- Nearest Neighbors coming next. In constructing effective fraud detection systems, the study focuses on the need to have proper feature engineering, data preprocessing and algorithm selection. Also, it points out the inefficiency of algorithms such as the Naive Bayes to handle interdependent variables and the need to keep re-training to keep up with changing fraud patterns.

title: DeepPainSense: A Real-Time, Explainable Multimodal System for Chronic Pain and Emotional State Detection
authors: R Rajeshwari., KB SanirGithya., A Jenifer., M Revathi.
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: DeepPainSense is an intelligentsystem that operates in real time to identify chronic pain as well as emotional conditions like stress and anxiety through a multimodal strategy. It gets information from three main sources: facial expressions from a camera, body movements from motion sensors, and muscle activity from sensors that measure muscle movement. muscle activity (monitored through EMG sensors). Advanced deep learning methods are employed to analyze these signals, utilizing ResNet-50 combined with LSTM for facial recognition, BiLSTM or Transformer models for recognizing motion patterns, and ID CNN with LSTM for processing muscle signals. For precise predictions, an attention-based fusion layer integrates all feature outputs. The system can tell when there is pain and also notice actions like guarding, limping, or bracing, and it checks how bad the pain is. It also uses multitask learning to identify emotional states, which helpes in fully understanding both the patient's physical and mental health. DeepPainSense also incorporates Explainable AI (XAI) through tools like SHAP and LIME, which clarify the rationale behind each prediction, fostering trust among both users and healthcare professionals. Real-time feedback is given via a chatbot or voice assistant, which is especially helpful for home physiotherapy, remote monitoring, and taking care of elderly people.

title: Enhancing Real-Time Fraud Detection in Financial Transactions using Advanced Machine Learning Models
authors: Md Shafiqur Rahman, Balayet Hossain, Mst Masuma Akter Semi, Mahmud Hasan, Md Kamrul Hasan, Khandakar Rabbi Ahmed
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Fraudulent transactions have increased exponentially as a result of the expanding trend of digital financial transactions, endangering banks and other companies alike. For instance, the dynamic of fraud approaches is incompatible with the majority of conventional fraud detection systems, which are mainly based on rule-based systems. In this paper, we analyze several cutting-edge machine learning (ML) models for real-time fraud detection in the financial transaction arena, such as LightGBM, DNNs, GCNs, and Transformers. We test these models on a dataset of more than 10 million transactions and assess their temporal efficiency, accuracy, precision, and recall. LightGBM is the best model for fraud detection, according to the results, since it performs better than the other models in terms of accuracy, precision, and recall. The issues of class imbalance, real-time adaptability, and computational cost related to these models are then discussed. To boost performance, we intend to investigate the combination of federated learning and deep reinforcement learning in the future.

title: Design of a Frequency Variable Capacitor Array as Part of a Load Sided Resonant Inverter for PMSMs
authors: Jan Loos, Daniel Zimnowoda, Niklas Reich, Kerstin Siebert, Holger Hirsch
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The proceeding decarbonization leads to an increasing demand on efficient power conversion in electrified powertrain applications. Resonant DC-to-AC converter topologies are well known for their improved efficiency in comparison to conventional converters, due to the reduction of switching losses. In this contribution a load sided resonant inverter operating a Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine is considered. In order to operate the machine under resonant condition at different speeds, the resonant tank must be adjusted. To do so, a capacitor array is designed, which enables a reactive power compensation across a specified speed range of the machine. The design and layout of the capacitor array is derived and the required capacitances are optimized via a Genetic Algorithm. The design is then validated with measurements of a demonstration setup.

title: Implement TCP Tahoe, Stop-and-Wait Protocol, Prim's Algorithm, and Bit Stuffing to Assess Latency and Throughput Performance
authors: Kiran V, Manjunath M, Akshay Ganesh S, Rishi Gowda A
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This work aims to implement and evaluate the performance of four fundamental networking algorithms and protocols: TCP Tahoe, Stop-and-Wait protocol, Prim's algorithm, and Bit Stuffing. Each method addresses a critical aspect of data communication—congestion control, reliable transmission, optimal routing, and frame synchronization, respectively. The work integrates these protocols across different layers of the OSI model to simulate real-world communication scenarios. Performance is assessed using key metrics such as latency and throughput, offering insights into the efficiency and reliability of each approach. The results, visualized through graphs and charts, help interpret the behavior and effectiveness of these strategies in ensuring robust data transfer. On average, the system achieved a latency of 0.0258 seconds and a throughput of 65.47 packets per second. This work emphasizes the importance of layered protocol design in achieving efficient and accurate network communication.

title: Strategic Risk Intelligence: A dual-framework Approach using OCTAVE Allegro and STRIDE
authors: Hilalah Alturkistani, Abdul Ghafar Jaafar, Suriayati Chuprat
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: In the realm of organizational security, the integration of risk assessment into the software development process for websites and organizations often involves relying on external security experts. However, our study proposes a self-contained dual-framework approach for internal teams. This research presents an agile methodology that uses two successful strategies to improve software risk assessment for web-based applications: (1) The OCTAVE Allegro risk assessment framework, which helps identify and evaluate an organization's critical assets. This framework produces reliable results even without extensive security expertise, (2) The STRIDE threat modeling tool which systematically identifies and assesses potential threats, providing a structured approach to threat assessment. The outcomes of this study deliver a comprehensive risk analysis for web application software, encompassing asset identification, risk assessment, and detailed analysis. A strategic roadmap is also outlined for mitigating risks and implementing effective countermeasures, particularly protecting investments that significantly impact core business operations. This research is especially beneficial for organizations aiming to enhance their information security frameworks, particularly those that rely heavily on web applications. As a practical outcome, the study proposes tailored mitigation strategies and countermeasures for assets with critical business implications, demonstrating improved assessment speed and clarity for small and medium-sized enterprises lacking in-house security expertise.

title: Generative AI and Cloud Data Engineering for Business Intelligence
authors: Kishore Ande, Sarvesh Kumar Gupta, Amit Ohja, Jakhongir Shaturaev, Bobur Mirzayev
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The GenAI and cloud-native data engineering confluence is revolutionizing the BI landscape to allow for real-time analytics, at scale, but closer to the human scale. This paper reviews the technical underpinnings, experimental validations, and system architecture of accommodating LLMs in cloud data platforms like Snowflake, BigQuery, and Azure Synapse. We evaluate the effectiveness of GenAI for augmenting data-to-insight pipelines from natural language querying, to prediction, forecasting and report generation, across ten key studies developed over 2019–2023. We also propose a unified theoretical framework, provide benchmark studies and experimental findings, which reveal GenAI's shift to a general-purpose, domain-agnostic, transformative utility but the limitation of practical cost, interpretability, and ethical deployment. Finally, we propose future research directions focusing on explainability, domain adaptation, and sustainable architectures for enterprise level adoption.

title: Expression of Concern for: Developing a System to Detect Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) in Children from Facial and Behavioral Features Using Multimodal Approach
authors: Muhammad Mubinur Rahman, Hasan Murad, Sharmistha Chanda Tista
publish: 2024 27th International Conference on Computer and Information Technology (ICCIT)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a brain disorder for which symptoms such as repetitive activities or movements start appearing in early childhood. Early detection of ASD empowers parents to take appropriate actions and proper care of the affected children. Earlier research works have mostly focused on detecting ASD from either facial images or behavioral data. However, combining both types of features would ensure better prediction of ASD. In this research work, we have proposed a system to detect ASD in children by evaluating both facial image and behavioral features. We have developed an integrated dataset that contains both images and behavioral data by combining two existing individual image and behavior datasets. We have designed a multimodal model architecture, trained different CNN models on the new integrated dataset, and evaluated the performance of each model. MobileNetV3Large model has outperformed all the other models with an accuracy of 97.36%. Finally, a simple webapp has been developed that takes an image and other behavioral data as inputs and predicts if the child is a probable ASD patient.

title: Unified Namespace: A New Paradigm for Industrial IoT Data Integration
authors: Juliam A. Díaz, Juan M. Rey, Iván Hernández, Natalia Duarte, Walker Reynolds
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Magazine
abstract: The adoption of Industry 4.0 has accelerated the use of advanced digital technologies in manufacturing. Unified Namespace (UNS)-based architectures offer a powerful solution by enabling seamless, real-time data integration and scalable interoperability across systems. However, their adoption remains limited due to the lack of comprehensive documentation and well-defined design methodologies. This paper addresses that gap by consolidating key concepts and design methods for UNS implementation in manufacturing. To demonstrate practical relevance, a case study illustrates how UNS enhances data integration and operational efficiency in real manufacturing environments. By providing a structured and practical reference, this work equips both academia and industry with the tools needed to accelerate UNS understanding and adoption.

title: Reconfigurable Holographic Metasurface Enabling Independent Manipulation of Radiating and Scattering Patterns
authors: Yuzhen Chen, Xiaoyi Wang, Feng Xu, Guo-Min Yang, Ya-Qiu Jin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This article presents a novel single-polarized, 1-bit reconfigurable holographic metasurface (RHM) capable of independent manipulating radiating and scattering patterns. The proposed architecture integrates a single PIN diode per unit cell to dynamically switch between distinct surface impedance states and reflection phases. This enables three concurrent functionalities: beam steering for radiating and scattering patterns; radar-cross-section (RCS) reduction through absorption; and polarization conversion, including linear-to-left/right hand circular polarization (LHCP/ RHCP) and cross-polarization transformations. A 32×24 reconfigurable metasurface array fed by a Rotman lens is designed, fabricated and measured. Experimental results show that the RHM can achieve E-plane beam steering from −30° to 60° and H-plane beam steering from −30° to 30° through surface impedance modulation and feeding port selection respectively, under 9 GHz surface wave (SW) excitation. Beam steering up to ±60° in E-plane is achieved across 11-15 GHz via programmed reflection phase gradients under space propagating wave (SPW) illumination.

title: An Automatic Calibration Method for Low-Overlapped Roadside RGB-D Camera Network
authors: Jingda Chen, Hanyang Zhuang, Yuesheng He, Chunxiang Wang, Ming Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Roadside multi-sensor networks, such as RGB-D camera networks, play a crucial role in Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS). These systems rely on accurate extrinsic parameters (i.e., the relative positions and orientations) of each camera in the network. However, achieving fast and accurate large-scale extrinsic parameter calibration is challenging, especially when the overlap between camera views is limited due to cost constraints. To address this issue, we propose an automated, scalable, and marker-free calibration method that requires no human intervention. Our approach leverages dynamic rigid bodies, such as moving vehicles, as bridges to establish associations among all cameras without manual placement or supervision. The proposed method consists of three main stages: 1) calibrating camera height, roll, and pitch using the ground plane; 2) estimating each camera’s 2D position and yaw angle based on trajectories; and 3) refining these estimates by matching features on the road surface using SuperPoint and SuperGlue. Real-world experiments involving 58 roadside RGB-D cameras deployed in a parking lot demonstrate that our method significantly improves calibration efficiency while maintaining high accuracy, making it well-suited for large-scale RGB-D camera network deployment.

title: Online Optimization on Hadamard Manifolds: Curvature-Independent Regret Bounds on Horospherically Convex Objectives
authors: Emre Sahinoglu, Shahin Shahrampour
publish: IEEE Control Systems Letters
abstract: We study online Riemannian optimization on Hadamard manifolds under the framework of horospherical convexity (h-convexity). Prior work mostly relies on the geodesic convexity (g-convexity), often leading to regret bounds scaling poorly with the manifold curvature. To address this limitation, we analyze Riemannian online gradient descent for h-convex and strongly h-convex functions and establish O(T) and O(log(T)) regret guarantees, respectively. These bounds are curvature-independent and match the results in the Euclidean setting. We validate our approach with experiments on the manifold of symmetric positive-definite (SPD) matrices equipped with the affine-invariant metric. In particular, we investigate online Tyler’s M-estimation and online Fréchet mean computation, showing the application of h-convexity in practice.

title: Artificial Boundary Design for Industrial Systems With Dual-Constraints Structure: A Two-Level Constraints Following Control Scheme
authors: Yuan Zhang, Yudong Wei, Dongyue Zhang, Yang Liu, Guoqing Qi, Chenming Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: A two-level control scheme for velocity limitation in mechanical systems is proposed, based on the Udwadia–Kalaba and diffeomorphism theory. First, a dynamic model incorporating equality constraints is developed. Considering uncertainties, the first-level robust control algorithm is designed. Second, using diffeomorphism theory, the system state is transformed, and the second-level control strategy is formulated to ensure compliance with inequality constraints. Furthermore, through Lyapunov stability analysis, the uniform boundedness and uniform ultimate boundedness of the system are validated. This control scheme constrains system velocity within the desired range and reduces the amplitude of velocity fluctuations. Finally, simulation-based validation on a nonlinear system confirms the effectiveness of the proposed control approach.

title: Tu(r)ning AI Green: Exploring Energy Efficiency Cascading with Orthogonal Optimizations
authors: Saurabhsingh Rajput, Mootez Saad, Tushar Sharma
publish: IEEE Software
abstract: AI’s exponential growth intensifies computational demands and energy challenges. While practitioners employ various optimization techniques, that we refer as “knobs” in this paper, to tune model efficiency, these are typically afterthoughts and applied in isolation without understanding their combined effects on energy efficiency. The goal of this exploratory empirical study is to emphasize on treating energy efficiency as the firstclass design consideration by demonstrating how strategic knob selection across five AI pipeline stages (data, model, training, system, inference) creates cascading efficiency gains. We evaluate 30 experimental variants on ModernBERT, an encoderonly architecture, examining individual techniques and their orthogonal combinations. Results shows that model pruning provides the highest single-knob energy savings (up to 84.6%), while orthogonal combinations reduce energy consumption by up to 94.6% while preserving 95.95% of baseline F1 score. This work provides actionable frameworks for informed green AI that balance efficiency, performance, and environmental responsibility in AI systems.

title: Guest Editorial of the Special section on Enhancing Consumer IoT Security With Immersive Embedded Cyber-Physical Systems
authors: Chinmay Chakraborty, Chao Huang, Bhuvan Unhelkar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Embedded cyber-physical systems that are immersive in nature and integrated into Consumer Internet of Things (CIoT) devices offer a host of benefits including: (a) Immerse Yourself: CIoT devices equipped with immersive technologies can provide interactive and engaging user experiences, including AR interfaces and multimedia content. (b) Contextual Intelligence: Immersive embedded systems allow CIoT devices to respond to contextual cues, providing personalized and adaptive functionalities based on user activities and environments. (c) Real-Time Responsiveness: Cyber-physical systems (CPS) within CIoT can analyze data in real-time, offering instant feedback and dynamic adjustments in response to user input or environmental changes. (d) Virtual Companions: Immersive technologies integrated into CIoT devices can offer lifelike virtual assistants, enhancing user engagement and natural interactions within smart home environments. (e) Sensory Exploration: Immersive embedded systems can provide advanced sensory feedback, including haptic feedback, spatial awareness, and environmental responsiveness, enriching user interactions and environmental perception.
