title: Ultrafast High-Voltage Pulse Shaping Using Dual-Path Ferrite Nonlinear Transmission Line
authors: Munan Lin, Wenbin Zhang, Haibo Li, Wenjie Han, Wenqing Zhang, Xin Qi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: High-power ultrafast pulses are critical for advanced applications such as diffraction-limited storage ring (DLSR) light sources, yet conventional pulse-shaping techniques face limitations in simultaneously achieving fast rise/fall times, minimal pulse oscillation, and high-voltage stability. To address this, we propose a dual-path ferrite nonlinear transmission line (DP-FNLTL) architecture integrating two functional branches: NLTL1 for rising-edge sharpening via current-dependent permeability modulation and NLTL2 for trailing-edge truncation through magnetic crowbar switching. Theoretical analysis, PSpice simulations, and experimental validation confirm that the DP-FNLTL compresses input pulses (34.6 ns bottom width, 5.86 ns rise time, and 7.7 ns fall time) to meet stringent DLSR specifications. The 70 mm NLTL1 configuration achieves a 2.27 ns rise time with <inline-formula content-type="math/tex" xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX" version="MathJax">$<$</tex-math> </inline-formula>1% prepulse oscillation, while NLTL2 compresses fall time to 1.94 ns via volt-second saturation. Integrated systems deliver 24 kV amplitude, sub-3 ns rise/fall times, 6.78 ns bottom width, and sub-3% prepulse/tail oscillations at an optimized 7 kA/m axial bias field, establishing DP-FNLTL as a robust solution for accelerator-compliant ultrafast high-voltage pulses.

title: How Does Firms' Artificial Intelligence Adoption Affect Different Stakeholders? A Systematic Review and the AIMS Framework
authors: Meiting Lin, Hugo K. S. Lam
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has been increasingly adopted by firms for different organizational purposes. While such AI adoption is expected to affect firm performance, it may also have different effects on firms' stakeholders such as employees, shareholders, and customers. To provide a more comprehensive understanding of the stakeholder implications of AI adoption, we conduct a systematic review of 84 relevant papers published in business journals in the past 8 years (2017-2024). Our review suggests that firms' AI adoption does have different, sometimes conflicting, effects on different stakeholder groups. We also uncover several limitations of the extant literature and develop an integrative AIMS (AI Impacts Multiple Stakeholders) framework that summarizes important directions for future research. Our AIMS framework emphasizes the need to consider underexplored stakeholder groups such as suppliers and competitors, as well as the trade-offs and dynamics among different stakeholder groups induced by AI adoption. Our framework also encourages future research to move beyond examining the direct impact of AI adoption on stakeholders by investigating when (contextual factors) and why (underlying mechanisms) AI adoption affects stakeholders, thereby advancing the literature on AI-stakeholder relationships. Finally, we discuss the implications for future operations management research, encouraging scholars to adopt a supply chain perspective to study the stakeholder implications of firms' AI adoption.

title: A Multi-Metric Performance Analysis of STAR-RIS Aided MIMO-NOMA Framework for CIoT-Enabled 6G Wireless Networks
authors: Debbarni Sarkar, Satyendra Singh Yadav, Vipin Pal, Keshav Singh, Kapal Dev, Hyundong Shin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Consumer internet of things (CIoT) devices are increasingly being integrated into various aspects of wireless communication, enhancing the scalability of networks. Along with these, in sixth-generation (6G) wireless networks, reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) has emerged as a prominent technology that can dynamically control the wireless environment. As a progression of this technology, recently, simultaneously transmitting and reflecting-RIS (STAR-RIS) has gained significant attention for its ability to achieve full-space coverage by simultaneously transmitting and reflecting signals. On the other hand, multiple input multiple output (MIMO) and non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) technologies have already proven their dominance in fifth-generation (5G) wireless communication networks by obtaining massive connectivity and high spectral efficiency. This paper proposes a mode switching-based STAR-RIS aided MIMO-NOMA framework for 6G wireless networks to cover the non-line-of-sight (NLoS) region as a footprint. The proposed framework adopts the selection combining and maximum ratio combining protocols to meet the quality of service requirements of the CIoT devices in NLoS regions. The study also derives mathematical formulations for the proposed framework by analyzing key performance metrics, including achievable data rate (ADR), outage probability, bit error rate (BER), diversity order, and throughput. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed system, comparative analyses are conducted against benchmark models such as STAR-RIS assisted single-input single-output (SISO) orthogonal multiple access and STAR-RIS assisted SISO-NOMA schemes. Simulation results affirm the superiority of the proposed framework for both the reflecting and transmitting regions of the STAR-RIS. In the transmitting region, under the maximum ratio combining protocol, the far CIoT device of the proposed STAR-RIS aided MIMO-NOMA framework attains an ADR at least 0.45 times higher than the conventional framework. Further, the BER of the proposed framework is 0.93 times lower than conventional framework.

title: XAI for Fraud Detection: An Attention-Based Ensemble of CNNs, GNNs, and Confidence-Driven Gating for Reliable Decision-Making
authors: Mehdi Hosseini Chagahi, Abolfazl Yekaneh, Saeed Mohammadi Dashtaki, Behzad Moshiri, Md. Jalil Piran
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: The challenge of fraud detection, especially in credit card transactions, continues to grow as fraudsters adapt to increasingly sophisticated tactics. Traditional methods, including rule-based systems, are often limited by high false positives and poor adaptability to new fraud patterns. This study introduces a cutting-edge approach using an attention-based ensemble framework that synergizes the strengths of convolutional neural networks (CNNs), graph neural networks (GNNs), recurrent neural networks (RNNs), and long short-term memory (LSTM) models. A key innovation of this model is its confidence-driven gating mechanism, which dynamically combines the most reliable prediction, ensuring both accuracy and transparency. By incorporating dependent ordered weighted averaging (DOWA) and induced ordered weighted averaging (IOWA) operators, the model effectively integrates outputs from various classifiers, improving robustness. Additionally, SHAP-based feature selection reveals the most influential variables, providing deeper interpretability. Extensive evaluations across three diverse benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of this framework, surpassing individual classifiers and existing ensemble models in both balanced and highly imbalanced settings. This research paves the way for more reliable and transparent fraud detection systems, capable of adapting to evolving fraud tactics in real-world financial environments.

title: A Simplified Probabilistic Framework for Evaluating the Contribution of Solar Photovoltaic Generation to Power Systems
authors: Changhee Han, Kwang Y. Lee, Rajesh Karki, Kyeong-Hee Cho, Kweonhoo Ko, Junzo Watada, Jaeseok Choi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy
abstract: This paper presents a probabilistic simulation framework for quantitatively evaluating the contribution of solar cell generators (SCGs) to modern power systems. Unlike conventional generators using storable fuels modeled by simple two states, solar generation is non-storable and inherently uncertain, requiring a more realistic approach. A multi-state probabilistic model is therefore developed—not as a fixed structure, but as a direct reflection of solar resource variability. By integrating the PV output curve with the empirical probability density function (pdf) of solar irradiance, the model captures weather-dependent generation behavior. Case studies on a scaled Jeju Island system verify its effectiveness in evaluating reliability (LOLE, EENS), production cost, and CO₂ emissions, and demonstrate its value for scenario-based planning under increased solar penetration. The proposed framework highlights the transition from deterministic assumptions to probabilistic realism, offering a robust foundation for sustainable and data-driven energy planning.

title: Towards Transparent Intrusion Detection: The Role of Explainable AI
authors: Ruan Haoda, Siti Norul Huda Sheikh Abdullah, Qi Jiale, Tajul Azhar Mohd Tajul Ariffin, Khairul Akram Zainol Ariffin
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The issue of network security is extremely urgent; an effective intrusion detection system is becoming increasingly important for modern network security. Thus, interpretable AI methods have played a role in real-world IDS. This study used two machine learning models to analyze the UKM-IDS20 and NSL-KDD datasets, namely LightGBM and CNN, mainly for training and evaluating binary and multi-label network traffic data. Moreover, interpretable artificial intelligence techniques such as SHAP and LIME were required to interpret the models. SHAP and LIME highlight the different feature importance patterns among models and enhance artificial intelligence models' transparency, understandability, and credibility. During the usage of SHAP, for the LightGBM binary classification model, the top 5 features contribute more than 72% to the interpretability of the model. Among them, the feature dst_bytes has a relatively significant impact. The same situation is that in the LIME analysis stage, the contribution value of dst_bytes is also the highest, which fully demonstrates that there is a high degree of consistency between SHAP and LIME. Moreover, in the NSL-KDD dataset, the outputs of CNN models such as Normal, DoS, Probe and R2L all achieved perfect scores (100%). Only the performance of the U2R class declined, with an accuracy of 80% and a recall rate of 36%. LightGBM has achieved excellent performance on the UKM IDS dataset, with a Metasploit accuracy score of 99%, which indicates that compared with CNN, LightGBM performs better in both binary classification and multi-classification scenarios. Therefore, adaptive intrusion detection systems are crucial for protecting computer networks. Furthermore, the continuous update of the IDS dataset also enables the proposed system to be applied to the datasets related to recent attacks for testing.

title: AI-Enhanced IP Surveillance Protecting Innovation in Real-Time
authors: D V Sarayu Reddy, Nischitha P, Akshita Chavan, Mishael Abhishek Zakkam, M N Vijayakumar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Patent infringement poses significant challenges to innovation protection and often results in lengthy legal proceedings. The increasing number of patent filings and advancements in technology demand more efficient detection mechanisms. Artificial Intelligence (AI), through Natural Language Processing (NLP), Machine Learning (ML), and Computer VISion, introduces a transformative methodology for automating and enhancing the detection of patent violations. This paper proposes an AI-based system capable of extracting semantic and graphical features from patents, evaluating similarities, and predicting potential infringements. Additionally, blockchain is introduced to ensure data immutability and verification of ownership. This method aims to offer a reliable, scalable, and cost-effective solution to patent protection, with achieved accuracies up to 85%.

title: Parkinson's Disease Prediction by Voice and Handwritings Using ML & DL
authors: S Sahana, S Swetha, A Jenifer, M Revathi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Parkinson's Disease is difficult to diagnose, particularly in the early stages when symptoms are not well defined and continually changing. In this present study, we have created a full machine learning system based on voice recordings as well as handwriting photographs to render PD diagnosis more consistent and precise. For the vocal aspect, we extract time-frequency features like MFCCs, spectral rolloff, and zero-crossing rate from on-the-fly audio and then process them through a Random Forest model. At the same time, we process handwriting features, which are affected by the movement problems in PD, through a convolutional neural network on black-and-white images. The system combines the output from each model using an ensemble method to give the ultimate diagnosis. Tests show that this voice-and-handwriting-based method is better than methods based on individual modalities alone. It has the potential to be an early-detection and telemedicine tool that is non-invasive, user-friendly, and low-cost.

title: Enhancing Crop Recommendations with Ensemble Learning and Explainable AI
authors: Haosheng Chen, Mohammad Tarek Aziz, Ziheng Xu, Shokhida Uktamova, Valisher Sapayev Odilbek Uglu, Min Wu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: The classification technologies of AI can provide precision crop recommendations for modern agriculture, and play a significant role in improving agricultural production. By combing the relevant literature, this study proposed a new ensemble learning model based on comprehending the highly accurate classification results of ensemble models used in agricultural crop recommendation with AI and IoT. Then, the historical data is used to train and test while considering as many factors as possible from previous studies. The proposed model has the best accuracy at 99.32%, which is higher than any single classification model used in its ensemble process and the models in previous studies. Meanwhile, in terms of precision, recall and F1 score, the proposed model is superior to the single classification model utilized in its integration, which shows the great reliability. Two XAI techniques (SHAP and LIME) were used to interpret the model classification results, quantifying the contribution of each feature to model prediction, improving system transparency and thereby enhancing intelligibility for farmers.

title: GAM-YOLO: An Enhanced Small Object Detection Model Integrating Global Attention Mechanism
authors: Yijie Yang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: To address feature loss in YOLOv5 when processing small objects and complex backgrounds, we propose GAM-YOLO with two key improvements:GAM integration: Embedded at critical Backbone and Neck nodes to suppress information diffusion and enhance salient feature capture.P2 detection head: Added for high-resolution features, forming a four-head architecture for small objects. Experiments on PASCAL VOC show GAM-YOLO achieves 89.7% mAP@.5, a 3.2% improvement over YOLOv5s. This provides a robust solution for challenging small object detection tasks like drone imagery.

title: Neural Architecture Search Algorithm for Designing Optimized Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Annapurnanand Tiwari, Gundavarapu Mallikarjuna Rao, Mariyam Ahmed, P.B.Edwin Prabhakar, Muntader M. Almusawi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Crafting excellent Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) by hand takes a lot of time and isn’t always the best choice because there are so many configurations. This work intends to use a Neural Architecture Search (NAS) algorithm to automate CNN design. This will allow more efficient and accurate models, hence solving the problem. The NAS method conducts a performance-guided search across a defined search region of network topologies to find the best CNN configurations. A controller network produces candidate structures from model input; reinforcement learning guides the search in this work. The improved CNNs found by NAS were more accurate in classification and ran faster than hand-made baselines. The models were also superior at generalizing over many low-variance samples. Ultimately, NAS provides a quick and strong tool to produce efficient CNN structures automatically.

title: Federated LSTM Framework for Secure and Robust High-Frequency Trading Prediction
authors: K Sukanya Varshini, Swapna Siddamsetti, Ramya H P, Ponni Valavan M, Malik Bader Alazzam, Adnan Burhan Rajab
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: A homogeneous financial marketplace requires High-Frequency Trading (HFT) to take advantage of the minute market price fluctuations by trading at high speed. Highfrequency trading prediction using conventional machine learning techniques is limited to performance since centralised processes generate privacy issues along with the delay and modelling biases due to limited data variability. The current study introduces a novel framework that combines Federated Learning technology with Long Short-Term Memory neural networks to obtain higher accuracy of the prediction of HFT and data privacy. The scientists plan to develop an HFT trend prediction method enabling encryption security with the combination of FL and LSTM concepts. This method is based on an integration of FL technologies and LSTM neural networks to provide distributed model training while preserving the confidentiality of raw sensitive data and market generalisation using different trading setups. During its analysis, the proposed Federated-LSTM framework processed NIFTY-50, NEPSE and SP-Feb 2021 datasets. The designed framework provided impressive performance output with up to 98.3 % accuracy, 98.1 % precision, 97.8 % recall, and a 98 % F1 score. The model used in the proposed project has demonstrated superior degrees of accuracy and had greater strength than other approaches, DNN-DWT and MLP and LSTM-CNN. FL with LSTM generates better HFT predictions that preserve the integrity of data protection. The method opens up new avenues of producing resistant financial trading methods that provide accurate outcomes.

title: A Case Study about Floating Solar Systems: Economic, Environment and Efficiency Analysis
authors: Ruhi Zafer Caglayan, Korhan Kayisli, Firat Hardalac, Abdelhakim Belkaid
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Renewable energy is very important to convert energy production from non-renewable energy sources to sustainable and long last sources. For this way the environmental friendly, sustainable, efficient systems are examined. For recent years, the new topic floating solar system is proposed to increase the effect of the solar power on the energy production. In this paper, the 2020-2025 time intervals open access literature is selected as based and the floating solar system topic is examined under economical, environmental and efficiency cases. The aim is to show the importance of the floating solar system topic.

title: Exploring How Content Features Drive Gen Z Engagement: The Mediating Effect of Perceived Relevance
authors: Jassim Algasawneh, Mahmoud Karam Almahasneh, Nada Alkhawajah, Gaith Abu Alfalayeh, Mohammad Alqsass, Almutasem Najjar, Zeid Alqatawneh
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: As social media usage continues to grow, Gen Z's use of the platforms has been progressively more prominent fueled primarily by the degree of personalization they interact with. The present study explores the influence of interactivity and personalization upon Gen Z's experience, namely how perceived relevance acts as a mediating variable for social site use. With data drawn from a sample of 412 members of Gen Z, the research employed a 17-question questionnaire to collect data and the SEM-PLS method of data analysis. All the hypotheses proposed in the study were supported through the findings. Specifically, the study proved that content personalization and interactive features both boost users' perception of content relevance. This sense of relevance, in turn, plays a key role in driving social media engagement—it effectively closes the gap between personalization and interactivity and higher user engagement. These insights provide important direction for marketers seeking to create content strategies that will truly resonate with Gen Z and result in higher engagement on social media.

title: Hierarchical Federated Learning for Scalable and Secure Big Data Analytics in Edge Environments
authors: Ranjit Sandilya, V.Mangaiyarkarasi, Kompalli Prasanna Laxmi, Zayd Balassem, Amarjeet Singh Ghosh, Mehdi Ebady Manaa, Ahmed Abdulsalam Alhayaly
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The rapid expansion of edge computing has made large-scale data analytics possible, but it also raised concerns over scalability, security, and the effectiveness of communications. Under decentralized scenarios, conventional Federated Learning (FL) methods struggle with heterogeneous devices, constrained bandwidth, and security vulnerabilities. This work proposes a Hierarchical Federated Learning (HFL) framework that enhances resource efficiency, scalability, and privacy for large-scale data analysis in edge scenarios to mitigate the above problems. Our approach introduces a multi-level aggregation structure where the resulting model is enhanced by a global server, but intermediate nodes perform regional aggregation, and edge devices train models locally. By restricting the exposure of raw data, this hierarchical framework enhances data privacy, reduces communication cost, and relieves computing bottlenecks. Compared to traditional FL, experimental evaluations on real-world datasets indicate that it reduces bandwidth usage by 40%, improves model accuracy by 8–12%, and enhances training efficiency by 35%. Applications where safe and scalable analytics are crucial, like smart cities, industrial IoT, and personalized healthcare, gain significantly from the proposed approach. Federated learning in edge computing can be a solid basis for HFL, encouraging the development of safe, effective, and flexible AI-powered analytics, as per our investigation.

title: Multi-Task Learning with AI-Powered Speech Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
authors: Sampathirao Govinda Rao, Shyam Maurya, S. Senthil Kumar, Rintu Kumar, Laith H. Alzubaidi, Zainb Hussain Ali, Alaa Khalid Abdalreda, Mustafa Ali Alwash
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) driven speech emotion recognition (SER) is bringing in more flexible and context-aware solutions in human-computer interaction (HCI). Conventional SER models find it difficult to fit changing activities and emotional settings. The innovative Multi-Task Learning (MTL) is designed to improve SER performance as it concurrently enables contextual sentiment analysis, speaker identification, and voice emotion categorization. The suggested approach maximizes audio signal feature extraction efficiency by using a transformer-based neural network that includes shared and task-specific layers. While the standard encoder stores high-level language and auditory features, individual task decoders improve emotional detection and auxiliary task representations. Self-attention guarantees adaptive feature weighting, therefore resisting speaker fluctuation and noise. The research seeks to make virtual assistants, customer support bots, and mental health monitoring apps more accurate, smart, and customized, enhancing real-time human-computer interaction (HCI) systems. Additional context from supplementary activities helps users to generalize their emotions. Experimental results using benchmark SER datasets reveal a quite significant 96.5% increase in emotional recognition efficiency compared to conventional single-task models. This work increases AI-driven human-computer interaction through enhanced emotional perception and reaction of robots. Improving real-time deployment in edge devices and extending it to multilingual datasets should be the main priorities of future development.

title: Interpretable Neural Network Control for Boost Converters in Quasi-Resonant Mode
authors: Zhi Li, Benjamin Schwabe, Lorenzo Servadei, Robert Wille
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Boost converters serve as critical components in modern electronic systems. While proportional-integral (PI) control remains the prevailing standard due to its intuitive design and high stability, it exhibits limitations in achieving fast dynamic response and high robustness for multiple operating points. Based on the framework of PI controllers, a neural network controller is proposed in this paper. The inherent structure allows it to be interpretable, and the nonlinear characteristics make it particularly advantageous for boost converters operating in quasi-resonant mode. A comparative analysis between the control performance of a PI controller and proposed neural network controller demonstrates the advantages of this method.

title: Analysis of the Hosting Capacity of a Distribution Network Integrated with Solar Photovoltaics Plants, Battery Energy Storage Systems, and Electric Vehicles
authors: Chukwuemeka E. Okafor, Azeez O. Olasoji, Mkhutazi Mditshwa, Komla A. Folly, David T.O. Oyedokun
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: The proliferation of solar PV, battery energy storage (BESS), and electric vehicles introduces technical challenges in distribution networks, including reverse power flow, thermal overloading, and harmonics. This study quantifies the hosting capacity for distributed energy resources (DERs) and additional (spare) loads that can be connected without violating operational limits or requiring network upgrades. A 31-bus distribution test system, modeled for time-domain analysis, is assessed using DIgSILENT PowerFactory’s hosting-capacity function under varied operating conditions. Results indicate that, at the CPUT bus during BESS charging, up to 20.24 MW of DER can be accommodated while respecting constraints. When BESS delivers active power, allowable spare-load capacity increases markedly: approximately 70% of buses exhibit enhanced hosting capability, with more than 50% spare-load accommodation. The findings provide actionable guidance on integrating DERs and leveraging BESS to defer upgrades while maintaining secure operation.

title: Blockchain and Machine Learning-Empowered Sdn for Secure and Optimized Anonymous Communication
authors: Sai Priya T. S, K. Saraswathi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: As 6G networks are expected to connect billions of diverse devices with ultra-high speeds and low latency, ensuring robust security and privacy becomes a critical challenge. Traditional security methods struggle to keep up with the scale and complexity of 6G environments, which face increased risks of cyberattacks. To address these demands, the proposed architecture combines Tor-style multi-hop routing with real-time intrusion detection via a 1D-CNN model, dynamic traffic rerouting using an SDN controller, and secure key rotation managed through blockchain smart contracts. This integrated system enables intelligent, scalable, and automated defense by quickly detecting attacks like DoS, maintaining seamless traffic flow, and ensuring trusted, immutable key management across massive device networks. Its flexibility and automation align perfectly with 6G's vision of AI-driven, secure, and privacypreserving communication, making it a robust solution for safeguarding the complex and highly connected 6G ecosystem. The results show that throughput decreased by 19.3% during the attack and recovered by 10.3% post-attack compared to the pre-attack phase. Delay increased by 22.1% during the attack and remained 12.6% higher than the pre-attack level even after mitigation. These findings indicate partial throughput recovery but with sustained delay overhead.

title: Modern Data Engineering for Cloud Etl, Migration, and Scalable Analytics
authors: Sarvesh Kumar Gupta, Vamsi Krishna Koganti, Peeyush Patel, Shokhjakhon Akhmedov, Nurbek Matyakubov
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The ETL migration and scalable analytics of cloud-native design has revolutionized the current data engineering through the faster transition to cloud-native designs. The resource usage in cloud systems is Pay-as-you-use, which is convenient in real time and bulk processing of data demanded by the businesses. The innovations enable the agile pipelines, migration of legacy systems and analytics migration at scale migration. Nonetheless, they still struggle with such problems as the ability to integrate heterogeneous data, schema change, low-latency processing, regulatory compliance and cost control. These are the main issues that will have to be addressed in order to realize the potential of cloud data systems. This review is going to investigate the trends of cloud-native ETLs, tools and strategies such as the data lakehouses and streaming architecture. The interactions of the modern pipelines are shown through experimental modeling whereas the constraints of the system can be stated by the comparative benchmarks. The analysis also determines the most significant gaps and future opportunities like serverless orchestration, fed ETL, and combined use of batch-stream processing to enhance the interoperability, efficiency and scalability of cloud data engineering.

title: Elemental Adaptation of Low-Rank Quantisation-Aware Training for Large Language Models on Natural Language Processing Tasks
authors: Akhilesh Anil, Chinmay Shivanand Muragod, Vinod G R, Sujatha R. Upadhyaya
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The growing capabilities of Large Language Models are accompanied by high memory & computational needs, posing significant challenges for deployment in resource-constrained environments such as edge devices. Traditional Post-Training Quantization, Quantization-Aware Training & Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) methodologies exhibit limitations in accuracy, memory & inference efficiency respectively. Recently proposed Low-Rank Quantisation-Aware Training (LR-QAT), serves as a lightweight, memory & inference efficient general extended pretraining QAT method. This paper presents an elemental adaptation of LR-QAT, making it feasible to train large models like GPT-2 Medium & BERT-Base-Uncased on low resource consumer grade GPUs. Our method freezes pretrained weights, injects simulated low-bit noise in accordance to LR-QAT, trains LoRA adapters and quantization parameters within this grid, fuses the adapters into a single full-precision checkpoint, and finally emits BF16, INT8 & NF4 models from one training run. Experimental evaluations on benchmark Natural Language Processing tasks such as Stanford Sentiment Treebank (SST-2) and Question-Answering Natural Language Inference (QNLI) from the General Language Understanding Evaluation (GLUE) dataset demonstrate that the proposed method edges past both traditional Post-Training Quantization and customized Quantized LoRA (QLoRA) in performance metrics, while maintaining comparable memory usages at reduced bit-widths.

title: Key Considerations For Adopting Transformative M4.0 Technologies In The Smart Manufacturing
authors: Ndala Yves Mulongo
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Investing in innovative manufacturing technology is a significant potential for middle market manufacturers aiming to distinguish themselves, enhance operational efficiency, and maintain a competitive edge. Prior to increasing their investment in and implementation of those technologies, firms must establish a digital transformation roadmap and blueprint that guarantees a deliberate and prioritised strategy. This will enable the advanced tools and processes to operate at their maximum efficacy. To this end, this study discuss the key considerations when implementing transformative M4.0 technologies. This study used a quantitative methodology. A systematic review method was employed in the initial phase to ascertain the primary key considerations when implementing AI in manufacturing sector. The second component, encompassing the quantitative phase of the research, employed a survey method to gather the perspectives of industry professionals. Data were collected from the Johannesburg Stock Exchange concerning 44 companies within the manufacturing sector listed on the exchange. The results from the descriptive statistics for the key to be taken into account when considering the adoption and implementation of Artificial intelligence technologies in a manufacturing company. Based on the 8 statements, developing clear objectives top the list.

title: Deep Autoencoder Model for Intrusion Detection in Financial Cybersecurity Monitoring Systems
authors: Muqdad Zaki Hammed Banana, Zain Al Abdeen Khaled Atiya, Salah Mahdi Saleh Alkhafaji, Ali Abbas Hadi, Mustafa Radif, Ali Fakhri Abbas
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Financial cybersecurity systems protect sensitive data and transactions from unauthorized access and malicious attacks. Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) are essential tools for real-time monitoring, identifying, and preventing cyber threats. However, traditional IDS methods often struggle to detect unknown attacks, handle high-dimensional data, and adapt to evolving threat patterns, resulting in increased false positives and reduced accuracy. To address these challenges, this study proposes a Deep Autoencoder (DAE)-based framework that utilizes unsupervised learning to model standard behaviour patterns in financial network traffic. The DAE is trained solely on benign data and flags anomalies based on reconstruction errors, effectively detecting zero-day attacks and previously unseen intrusions. The proposed method is applied to real-time financial transaction logs and network activity data to monitor irregularities and cyber threats. Experimental results demonstrate that the DAE model significantly improves detection accuracy while reducing false alarms, outperforming conventional IDS techniques. This highlights the DAE's potential as a robust, intelligent intrusion detection mechanism tailored to financial cybersecurity environments.

title: Impact of Inverter Based Resources on Critical Clearing Time
authors: Trupal Patel Holcombe, Sukumar Brahma Holcombe
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: Inverter-based resources (IBRs) such as solar and wind plants are being connected in large numbers to the power grid. Additionally, fossil fuel-based generation is being phased out, resulting in the loss of rotor inertia, a key contributor to the transient stability. Unlike a synchronous generator (SG), an IBR’s response to a disturbance depends on its controls, involving factors such as operating mode, current limits, and grid code requirements. Therefore, the large-signal behavior of IBRs and their impact on transient stability must be studied. This paper presents hypotheses rooted in the physics of the transient stability phenomenon, choosing the most accurate models for IBRs to study the phenomenon, and documents simulation results on the IEEE 9-bus test system. The simulation results corroborate the hypotheses and highlight the impact of different control designs and operating modes on the critical clearing time (CCT), the metric considered for transient stability in this paper.

title: Design and Simulation of a Universal Shift Register Using Modified Supply Voltage Level D Flip-Flops with Timing Analysis
authors: Chaitra V K, Mayavati, Meghana P Manru, Priyanka C R, Shylashree N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Supply voltage level D flip-flops (SVL-DFFs) are used in this research to present a flexible and power-efficient universal shift register architecture. The SVL-DFF architecture allows for dynamic supply voltage adjustment, which conserves power without losing functionality. The design can easily expand due to its modular architecture, enabling multiple modes of operation. Extensive simulations confirm its effectiveness. The results show improved timing performance, achieving a worst hold slack of 0.168 ns, worst pulse width slack of 2.148 ns, and worst negative slack of 7.885 ns, all with zero total slack violations. These results indicate strong timing margins and stable high-speed operation. This architecture can be applied in areas like data processing, control systems, and communication systems. Overall, it provides a practical solution for powerconstrained applications, which contributes to modern digital circuit designs and meets the industry's changing needs.

title: Leveraging Machine Learning Algorithms for Predictive Modeling in Chemical Synthesis
authors: Sujeet Kumar Pandey, G. Jayapriya, Charunayana V, Sundar Saranya, S. Vinodha, Vivek Panyam Muralidharan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: In chemical synthesis, machine learning (ML) has grown a potent tool that facilitates prediction, optimisation, and the discovery of new molecules and processes. Because of their biocompatibility, silver nanoparticles make great candidates for a variety of nonmedical uses. In order to forecast the antibacterial potential of silver nanoparticles, we introduced machine-learning techniques and expanded on the research studies on antifungal. In the first phase of this investigation, 45 data points were collected for the algorithm's training, including ZOI, dose, bacterial/fungal type, core size, and nanoparticle shape. As indicated by the feature significance investigation, the silver nanoparticles' core size is the most vital determinant of their antibacterial potential. Six distinct machine-learning regression techniques were then used to train the data, and four metrics-RMSE, MAE, MSE, and R2 were utilized to evaluate the models' efficiency. Additionally, the significance of the features incorporated into the prediction models has been assessed. The best model for forecasting antifungal and antibacterial activity has been found. Through this approach, researchers may use machine learning to reduce the need for trial and error while addressing the issues of cost and time consumption in laboratory studies.

title: Design of a Machine Learning-Based Controller for Buck Converters with Direct Gate Control
authors: Noboru Katayama
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has emerged as a promising approach for power electronic converter control, offering the capability to optimize switching behavior without relying on an explicit mathematical model of the circuit. This study applies a direct gate control (DGC) framework, in which the DRL agent directly determines the on/off state of the switching device, thereby eliminating the need for conventional PWM generation. The control policy is trained through interaction with a simulation model of a buck converter, and the reward function is carefully designed to balance voltage regulation accuracy and switching loss reduction. Building upon previous work, this paper analyzes the influence of the switching penalty coefficient in the reward function on control performance. Simulation results demonstrate that increasing the penalty effectively reduces the switching frequency while maintaining fast transient response and stable voltage regulation, achieving a flexible trade-off between efficiency and dynamic performance. Moreover, the DGC framework exhibits fast convergence and stable operation, enabled by its frequency-independent and direct control characteristics. These results highlight that appropriate reward parameter tuning is essential for achieving both robustness and efficiency in DRLbased converter control and suggest future potential for extending the reward formulation to minimize actual switching losses throughout transient operation.

title: Research on UAV Logistics Operation Mode Based on Low Altitude Air Corridor Hierarchical Management
authors: Biaoxin Chen, Jiancai Li
publish: 2025 Low-Altitude Economy Forum &amp; International Conference on Low-Altitude Flight Technology and Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Application (LEF &amp; ICLU)
abstract: With the increasing popularity of drones in urban logistics and distribution, low-altitude airspace congestion and scheduling conflicts have become increasingly prominent. Achieving efficient and safe channel management has become a pressing issue. This paper proposes a drone logistics operation model based on hierarchical channel management. Tasks are scheduled in layers according to payload, speed, and mission type to address resource conflicts and operational risks under varying mission requirements. In terms of methodological design, this study constructs a system architecture encompassing task access and classification, channel allocation and optimization, and operational monitoring and feedback. An optimization objective function is introduced to balance operational efficiency and safety. Experimental verification in a real-world urban setting demonstrates that the hierarchical channel model significantly outperforms traditional models in terms of average task completion time, channel utilization, conflict rate, and emergency response time. Channel utilization is increased by over 25%, and conflict rate is reduced by approximately 35%. These results demonstrate that the proposed method not only effectively improves the overall operational efficiency of logistics tasks but also maintains system stability and robustness under high-demand and emergency response conditions. The research’s contribution lies in incorporating the hierarchical concept from transportation engineering into drone airspace management. It proposes a scalable hierarchical scheduling mechanism, providing new technical insights for the efficient operation of future urban drone logistics systems.

title: Imputing Wind Power Industrial Time Series via Segment-Aware Transfer Learning
authors: Gangliang Li, Xiaodong Huang, Chengfeng Chen, Shouqiang Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Wind power has become an essential component of modern renewable energy systems. However, in real-world industrial settings, wind farm data often suffer from missing values due to communication failures, power fluctuations, or extreme weather conditions. These data gaps pose significant challenges to downstream tasks such as forecasting and operational scheduling. Existing deep learning-based imputation methods are typically point-wise and fail to model the structured and temporal nature of missing data in wind power systems, resulting in suboptimal performance.To address this issue, we propose TA-MaskImpute, a novel imputation framework that integrates dynamic segment masking and temporal-aware strategies for wind power data restoration. Built upon the pretrained time-series model Timer, our framework adopts a decoder-only structure for lightweight transfer learning. Specifically, we introduce: (1) a dynamic segment masking mechanism that samples mask locations and lengths from statistical distributions (e.g., Gaussian or Pois-son), combined with a staged masking schedule to improve generalization and training diversity; and(2) a temporal-aware guidance module that addresses the overlooked autocorrelation in label sequences by incorporating frequency-domain consistency into the training objective, thereby complementing time-domain reconstruction and improving robustness in multi-step imputation.Extensive experiments on real-world multi-site wind farm datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing baselines in both accuracy and stability, showing strong potential for practical deployment in industrial wind power scenarios.

title: Optimizing Power, Performance, and Area in Digital Design Using ML Based Design Space Exploration
authors: Vedashree B S, Shilpa D R
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: With increasing complexity in VLSI design and shrinking technology nodes, optimizing Power, Performance, and Area (PPA) has become a critical challenge. Traditional manual and heuristic-based methods often fall short in exploring the vast design space efficiently. This work proposes a machine learningbased design space exploration approach using Synopsys DSO.ai integrated with Fusion Compiler for RTL-to-GDSII digital flow. The methodology intelligently explores various design parameters at the compile, clock, and route stages, guided by user defined metrics. Compared to the traditional Fusion Compiler flow, the DSO.ai enhanced flow achieved notable improvements: congestion was reduced by 19.42 %, standard cell area decreased by 5.27 %, and frequency increased by 16.44 %. In addition, all timing violations were resolved, including WNS and TNS, and the total power consumption was reduced by approximately 10.22 %. The design also saw significant reduction in design rule check (DRC) violations and better overall utilization. These results validate the effectiveness of AI-driven optimization in improving design QoR, reducing closure time, and minimizing manual intervention, thereby paving the way for intelligent, automated, and scalable physical design flows.

title: Dynamic Feature Fusion with Skip-Enhanced Neural Networks for Robust Modulation Classification
authors: Yue Lan, Qiyuan Ma, Changchang Sun
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Network Communication and Information Security (ICNCIS)
abstract: This paper proposes a robust modulation classification method integrating skip connections and dynamic feature fusion to tackle feature loss in low-SNR environments and gradient vanishing in deep networks. A cross-layer feature reuse architecture preserves high-frequency details via skip connections. Innovatively, an SNR-aware dynamic gating unit enables adaptive multi-scale feature fusion, while a dual-attention mechanism enhances critical feature representation. A lightweight design drastically reduces computational complexity without sacrificing accuracy, demonstrating strong potential for deployment on edge devices in complex electromagnetic environments.

title: Behavioral Data-Driven Learning Analytics for Early Intervention in At-Risk Students
authors: Tresa Maria Josylin, Ganeshayya Shidaganti
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Timely identification of at-risk students is essential for improving academic outcomes and supporting personalized interventions. With the increasing adoption of digital learning environments, vast amounts of behavioral data are generated through student interactions with educational platforms. Analyzing these behavioral patterns presents a promising opportunity to proactively identify students who may require additional academic support. The study introduces a comprehensive learning analytics framework that analyzes behavioral engagement data to uncover meaningful patterns and predict academic risk. By identifying distinct behavioral personas through clustering of engagement patterns, we uncover how varying interaction styles relate to academic performance. Predictive models such as XGBoost and Random Forest are then used to detect at-risk students, with the latter achieving 97% accuracy and an AUC of 0.99. SHAP-based interpretability further reveals key behavioral drivers of risk. Dimensionality reduction techniques like SVD highlight latent patterns in student behavior. The approach offers a holistic, explainable, and data-driven method to support early identification and intervention for at-risk learners.

title: Deep Learning Based Optimal RIS Position Analysis for Energy Harvesting in Medical IoT Devices
authors: Himashree N R, Hamsaveni R, Jeevan T S, Ritik Kumar Singh, Likhitha S, R Likhitha, Avik Banerjee
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Medical IoT devices for health monitoring require constant power and connectivity, yet they face challenges in complex indoor environments like hospitals due to signal blockages and energy constraints. This paper proposes a deep learning-based approach for determining the optimal position and phase shift of a Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS) to enhance both energy harvesting and communication throughput. Simulations using OpenEMS and Octave model signal behavior in a hospital-like scenario. A regression-based neural network is trained using TensorFlow to predict the optimal RIS configuration. Results demonstrate a nonlinear, positively correlated relationship between RIS parameters and performance metrics, enabling intelligent optimization of RIS for real-time health IoT applications.

title: A Heat-Wave-Aware Degree-Day Model for Predicting Flowering Time in Chickpea
authors: Md Tanzimul Islam, Jobayar Alom, Masuduzzaman Niloy, Md Shafiq Ullah, Sheikh Razia Sultana, Kamruddin Nur
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Accurate prediction of flowering time under climate extremes is essential for developing resilient chickpea cultivars. This study proposes a heat-wave-aware extension of the degreeday model using a Generalized Additive Mixed Model (GAMM) framework. The model integrates cumulative growing degree days, heat-wave intensity, and a temporal kernel that emphasizes heat stress occurring near floral initiation. Using multi-year field data and ERA5-Land weather inputs, the proposed model achieved a root mean squared error (RMSE) of 4.76 days and a mean absolute error (MAE) of 3.62 days, improving prediction accuracy by over 15% compared to a conventional linear degreeday model (RMSE: 5.63 days). Partial dependence analysis revealed a saturating delay effect beyond six heat-wave days, particularly when stress occurred within $\mathbf{1 0 - 1 5 \%}$ of cumulative GDD around floral initiation. The model generalized well across cultivars and site-years, providing a robust and interpretable tool for phenology modeling under heat stress. These findings offer practical implications for climate-adaptive chickpea breeding and management.

title: Postpartum Psychiatric Disorder Prediction Using Machine Learning and Explainable AI
authors: Rezoan Ahmed Abir, Mahfuzulhoq Chowdhury, Lorin Tasnim Zeba, Nasrul Karib, Md. Yasin Arafat, Afroza Akter
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: When women with postpartum mental disorders (PPD) do not receive treatment, their health is seriously at risk. The existing research works suffered from several issues like inefficient feature selection, imbalanced datasets, binary classification, lower accuracy, and inadequate hyper parameter tuning. This paper uses a clinically validated dataset to propose a machine learning framework for multiclass categorization of postpartum psychiatric illnesses in order to fill these gaps. Advanced preprocessing, ensemble feature selection, and hyper parameter tuning using Randomized Search are all included in this proposed approach. SMOTE was used in this work to reduce class imbalance problem. XGBoost outperformed the other ML algorithms that were assessed and achieved 94.6 percent accuracy value. The proposed PPD prediction method outperforms previous works by achieving at least 5 % gain in accuracy and 6.3 % gain in F1score. To improve model interpretability for each prediction, explainable AI (XAI) techniques specifically SHAP were used.

title: SiberBox: Design and Implementation of a Lightweight Sandbox Environment for Cybersecurity Labs Using Containerization
authors: Herlambang Rafli Wicaksono, Prasetyo Adi Wibowo Putro, Nathanael Berliano Novanka Putra, Rayhan Ramdhany Hanaputra, Muhammad Faturrohman Sugiyarto
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: The persistent cybersecurity skills gap highlights the inadequacy of traditional theory-based education and the limitations of existing hands-on training platforms, which are often proprietary or insecure. This paper presents the design, implementation, and empirical evaluation of SiberBox, an open-source, multi-tenant platform for cybersecurity training that addresses these challenges. Our architecture leverages OS-level containerization to provide lightweight, on-demand sandboxed environments. It features a centralized manager that orchestrates a distributed fleet of container hosts via a secure agent-based model and utilizes a VPN gateway to enforce strict network isolation, effectively separating the control and data planes. Evaluation of the prototype provides concrete evidence of its capabilities: a single host can concurrently support a class size of 25 isolated lab environments, while its load-balancing engine seamlessly distributes requests across multiple nodes to ensure horizontal scalability. Furthermore, security assessments confirm robust user isolation, with all inter-container and control-plane access attempts successfully blocked. The findings establish SiberBox as a viable, cost-effective blueprint for academic institutions to deploy their own flexible and secure hands-on cybersecurity laboratories, thereby helping to democratize practical cyber education.

title: Medic-AI Application for Multiclass Brain Tumor Detection Using CNN
authors: Payal Chhabra, Neo Kurian Peter, Laxman Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The detection of medical images of brain tumors is a common application of artificial intelligence in medical sciences. This work discusses a transfer learning method for automated brain-tumour analysis on MRI scans, we implemented a convolutional neural network that learns to recognise the unique spatial and textural patterns of each category. The model reliably separates glioma, meningioma, pituitary tumours and healthy tissue by extracting multi-scale features, progressively refining them through stacked convolutional and pooling layers, and mapping the resulting representation to class probabilities via fully connected layers and soft-max activation. The system offered high classification accuracy with less computational power, making it suitable for clinical applications. Our work demonstrates the effectiveness of transfer learning for medical image analysis and its potential to assist medical professionals in diagnosis.

title: ACBLM: Goal Recognition Across Rational and Irrational Planning Domains
authors: Junbin Li, Zhanmao Cao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Traditional goal recognition methods suffer performance degradation under irrational trajectories, partial observability, and noisy environments due to their reliance on predefined domain models and planners. To address these limitations, this paper proposes ACBLM (Attention-Based CNN-BiLSTM Model), which integrates a 1D-CNN to extract local action features, a bidirectional LSTM to capture global temporal dependencies, and an attention mechanism to focus on key behaviors while suppressing noise. Experiments on six rational and four irrational planning domains show that ACBLM consistently outperforms GRNet and LGR across various observation ratios, achieving higher accuracy and stability, particularly under low observability and complex behavioral scenarios. The results demonstrate ACBLM’s robustness, generalization capability, and potential for real-world applications.

title: Quasi-uniform Quantization based Iterative Detection and Decoding for LDPC Coded SCMA Systems
authors: Hao Cheng, Jun Chen, Min Zhang, Yongming Huang
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Sparse code multiple access (SCMA) has been considered as a competitive candidate multiple access technology to address the challenge of high spectrum efficiency and massive connectivity for 6G communications. However, the use of uniform quantization with limited accuracy may lead to considerable BER performance degradation for the message passing algorithm (MPA) in SCMA detection. In practical communication systems, SCMA operates with channel coding to provide low-latency and reliable communication, and low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes are employed in this work. To address this issue, the quasi-uniform quantizer is proposed, where the uniform quantization strategy is adopted when the probability information value is small, otherwise, the non-uniform quantization is used, which improves the dynamic range of message exchanging in MPA and minimum sum algorithms. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed quasi-uniform quantizer achieves superior BER performance even with lower quantization precision compared to the uniform quantizer, and subsequently, the computation cost for hardware implementation can be reduced.

title: Overshoot Reduction in Levitation and Propulsion Control of Linear Induction Motors
authors: Takumu Horimoto, Toshimitsu Morizane, Hidehito Matayoshi, Soma Jinno
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This study presents an innovative magnetic levitation transmission (MLT) system that relies solely on linear induction motors (LIM). This system achieves simultaneous control by superimposing two frequency components, one to generate propulsion and the other to manage the levitation force. This design is expected to reduce both space requirements and cost. In addition, experimental results validate the system’s responsiveness in velocity control and gap control.

title: Transformative Evolution of Augmented, Virtual, and Extended Realities
authors: Ajeet Singh, Atul Pratap Singh, Monica, Puneet Kumar Aggarwal, Anuj Gupta, Kritika Soni
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The article explores the transformative impact of Augmented Reality (AR), Virtual Reality (VR), and Extended Reality (XR) on the modern world and various industries. These technologies are reshaping interactions by blending virtual and real environments through devices like cameras and depth sensors, as well as development frameworks such as Unity and ARKit. A conceptual framework called the Virtual Continuum has been introduced to represent reality across four stages: real, augmented, augmented virtuality, and virtual. The paper highlights the rapid adoption of XR across industries including retail, healthcare, manufacturing, education, and gaming. An AR project is imple- mented in a practical way, and it shows image recognition, depth computation, and replication of the environment. This evolution is being hugely facilitated by big tech corporations such as Apple, Meta, and Nvidia along with Indian companies such as Tata ELXSI and Parallax Labs. The paper concludes that XR is transforming user experiences, immersive education, improved industry workflows, and new social interactions catalysed by platforms such as the Metaverse.

title: Optimizing Cultural Event Management Through Advanced IoT-Driven Crowd Analytics and K-Means Clustering
authors: Raja Thimmarayan, Suganya G, V Sasirekha, Mudunuri Vijaya Durga, G. Rajasekar, S. Murugan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Efficient crowd managing is essential to the effectiveness and security of cultural events, due to current data can significantly increase development and reaction. It presents an Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled crowd analysis method that uses K-Means Clustering to optimize user allocation and movement during massive incidents. IoT components, including infrared indicators, tags with RFID, and ecological sensors, were deployed in five key events locations to evaluate population level and mobility. Data collected throughout a three-day cultural event with 25,000 attendees had been analyzed using K-Means Clustering, successfully identifying four distinct crowd behaviour characteristics. The method achieved a 37 % increase in allocated resources productivity, a 28 % reduction in overcrowding in areas with heavy traffic, and a 42 % enrichment in the precision of quick reaction durations compared to previous people methods. The predicted accuracy of average zone occupancy reached <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 1. 3 \%}$</tex>. Findings demonstrate the performance of combining IoT with machine learning for proactive monitoring of events. It proposes an adaptable, data-informed outcome for enhancing attendance experience, protection, and reliability in culture events environments.

title: EEG-Based Classical Framework for Autism Spectrum Disorder Diagnosis
authors: Praveen Asthana, Rajveer Singh Lalawat, Rishabh Kumar Baudh, Shivanshu Kumar Anand
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The objective of signal processing using transformation techniques, is to accurately detect the frequency and extract small variations within the signals. Previous studies have explored various algorithms aiming to extracted the signals and classify Autism Spectral Disorder (ASD) based on Electroencephalography (EEG) signals, offering valuable insights. However, there is still scope for improvement in handling highly non-stationary signals across ASD diagnosis. The article propose a model that named as Convolution neural network (CNN-ASD) and the Continuous wavelet transform (CWT) to properly take features from EEG signals. This approach uses an adaptive filter bank to control dynamic data in the frequency domain to accurately distinguish both stages. Our experiments demonstrate that, the proposed model outperforms BiLSTM with AM and ResNet50, and it achieves notable classification accuracy for normal and ASD classes. This method enhances the performance of medical devices and benefits for their use in healthcare.

title: AMPED: Accelerating MTTKRP for Billion-Scale Sparse Tensor Decomposition on Multiple GPUs
authors: Sasindu Wijeratne, Rajgopal Kannan, Viktor Prasanna
publish: Proceedings of the 54th International Conference on Parallel Processing
abstract: None

title: Blockchain-Enabled Federated Learning for Privacy-Preserving Credit Risk Assessment
authors: P. Bhuvaneshwari, Ammar Hameed Shnain, Shital Kewte, Patel Prathibha Swaraj, K. Yuvaraj, Muhannad Khamis Abed, Sameer Algburi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Credit risk evaluations enable the financial sector to determine the eligibility of investments and loans. When used to manage private financial data shared across several organizations, centralized machine learning (ML) systems pose data privacy, security, and compliance issues. For competitiveness and regulatory purposes, financial companies may conceal customer information, which can reduce the accuracy of models and datasets. Cyberattacks on central archives complicate the development of secure, collaborative credit scoring systems. This study proposes the Blockchain-Enabled Federated Learning Credit Risk Assessment System (BFL-CRA) to address these issues. A permissioned Blockchain and Federated Learning (FL) protect raw data and decentralize model training across financial organizations. The BFL-CRA protocol requires each institution to establish a model and utilize blockchain smart contracts to deliver encrypted model modifications. Through agreement, the system verifies and safely aggregates alterations into a global model. Training is auditable, immutable, and visible on the blockchain, ensuring honesty and responsibility.

title: AI-Driven Secure Audit Trails for Financial Compliance Using Immutable Blockchain Logs
authors: Dlovan Wrya Hamad Ameen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: AI-driven secure audit systems are revolutionizing how financial institutions ensure compliance, transparency, and data accountability. By integrating immutable blockchain logs, audit trails can be made tamper-proof, enhancing trust and regulatory visibility. However, existing centralized compliance systems face significant challenges, including vulnerability to data breaches, a lack of transparency, and difficulties in maintaining cross-jurisdictional regulatory alignment. To address these limitations, this work proposes a novel framework that combines Federated AI with Blockchain-Integrated Audit Logging (F-AI-BC-AL). Federated learning enables decentralized model training across institutions without sharing raw financial data, preserving privacy and reducing data transfer risks. Concurrently, blockchain ensures every transaction, data access event, and AI-driven compliance check is logged immutably using smart contracts for policy enforcement. The proposed method is applied to real-time Anti-Money Laundering (AML) monitoring in cross-border financial transactions, enabling institutions to detect suspicious activities while collaboratively maintaining secure auditability. Results demonstrate enhanced detection accuracy, data confidentiality, and improved regulatory traceability, with a significant reduction in audit reconciliation time. The outcome establishes a secure, scalable, and regulation-aligned compliance ecosystem that is resilient to tampering and privacy violations.

title: Multi-Violation Traffic Monitoring Using Yolov8: A Smart Surveillance Approach
authors: Aarthi M, Frinifa Babu B M, R Priscilla, J Gold Beulah Patturose
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: In the era of increasing urban traffic and road safety concerns, real-time detection of traffic violations is vital for enforcing regulations and preventing accidents. This project presents a comprehensive smart surveillance system titled “MultiViolation Traffic Monitoring Using YOLOv8: A Smart Surveillance Approach”, designed to detect three key violations: helmet non-compliance, triple riding, and number plate recognition for two-wheelers. The system leverages the state-of-the-art YOLOv8 deep learning object detection framework due to its enhanced speed, accuracy, and lightweight design suitable for real-time applications. In addition, specialized improvements such as data augmentation, few-shot learning techniques, and OCR integration are incorporated to tackle challenges such as low lighting, small targets, and diverse camera angles. The system processes CCTV and webcam footage to detect violators, annotate video frames, and log incident details. This integrated AI-powered approach significantly enhances traffic law enforcement and minimizes manual monitoring, making it scalable for smart city deployments. The results demonstrate high accuracy in complex urban environments, proving the robustness and effectiveness of the proposed system.

title: Wavelet Transform Enhanced Signal Processing for Low-Latency Audio Recognition in Edge Devices
authors: Haider M. Fahim, D Kalidoss, Khabibullayeva Sayyorakhon Makhamadali Kizi, Abdullah Ghanim Jaber
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Low-latency audio recognition in edge devices is critical for real-time applications such as voice assistants, surveillance, and wearable tech. Wavelet Transform has emerged as a powerful tool in signal processing due to its ability to analyze non-stationary signals at multiple resolutions. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational costs, limited noise resilience, and suboptimal performance under constrained edge environments, making them less suitable for real-time deployment. To address these challenges, this paper introduces a novel framework named WESP-LAR (Wavelet Enhanced Signal Processing for Low-latency Audio Recognition), which leverages Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) for efficient time-frequency feature extraction and integrates lightweight neural models for classification. WESP-LAR is optimized for low-memory usage and real-time execution on edge processors. The proposed method enhances audio feature representation while significantly reducing latency and computational overhead, making it ideal for embedded AI scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that WESP-LAR achieves superior accuracy and robustness across diverse audio datasets, outperforming traditional FFT-based and raw waveform approaches.

title: Towards Efficient Task Offloading Strategy in Mobile Edge Computing Environments
authors: Divya Gupta, Sheenam, Jaspreet Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) has emerged as a transformative solution for enhancing computation capacity at the network edge, offering substantial benefits to mobile and Internet of Things (IoT) devices, which often operate under stringent resource constraints. Despite its potential, one of the critical challenges in MEC systems is optimizing energy consumption while maintaining acceptable latency and ensuring Quality of Service (QoS). In this work, we present an ideal task offloading technique that successfully strikes a compromise between latency and energy usage in extensive IoT communication networks. Considering energy limitations and delay sensitivity, IoT device users assess their local conditions and decide whether to offload compute jobs in the first step. To further reduce MEC resource constraints, the second stage dynamically coordinates with central cloud servers to optimize power allocation and channel selection algorithm. The blended offloading system ensures effective use of edge and cloud computing infrastructures. Through simulations the suggested algorithm performs significantly better than conventional offloading techniques for task delay and energy usage. The outcomes demonstrate the usefulness of our model in real-time Internet of Things scenarios, providing a scalable and efficient solution for intelligent, energy-conscious, and delay-aware task offloading.

title: EduBot: A Low-Cost Multilingual AI Educational Robot for Inclusive and Scalable Learning
authors: Anish Giri, A S M Ahsanul Sarkar Akib, Abu Zahid Md Jalal Uddin, Md Sazibur Rahman, Abdul Hasib, Monica Khadgi, Mohammad Farhan Ferdous, Manish Giri, Bishesh Shahi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: This paper presents EduBot, a novel, low-cost, AIpowered educational robot designed to foster inclusive and scalable learning for Bangla and English-speaking communities. EduBot addresses critical limitations in existing educational robotics-high cost, restricted language support, and lack of contextual adaptability-by integrating multilingual interaction, Optical Character Recognition (OCR), speech recognition, face detection, and deep learning-based natural language processing within a compact, affordable system. Built using open-source software and economical hardware, EduBot delivers real-time interactive learning via a mobile application. Capabilities include voice-enabled Q&A, book scanning, storytelling, math problemsolving, and expressive gestures. Experimental results demonstrate EduBot’s superior performance: achieving OCR accuracies of 95.2% for Bangla and 97.6% for English, a response time of 150 ms, and significantly higher user satisfaction compared to existing solutions. Its modular architecture enables deployment across traditional, hybrid, and remote learning environments. Furthermore, its culturally relevant design ensures accessibility in resource-constrained settings. This work advances educational technology by offering a practical, scalable platform for personalized, AI-driven learning. EduBot establishes a new benchmark for low-cost, multilingual educational robots and presents a promising model for future integration into global learning ecosystems.

title: Semantic Segmentation of Fetal Thoracic and Abdominal Organs in Prenatal Ultrasound Volumes Using Swin Transformer Networks
authors: Mahmoud Mussleh Jawad, Hassan Ali Abood Nassrullah, Hussain Ali Hussain, Mohammad Kazem Abd, Ameer Yalmaz Asaad Asaad, Zainab I. Mohammed, Rawezh Mohammed Hussein, Abu Saleh Musa Miah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research proposes a high-accuracy Transformer-based segmentation framework for fetal thoracic and abdominal organ delineation in prenatal ultrasound volumes, utilizing Swin Transformer architecture, multi-scale hierarchical attention, and deep supervision techniques. The model ingests volumetric ultrasound data encoded as 3D spatial patches and processes them through shifted window attention layers to capture both local texture and global anatomical context. Benchmarked across clinically annotated datasets, the framework achieved average Dice scores exceeding 89.2% and IoU scores above 85.6% across key fetal organs including the lungs, liver, stomach, and heart. Compared to traditional CNN-based models such as U-Net and V-Net, the proposed method improved segmentation precision by 4.5–5.2%, particularly in challenging regions with occlusions, shadow artifacts, or low contrast. Integration of boundary-aware loss functions and positional attention embedding’s enhanced boundary adherence and organ separability. With inference times under 500ms per 3D volume and generalization maintained across gestational weeks 20-36, the model supports real-time clinical deployment. Its scalable architecture and robust anatomical encoding present a strong foundation for advanced prenatal diagnostics and organ-specific fetal biometrics.

title: AI-Driven Resilient Control Systems for Critical Infrastructure: Challenges, Solutions, and Future Directions
authors: Quazi Rian Hasnaine, Mohamed I. Ibrahem, Mostafa M. Fouda
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: In many industries, such as water distribution, energy, industrial automation, and transportation, resilient control systems (RCS) are very crucial. These systems provide uninterrupted and secure operation of cyber-physical systems (CPS). CPS must be resilient to external shocks, system malfunctions, and cyberattacks. With the advancement of cybersecurity, machine learning (ML), and artificial intelligence (AI), control systems are now significantly more robust. This study aims to provide a comprehensive examination of robust control system methodology, its challenges, and novel solutions, with a focus on integrating AI-driven techniques to reduce vulnerabilities and enhance adaptive control strategies.

title: Connectivity-Aware Graph Neural Network for Predictive Management of Adaptive Mobile Sinks in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Subhrasmita Bhoi, Jyotirmaya Mishra, Rashmi Ranjan Sahoo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Mobile sinks management is essential in the efficiency of Data collection and transfer of distributed sensor nodes within the Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs). Trustworthy data transfer coupled with maximizing energy usage is a hugely significant problem. Adaptive mobile sinks navigate the network dynamically to gather data, making them less congested and consuming less energy as their trajectories shift according to data streams, node density and network status. This paper suggests a proposal of a graph neural network to predictive management of adaptive mobile sinks in WSNs, known as Connectivity-Aware Graph Neural Network (CAGNN-MSP-WSN). First, sensor node input data is collected and sensory data is trained through a Connectivity-Aware Graph Neural Network (CAGNN) to determine mobile sink routing. To maximize the weight parameters of CAGNN classifier, an Augmented Gold Rush Optimizer (AGRO) is presented to improve routing prediction accuracy. The CAGNN-MSP-WSN is applied and tested on the basis of the performance metrics, such as accuracy, error rate, energy consumption, and computational time. The findings indicate that CAGNN-MSP-WSN method has a higher accuracy of 30.57, 17.21, and 24.10 and lower computational time of 19.84, 24.93, and 31.62, respectively than available approaches.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Allocation Strategies in Transportation Problems
authors: Sheetal Gonsalves, Varun Chani, Ujjwal Rastogi, Manya Saxena
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Reducing transportation costs is essential for enhancing overall operational efficiency across various sectors. Six distinct approaches to solving TP's were investigated to determine an efficient place to start for cost optimization: NWCM, VAM, KSAM, Raval's Approximation, AMSTP, and AMM. Each method's accuracy and computational speed were evaluated using self-developed Python code across ten test cases. Solutions were manually verified and cross-validated using MS Excel to ensure their correctness. The results showed that KSAM provided the most precise results, matching the optimal cost in 60 % of cases and having the lowest average deviation (2.60%). VAM performed well with a 4.18% deviation, while Raval's Approximation (7.83%) and AMM (9.06%) had moderate accuracy. NWCM, which does not consider costs, had the highest deviation (44.23 %), making it the least suitable for cost-focused decisions. AMSTP, though the fastest, had a higher deviation (10.31 %), making it a good choice when speed is a priority but not ideal for accuracy. Execution times showed that AMSTP was the quickest, while Raval's Approximation took the longest. This study highlights that KSAM is best for precise cost calculations, AMSTP is useful for fast estimates, and NWCM should be avoided in cost-sensitive situations.
