These insights can help businesses make smarter transportation decisions, reducing costs and improving efficiency.

title: Colorimetric Surveillance of Gas Leaks in Chemical Industries Using Bioindicator Monitoring System
authors: Gaurav Kumar, Mahak Mittal, Kasvi Gupta, Aarush Garg, Manasa M, Keshava Murthy Y. C.
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Undetected leaks of hazardous gases and vapors in chemical industries pose significant risks to human health, safety, and the environment. This paper proposes a novel, eco-friendly, and scalable system for real-time detection of such leaks by leveraging the bioindicator properties of peat cushion moss. The framework combines biological sensing with computer vision (OpenCV), IoT-based environmental sensors, and a Blynk-enabled alarm system to ensure early detection and rapid response. Target chemicals include acetic acid (CH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>COOH), acetone (CH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>COCH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>), ethyl acetate (C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">8</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), concentrated sulfuric acid (H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>SO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>), and ammonium hydroxide (NH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>OH). Moss samples are monitored using an ESP32-CAM module, with HSV-based image processing to detect progressive discoloration indicative of chemical stress. Additional environmental sensors, including DHT22 (humidity/temperature), LM35 (temperature), and KY-038 (sound levels), provide contextual data for accurate monitoring. Preliminary experiments show measurable moss color changes under chemical exposure, validating the system's potential as a sustainable, cost-effective alternative to conventional gas sensors for industrial safety and environmental monitoring.

title: The Effects and Classification of Psychoactive Substances: A Machine Learning Approach
authors: Manasvini Kandikonda, Chirayu Nilesh Chaudhari, Janya Billa, Parvathy Unnikrishnan, Vasavi C.S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Psychoactive drugs, which influence mood, awareness, thoughts, and behavior, are widely researched upon due to their impact on both individuals and society. This work presents a Psychoactive Fusion Machine Learning framework consisting of a classification model to identify psychoactive drugs based on chemical attributes and drug usage, utilizing personality traits and demographic data. Combined with a regression model to predict impulsivity and sensation-seeking scores (ImpSS) using demographic and personality features. This model leverages various algorithms including XGBoost resulting in an accuracy of 85 % for the identification of psychoactive drugs, Logistic Regression and Support Vector Machine yielding high accuracies of around 97 % when used in the prediction of behavioral patterns under drug influence, Random Forest with an accuracy of 83 % in the prediction of Impulsivity. The results demonstrate the potential of combining personality psychology and chemical analysis with machine learning to achieve precise and explainable predictions, opening pathways for applications in healthcare, policy-making, and substance use research, such as early predictions of critical care patients and patients who need an immediate intervention in order to avoid the severities of the abuse.

title: A Program Study Plan Recommender System based on the Greedy Algorithm
authors: Jerome M. Fabregar, Ryndel V. Amorado
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Despite the broad applicability of recommender system, these remains underutilized in many academic services, such as student assessment, evaluation, and monitoring. To address this gap, this study aims to design and develop a recommender system for undergraduate program study plans, with a focus on assisting irregular students. A greedy algorithm is employed to provide a simpler, more precise, and efficient approach to creating a Program of Study (POS). The frontend and backend are developed using Nuxt and Vue, while PostgreSQL is used for the database. The accuracy is validated by comparing its generated study plans with those created by domain experts. The results show no significant difference in recommendations, indicating high accuracy in course selection. Nevertheless, variations are observed in course allocation and the number of units per semester, allowing the system to maximize the available units in each term. As a result, fewer units are undertaken in the latter part of the curriculum. This means that the developed system optimizes the academic load distribution. Additionally, the system outperforms manual evaluation in terms of time efficiency with an average of 0.32 seconds, compared to the 30-minute to 1-hour manual process. These demonstrate that the system has the potential to optimize academic planning, which ensures efficient course distribution, maintains accuracy, and reduces processing time.

title: Intelligent Systems for Inclusive Learning: Deaf and Dumb Education
authors: Gull Kaur, Akash Bhatt, Aditya Raj, Abhishek
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: This article describes a multimodal AI-driven communication system designed to improve access for the Deaf and Dumb community. By combining computer vision and natural language processing to detect hand gestures using the YOLOv11 object detection model, and to provide voice input and output using the Vosk speech recognition library, the proposed application has the flexibility to develop a host of useful and functional capabilities. The primary functionality is incorporated in a simple and web-interactive Streamlit interface which collectes and capable of real-time translation of sign language to speech and speech to text content. To support natural interactive and context based interaction, the system utilizes the Gemini API to give smart response based on the provided transcript. This creates inclusive converstation and provides inclusive learning environments for Deaf and Dumb individuals and their hearing peers through the removal of barriers for communication. The system represents an amazing step toward acheiving accessible intelligene for Deaf and Dumb persons and inclusive engagment for hearing. Comparative analysis provide evidence of 18.7% improvement in accuracy against previous CNN - RNN hybrids and 62% improvement in latency against HMM approaches leading to the conclusion that the system proves effecient and effective for outpacing other available systems and produced a positive educational and in group meetings where 87% of participants understood within the real-time learning experience.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Ensemble Models for Flower Recognition and Freshness Estimation
authors: Manjula Gururaj Rao, Naganna Chetty, Prthu Rao H, Chinmai Shetty, Vaikunta Pai T, Samarth Shanbhag
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Flora plays a vital role in various industrial and commercial sectors, necessitating efficient methods for accurate flower recognition and freshness assessment. Manual classification and evaluation processes are often time-consuming, error-prone, and lack scalability. This study introduces a hybrid ensemble of deep learning models aimed at automating the detection, classification, and freshness estimation of flowers. The proposed system targets five flower categories—daisy, dandelion, rose, sunflower, and tulip—utilizing state-of-the-art architectures including CNN, ResNet50, MobileNetV2, EfficientNetB0, and VGG16. To enhance predictive performance, ensemble techniques such as model averaging and stacking are employed. In addition, freshness estimation is conducted by analyzing five visual parameters through image processing techniques. Experimental results reveal that the ensemble model achieves an average classification accuracy of 86%, validating its effectiveness. This hybrid approach offers a robust and scalable solution for real-time floral classification and freshness prediction, with potential applications in agriculture, floriculture, and supply chain automation.

title: Duplex Mode Optimization in Multi-Static ISAC Systems With Network-Assisted Full-Duplex
authors: Maowen Luo, Ruoyun Liu, Feng Ye
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Multi-static integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) technology is considered as one of the key technological directions for future sixth-generation (6G) networks, fulfilling the increasing demands of high-precision sensing and low-latency communications. In this paper, the access point (AP) duplex mode optimization problem for a multi-static ISAC system based on network-assisted full-duplex (NAFD) that supports simultaneous uplink (UL) and downlink (DL) communications is studied. We introduce a comprehensive performance evaluation framework that employs communication rate and the squared position error bound (SPEB) as the evaluation metrics for communication and sensing performance. To tackle this multi-objective optimization problem (MOOP), we propose an AP mode optimization algorithm based on Deep Q-Network (DQN) to maximize the communication rate and minimize the system SPEB simultaneously, and analyze the trade-off between the communication performance and sensing performance of the system. The simulation results show that the method proposed can maintain good convergence for different communication and sensing performance weights.

title: Lumina Adapt: Real-Time Content Analysis Approach for Adaptive Blue Light Filtering
authors: Reevan Coelho, Veerasagar S S, Vinod A. R, B. G. Sudarshan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Prolonged exposure to high-energy visible (HEV) blue light from digital displays is a growing health concern, linked to digital eye strain, sleep cycle disruption, and potential long-term retinal damage. Conventional blue light filters are typically static or manually configured, failing to adapt to the dynamic nature of on-screen content, which often leads to suboptimal filtering or a compromised visual experience. This paper introduces LuminaAdapt, a novel, real-time adaptive filtering system designed to mitigate blue light exposure intelligently. The system operates by continuously capturing the display content through a low-latency screen-sharing pipeline. Each frame is processed in real-time to extract key colorimetric and luminance properties, including average brightness, dominant hue, and color temperature. A novel control algorithm leverages these extracted features to automatically and dynamically modulate the color temperature of a system-level overlay filter. This content-aware approach ensures that the filtering intensity is precisely tailored to the visual information being displayed, applying stronger filtering for bright, blue-rich content (e.g., documents, web pages) and lighter filtering for dark or color-sensitive content (e.g., media, graphics). Experimental results demonstrate that LuminaAdapt can reduce blue light emissions in the critical 440–490 nm wavelength range by an average of 68.7% during typical computer usage, significantly lowering user exposure while preserving high perceptual image quality and color fidelity. By providing an automated and adaptive solution, LuminaAdapt presents a promising approach to enhancing digital wellbeing without requiring user intervention.

title: Expression of Concern for: Advanced Hybrid Transfer Learning Approaches for Autism Spectrum Disorder Detection Using Facial Features
authors: Surya Lakshmi Kantham Vinti, Bharathi Panduri, Vijayshri Khedkar, Mahesh Babu Ketha, A. Lakshmanarao, Thokala Srivalli
publish: 2024 5th International Conference on Data Intelligence and Cognitive Informatics (ICDICI)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a complex neurodevelopmental condition characterized by deficits in social interactions, communication, and emotional regulation. Early identification is crucial for improving outcomes. This work presents a DL approach for ASD detection using facial features extracted from the Autistic Children Facial Dataset. Initially, transfer learning models including VGG16, EfficientNet, DenseNet, and MobileNet were applied individually to extract and analyze critical facial characteristics. VGG16 and DenseNet provided detailed high-level features, EfficientNet offered efficient feature extraction, and MobileNetV3 enabled rapid processing. Later, a hybrid model was developed by merging the features extracted from the above applied models for emotion-based ASD identification. The hybrid approach was trained and evaluated using SVM and random forest ML models. Experimental results demonstrated that the hybrid approach enhanced detection accuracy for early ASD detection.

title: TG-TSGNet: A Text-Guided Arbitrary-Resolution Terrain Scene Generation Network
authors: Yifan Zhu, Yan Wang, Xinghui Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: With the increasing demand for terrain visualization in many fields, such as augmented reality, virtual reality and geo-graphic mapping, traditional terrain scene modeling methods encounter great challenges in processing efficiency, content realism and semantic consistency. To address these challenges, we propose a Text-Guided Arbitrary-Resolution Terrain Scene Generation Network (TG-TSGNet), which contains a ConvMamba-VQGAN, a Text Guidance Sub-network and an Arbitrary-Resolution Image Super-Resolution Module (ARSRM). The ConvMamba- VQGAN is built on top of the Conv-Based Local Representation Block (CLRB) and the Mamba-Based Global Representation Block (MGRB) that we design, to utilize local and global features. Furthermore, the Text Guidance Sub-network comprises a text encoder and a Text-Image Alignment Module (TIAM) for the sake of incorporating textual semantics into image representation. In addition, the ARSRM can be trained together with the ConvMamba-VQGAN, to perform the task of image super-resolution. To fulfill the text-guided terrain scene generation task, we derive a set of textual descriptions for the 36,672 images across the 38 categories of the Natural Terrain Scene Data Set (NTSD). These descriptions can be used to train and test the TG-TSGNet<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>. Experimental results show that the TG-TSGNet outperforms, or at least performs comparably to, the baseline methods in image realism and semantic consistency with proper efficiency. We believe that the promising performance should be due to the ability of the TG-TSGNet not only to capture both the local and global characteristics and the semantics of terrain scenes, but also to reduce the computational cost of image generation.

title: An All-Metal High-Efficiency Wide-Angle Scanning Phased Array Based on Dual-Port PMA
authors: Xudong Tang, Jianzhong Chai, Han Zhou, Xuepeng Li, Heci Liu, Jinke Shi, Mingxia Meng, Zhenhao Zhang, Huasheng Zhao, Junping Geng, Chong He, Ronghong Jin, GuoLin Tong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: In this paper, an all-metal high-efficiency dual-port phase mode antenna (PMA) is proposed. By adjusting the phase difference between the two ports in the PMA, distinct characteristic modes are excited, enabling a continuous transition of the radiation pattern from a conical beam to an axial beam. Consequently, the PMA achieves element-level two-dimensional beam steering, with the main beam capable of scanning within ±45° in the xoz plane and ±48° in the yoz plane. Furthermore, high port isolation exceeding 30 dB in the dual-port PMA is achieved by introducing a novel decoupling technology, named the evanescent-wave-based decoupling method. Due to its all-metal structure and high port isolation, the PMA maintains a total efficiency exceeding 98% under all excitation conditions. To validate its potential for high-efficiency wide-angle scanning, a 4 × 4 planar phased array based on the PMA is designed and fabricated. By employing enlarged element spacing and introducing the defected ground structure, mutual coupling between array elements is significantly reduced, resulting in improved array efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that the 4 × 4 array achieves wide-angle beam steering of ±66° in the xoz plane and ±90° in the yoz plane, with a total efficiency ranging from 79% to 94.5%.

title: Channel Denoising in Digital Semantic Communication Systems via Discrete Diffusion
authors: Wenqian Tang, Zian Meng, Qiang Li, Mingdie Yan, Xiaohu Ge
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Existing denoising models of semantic communication (SemCom) rely on continuous diffusion, requiring analog signal reconstruction at the receiver. To be compatible with the prevailing digital systems, a fully digital generative SemCom framework is proposed by designing a Channel Discrete Denoising Diffusion Model (CD3M). To capture symbol transitions under digital channel distortions, a discrete Markov chain model is first constructed, which guides CD3M to learn robust denoising dynamics over digital constellations. On this basis, a unified generative digital SemCom architecture is established by integrating CD3M with Vector Quantized Variational Autoencoder (VQVAE), i.e. CD3M-VQVAE, which enables channel-adaptive denoising with a single codec pair. Simulation results demonstrate that CD3M-VQVAE outperforms other single-codec and classical coded-modulation schemes, and can reach the performance of multi-codec methods at moderate SNRs under certain compression rates.

title: Flux-driven Josephson Parametric Amplifiers Based on an RF SQUID and DC SQUID in Keysight ADS
authors: Keith Krause, Michael C. Hamilton, Mark Adams
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: Josephson parametric amplifiers (JPAs) have become an important component of superconducting applications. Simulating these circuits is vital for optimizing their performance, including their gain and stability. Previously, simulating JPAs has been inefficient due to the limits of using SPICE-based simulators that work in the time domain. JPAs are better suited to frequency domain simulations over a broad frequency range and parameter space. We present JPA simulations using the recently released flux-aware Josephson junction (JJ) and inductor models in Keysight Advanced Design Systems (ADS). We simulate two different flux-driven JPAs: one based on an RF SQUID, and another based on a DC SQUID. We efficiently run harmonic balance simulations over a wide range of circuit parameters. We compare the use of RF and DC SQUIDs in these JPAs by analyzing their simulation results. This work provides a foundation for future SQUID-based JPA simulations in Keysight ADS.

authors: R. Konishi, Y. Emori, R. Ozumi, H. Handa, H. Miyazaki, S. Miura, H. Sasa, M. Iwakuma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: To reduce carbon dioxide emissions from aircraft, superconducting electric propulsion systems are attracting attention. For aircraft, high power density is particularly important, and increasing the power density requires higher rotational speed. Therefore, we are studying a saddle-shaped field coil made with REBa<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>Cu<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7-δ</sub> (REBCO) tape. This coil can be fixed directly to the shaft, which helps provide the mechanical strength needed for high-speed rotation. However, because of the shape characteristics of the REBCO tape, the coil ends tend to become long, increasing the axial length of the motor. In addition, excessive bending or twisting can damage the tape; thus, careful design is necessary. In this study, we developed a design method to shorten the saddle-shaped field coil and evaluated its electromagnetic performance. We introduced a generalized flatwise curvature to represent bending and twisting and set the allowable curvature of the REBCO tape to 0.1 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> based on its mechanical limits. Using this condition, we designed two types of shortened coils. Model A arranges the coils based on the curvature of the innermost coil, while Model B equalizes the curvature of all coils to prevent interference at the coil ends. Three-dimensional finite-element analysis revealed that the axial gap flux density distribution of both models is almost the same. However, Model B has a slightly larger high-flux-density region because its straight part is longer, resulting in better output performance. The obtained torque also exhibits a strong proportional relationship with the axial integral of the gap flux density, confirming that the coil ends are important regions that contribute to motor output.

title: MOLENA: Analyzing the Two-Step Message Flow and Opinion Evolution Process in Social Networks
authors: Huisheng Wang, Yuejiang Li, Yiqing Lin, H. Vicky Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal and Information Processing over Networks
abstract: From mass media theory, the message flow and the opinion evolution in real social networks adhere to a two-step communication process: opinion leaders first receive the messages from the message sources, and then convey their opinions to the normal agents. During this process, opinion leaders often exhibit confirmation bias by updating their opinions based on messages close to their opinions, reflecting their limited willingness to accept dissonant messages. However, few prior works jointly consider the two-step communication process involving message sources, opinion leaders, and normal agents, as well as the confirmation bias of opinion leaders. In this paper, we propose a unified framework called MOLENA to analyze how messages f low and opinions evolve in the two-step communication process. In the MOLENA framework, we introduce a mathematically tractable message preference model to quantitatively describe the confirmation bias. We obtain the approximate analytical solution of the opinion leaders' and normal agents' steady-state opinions, and theoretically analyze the influence of system parameters on their steady-state opinions. Furthermore, we examine the influence of messages on opinion leaders' steady-state opinions and study how opinion leaders influence normal agents' steady state opinions in the two-step communication process. Finally, we validate our theoretical analysis through numerical experiments and verify the correctness of the MOLENA framework via social experiments. This study is critical to understanding how messages f low and opinions evolve in real social networks and to designing effective mechanisms to guide agents' opinions.

title: Movable Access Points in Visible Light Communications: Opportunities, Challenges and Future Directions
authors: Sylvester Aboagye, Telex M. N. Ngatched
publish: IEEE Communications Magazine
abstract: Visible light communication (VLC) is expected to be a key component of future wireless networks due to its abundant license-free spectrum, inherent high-level security, and the already deployed lighting infrastructure. VLC performance, however, depends on device orientation and the availability of an unobstructed line-of-sight (LoS) link, with transmitter semi-angle and receiver field-of-view (FoV) further affecting alignment, coverage, and reliability. Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) can mitigate blockages, orientation issues, and mobility challenges, but their data rates remain far below those of direct LoS links. This article introduces the novel concept of movable access points (MAPs)-aided VLC systems, where dynamically repositioned APs provide new degrees of freedom to ensure LoS connectivity, and transmitter-receiver alignment while providing ultra-high data rates for mobile users. Simulation results show MAPs outperform RIS-aided, fixed- AP, and RIS-only VLC systems in dynamic environments. The article also outlines key challenges and future research directions, including integration with emerging wireless technologies.

title: Examining the Factors Influencing Student Choice to Study: A Review of Mobility Trends in Higher Education
authors: Chenxuan Gong
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The system that affects students to choose learning education information is a flow trend in higher education, the key factors in influencing students to choose learning, the flow trend in higher education is an important goal of the system design of students to choose learning education information. This study is based on the practice of an educational evaluation allocation system based on factors influencing students' choice of learning and gives several optimization schemes. Among them, the current situation of higher education is regarded as a factor in the possibility of educational evaluation conversion, so that the sustainability of the key factors of efficient methods in the process of influencing factors is enhanced. Based on the educational information of the key factors, these educational information is integrated into the calculation of the influence probability, so that the key factors can keep the direction in the process of finding the method. In this study, the factors affecting students' choice of learning were used to simulate the optimization strategy, and then compared with the preliminary algorithm. The simulation results show that the optimized strategy is optimized compared with the other two algorithms in terms of increasing the cycle of key factors and ensuring the higher education balance of influencing factors.

title: Diagnosis of Power Transformer Winding Deformation Under Short Circuit Fault Using Non-Intrusive Magnetic Measurement
authors: Yuxin Zhang, Arsalan Habib Khawaja, Qi Huang, Haoyang Fan, Haotian Shi, Dongsheng Cai, Yankai Xing
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Winding deformation in power transformers under Short-Circuit (SC) faults compromises equipment integrity and grid reliability, yet conventional diagnostic methods, such as Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA) and Frequency Response Analysis (FRA), rely on offline procedures, hindering timely fault detection. This study proposes a non-intrusive, real-time diagnostic technique based on Leakage Magnetic Field (LMF) analysis to quantify axial and radial winding deformation. A three-dimensional electromagnetic-structural finite element model, developed for a 110 kV transformer, establishes a nonlinear mapping between LMF distribution and mechanical stress, validated by simulations showing a 26-fold deformation increase under fault conditions. A high-sensitivity magnetic sensor array, strategically placed on the transformer tank, captures dynamic LMF variations, following optimized layout principles for enhanced accuracy. Coupled with a Least Squares (LS) based magnetic field inversion algorithm, the system achieves precise deformation diagnosis with errors below 1.3%, enabling millisecond-level fault warnings. Experimental validation confirms the method’s accuracy and feasibility, offering a cost-effective, safe solution for real-time condition monitoring in smart grids. This approach overcomes the spatial-temporal limitations of traditional diagnostics, supporting predictive maintenance and paving the way for advanced fault warning systems.

title: A Lightweight Spectral-Spatial Unified Feedforward Convolutional Transformer Framework for Spaceborne Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Lei Xia, Yin-Nian Liu, Siwei Zhao, Pengfei Li, Qingyong Wang, Yun Zhao, Mengyang Chai
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Large-scale and high-precision classification are key merits of spaceborne hyperspectral technique, providing a vital basis for rapid discovery of diverse anomalies. However, its vast data volume poses major challenges for real-time applications. Compared to classical hyperspectral image classification (HSIC) methods, deep learning (DL) strategies have improved accuracy but still face bottlenecks due to model complexity and cannot be conducted on resource-constrained orbital platforms. Thus, we propose a lightweight framework to achieve the optimal trade-off among memory, time, and accuracy. The key breakthrough adopts a memory-efficient dimensionality reduction (DR) method that reduces the memory cost by over 60% while breaking away from the conventional paradigm that spectral DR inevitably compromise spectral-spatial structures, thus greatly enhancing information fidelity. Moreover, the created convolution-enhanced Transformer (CET) fulfills seamless integration of global–local feature using minimal convolutional blocks on the single encoder, thereby remarkably reducing network complexity and enhancing computational speed. Extensive evaluations demonstrate that our model matches the accuracy of state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods and exhibits remarkably low computational cost (parameters < 35 K, FLOPs < 300 M, GPU memory < 1.5GB), suggesting its potential for onboard deployment. And the devised architecture reduces detection time by at least 20% while sustaining robust capability across varying imaging scenarios. Our results create a new efficiency-accuracy paradigm for real-time HSIC, crucial for achieving instantaneous remote sensing. The source code will be released at https://github.com/leixia9601/SSUFCT after accepted.

title: A Multisource Heterogeneous Water Hammer Energy Harvester in Flow Pipeline Ambient
authors: Bingduo Zhou, Dandan Jiang, Ao Zhang, Hongbo Zheng, Wenjun Gao, Liuhong Ma, Mengke Li, Zhiyong Duan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The water hammer effect, an energy dissipation phenomenon in fluid pipelines triggered by transient fluid impact, possesses both destructive potential and exploitable energy. Addressing traditional energy harvesters’ narrow bandwidth and low spatial efficiency, this article designs a multisource heterogeneous ambient energy harvester. This device achieves efficient recovery of water hammer impact energy through the synergistic operation of piezoelectric, electromagnetic, and triboelectric mechanisms. The harvester employs a ring-symmetrical three-dimensional structure. By utilizing multiple sets of piezoelectric cantilever beams and a free inertia vibrator, combined with a modal decoupling strategy, it converts axial impact into radial multimodal vibrations, synchronously capturing tri-axial energy. Experimental validation confirmed the power density metrics and electromechanical conversion efficiency under multisource synergy. The piezoelectric volume energy density reached 36.65 mW/cm<inline-formula content-type="math/tex" xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX" version="MathJax">$^3$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, while the electromagnetic and triboelectric surface power densities were 0.56 and 0.12 mW/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, respectively. The collaborative conversion efficiency has reached approximately 79.29%. This device can provide self-power for smart pipeline monitoring systems while concurrently reducing the risk of water hammer-induced damage, demonstrating significant engineering application value.

title: Expression of Concern for: Development of AI Based Autism Detection System
authors: Manya Tuli, Anupriya Chandrasekhar, Shubham Tyagi, Abhishek Singhal
publish: 2024 14th International Conference on Cloud Computing, Data Science &amp; Engineering (Confluence)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a complex neurodevelopmental condition that impacts individuals of all ages. This disorder comprises of symptoms ranging from social and communicational challenges to an exhibition of repetitive behaviors. Early diagnosis and prognosis of ASD is focal for managing its symptoms, supplementing learning outcomes, and social skill development. Conventional diagnosis of ASD based on behavioral evaluations confronts problems owing to the lack of clear-cut rules. On the other hand, Machine Learning and Deep Learning models-based techniques excel in diagnosing ASD by assessing behavioral factors, finding even the tiniest contrariety in gaze and facial attributes. This paper aims to propose an AI-based Autism Detection System leveraging two distinct models. For children aged 2 to 8, XceptionNet model is employed to assess facial dysmorphology in Autistic children's images with an accuracy of 85%, while individuals aged 9 and above undergo evaluation by Light Gradient Boosting Machine Classifier which considers diverse indicators, such as the ASD score, age, gender, ethnicity, etc. to detect Autism with 99% accuracy. Thus, the proposed models enhance the accuracy of ASD detection by addressing the distinct characteristics and requirements of people of all age groups with Autism.

title: Deep Character-Level Convolutional Model for Fine-Grained URL Classification
authors: Reeaa Rana, Suhani Khandelwal, Divya Gautam, Ajit Kr. Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The Web-borne threats are mainly those which involves phishing attacks and malicious URLs, it offer a significant risk to the users working online. Traditional URL classification techniques often rely on manually engineered features, which can easily be circumvented through obfuscation methods and also lack adapt- ability. This research aims at designing a robust and intelligent character-level CNN in order to learn URLs into a variety of classes through end-to-end learning. Raw URLs are fed into the model at the character level, and convolutional layers are used to extract sequential patterns bearing information on the URL type. Tests carried out on a public dataset show our approach achieves a test accuracy of 98.2, with both high precision and recall in all classes. The study proves the deep learning paradigm is effective when applied to raw sequential data in cybersecurity and provides interpretability and performance benefits for character- level models.

title: Jain’s Fairness Index Optimization in RIS-Assisted UAV V2X Systems Based on MASAC
authors: Luying Li, Zhenting Chen, Sunyan Hong, Xiaozhen Li
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: This paper investigates a land-air integrated vehicular network (V2X) system comprising heterogeneous communication links, including vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) links, base station-reconfigurable intelligent surface-vehicle (BS-RIS-V) links, and unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>-UAV) links. To ensure fairness in resource allocation, we first establish transmission rate models for each communication link. We then formulate an optimization problem aimed at maximizing Jain’s fairness index (J), subject to constraints on transmission power, bandwidth, and IRS configuration. To tackle this challenging non-convex problem, we develop a Multi-Agent Soft Actor-Critic (MASAC) algorithm tailored for joint resource optimization. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, showing significant improvements in both fairness and system throughput. Compared to baseline methods, our algorithm achieves a more balanced resource distribution while maintaining high overall performance.

title: Multimodal Intelligent Monitoring System for Physiological Parameters Based on STM32F4 and Fiber Grating Sensor
authors: Zixuan Xue, Shijuan Yang, Yahui Zhang, Tingquan Liu, Huanyu Ai, Zhongyi Wang, Wenkang Ren
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: A multimodal physiological parameter intelligent monitoring system is designed based on STM32F4 microcontroller and fiber grating sensing technology. By integrating fiber Bragg grating (FBG) and surface plasmon resonance (SPR) sensors<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[1]</sup>, the system collects optical wavelength drift signals reflecting heart rate, blood pressure and body temperature, and refractive index change signals reflecting blood glucose concentration, respectively. The above optical signals are converted into electrical signals by the photoelectric conversion circuit and input into STM32F4 microcontroller, enabling high-precision synchronous monitoring of multiple parameters including heart rate, blood pressure, body temperature, and blood glucose. The system relies on the STM32F4 platform to realize real-time data processing and edge intelligent diagnosis, and uploads the data to the cloud platform through Bluetooth and Wi-Fi hybrid communication, which supports the users to view the health data and receive the three-level warning in real time through APP. Experimental results show that the measurement error of the system is less than 1.5% with an abnormality recognition accuracy exceeding 95% providing a feasible technical solution for building a hierarchical diagnosis and treatment system.

title: Design and Performance Analysis of a MIMO Communication System Using SDRs
authors: Subrahmanya Rao D P, Anjali S, Ainesh Sri Patnaik, Mahesh A, Srivani S G
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex> Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) wireless communication system using the Alamouti Space-Time Block Coding (STBC) scheme. The system is realized using USRP 2920 software-defined radios, synchronized with an Octo Clock CDA 2990, and designed to operate at 915 MHz. The signal chain includes pulse shaping, down sampling, symbol and frame synchronization, channel estimation, and Alamouti decoding. Transmission of text data is demonstrated successfully, showcasing the robustness of the system in real-time scenarios. The implementation serves as a practical validation of MIMO techniques and provides a scalable platform for wireless communication research.

title: Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis with IndoBERT for Mapping Public Perception of Nusantara’s Capital in Smart City Domains
authors: Kesi Restian Dwi Pujawati, Herry Irawan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: The development of Nusantara Capital City as a national strategic project has generated diverse public perceptions. This study applies Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis with a fine-tuned IndoBERT model to map these perceptions across six smart city domains using tweets from platform X. The fine-tuned models achieved macro F1-scores of 0.77 for aspect detection and 0.84 for sentiment classification. The analysis shows that overall public sentiment is predominantly negative, with Smart Governance being the most discussed domain, driven by concerns over transparency and budget allocation. The study also uncovers a nearly balanced sentiment on Smart Economy and a paradoxical negative sentiment towards Smart Environment. These findings provide insights in a data-driven framework for policymakers by offering granular insights that align with the Satu Data IKN initiative and can inform more effective communication strategies.

title: Zero-Day Threat Detection in Autonomous Vehicles Using Few-Shot LSTM Autoencoders on CAN Bus Data
authors: Belal Abdalhamza Azeez, Ahmed Dheyaa Radhi, Hassan Mahmood, Mohammed Amin Almaiah, Mohammed Abdul Jaleel Maktoof, Hayder Abd Alrazaq, Muhammad N Majed, Wasan Adnan Hashim
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research presents a computationally efficient, few-shot learning framework built on LSTM autoencoders for zero-day threat detection in autonomous vehicle (AV) CAN bus networks. The model integrates sequence reconstruction, meta-learning adaptation, and dynamic threshold calibration to detect previously unseen anomalies in real-time. Experimental validation across diverse AV scenarios—urban traffic, high-speed CAN injection, ECU impersonation, and V2X interference—yielded up to 98.3% detection accuracy, 0.89 F1-score, and 87.4% zero-day generalization. The system reduced false positives by 76% compared to rule-based IDS and delivered inference latency under 13.9 ms on 32-bit embedded ECUs. Using only 3-5 labeled instances per novel attack, the architecture achieved rapid adaptation through episodic fine-tuning and latent-space anomaly scoring. It is lightweight, retraining-free, hardware-compatible, and compliant with ISO/SAE 21434 and UN R155 cybersecurity mandates—making it a scalable, real-time IDS solution for next-generation connected and autonomous vehicles.

title: The Effect of Mobile Marketing on Consumer Engagement in the Retail Sector
authors: Ayman Mansour, Nawal Qasim Hammadi, Zeid Alqatawneh, Almutasem Najjar, Jassim Algasawneh, Mohammad Alqsass, Alanoud Mbaidin
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Mobile marketing is one of the major advancements in digital marketing strategies, which aims to bring with it great benefits to mobile users. This paper aims to explore the influence of mobile marketing on customer engagement in the retail sector. Using a quantitative approach, a sample of 261 customers was utilized, and an instrument of 15 items was used. Findings revealed that Mobile-optimized marketing campaigns, push notifications and the integration of location-based services are major predictors of customers’ engagement and interaction in the retail sector compared to non-mobile-optimized campaigns and email marketing. Retail sector should focus on utilize the benefits of these strategies to encourage customers to engage and interact with brand, where substantial efforts need to incorporate geolocation services into mobile marketing strategies to enhance customer engagement in the retail sector.

title: Adaptive Curriculum Generation in Mobile Learning Systems Using Graph Attention Networks
authors: Ahmed Abd Aoun Abd Ali, Imadin Maged Zannrni
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Adaptive curriculum generation in mobile learning systems aims to personalize educational content based on learners' needs, preferences, and contextual factors. With the rise of mobile technology, intelligent curriculum adaptation has become essential for enhancing learning efficiency and engagement. However, existing methods often rely on static learner models or shallow personalization techniques, which fail to capture the complex and dynamic relationships among learners, content, and contexts. To address these limitations, this study proposes a Graph Attention Network-Based Learner Profiling (GAT-LP) framework that models learners and educational resources as interconnected nodes in a heterogeneous graph. The graph attention mechanism dynamically assigns weights to nodes based on their relevance, enabling fine-grained profiling and real-time curriculum adaptation. The GAT-LP framework is applied to generate personalized microlearning pathways in mobile environments, where learners receive content sequences optimized for their current knowledge state, interaction history, and peer influence. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves learning outcomes by 98.4%, engagement rates by 97.5%, content relevance by 97.4%, and adaptation latency by 96.3% compared to traditional methods. This highlights the potential of graph-based attention models in transforming mobile learning experiences through deeper personalization and contextual awareness.

title: Gamified Cybersecurity Training Using AI-Driven Learning Analytics in UK STEM Programs
authors: Maruf Farhan, Usman Butt, Rejwan Bin Sulaiman, Madhuki Rajapakshe, Taher M. Ghazal
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The United Kingdom (UK) faces a significant cybersecurity skills shortage, with approximately 44% of businesses experiencing basic cybersecurity skills gaps, and incident management skills gaps increasing from 27% in 2020 to 48% in 2024. Traditional cybersecurity training methods often fail to engage learners effectively or provide adequate assessment of knowledge retention. This paper presents a novel framework combining gamified cybersecurity training with Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven learning analytics specifically designed for UK Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) programs.This approach utilizes behavioural science principles together with machine learning algorithms and incorporates real-time performance tracking, predictive modelling, and automated content adaptation based on individual learning patterns to create personalized, adaptive learning experiences. This optimizes both engagement and improves cybersecurity competencies. The effectiveness of this approach is highlighted through case studies of UK-based implementations, including the Cyber Explorers program and Gamified Intelligent Cyber Behaviour Assessment and Skills Training (GICAST) initiative. These case studies demonstrate significant improvements in learner engagement and knowledge retention as well as skills application, through data such as 60% boost in learner engagement by gamified training and 77% improvement in concept understanding from GICAST. Moving beyond conventional compliance-based training to establish interactive, data-driven experiences, the proposed framework addresses the key challenges in cybersecurity education and fosters long-term behavioural change. Results of AI-enhanced gamification show its ability to effectively bridge the cybersecurity skills gap while providing data-driven insights to educators for continuous program improvement.

title: AI-Driven Autonomous API Orchestration for Multi-Cloud Integration
authors: Maninder Pal Singh, Vishnu Ravi, Vineet Kumar Srivastava, Nuzhat Prova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The effective processing of API calls by cloud providers such as AWS, Microsoft Azure, or GCP has become increasingly challenging as multi-cloud adoption has increased. Reliability, cost maintenance, latency reduction, and performance improvement are some advantages of using several clouds. Traditional approaches frequently fail because they don't respond well to the dynamic and shifting nature of workloads in multi-cloud environment. We solve this by introducing a deep Q-network-based AI approach for autonomous API request routing. This provides reinforcement learning for picking the most relevant and valuable cloud provider based on live metric parameters such as latency, cost, and failure rates. The system remains versatile, subject to changing conditions, to ensure that performance optimization is achieved across AWS, Azure, and GCP. These findings show significant improvements and accomplishments in key performance indicators (KPI). API latency has been reduced from 250 ms to 140 ms, approximately a 44% reduction, with a corresponding decrease in the cost per request of 20%. The success rate has increased from 92% to 98%, and the failure rate has decreased from 8% to 2%. There is also a balanced load across the three clouds <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(34 \%, 33 \%$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$33 \%)$</tex> with an energy savings of 10%. Thus, our results demonstrate that AI-enhanced reinforcement learning can be highly beneficial in enhancing multi-cloud API orchestration. Besides these, they will also be resource-efficient and therefore very scalable solutions for the modern-day cloud architectures.

title: Security and Privacy in IoT-Enabled EEG Brain–Computer Interfaces: A Survey and Comparative Analysis
authors: Ali Baghban Baghestan, Mahdi Rabbani
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) based brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) are increasingly integrated with Internet-of-Things (IoT) ecosystems to enable assistive, healthcare and smartenvironment applications. However, EEG signals encode sensitive cognitive and biometric information, and networked BCIs inherit IoT vulnerabilities plus machine learning (ML)–specific threats. This paper surveys the literature (2020–2025) at the intersection of EEG, IoT, and cybersecurity with the following contributions: (1) a unified architecture and threat model for IoT-enabled BCIs; (2) a taxonomy of known attacks and defense techniques; (3) an analysis of EEG-to-text and LLM-enabled pipelines and their security implications; and (4) comparative tables summarizing representative works and design trade-offs. We highlight open challenges, including real-time privacy-preserving computation, standardized threat benchmarks, and governance for neural data.

title: Multi-Model Urban Road Demand Forecasting: A Graph Neural Network-Based Approach Using National Roadway Statistics
authors: Ragini Rani
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Accurate urban traffic demand forecasting is essential for reducing congestion, enhancing mobility, and informing infrastructure development. This study proposes a comprehensive AI-driven framework that integrates machine learning (ML), deep learning (DL), and graph neural networks (GNNs) to predict traffic demand and identify high-traffic zones in major U.S. cities. Leveraging the Highway Statistics Series: Urbanized Areas dataset, traditional ML models (e.g., Logistic Regression, Random Forest) served as baselines, while DL models with deeper architectures (Dropout and Batch Normalization) were applied to better capture non-linear patterns. To model spatial dependencies inherent in urban traffic networks, GNN models—including GCN, GraphSAGE, and GAT—were applied by treating roadways and intersections as graph structures. Among all models, the Wide-Deep (DL) and GraphSAGE (GNN) achieved the highest accuracy (94% and 95%) with F1-scores of 0.93 and 0.93, respectively. These findings underscore the effectiveness of combining structural learning with deep/spatial architectures for urban road/traffic analysis. Beyond prediction, the framework offers actionable insights for urban planners-infrastructure stress, need for supplementary roads, and improving public transit system allocation, laying the groundwork for future extensions involving real-time data integration and adaptive traffic control via hybrid GNN-reinforcement learning models.

title: Pre and Post Silicon Validation for Display IP
authors: Prathap C, M Govinda Raju
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The growing demand for high-resolution multimedia on System-on-Chip (SoC) platforms has made robust validation of Display Intellectual Property (IP) a critical aspect of silicon tape-out. Traditional RTL simulations are inadequate for exercising real-time display scenarios, leading to an increased focus on FPGA-based emulation and post-silicon debug methodologies. This paper presents a dual-phase validation framework for Display IP that leverages FPGA emulation for pre-silicon testing and a hardware platform for post-silicon validation. The methodology adopts configuration-driven regression scripts and test cases targeting functional, protocol, and performance features of the Display Processing Unit (DPU). Validation includes sanity checks, resolution upscaling, underrun simulation, Cyclic-Redundancy-Check(CRC) based accuracy testing, and DisplayPort protocol compliance tests. The proposed framework achieves greater than 95% functional coverage and approximately 90% feature coverage and supports faster bug detection and shortened debug cycles. The results demonstrate that the dual-phase approach is reusable, scalable and provides high confidence in silicon readiness of Display IPs integrated in modern SoCs.

title: SARBNet: A Shuffle Attention Hybrid Network for WiFi CSI-based Human Activity Recognition
authors: Zhibin Lin, Jiangnan Yuan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Network Communication and Information Security (ICNCIS)
abstract: WiFi signals play a crucial role in Human Activity Recognition (HAR) tasks due to their widespread availability and privacy-preserving characteristics. WiFi channel state information (CSI) varies with human movement, providing rich spatiotemporal information for activity recognition tasks. Considering that the spatial characteristics of CSI signals can determine an individual’s location, the temporal characteristics can be used to analyze the motion state of the human body. This paper proposes a modified residual network architecture, constructing an inverted residual shuffle attention block (IRSAB) that emphasizes spatial and channel features while preserving temporal information. This information is fed into Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory(BiLSTM) to extract forward and backward temporal dependencies. Through comparative experiments with other existing models, our method achieved an average recognition accuracy of 99.06% on the UT_HAR dataset, surpassing existing approaches.

title: Design of Fire Smoke Detection Based on Deep Learning
authors: Yaowei Ji, Meixuan Li, Yuzhi Ma, Qi Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Network Communication and Information Security (ICNCIS)
abstract: As a typical sudden public safety incident, fires pose a continuous threat to people’s lives and property. The recent frequent occurrence of various fires has made the effective prevention of fires a matter of global concern for researchers. To address this issue, an improved method for fire smoke detection has been proposed. Based on the YOLOv8 algorithm, an efficient object detection system was developed. The system uses this algorithm as its basic framework and introduces the SE attention mechanism to optimize the model’s feature extraction capability, enhancing the model’s accuracy in detecting fire smoke. To validate the improved method, a fire smoke detection system was designed, supporting single images, image folders, and real-time detection, with real-time display of detection results and data export. The experimental results indicate that the improved model has an average accuracy increase of 0.27% compared to the traditional model, as well as improvements of 0.23% and 0.27% in precision and recall, respectively.

title: Deep Learning-Enhanced Indoor Localization Using Joint AOA-TOA Fingerprints
authors: Dongyuan Liu, Liang Wu, Zaichen Zhang
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: With the rapid proliferation of smart mobile devices and the fast development of mobile internet services, there is an increasing demand for high-precision indoor positioning. However, in complex indoor environments, Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) propagation and Multipath Components (MPC) significantly degrade positioning accuracy. This paper focuses on the study of intelligent location awareness technologies in complex dynamic environments, proposing a hybrid fingerprint indoor positioning scheme based on Angle of Arrival (AOA) and Time of Arrival (TOA). The feasibility of the proposed scheme is analyzed. The scheme is based on channel modeling using scene geometric information, and utilizes the obtained Channel State Information (CSI) to estimate the AOA and TOA through algorithms based on enhanced matrices and matrix beams. The estimated AOA and TOA are used as fingerprints for training. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme achieves high positioning accuracy in Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) environments.

title: Assessing Vegetation-driven Reduction in Window Solar Heat Gain using LiDAR-based Modelling
authors: Marko Bizjak, Gorazd Štumberger, Domen Mongus, Niko Lukač, Jihui Yuan
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Window solar heat gain significantly contributes to cooling energy demand in urban buildings, particularly during summer months and in dense cityscapes affected by the urban heat island effect. Vegetation has been shown to reduce this gain through shading, yet precise assessment of its impact at the sub-window level remains underexplored. This paper presents a high-resolution methodology for estimating the effect of vegetation on window solar heat gain using LiDAR-derived 3D environment comprising of 2.5 D grid, 3D building models and vegetation. Within this environment, solar heat gain is computed per window triangle by incorporating dynamic shading via ray-casting. Results demonstrate that vegetation reduces cumulative annual window solar heat gain by $11.31 \%$ in an urban setting, with greatest reductions observed on south-facing, upper-story windows and during summer months. The presented work provides detailed spatial insights into the thermal benefits of urban greenery and supports climate-sensitive urban planning and energy-efficient building design.

title: Gamification Mechanics and AI-Driven Personalization: Enhancing Continuous Use in Freemium Game Platforms
authors: Vera Dumonda Silitonga, Christian Lim, Gromyko Bongso
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: The rise of digital gaming in Indonesia has brought new forms of consumer behavior, especially within platforms like Steam that combine entertainment with social interaction and commerce. This research explores the psychological and social drivers behind gamers’ decisions to purchase virtual goods, with a focus on enjoyment, social influence, personal attitude, and repeated platform use. The study centers on understanding what truly motivates spending in a freemium environment. An online survey targeted Indonesian Steam users who had previously made in-game purchases. From the 202 valid responses, statistical analysis using PLS-SEM was applied to test behavioral relationships among key variables. The results suggest that consistent platform engagement and peer influence are stronger predictors of purchase decisions than personal attitudes. Contrary to expectations, attitude alone does not significantly shape buying behavior in this context. Instead, enjoyment fuels continued use, which in turn increases the likelihood of purchasing. These findings suggest that spending on digital goods is less a matter of rational choice and more a product of habit and social immersion. While the results provide valuable insights for digital platform designers and marketers, the focus on a specific demographic and platform limits broader generalization.

title: Auction-Based Dynamic Resource Allocation for Optimized Edge Computing in Distributed Networks
authors: Md Anisur Rahman Chowdhury, Khandakar Rabbi Ahmed, Kefei Wang, Aizaada Akylbekova, Shah Tawkir Nesar, Sabrina Mohona
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Edge computing networks need to dynamically distribute their limited and heterogeneous computation resources to handle changing tasks efficiently. This paper proposes a new auction-based dynamic resource allocation strategy for completely decentralized, heterogeneous edge situations. To ensure fair and optimal task assignment, end-to-end resource exploitation is optimized by allowing independent edge nodes to bid aggressively for incoming tasks depending on their available capacity and processing quality in real time. Extensive experiments conducted on a heterogeneous five-node testbed show that, in contrast to conventional static allocation techniques, the auction-based mechanism achieves a very high 98.2 % utilization rate of resources, minimizes task rejection to zero, and significantly prevents residual resource fragmentation. Fairness metrics also make sure that nodes are assigned tasks more fairly. The system shows remarkable scalability and flexibility to near-saturation network conditions with minimal computation overhead. The study adds to the decentralized edge resource orchestration and offers promising possibilities for use cases in smart cities and the Internet of Things that are limited by latency. In the future, the model will be scaled to massive-scale real-time edge settings, communication overhead will be reduced, and adaptive bidding will be used to mitigate load concentration.

title: Perspectives for the Decarbonization of a Mountain Hut in the Trentino Region
authors: Niccolò Andreetta, Spyridon Chapaloglou, Elisa Bortolotti, Elisabetta Tedeschi
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Abstract-Among the many infrastructures transitioning in recent years toward more sustainable energy paradigms, Mountain Huts (MHs) deserve particular attention due to their location in fragile environments and frequent isolation from the main power system. As a result, their operation must rely solely on local electrical production. For this purpose, Diesel Generators (DGs) are currently their main or unique energy source, with a negative economic and environmental impact. In addition, especially in the Italian Alpine region, MHs are expected to experience a future increase in load consumption, due to their growing touristic popularity. A recent trend among visitors is to reach MHs by Electric Bicycles (EBs), which may require local recharging, thus further contributing to increasing the MH energy needs. This paper optimizes the size of a pool of renewable generators and energy storage systems, alongside the traditional DG, to supply the power required by a MH. Moreover, the effect of the presence of EBs is evaluated both as a challenge due to load increase, but also as a potential source of income and technical opportunity to improve energy management, via bidirectional battery charging. The results based on real load data from an Alpine hut show that the use of only DG has a cost more than four times higher than the proposed optimal solution. Additionally, the foreseen presence of EBs could generate an additional income, further reducing the total operational cost. Finally, the proposed EB recharging policy enables a further small economic benefit.

title: Experimental Verification of Single-Phase Supplied Motor Power Pulsation Buffer Dual-Inverter Variable Speed Drive
authors: Spasoje Mirić, Junzhong Xu, Jonas Huber, Michael Haider, Samuel Kälin, Dominik Bortis, Johann W. Kolar
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Single-phase-supplied variable-speed drive (VSD) systems are widely used in industrial applications, typically following a two-stage design with a boost-type power factor correction (PFC) rectifier at the input and a three-phase voltage source inverter (VSI) at the output. However, the reliance on large electrolytic DC-link capacitors, required to buffer power pulsations at twice the grid frequency, together with the boost inductor, introduces drawbacks in terms of reliability, volume, cost, and complexity. To address these limitations, a dualinverter topology with a three-phase open-end winding (OEW) machine and the motor power pulsation buffer (MPPB) concept is employed. In this approach, power pulsations are absorbed by the total drive system’s inertia, drastically reducing the required DClink capacitance and thereby eliminating the need for electrolytic capacitors, which enables a more compact, reliable, and longlifespan drive system. This paper presents hardware verification of the dual-inverter MPPB system. A custom-built 1.8 kW demonstrator, supplied from a single-phase $230 \mathrm{~V}_{\text {rms }} \mathrm{AC}$ grid and driving a threephase OEW motor, is developed and experimentally tested. The measured waveforms confirm that power pulsations are buffered in the mechanical inertia rather than in capacitors, while maintaining PFC operation, regulating the secondary DClink voltage, and ensuring stable speed control. These results validate the effectiveness of the dual-inverter MPPB concept.

title: Evaluation of passive maximum power point tracking performance of power conditioner-less PV-storage battery systems
authors: Yasuyuki Kanai, Fujio Kurokawa
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This paper experimentally verified the dynamic characteristics of a PV battery system that maximizes PV panel power generation using passive methods without a power conditioner. The method for maximizing power generation involves determining the number of PV panels to connect in series during the system design phase so that the maximum power point voltage of the PV array matches the battery voltage. After that, the PV array and battery are simply connected directly during the construction of the PV battery system. In practice, the maximum power point voltage of the PV array is affected by PV cell temperature. The design ensures these two voltages match at the cell temperature corresponding to high solar irradiance and high power generation. Previously, the highest cell temperature was used. This paper improves upon that by using the cell temperature commonly observed between 10:00 AM and 2:00 PM. In the experiment, the theoretically calculated maximum power point voltage was determined from the measured cell temperature. The deviation between this voltage and the operating voltage of the battery (the PV array’s operating point) was measured, along with the utilization efficiency of the generated power. Experimental results showed that during low solar radiation conditions like rain or cloudy weather, this deviation increased, causing efficiency to drop to around 95%. Conversely, during sunny conditions with high solar radiation and high power generation, the deviation decreased, achieving maximum efficiency of 100%. Under daytime weather conditions suitable for power generation, power was generated with high efficiency exceeding 95%, yielding results as expected.

title: Classification of Induction Motor Rotor Bar Damage Using Discrete Wavelet Transform and Artificial Neural Network
authors: Hilmaniyya, Aghus Sofwan, Mochammad Facta, Trias Andromeda, Karnoto, Shahrin Bin Md Ayob
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Induction motors are widely used in industry as prime movers because they play an important role in the industry for the conversion of electricity into mechanical energy. Rotor bar damage in three-phase AC induction motors can cause performance degradation and system failure. This study aims to develop an effective method in detecting and classifying rotor bar damage early. This work was carried out by collecting current and vibration signals from motors with various conditions and amounts of rotor bar damage. The signals were processed using Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) with levels 8 and 11 to obtain approximation coefficients around 30 Hz. Feature extraction on the DWT processing results was carried out to obtain important information. Artificial Neural Network (ANN) was carried out as a signal analysis to classify signals into healthy bar and damage bar. The damage bar are represented in four conditions namely one, two, three and four broken bars. Performance testing results show that the proposed classification model method has an accuracy of 95-100% on five different signals taken from five different conditions. The result indicates the excellent and consistent model performance across signal data variations. In addition, testing results show that the combination of current and axial vibration signals does not significantly influence on the accuracy.

title: Next-Packet Prediction with Temporal Transformer Networks: A Non-Contrastive Self-Supervised Approach for AI-Powered Cybersecurity Threat Detection
authors: Jiawei Chen, Yulin Zhou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Network Communication and Information Security (ICNCIS)
abstract: We propose a novel non-contrastive self-supervised learning framework for intrusion detection, which reformulates threat detection as a next-packet prediction task to eliminate the reliance on labeled data and explicit negative sampling. The proposed method integrates a Temporal Transformer Network (TTN) to autoregressively model packet sequences, learning latent representations by predicting subsequent packets in unlabeled traffic flows. These representations are then refined through a Graph Attention Head (GAH) during fine-tuning, which constructs dynamic graphs to capture temporal and semantic relationships for accurate threat classification. The TTN-GAH cascade inherently addresses evasion tactics by modeling causal dependencies in network traffic while mitigating class imbalance through graph-based label propagation. Moreover, the architecture achieves computational efficiency by avoiding contrastive pairs, reducing pre-training costs significantly compared to conventional approaches. Experimental validation demonstrates that the method generalizes to novel attacks by leveraging its pre-trained embeddings, offering a paradigm shift from static feature classification to dynamic sequence modeling in cybersecurity. The results highlight superior detection performance and robustness, establishing the framework as a scalable solution for modern ML-based intrusion detection systems.

title: Energy Supply Optimization and Demandside Flexibility of a Paper Drying Plant
authors: Marco Lauricella, Jan Christoph Schlake, Andreas Zehnpfund, Jonathan Sejdija, Ralf Schemm, Philip Kayser
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: An energy management system (EMS) with demand-side flexibility is presented, to support renewable energy integration and emissions reduction in industrial sites, and to enable industrial loads participation to ancillary services programs. We propose a hierarchical EMS, with a model simulating a paper drying plant at its core. A day-ahead energy cost optimizer schedules the use of fossil fuel-based and electricity-based heat generation sources to minimize the cost of energy and greenhouse gas emissions. The upper layer estimates the available demand-side flexibility of the energy sources use and outputs optimal bids for the ancillary service market. The proposed hierarchical EMS allows energy intensive industries to support the power grid while creating revenues and reducing emissions.

title: Predictive Modeling of Bankruptcy Risk in SMEs Using Explainable AI with Temporal and Financial Health Indicators
authors: Amel Abed Mohammed Ali, Hussein Basim Furaijl, Murtadha A. Kadhim, Islam Mohamed Mahmood, Wisam Al-Anezi, Omar Howaidi, Raghad Jawad Ali, Hashim H. Muqdad, Ahmad Faead
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This paper introduces a high-performance bankruptcy prediction model for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) based on the incorporation of state-of-the-art feature learning, interaction modeling, and explainable AI methods. Relying on autoencoder-influenced latent feature extraction, factorization machines to capture high-order financial interactions, and a combination of deep neural networks and gradient boosting, the model was trained using multiyear SME financial data for various industries. It obtained classification accuracies of at least 97.1% consistently, with F1-scores as high as 0.94 and interpretability robustness scores as much as 0.91. Relative to conventional ratio-based and static learning models, the proposed method enhanced predictive accuracy by more than 6%, while providing better decision transparency through tree-based feature attribution and interaction-aware representations. This architecture allows for early recognition of financial distress and sector-specific insolvency trends, enabling actionable insights into credit scoring and regulatory monitoring. With computational efficiency optimized—training in less than 1.1 seconds per epoch—the model is still extremely scalable and flexible in various SME settings without retraining at the architecture level.

title: Malicious Vulnerability Scanning Detection Using Ensemble-Based Machine-Learning and Explainability-Based Feature Selection
authors: Mohammed M. Alani
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The rapid rate of adoption of Internet-of-Things in various applications in our daily lives have made it an important target for malicious actors. Most of these threats emerge from simple scans that could result in finding significant vulnerabilities. In this paper we address an important security threat which is vulnerability scanning conducted by malicious actors. This scanning takes place in the reconnaissance phase of the attack, and helps the attack gain important insights into the vulnerabilities that exist in the device leading to exploiting them. We introduce a machine learning-based vulnerability scanning detector that utilizes explainable machine learning for feature selection. The proposed detector analyzes network traffic patterns to identify malicious vulnerability scanning and enables the network to stop it. SHAP-based explainability is used to identify the most effective features to perform feature selection. The proposed system was trained and tested using CIC-IoT-2023 dataset. Tests have shown reliable results with accuracy exceeding 99.9% and F<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf> Score of 0.999 while reducing the number of features from 46 to 24.

title: Malware Detection in Executable Files Using Dynamic Analysis and Gaussian NB
authors: Septiani Kusuma Ningrum, Nurul Afifah, Muhammad Qurhanul Rizqie, Fahron, Nensi Fitriyanti, Indrajani Sutedja
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Malware detection in executable files is a critical challenge in cybersecurity, especially with the increasing number and complexity of modern Trojan-Ransomware attacks. While advanced models exist, a foundational understanding of baseline performance and key behavioral indicators is often overlooked. This study identifies the most significant dynamic behavioral features for detecting modern Trojan-Ransomware. Using features from dynamic analysis and the Gaussian Naive Bayes (GNB) algorithm as a baseline model, this research evaluates the discriminative power of these features on training and testing data (80:20). Experimental results show that GNB is highly effective in identifying malware (recall 94.2%), but its performance is weak in recognizing normal files (recall 45.4%). This imbalanced performance highlights the importance of feature analysis to understand the causes of classification errors. The main contribution of this study is not to propose GNB as an optimal solution, but to use it as an analytical tool to identify the most characteristic behavioral features of ransomware, and rigorously document the limitations of a simple baseline model. This analysis provides crucial insights into why misclassifications occur and establishes a clear performance benchmark that more sophisticated models must surpass.

title: Conditional Differential Attack on Lightweight Stream Cipher Atom
authors: Xiaojuan Lu, Zixin Tan, Hongcai Xin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Network Communication and Information Security (ICNCIS)
abstract: Knellwolf et al. introduced a conditional differential attack on NFSR-based cryptosystems at ASIACRYPT 2010. Since then, this method has been extensively employed to evaluate the security of various cryptographic algorithms with Grain family structures. Atom is a small-state stream cipher with a 159-bit internal state, based on the Grain family structure, and offers 128-bit security. It was proposed by Subhadeep Banik et al. in ToSC 2021. Given its structure and security claims, Atom presents an interesting target for further cryptanalysis. In this paper, we conduct a detailed study of conditional differential attacks on Atom. We first investigate the difference propagation of roundreduced Atom with differential algebraic transitional form (DATF) technique introduced by Liu et al. and develop an input difference selection strategy. Next, we present a condition imposing algorithm to handle the complicated conditions. We revisit previous research and show that our algorithm can control differential propagation over the same number of rounds (0–15 rounds) using just 21 conditions, a significant reduction from the 98 conditions required by prior methods. Finally, we apply the conditional differential attack to 51-round Atom, enabling the recovery of 3 key bits with data and time complexities of 2^29. The distinguisher of 51-round Atom has been thoroughly verified through practical experiments conducted on a 4.20GHz AMD 7950X3D CPU. To the best of our knowledge, this is the best result of conditional differential attack on round-reduced Atom reported in the publicly available literature.

title: Digital Twins for Human Organs Using Bioelectronic Data and CNN
authors: Manyu A K, Pramukh K, Subramanya G M, Lipika S, Shravan V, Shashank N, Avik Banerjee
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
