abstract: Digital Twin (DT) technology has emerged as an effective solution to enhance monitoring, forecasting, and control of complex systems. Digital Twins create a virtual representation of physical assets in real-time; by continuously providing feedback, they can add an additional layer of reliability to our systems and minimize undesired or problematic behaviors over the entire life cycle of a system. Initially established as a concept in engineering and manufacturing, the idea has advanced to different domains such as healthcare and smart cities. Within medicine, combining Digital Twins with biofeedback systems can offer precision-based treatment, remote monitoring, and result in improved patient outcomes as we have access to real-time physiological data. In the context of cities, smart services derived from Digital Twin platforms are assuredly citizen centric as they address accessibility, trust, and efficiency in city operations. Therefore smart healthcare, as part of this digital evolution encompasses the integration of AI, IoT, and cloud-based solutions, all of which should enhance decision-making, service delivery, and sustain ability. Industry activity indicates that Digital Twins are heading toward mass adoption leveraged through advances in connectivity, data analytics, and modeling capabilities, but face challenges with limitations in system interoperability, data privacy and security, and achieving real-time synchronization. Regardless, Digital Twins are increasingly essential for smart infrastructures that reflect a future-proof precaution across industries.

title: Cybersecurity Management in the Age of Digitalization: Strategies and Best Practices
authors: Muttappa M Mantur, Abdulnaser A. Hagar, Manesh R. Palav, Aniket Kulkarni, Kehkashan Habeeb, Jehad Aldehayyat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Cybersecurity has become essential in today's more interconnected digital world to protect people, businesses, and countries from a wide range of cyber threats. With an emphasis on identifying risks and bolstering defences, this research paper offers a thorough analysis of cybersecurity in the digital era. Although there are still vulnerabilities in cybersecurity and an increasing concern in the IoT area regarding the detection of assaults in IOT systems, IoT networks are a promising technology whose deployment is expanding quickly. IDS emerges as the top security option. Protecting networks from a variety of hostile activities is mostly dependent on anomaly-based network IDS (intrusion detection system). One of the most important concerns nowadays is enhancing the security of IoT networks. The effectiveness of several ML methods in forecasting attacks on Internet of Things devices has been examined in this study. The ADASYN techniques were then applied to the problem of unequal classes. The evaluation measures used in the performance comparison include the AUC curve, recall, accuracy, precision, and F1 score.

title: Graph Neural Network Approach for Intrusion Detection in Financial Networks
authors: Namrata Mishra, Zaid Alsalami, Karri Hemalatha, P. Kavitha, R. Velmurugan, Qusai AL-Durrah, Abdulkareem A. Jasim Abushraida
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Intrusion detection in financial networks endures an essential challenge to preserving data safe and interrupting sophisticated cyber threats that target transactional systems. Cyber threats that target transactional systems are challenging to comprehend. Traditional machine learning and rule-based methods often fail to perform effectively because they are unable to recognize the complex, changing, and non-Euclidean structure of financial data or the intricate relationships between entities. This study presents a method for detecting intrusions in financial networks based on Graph Neural Networks (GNN). The technique leverages the capabilities of GNNs to model dependencies at the node, edge, and graph levels. The results of this study demonstrate that when current methods have not proven adequate, including their inability to depend on fixed attributes and evolve to deal with new forms of threats. It also offers a new architecture that takes into consideration node embeddings, temporal dynamics, and information about the graph’s topology to ensure it can appropriately identify unusual behavior. The proposed model consistently outperforms traditional methods in terms of precision, recall, and F1 Score. The results can be demonstrated by experiments on datasets containing real-world financial transactions, and the significance of GNNs contributes to ensuring intrusion detection systems that are accurate, scalable, and adaptable. These outcomes have a significant impact on both the progress of fraud prevention and the real-time safety of financial systems.

title: Investigating the Impact of Interactive Multimodal Learning Strategy to Improve Language Teaching
authors: Yaling Deng, Senyue Tian
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: In order to meet the application needs of improving language teaching and the unreasonable distribution of the comprehensive interactive platform, in order to meet the application needs of improving the comprehensive interactive platform of language teaching, this paper studies the reasonable distribution of improving the application of language teaching. First of all, the number of comprehensive interactive platforms needed to improve the language teaching in the research area is calculated through the language teaching index. On the basis of the reclassification of land types, the interactive learning area is divided, and the application demand coefficient of the comprehensive interactive platform for improving the language teaching is calculated. Then the interactive multimodal learning strategy is proposed, the interactive multimodal learning is introduced to enrich the diversity of the population, the control factor of interactive learning is used to prevent the algorithm from falling into the local optimum, and complete the reasonable distribution study of improving language teaching application. Simulation experiments prove that the proposed method in this paper can effectively meet the needs of improving the application and the convenience of the language teaching interactive platform.

title: Measurement-based Orbital Angular Momentum Channel Modeling at 132 GHz in Indoor Environments
authors: Yuqi Wang, Jie Zhang, Xi Liao, Tao Hu, Yang Wang
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Orbital angular momentum (OAM) communication is envisioned as a key technology for sixth generation wireless systems (6 G) and can be combined with terahertz (THz) communication technology to significantly enhance spectral efficiency. The measurement and accurate analysis of the channel provide an important foundation for terahertz OAM communication technology. Based on this, this paper first proposes a path loss model for OAM waves. Then, a terahertz OAM measurement platform is constructed in indoor scenarios, and a spiral phase plate (SPP) is used to generate multi-mode OAM waves at 132 GHz. Finally, the large-scale characteristics of the measured channel data are analyzed. The results show that, compared with the free space propagation loss model, this model better explains the wave loss characteristics of vortex waves, and the prediction accuracy is improved by an average of 11.8%.

title: Developing an IoT-based Nanogrid for Remote and Rural Areas
authors: Eraste Rukundo, Mirco Mongilli, Viviane Ishimwe, Guido Matrella, Paolo Ciampolini
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: This paper presents the design and early implementation of an IoT-based solar nanogrid for rural settings, focusing on the Busengo Living Lab in northern Rwanda within the EU-funded GREATER project. In regions where national grid extension is limited by challenging terrain and dispersed populations, decentralized PV nanogrids offer a viable solution for reliable electricity access. The system uses an AC bus to interconnect community buildings including a training center, parish house, and church, each with distinct energy consumption profile. Solar generation, storage, and a master inverter enable autonomous operation, while an IoT ecosystem supports real-time monitoring, optimization, and fault detection. Network analysis and MATLAB simulations confirm stable supply under variable loads. The IoT-enabled platform further supports demand-side management, improving efficiency. Designed for scalability and potential grid interconnection, the Busengo nanogrid offers a replicable model for sustainable rural electrification in Sub-Saharan Africa, advancing progress toward universal, affordable, and clean energy access.

title: MAC Protocol Recognition using Transformer-based Neural Network
authors: Yifan Lin, Jinlong Zhuang, Jiyan Lan, Shengliang Peng
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: In modern communication systems, accurate recognition of Media Access Control (MAC) protocols is crucial for achieving comprehensive awareness of the wireless environment. With the rise of Deep Neural Networks, MAC protocol recognition based on Deep Learning (DL) has gained significant attention in recent years. However, existing DL-based MAC protocol recognition methods still suffer from insufficient adaptability to complex channel environments and limited ability to capture long-term dependencies, leading to challenges in achieving high accuracy. This study proposes a transformer-based MAC protocol recognition model to overcome these limitations of traditional methods. Utilizing the transformer’ s encoder structure, the model effectively captures long-term dependencies and global features within the data, thereby enhancing its ability to accurately identify various MAC protocols. Experimental results demonstrate that the transformer-based approach outperforms other classical networks, underscoring the potential of transformers in handling sequential data and improving model performance.

title: Design and Implementation of Hybrid Microgrid for Rural Communities
authors: Sreejith Kunnath, Rishikesh S, HariKrishnan Pashnath, Shankar Nalinakshan, Divya R
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Electricity is an integral part for the survival of human beings in the era; a lack of electricity is stripping a person of his opportunity to develop and move forward. Though India is almost fully electrified, there still exist certain parts that haven't yet received electricity due to a number of reasons. The places that has access to electricity, its reliability is still under question The development of hybrid microgrids presents a sustainable and cost-effective solution for electrifying rural areas. By integrating photovoltaic systems (PV) with other renewable energy sources, in this case a biogas-powered generator, battery storage, and connection to the main power grid, hybrid systems ensure reliability, reduce dependency on fossil fuels, and mitigate power shortages. This work explores the design and implementation of a microgrid that manages two energy sources and a battery system. By integrating renewable resources and leveraging innovative storage and control strategies, this hybrid microgrid design demonstrates the potential for a cost-effective, reliable, and environmentally friendly energy solution. The proposed system also provides better quality of power produced due to its less TDH value.

title: Segmenting the Morphological Spectrum of Gallbladders in Neonatal Cholestasis: A MAF-UNet Approach for Biliary Atresia Assessment
authors: Yuyao Li, Fan Fan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Systems (ICCS)
abstract: Biliary Atresia (BA) is the leading cause of liver transplantation in infants, making early diagnosis critical. While ultrasound is the primary screening tool, automated segmentation is challenged by the atrophic, irregular gallbladders with indistinct boundaries and low contrast common in BA patients. This task is further hindered by a key limitation in existing networks: skip connections often introduce background noise when fusing high-resolution details with high-level semantics, leading to failures in localizing weak boundaries. To directly address this fusion-related issue, we propose MAF-UNet, an architecture centered on our novel AttenFusionBlock (AFB). This cross-attention-based module leverages decoder features ("Query") to adaptively select and re-weight crucial details from encoder features ("Key/Value"), enabling precise, context-aware feature fusion. The complete MAF-UNet architecture also incorporates a MixStructure Block (MSB) to capture diverse morphologies and a cascaded dual-path gated prediction head to refine the final output. On a clinical dataset of 80 infants, MAF-UNet achieved an Intersection over Union (IoU) of 84.60%, significantly outperforming several state-of-the-art models. Ablation studies confirm that the performance gain is primarily attributed to our core AFB module. MAF-UNet effectively segments morphologically diverse gallbladders, providing a reliable quantitative basis for the early assessment of BA.

title: Smart Scan: A Next-Gen Android Vulnerability Framework Powered by CVE Intelligence
authors: Saptadeepa Kalita, Anand Kiran, Avinash Kumar, Shweta Soni, Venkata Sai Rahul Trivedi Kothapalli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The mobile phone has evolved into an essential tool in modern life, extending far beyond its original purpose of voice communication. Today, it plays a crucial role in banking, entertainment, education, and countless daily tasks, handling a vast amount of personal and sensitive data. As a result, securing mobile applications and their operating systems has become a pressing necessity. With Android dominating the global smartphone market, it has also become a prime target for cyberattacks due to its open architecture and widespread use. Recognizing these vulnerabilities, this work proposes a comprehensive scanning tool that integrates all critical features required to identify potential threats and system weaknesses. The scanner is designed to detect vulnerabilities effectively, ensuring better protection for end users. Additionally, the system leverages the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) database to recognize recent and critical threats, enabling timely detection and mitigation. By combining essential scanning capabilities with up-to-date threat intelligence, the proposed solution aims to enhance mobile security, particularly for Android devices, and address the growing concern of mobile-based cyber threats.

title: Fine-Grained Emotion Recognition from Short Video Clips Using CNN-LSTM with Facial Action Heatmaps
authors: Zahraa Haimeed Rasool, Haneen Siraj Ibrahim, Enas Ahmed Abed, Mina Taha Ibrahim, Nourhan Ahmed Waheed, Azhaar A. Shalal, Wael Yahya Yaseen, Inbithaq Ahmed Shakir
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The human face is considered a mirror, reflecting a multitude of emotions, sometimes manifesting involuntarily due to the expressive movements of facial muscles. This topic falls within the concept of artificial intelligence in computer vision. It seems easy for humans to recognize a person just by looking at them, unlike machines. In this paper, we propose developing a hybrid model that combines spatial CNN features, temporal representation of parameters using an LSTM model, and facial action units (AUs). This model is capable of more accurately understanding and detecting subtle facial expressions. The model uses VGGNet and ResNeXt models to extract features from image sequences and uses AU maps as auxiliary input to improve model performance, adding tangible physiological interpretations to the model. The LSTM model is used to recognize temporal patterns. The model was trained using the Emotional Wearable Dataset 2020 video database due to the lack of a robust and available Arabic database for similar purposes. Frame preprocessing was performed to identify facial edges and enhance illumination to enhance images. The model achieved a high accuracy of 68.7% for accurate facial expression detection using the video database.

title: Blockchain-Based Authentication and Authorization Mechanisms for Secure EV Supply Chain Management
authors: Shubham Kumar, T NandhaKumar, Somesh Nandi, B Sathish Babu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This research paper addresses the challenges stakeholders face in the EV supply chain, including EV manufacturers, suppliers, distributors, and consumers. By integrating blockchain technology, the paper proposes solutions to mitigate risks such as identity fraud, data tampering, unauthorized access, and supply chain disruptions caused by counterfeit components or vehicles. A threat assessment model is developed to identify potential threats and their impacts, and the proposed solutions include robust authentication mechanisms, finegrained access controls through smart contracts, and data integrity measures. The paper also explores blockchain architecture, leveraging its decentralized and immutable nature to establish trust, transparency, and tamper resistance in the EV supply chain. The research enhances security and reliability, fostering trust, transparency, and efficiency within the EV industry for sustainable growth and development.

title: Stacked-Plate Heatsink Design for Effective Thermal Management of Power Semiconductor Modules
authors: Jiyoon Choi, Sihoon Choi, Jun Imaoka, Kazuhiro Umetani, Masayoshi Yamamoto
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Advances in power semiconductor devices and packaging technologies have increased power density in power conversion systems, making effective thermal management be critical. This study evaluates stacked-plate architecture against conventional pin-fin heatsinks using finite element method (FEM) simulations, in terms of cooling performance and pressure drop. Based on the findings, a novel stacked-plate heatsink structure for power semiconductor module is proposed that achieves higher cooling efficiency with low pressure drop, which addresses the traditional trade-off relationship in heatsink design.

title: From Voice to Efficiency: Natural Language Processing for Energy-Optimized Robot Programs
authors: Zeynep Sezen Osmanpasaoglu, Mustafa Caner Akuner
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Despite robotic automation is crucial for producing renewable energy technology, operational energy optimization is often overlooked as it typically requires expert intervention. This study proposes a hybrid architecture using natural language commands to optimize robot programs for either speed or energy efficiency. The framework integrates a Large Language Model (LLM) with an expert-defined Knowledge Base (KB) to create a verifiable optimization tool. Evaluated in a simulated pick-and-place task, the energy-prioritized program achieved a $42.1 \%$ reduction in total energy consumption with a $15.8 \%$ increase in process time compared to its speed-prioritized counterpart. These results confirm that significant energy savings, made accessible through natural language, can substantially reduce the carbon footprint of renewable energy production.

title: Enhanced Quadrotor Trajectory Tracking Using an Integral Sliding Mode Controller in Wind-Disturbed Environments
authors: Muhammad Majid Gulzar, Hassan Zia Ullah, Salman Habib, Noman Bashir, Ahlam Jameel
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial vehicles (UAVs) are massively used currently for different commercial and local applications like surveillance, searching, deliverance, etc. One of the main applications of UAVs is in the field of Intelligence Transportation System (ITS). For ITS, the actual path of the trajectory should be the same as the desired input for an appropriate location with respect to the desired trajectory. Moreover, it should be fast and robust with minimal overshoot and error between desired and actual path for the desired purpose of ITS. The kinematics of the quadrotor is highly unstable and it is an underactuated system with 6 Degrees of Freedom (DOF), whereas the movement of the quadrotor is dependent upon rotational and translational subsystems. In this paper, the trajectory of the quadrotor is tracked by using the Integral Sliding Mode Controller (ISMC) which is a modified form of the Sliding Mode Controller (SMC). The advantage of using ISMC control is the robustness, convergence, accuracy and the ability to operate under varying disturbance conditions. The integral action in ISMC compensates the phenomenon of chattering which exhibits in the conventional sliding mode controller and as a result, the trajectory becomes smooth with fast converging towards the desired point. Moreover, a comparison analysis is carried out by implementing different state-of-the-art controllers including Proportional Integral Derivative (PID), Backstepping and Sliding Mode Controller (SMC) in MATLAB.

title: Integrating Block Chain with IoT for Secure and Transparent Supply Chain Management in Sustainable Manufacturing
authors: Indra Kishor, Udit Mamodiya, Manmohan Sharma, Gireesh Kumar, Parul Goyal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Sustainable manufacturing needs secure, transparent, and real-time supply chain management systems that are compliant with environmental regulations. Traditional centralized systems are traceless, data-integrity-prone, and operationally manual, which is not suitable for dynamic and ESG-focused industrial environments. The aim of this work is to develop an integrated framework combining Blockchain and Internet of Things (IoT) to address key challenges in supply chain transparency, environmental control, and data protection for sustainable production processes. A multi-layer architecture was designed with calibrated IoT sensors (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex>, temperature, energy, GPS), secure MQTT communication, and a permissioned blockchain (Hyperledger Fabric). Smart contracts were leveraged to program ESG check automation with predefined thresholds: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}>450\ \text{ppm}$</tex>, energy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>1.2 \text{kWh} / \text{batch}$</tex>, and temperature deviation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$> \pm 3^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>. The system was tested on 850 simulated production batches within a 72 -hour period. The test system achieved a 95 % reduction in risks of data manipulation, an 87 % increase in traceability efficiency, and an 88.7 % success rate for ESG compliance. Smart contracts were applied, with a completion time of 310 ms, on a blockchain that produced 238 transactions per second, limiting node synchronization latencies to less than 1.2 seconds. Conformity certificates were issued in real-time automation, and non-conformities were securely recorded on the blockchain. The underlying infrastructure digitizes green manufacturing and allows for a decentralized, AI-supported future reality supply chain.

title: Analysis Method for Turn-off Oscillation Considering Turn-off Voltage
authors: Kota Okada, Sihoon Choi, Kazuhiro Umetani, Jun Imaoka, Masayoshi Yamamoto, Hironari Takase, Juman Yoon, Hiroki Nishi
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Wide-bandgap semiconductor devices enable highspeed switching but cause instability phenomena such as false turn-on and oscillation due to parasitic component effects. A negative voltage is applied to the gate during the off period to suppress these issues. This voltage is called turn-off voltage; however, conventional switching instability analysis methods do not consider the influence of turn-off voltage. This paper proposes an analytical method for turn-off instability focusing on turn-off voltage influence. Analysis was conducted on a double-pulse test circuit using the proposed method. The analysis clarifies the influence of the turn-off voltage on the circuit’s operating regions. These findings form the basis of a design guideline to reduce both circuit loss and cost.

title: Output Power Characteristics and Its Control Range of Star-Delta Connected Three-Phase SR-SAB DC-DC Converter
authors: Yu Sonohara, Kohei Budo, Wataru Kitagawa, Takaharu Takeshita
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This paper presents the output power characteristics and its control range of a three-phase secondaryresonant single-active-bridge DC-DC converter using a star-delta connection transformer. In the proposed circuit, the output power can be controlled over a wide range from rated output power to one-fifth times by varying the primary voltage frequency. In addition, the star-delta connection is suitable for input-to-output buck operation, making it suitable for fast battery chargers. The effectiveness of the proposed output power characteristics is verified by experiment using laboratory prototype.

title: Application of AI Algorithm for Improved Driving Comfort and Braking Control in Autonomous Vehicle
authors: Ranjit Vasant Rajale, Rohit Krishnan M, Md Abdullah Al Mamun, Koppuravuri Sri Lakshmi Sruthi, Hallis Nisar A, Vani Pradhan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Two essential components for passenger safety and ride quality, brake control and driving comfort, have been greatly improved by the incorporation of Artificial Intelligence (AI) algorithms into autonomous cars. In order to maximise these crucial elements, this study investigates cutting-edge AI-driven methodologies such as machine learning (ML). Real-time data from sensors, cameras, and LiDAR systems is processed by AI algorithms to forecast road conditions, identify obstructions, and estimate passenger and driver preferences. AI uses predictive control to modify steering, speed, and suspension for more comfortable driving. Adaptive AI algorithms in braking control minimise sudden stops and analyse dynamic traffic situations to guarantee precise braking. The system can further enhance itself through experience owing to reinforcement learning. Improved riding smoothness, less jerk, and safer, more effective braking reflexes are all provided by the suggested AI architecture. This report emphasises how AI is revolutionising autonomous driving technologies to increase comfort, safety, and trust.

title: Advanced Electrode Homogenization-Based Design of an Electrochemical Pseudo-2D Model for Fast Charging Li-ion Batteries
authors: Raymonda Diab, François Auger, Emmanuel Schaeffer, Philippe Poizot, Jean-François Cousseau
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Recharging Li-ion batteries in 10 to 15 minutes without compromising their durability and safety is one of the main challenges facing the wider adoption of electric vehicles. To address this issue, we have designed an original pseudo-2D model derived from the Doyle-Fuller-Newman electrochemical battery model. This model enables real-time monitoring of the negative electrode potential, ensuring maximal charging currents without the risk of lithium plating. By employing an electrode homogenization approach rather than the traditional spherical particle approximation and applying a nonuniform spatial discretization of the partial differential equations, a nonlinear statespace model was derived from the local electrochemical equations with minimal simplifying assumptions. Preliminary experimental tests were carried out using a 3-electrode assembly to calibrate and validate the model in the Matlab environment for charging rates up to 2C.

title: Research on Data Link System Security and Future Development Outlook
authors: Meng Wen, Nan Li, Jianhua Qin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Network Communication and Information Security (ICNCIS)
abstract: The multidimensional, high-intensity, and intelligent nature of future warfare imposes heightened demands on data link security and confidentiality systems. This paper comprehensively analyzes the security requirements and key technologies for future battlefield data link systems, drawing on an examination of major foreign data link security frameworks. It proposes a novel security framework tailored for future data link systems and explores the potential of emerging technologies—including artificial intelligence, blockchain, intrinsic security, zero trust, and software-defined networking to advance data link security. This work lays the foundation for addressing real-time information security challenges across multi-chain, cross-domain, and large-scale environments, providing technical support for unified, efficient information security management within distributed kill chains.

title: Real-Time Ransomware Detection and Response System Using Behavioural File and Process Monitoring
authors: Harishni L, Sowmyarani C N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The ability of ransomware to encrypt user data and interfere with essential services makes it one of the most prevalent and destructive cybersecurity threats. These assaults have become more sophisticated; some versions can now extract private data prior to encryption, which adds another level of extortion. According to Cisco's most recent Cyber Threat Trends Report, ransomware is still one of the most common dangers seen in DNS traffic.In the last year, there has been a tremendous spike in ransomware attacks that target healthcare facilities, with 154 million infections reported altogether, according to the research. The necessity of effective detection and response systems to counter these sophisticated threats is emphasized in the paper. The suggested approach, which is based on file and process behavior monitoring, offers a simple, real-time ransomware detection and response solution. In contrast to conventional signature-based techniques, the suggested approach makes use of dynamic signs like high entropy in altered files, frequent file renaming, suspicious file extensions (like.locked or.encrypted), and anomalies in processes (like svchost.exe running without authorization). The system continually monitors a specified directory, looks for code injection signatures in Portable Executable (PE) structures, detects rapid renaming patterns, and computes entropy levels to identify potentially encrypted data. A built-in quarantine module separates infected files, while an alert mechanism provides email messages and refreshes a live dashboard. In order to detect possible command-and-control (C2) activities, the system also incorporates outbound traffic monitoring. According to experimental data, the system can detect ransomware-like actions in real time with little system overhead.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Smart Vending Machine for Secure Medicine Management in Emergency Healthcare Units
authors: Muthu Lakshmi S, Malathy Sathyamoorthy, Karuppasamy M, Narenthar R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Critical hospital emergency units face challenges in terms of managing medicines efficiently, securely, and accurately. The usual manual methods for tracking the medicine inventory, checking the date of expiry, and correct dosages are likely to be error-prone and delayed, with possible security breaches. This paper proposes a blockchain-enabled smart vending machine designed specifically for safe and automated management of medicines in emergency healthcare environments. The proposed system integrates blockchain technology with an IoT-based vending machine, utilizing authentication for authorized access; automates mechanisms with consequent deadlines and expiry date verification, along with tamper-proof data storage. This system reduces the occurrence of human error, improves the inventory management system, and enhances security in dealing with such critical medicines.. (Abstract)

title: Optimization of Distribution Network Reconfiguration Using Archimedes Algorithm to Enhance FLISR Readiness at Sentul Substation
authors: Tribagja Manoptika, Mokhammad Setyonegoro
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: The distribution feeders of Sentul Substation supplying the industrial area have experienced multiple distribution network disturbances in recent years, causing extended outages and operational challenges. Self-healing technology such as FLISR (Fault Location, Isolation, and Service Restoration) is capable of accelerating fault recovery by automatically isolating faults and performing service restoration. However, the successful implementation of FLISR requires the availability of sufficient spare capacity in backup feeders and their corresponding substation transformers. This study proposes a pre-fault optimization method for distribution network reconfiguration using Modified Archimedes Optimization Algorithm (AOA) to determine an optimal switching configuration that minimizes total power losses while ensuring sufficient backfeed capacity to implement FLISR operation. This study developed a model based on available network data from distribution feeders at Sentul Substation and performed simulations under selected fault scenarios. Simulation results show that the proposed modified AOA-based reconfiguration reduced total power losses by 41.7%, relieved transformer overloads from 95.5% to 83.16%, improved the minimum bus voltage from 0.9474 p.u. to 0.9603 p.u., and increased spare restoration capacity from 8.23 MW to 14.25 MW. These results highlight the main contribution of this study: a modified AOA-based reconfiguration model that improves smart grid resilience and supports FLISR deployment.

title: PUFchain: Secure IoHT Authentication via PUFs, ZKPs, and Blockchain
authors: Vincent Duronio, Mohamed Firas Aguir, Hari Sai Kaja, Andrew Kalafut, Mostafa El-Said, Samah Mansour
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: The Internet of Health Things (IoHT) introduces new opportunities for remote patient monitoring but also exposes sensitive medical data to serious security risks. Traditional authentication mechanisms are often too resource-intensive for IoHT devices, which are constrained in terms of storage, computation, and energy. This paper presents a lightweight, decentralized authentication protocol tailored for IoHT environments, integrating blockchain technology, Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs), and zero-knowledge proofs (zk-SNARKs). Our protocol employs the Proof of Elapsed Work and Luck (PoEWAL) consensus mechanism, enabling secure, energy-efficient participation in a private Hyperledger Fabric blockchain. The scheme ensures strong mutual authentication between healthcare providers and IoHT devices without exposing sensitive data. An informal analysis is done to demonstrate the protocol’s resilience against common attacks. This protocol offers a secure solution for enabling trustworthy healthcare communication in resource-limited IoHT networks.

title: High-Penetration of Wind Farm in Transmission Expansion Planning
authors: Nomihla W Ndlela, Katleho Moloi, Musasa Kabeya
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: In response to the escalating energy issues and environmental degradation, the use of renewable energies (RE) is garnering greater attention. Incorporating high-penetration wind farms into the electrical system offers substantial benefits with intricate problems. As global energy demands transition to renewable energy sources (RES), wind energy is essential for mitigating carbon emissions and promoting sustainable development. However, its intermittent characteristics and fluctuations present risks to grid stability, necessitating creative methods for smooth integration. This study designs and simulates a wind farm to demonstrate its integration into the grid network, accounting for variable power generation due to weather conditions. It also records all necessary calculations, including losses, energy, and profit, utilizing appropriate methodologies. Furthermore, it employs available transfer capability to illustrate the power that can be transmitted to the rest of the network as generation fluctuates to expand transmission lines effectively.

title: SQL Injection Detection, Prevention and Deception Using ML Classifiers
authors: Lakshmi M R, Shalini S, Chethan S, C Dharshan, Gandrajupalli Naga Koushik, Adarsh Bhaskar Shetty
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: SQL injection (SQLi) attacks are arguably the most prevalent and destructive security attacks against web applications currently in use. SQLi attacks allow malicious users to exploit input validation vulnerabilities, thus granting unauthorized database access, data exfiltration, and even complete system compromise. To address this critical issue, this paper proposes a combined framework that employs machine learning techniques along with secure coding practices for the prevention, detection, and mitigation of SQL injection attacks. A Naïve Bayes classifier identifies anomaly-based SQLi attacks by monitoring HTTP requests for anomaly-based signatures that indicate the existence of evil SQL code. This machine learning-based detection system learns to evolve with new and changing attack vectors and gets better with time. In addition to detection, preventive measures such as prepared statement usage, input validation, and real escape string functions are employed to clean user input and eliminate injection points. Moreover, the system also includes a deception system, which leads the attackers to a decoy or imaginary database, so there can be ongoing observation of malicious activity without any loss of actual assets. This not only helps with threat analysis but also serves as a deterrent. The integration of proactive defense, reactive detection, and strategic deception greatly improves web application security. The system as presented shows strong immunity to both currently known and as-yet unknown SQL injection attacks, and thus it is a complete solution to one of the most vexing problems on web application security. [2].

title: Market-Based Strategies for Enhancing Grid Resilience under High Renewable Penetration
authors: Syed Mohammad Ghouse, E Nagaraju, Om Prakash, Ismail Zabiullah, Anil B Gowda, Mohammed Ismail Sharief
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The rise in penetration of renewable energy sources (RES), especially wind and solar, presents important challenges to power system operation and electricity markets. Renewables cut emissions and are cheaper in the long run but are intermittent, creating volatility, uncertainty about revenues, and reliability risks. This study analyses the performance of markets in delivering resilience to the grid given high levels of renewables. A grid simulation over 24 hours was then developed in order to study four aspects of the problem; (i) Stability of revenues for the generators, (ii) Reduction in the cost of imbalances as a result of flexibility, (iii) Reliability in terms of Loss of Load Expectation (LOLE), and Energy Not Served (ENS), and (iv) the impact on costs for consumers. Findings show that flexibility participation reduces costs incurred due to imbalance by $\sim 60 \%$, and resilience mechanisms reduce the effective tariff faced by consumers from ₹32/kWh to ₹6.8/kWh. Reliability indices also improve greatly when flexibility and ancillary services markets are introduced. In addition, a Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) model was applied to find the optimum levels of renewable penetration and flexibility that result in the least total system cost, which correspond to approximately 0.7 for flexibility and approximately $\mathbf{5 5 - 6 5 \%}$ for renewables. These results point to the economic and technical need for reengineered electricity markets that incorporate flexibility products, ancillary services, and resilience incentives. This dissertation provides a complete methodology of simulation, reliability metrics, and optimization to inform policy makers, system operators, and investors of resilient renewable dominated grids.

title: Designing a SparkLink-enabled Wireless Peripheral System to Achieve Ultra Low-Latency Interaction
authors: Yihe Wang, Zhe Zhang, Xiaojun Hei
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Wireless peripherals have been widely used in high real-time scenarios, while the limitations of traditional Bluetooth technology in latency, power consumption, and anti-interference performance are becoming increasingly prominent. In this paper, we propose a SparkLink-enabled wireless keyboard and mouse system, which constructs a wireless communication architecture with ultra-low latency and high reliability based on the HiSilicon BS21 chip integrating the SparkLink Low Energy (SLE) protocol and the Polar codes. This system applies the modular hardware design combined with event-driven software optimization strategies, achieving collaborative acceleration of hardware interrupt response and protocol stack processing. We implemented this system and conducted evaluation experiments. Our preliminary experiment results demonstrate various performance advantages in input response speed, trajectory sampling accuracy, and multi-device coordination, making it particularly suitable for demanding real-time applications such as e-sports and industrial control. Experimental results also show that the system can meet sub-millisecond latency transmission requirements while maintaining extremely low power consumption.

title: A Review of Zero Trust Architecture Security Research
authors: Tianyu Zhang, Lyuyi Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Network Communication and Information Security (ICNCIS)
abstract: With the popularization of technologies such as cloud computing and mobile office, enterprise network structures are becoming increasingly complex, and traditional network security models based on boundary protection are no longer able to meet current needs. Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA), as an emerging network security model, does not distinguish between internal and external networks. All entities accessing resources require authentication and authorization, which can effectively address the challenges brought by boundary blurring [1–3]. ZTA, as an emerging paradigm of network security, adheres to the core principle of “never trust, always verify”, abandons the traditional mode of distinguishing between internal and external networks, and requires all access requests to undergo strict identity authentication and authorization[4]. This article first introduces the background, definition, and development process of ZTA, and elaborates on its process from initial theoretical proposal to gradual implementation and practice. Then, a detailed analysis was conducted on the general architecture model of ZTA, including core technical components such as identity authentication, access control, and trust evaluation. At the same time, the application practice of ZTA in typical scenarios such as enterprise environment, cloud services, and the Internet of Things was explored, demonstrating its flexible adaptability in different business scenarios[5]. Finally, the future development trend of ZTA is discussed, and it is pointed out that it will continue to evolve in terms of deep integration with traditional security protection concepts, enhancing its own security and elastic service capabilities.

title: Scalable Strategies for Supply Chain Technology Adoption
authors: Tejaswini Kumar, Sharath Babu Chikkamma Govinda, Naveen Saikrishna Puppala, Sridhar Dachepelly, Ajay Kumar Yadav
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: In this review, the author analyses the effects of digitization on the supply chain because of the emerging technologies of AI, blockchain, IoT, and cloud computing that provide more visibility, automation, and data-driven decision-making. Despite the apparent benefits, the vast majority of the businesses do not manage to transform pilot projects into general use due to the existence of legacy systems, scarcity of resources, the lack of alignment within organizations, and the incompleteness of digital ecosystems. The paper identifies technology preparedness, organization fit and collaboration within the ecosystem to be important keys of successful digital transformation. It gives cross-industry examples of why strategic and industry-specific strategies are needed and gives gaps in research on change management, integration of partners, and scalability diagnostics, giving some future directions on how to best use digital in global supply chains.

title: A Comparative Evaluation of Speech Separation Models on Multi-Speaker Child Speech Recordings
authors: Phie Chyan, Heni Gerda Pesau, Norbertus Tri Suswanto Saptadi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: The task of separating overlapping sounds, known as the cocktail party problem, becomes even more challenging when applied to children's voices, which have higher acoustic variability and spontaneous articulation. While deep learning-based models such as Conv-TasNet, DCCRN, DPRNN, and SepFormer have demonstrated strong performance on adult voice data, their robustness to children's voices remains rarely explored. In this study, we present a comparative evaluation of four speech separation models using a specialised dataset constructed from overlapping recordings of elementary school children speaking. These models were pre-trained using the LibriMix dataset with noise from WHAM! and then fine-tuned on synthesised child voice mixes. Evaluations were conducted using real classroom recordings involving two to five simultaneous speakers. The SI-SNRi metric was used as the primary measure, complemented by qualitative analysis using spectrograms and waveforms. Our results show that SepFormer consistently outperforms the other models, achieving up to 14.1 dB SI-SNRi with two speakers and maintaining 9.4 dB with five speakers, followed by DPRNN (13.2–8.5 dB). Conv-TasNet and DCCRN performed lower, particularly under heavy overlap. Qualitative observations confirm that the transformer-based architecture provides better harmonic reconstruction capabilities and temporal accuracy in the context of child speech. These findings emphasise the importance of long-term modelling for speech separation tasks in educational settings and real-world applications for children.

title: AI-Driven ERP Modernization in Cloud-Native Systems
authors: Sharath Babu Chikkamma Govinda, Mukesh Garg, Prakash Subramani, Munis Kurbonov, Mirjalol Ismoilov Ruziboy Ugli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: As businesses shift to agility, data-driven decision-making, and scalability, the monolithic ERP solution is no longer suitable to address the requirements of digital transformation. This paper explains how AI may be applied to bring ERP back to life in cloud-native ecosystems. It discusses how smart automation, predictive analytics, and natural language interfaces will help to make ERP a real-time decision-making system. The paper proposes AI streamlined, container based microservices systems that may be deployed on a public cloud, a personal cloud or a hybrid cloud. Business process intelligence, resource forecasting, user personalization and anomaly detection are the most significant ones. These kinds of issues such as the data governance, the complexity of migrations, integration, and security are overcome. The article gives the strategic roadmap of the AI-enhanced ERP systems and demonstrates how they will be able to greatly improve operational efficacy, scalability, and responsiveness in the digital era.

title: Adaptive Differential Evolution Algorithm with Improved Exponential Crossover Based on a Leader–Follower Model
authors: Huanhuan Wu, Xiaobo Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Since its introduction, the Differential Evolution (DE) algorithm has attracted considerable attention from researchers worldwide due to its simple structure, ease of implementation, and remarkable performance in continuous optimization problems. In the existing literature, DE algorithms typically employ two types of crossover: exponential and binomial. To address the limitations of exponential crossover, this paper proposes an enhanced approach that replaces the traditional crossover probability CR with crossover length L. This modification helps maintain an appropriate crossover ratio during the evolutionary process, thereby improving both the stability and performance of the algorithm. Building on this foundation, we further propose an adaptive DE algorithm that integrates the improved exponential crossover with a leader-based framework, namely DLADE. In each generation, the population is divided into leader and regular subpopulations. The leader subpopulation adopts three distinct mutation strategies to strengthen exploration, preserve population diversity, and mitigate premature convergence. Meanwhile, collaboration between leader and regular subpopulations is achieved through information exchange and sharing, effectively balancing global exploration and local exploitation. Experimental evaluations on the CEC 2017 benchmark functions demonstrate that the proposed algorithm consistently outperforms several representative adaptive DE variants, highlighting its superior performance and promising application potential.

title: Aerodynamic Wing Optimization Using Deep Reinforcement Learning: A Comparative Study of PPO and DQN
authors: Ashok R, Tarun Prabash P, Tushar Mongia, Y. Sailaja
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Despite ongoing progress in the aerospace industry with the goal of improving the design of aircraft, traditional wing design processes are limited by computational and conceptual constraints making them inefficient for large design spaces or multi objective optimization. This paper proposes a novel Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) framework for aerodynamic wing optimization. We compare two of the most popular DRL algorithms, Deep Q-Network (DQN) and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), within a multi-fidelity setup combining fast Python-based surrogates an high fidelity Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) simulations using ANSYS Fluent. The optimization objectives, e.g., lift-to-drag ratio, fuel economy, and structural weight constraint, are integrated into the multi-fidelity reward function. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) based architecture bridges aerodynamic geometry and performance space. The findings show that PPO outperforms DQN in continuous design space. The findings show that PPO performs better in a continuous design space, leading to an improvement in aerodynamic performance. This paper is interested in the technical feasibility of employing DRL and the significant improvement achievable with its use, specifically in aircraft wing shape optimization where DRL can autonomously find highly efficient aerodynamic configurations.

title: A Multi-Layered Security Concept Model for SDN-Enabled Smart Grids
authors: Seref Sagiroglu, Murat Dener, M. Sedef Demirci, Ali Kara, Yilmaz Atay, Mehmet Demirci, Samed Al, Selcuk Yilmaz
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Smart grids integrate advanced communication and control technologies to improve efficiency and reliability of power delivery, but their interconnected nature exposes new cybersecurity vulnerabilities. Recent attacks ranging from malware to false data injection have demonstrated the need for robust, multi-layered defenses spanning physical devices, network infrastructure, control systems, and applications. SoftwareDefined Networking (SDN) offers centralized, programmable control over grid communications to dynamically isolate threats and reroute traffic during attacks. However, securing SDNenabled smart grids requires a defense-in-depth approach that combines diverse emerging technologies. This paper proposes a multi-layered security concept model leveraging blockchain for data integrity, explainable AI for transparent decision-making, generative AI for adaptive threat detection, quantum-safe cryptography for future resilience, big data analytics for anomaly detection, and radio frequency fingerprinting for device authentication. We present our model and discuss how each layer and technology contributes to a cohesive security architecture. We also identify open research challenges for integrating these solutions seamlessly to move towards the secure grids of the future.

title: Analysis of Rectangular Patch Antenna for Millimeter Wave Application Using Different Feed Methods
authors: Somesh Kumar Malhotra, Ashok Kumar Shankhwar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The current demands of high-speed systems, large bandwidth, and compactness are leading to the augmented utilization of the millimeter wave in communication systems. This study investigates the efficiency and performance of a microstrip rectangular patch antenna for different feed methods at 28.00 GHz, focusing on reflection loss, Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR), and directivity. Three feeding techniques were tested, including line feed, aperture coupling feed, and coaxial feed. The findings suggest that the line feed is the most efficient overall, the aperture feed excels in directivity, and the coaxial feed demonstrates moderate directivity but lower efficiency. These insights guide selecting the optimal feeding technique based on specific application requirements. Rogers/RT5880, which has a permittivity of 2.2, is one of the most commonly used materials for high-frequency broadband applications and was used for simulation. The High-Frequency Structure Simulator (HFSS) software analyzed the simulated results and antenna geometry.

title: Real-Time Biomechanical Posture Analysis and Avatar-Based Visualization Using Dual-Camera Pose Estimation
authors: Nazar Abbas, Woei-Nan Bairame, Anwar Elhadad
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: This project presents a novel, cost-effective system for real-time posture and leaning angle analysis using dual-camera pose estimation and avatar-based visualization. Leveraging front and side camera views, the system accurately captures critical biomechanical metrics, including torso and knee leaning angles, as well as lateral body tilt. Unlike traditional medical equipment, which is often expensive and intrusive, this solution utilizes affordable camera hardware and open-source tools to deliver high-resolution, real-time feedback. This approach not only democratizes access to posture assessment tools but also enhances remote diagnostics and rehabilitation by providing clinicians with accurate, real-time visualizations of patient movement. The integration of machine learning, computer vision, and 3D animation offers a scalable and secure alternative to conventional motion analysis systems.

title: Intelligent Cloud Deployment via GNNs
authors: Akash Potti, Nishaant N. U, Sharan Reddy, Dhanya Bharadwaj, Asha Rani K. P, Gowrishankar S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The rapid expansion of cloud computing has catalyzed an increasing demand for robust Infrastructure as Code (IaC) tools capable of facilitating automated deployment management. The traditional manual configuration of YAML/JSON within conventional IaC tools is time-consuming and elevates the risk of errors. This research introduces an innovative framework that integrates natural language processing (NLP) in conjunction with graph neural networks (GNNs) to automate the generation of Infrastructure as Code (IaC). Ollama Llama3 converts user prompts into structured components, which are subsequently transformed into a graph representing cloud service dependencies. A graph neural network constructed using PyTorch analyzes this graph to generate optimized YAML configurations that conform to cloud best practices. The system achieves an impressive 92% edge prediction accuracy over synthetic datasets while concurrently reducing deployment time when compared to manual methodologies. Furthermore, this system supports DevOps automation, optimizes costs, and effectively manages multi-cloud environments. This research bridges user requirements with IaC execution, rendering cloud resource management attainable for non-expert users. The approach demonstrated significant reduction in YAML configuration generation time, processing requests in around 15-20 seconds.

title: Energy Efficient Beamforming Techniques for 5G MIMO Systems
authors: Nikhil G K, P N Jayanthi, Ramavenkateswaran. N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The increasing demand for energy-efficient wireless communication has propelled research into advanced beamforming algorithms suitable for 5G MIMO systems. This study presents a comprehensive simulation-based evaluation of three beamforming techniques: Least Mean Squares (LMS), Minimum Variance Distortionless Response (MVDR), and Analog Beamforming. The performance is assessed in terms of energy efficiency (measured in bits/Joule), directional gain, and beamformed signal characteristics under varying signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions using a uniform linear array (ULA) antenna configuration. Results demonstrate that the LMS algorithm consistently yields superior energy efficiency compared to the other methods. Specifically, at an SNR of 20 dB, LMS achieves an energy efficiency of approximately 12.6 bits/Joule, outperforming MVDR (10.4 bits/Joule) by 21.15% and Analog Beamforming (11.2 bits/Joule) by 12.5%. These improvements indicate that LMS is particularly well-suited for energy-constrained 5G environments, balancing low computational complexity with robust signal enhancement. The study highlights the trade-offs inherent in each technique and provides valuable insights into the selection of beamforming strategies for next-generation wireless systems.

title: Expression of Concern for: Autism Spectrum Disorder Classification via Local and Global Feature Representation of Facial Image
authors: Md. Nadim Mahamood, Md. Zasim Uddin, Md. Arif Shahriar, Fady Alnajjar, Md Atiqur Rahman Ahad
publish: 2023 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder that affects social communication and interaction. Early diagnosis of ASD can mitigate the severity and help with ideal treatment direction. Computer vision-based methods with traditional machine learning and deep learning are employed in the literature for automatic diagnosis. Recently, deep learning with a facial image-based ASD classification has gained interest due to its ease of collection and non-invasiveness. We observed that the existing approaches utilized either local or global features of facial images to diagnose ASD. However, its important to consider both local and global features to obtain fine-grained details and larger contextual information for accurate detection and classification. This paper proposes a sequencer-based patch-wise Local Feature Extractor along with a Global Feature Extractor. Finally, the features from these modules are aggregated to obtain the final feature for the classification of ASD. Experiments on a publicly available Autism Facial Image Dataset demonstrate that our proposed framework achieves state-of-the-art performance. We achieved accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score of 94.7%, 94.0%, 95.3%, and 94.6%, respectively.

title: Expression of Concern for: Enhancing Autism Detection Through Visual Pattern Analysis Based On Machine Learning
authors: Ari Kusumaningsih, Medika Risnasari, Koko Joni, Kurniawan Eka Permana, Cucun Very Angkoso
publish: 2023 International Conference on Advanced Mechatronics, Intelligent Manufacture and Industrial Automation (ICAMIMIA)
abstract: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder that may be discovered at a young age by analyzing the visual patterns of children's faces, which, unfortunately, requires the expertise of professionals. SVM is a powerful machine-learning technique that can be used in classification tasks, including autism identification. Our study investigates machine learning methods based on Support Vector Machine (SVM) techniques and the effectiveness of using the green channel for early identification of autism through facial visual patterns in children to help automatically diagnose ASD. Our study employs a different feature extraction approach based on the Gray-Level Co-occurrence Matrix to lower the dimensionality of features. Finally, we evaluated different SVM kernels, such as linear, radial basis function (RBF), and polynomial kernels, to evaluate system effectiveness in identifying visual patterns indicative of ASD. The RBF kernel produces the best performance of 0.73, and using the green channel can increase system performance by 3.51%.

title: Fast FPGA Accelerator of Graph Cut Algorithm based on Cached Folding Grid Architecture
authors: Guangyao Yan, Rui Li, Shen Zhang, Hao Sun, Weixiong Jiang, Hui Wang, Yajun Ha
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Graph cut algorithms are widely used to solve min-cut/max-flow problems across various optimization applications. A common approach in recent FPGA accelerators of graph cut algorithms is to store the entire graph data in on-chip memory, thereby facilitating parallel computation. While effective for small graphs, this approach fundamentally limits scalability and prevents the processing of large-scale graphs. To address this limitation, first, we propose a cached folding grid architecture that dynamically manages graph data between on-chip and off-chip memories for large-scale graph processing. Second, to reduce redundant off-chip data movement, we develop an algorithm-specific selective fetching strategy that fetches only the necessary data of graph cut algorithms. Third, we introduce a selective traversal technique designed to reduce the execution time of the re-height operation by skipping invalid data. Compared to state-of-the-art FPGA accelerators, which are restricted to processing graphs with up to 2 million nodes, our design significantly improves scalability and can handle graphs with over 8 million nodes using the same on-chip memory. Moreover, our proposed accelerator achieves a 2.9× and 2.0× speedup compared to the fastest CPU and GPU implementations, respectively.

title: Adversarial Perturbations Maximization in Online Social Networks
authors: Dongyu Mao, Weili Wu, Ding-Zhu Du
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: Seeding conflict in online society is a public issue obtaining increasing attention. In this paper, we take a step to study the problem of maximizing conflict in online social networks from the adversarial perspective. More specifically, we combine the widely used stochastic information propagation model and opinion dynamics model to jointly model the processes of adversarial content propagation and opinion evolution through peer pressure on social networks, based on which we define the adversarial perturbations maximization (APM) problem. The APM problem focuses on two popular network conflict measures, disagreement and polarization. Our analysis begins by showing the complex nature of the APM problem. We show that by decomposing the objective into a subtraction of two set functions, an upper bound of the objective which is essentially a difference of two submodular (DS) functions can be devised. Then inspired by the success of modular-modular procedure and reverse influence sampling technique in related optimization tasks, we build a two-level approximation framework to maximize the upper bound heuristically with a data-dependent guarantee and further strengthen the approximation result using the sandwich approximation framework. Also, we apply dimension reduction technique to design a faster naïve greedy algorithm for the objective. Experiments show both the seriousness of this problem and the performance of our proposed algorithms.

title: Harmonic Suppression Strategy for PMSM Based on Multiple Synchronous Rotating Frame Transformations and Model Predictive Control
authors: Zhiyong Lan, Liyu Zhang, Bin Hu, Jinwei Wu, Yuhang Wu, Hongbiao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article aims to solve the problem of current harmonics in permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM), primarily caused by inverter nonlinearities and dead-time effects. A better harmonic suppression strategy is proposed, which uses multiple synchronous rotating frame transformations (MSRFTs) with model predictive current control (MPCC). First, mathematical models for the dominant 5th and 7th harmonic components are established. Second, the MSRFTs change these harmonic components into dc quantities within their respective frames. Low-pass filters (LPFs) are employed to extract the harmonic currents respectively. The MPCC algorithm generates compensating voltages based on the extracted harmonics, which are injected into the stationary reference frame to achieve effective harmonic suppression. Meanwhile, a complex vector decoupling strategy is adopted to eliminate the d–q axis cross-coupling in the fundamental current control loop, for enhancing the parameters robustness. Simulation and experimental results demonstrated that the method mentioned above significantly reduced the total harmonic distortion (THD) of the phase current over a wide speed range. Furthermore, it’s better than the conventional MSRFTs combined with proportional-integral (PI) control method. This approach exhibits superior harmonic suppression capability and dynamic response performance.

title: Alzheimer’s Disease Diagnosis Based on Derivative Dynamic Time Warping Functional Connectivity Networks
authors: Xin Hong, Yongze Lin, Zhenghao Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging
abstract: Due to the dynamic changes and complex time-delay characteristics of signal transmission between brain regions, this information can help identify early signs in individuals with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). Conventional Functional Connectivity Networks (FCN) may overlook interaction delays, leading to inaccurate representations of activity between brain regions. Recognizing the varying delays between patients and healthy individuals, we constructed a dynamic FCN using a Sliding Window based on Derivative Regularity Correlation (SWDRC) and a Functional Delay Network (FDN). These methods aim to improve the detection and analysis of brain networks through the Correlation-based Derivative Regularity (CDR) algorithm. The key advancement of this study is the CDR algorithm, which enables nonlinear time series alignment, unlike traditional correlation methods. This improvement allows for the analysis of asynchronous and nonlinear features in brain activity. Using CDR, SWDRC identifies local and asynchronous characteristics via a sliding window, while FDN quantifies measurable delays between brain regions in both healthy subjects and patients. Our methods show strong potential for revealing the mechanisms underlying neurodegenerative conditions. In classification experiments, combining complementary features from SWDRC and FDN achieved higher accuracy, effectively extracting disease-related patterns. FDN analysis of ADNI data indicates an increasing network delay from Healthy Control to Mild Cognitive Impairment to AD. Our code and models are available at https://github.com/hxpotato/SWDRC.

title: DNN-based HRIRs Identification with a Continuously Rotating Speaker Array
authors: Byeong-Yun Ko, Deokki Min, Hyeonuk Nam, Yong-Hwa Park
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Conventional static measurement of head-related impulse responses (HRIRs) is time-consuming due to the need for repositioning a speaker array for each azimuth angle. Dynamic approaches using analytical models with a continuously rotating speaker array have been proposed, but their accuracy is significantly reduced at high rotational speeds. To address this limitation, we propose a DNN-based HRIRs identification using sequence-to-sequence learning. The proposed DNN model incorporates fully connected (FC) networks to effectively capture HRIR transitions and includes reset and update gates to identify HRIRs over a whole sequence. The model updates the HRIRs vector coefficients based on the gradient of the instantaneous square error (ISE). Additionally, we introduce a learnable normalization process based on the speaker excitation signals to stabilize the gradient scale of ISE across time. A training scheme, referred to as whole-sequence updating and optimization scheme, is also introduced to prevent overfitting. We evaluated the proposed method through simulations and experiments. Simulation results using the FABIAN database show that the proposed method outperforms previous analytic models, achieving over 7 dB improvement in normalized misalignment (NM) and maintaining log spectral distortion (LSD) below 2 dB at a rotational speed of 45°/s. Experimental results with a custom-built speaker array confirm that the proposed method successfully preserved accurate sound localization cues, consistent with those from static measurement. Source code is available at https://github.com/byko0810/DNN-based-HRIRs-identification.

title: A Broadband Spherical Quadrifilar Helical Antenna for Intelligent Marine Propulsion System Applications
authors: Zi-Yu Pang, Guan-Long Huang, Jun-Xiao Liu, Kam-Weng Tam, Geng-Bo Wu, Chow-Yen-Desmond Sim, Yiannis Vardaxoglou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents a novel broadband spherical quadrifilar helical antenna (SQHA) to address the challenges of multi-system and multi-band compatibility in automatic satellite navigation and positioning for intelligent marine propulsion system applications. The proposed antenna comprises conformal radiating arms, a spherical polylactic acid (PLA) shell, and a broadband feed network. In contrast to conventional QHAs with identical radiating arms, the radiating arm in this design incorporates four sphere-conformal helical segments with unequal widths, which significantly enhance impedance matching and broaden the operational bandwidth. Furthermore, the designed feed network delivers equal-amplitude excitation signals with a 90° phase difference across a wide frequency range, thereby ensuring stable and high-quality circular polarization. To validate the design, an antenna prototype is fabricated and measured. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed antenna achieves a wide impedance bandwidth of 87.3% (0.745–1.90 GHz) and a wide 3-dB axial ratio (AR) bandwidth of 82.7% (0.73–1.76 GHz), with a maximum gain of 5.5 dBic. The design exhibits excellent impedance and AR bandwidths, high gain, and robust conformal adaptability, offering a promising solution for enhancing the navigation accuracy and communication reliability of intelligent marine propulsion systems in dynamic marine environments.

title: Hybrid Noise Rectified Flow for Industrial Time Series Generation with Conditional Priors and Bimodal Adaptive Sampling
authors: Jun Li, Bo Liu, Pengcheng Xia, Yiyang Ni, Yuwen Qian, Shi Jin
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Industrial time series often display complex, non-stationary behaviors with trends, periodicity, and abrupt fluctuations. Generating high-quality synthetic data in such domains is essential for simulation, forecasting, and anomaly detection in Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) applications. However, distributional heterogeneity, sparse failure patterns, and long-term dependencies make this task highly challenging. We introduce HNRF-TS, a rectified flow framework with hybrid noise initialization, designed for scalable and robust time series generation. The hybrid prior combines isotropic Gaussian noise with structured codes from a lightweight generative adversarial network (GAN), yielding semantically aligned and diverse latent representations. To improve sampling efficiency, we propose a bimodal adaptive strategy that allocates denser ordinary differential equation (ODE) steps at the beginning and end of the trajectory while using coarser steps in smoother middle regions. This preserves critical temporal features while lowering computational cost. We further enhance fidelity with modules dedicated to modeling trends and seasonality, which capture global drifts and periodic signals inherent in industrial data. Across multiple IIoT datasets, HNRF-TS outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, including GAN-based and diffusion-based methods. It achieves up to 75.8% reduction in Context-FID and over 60% improvement in correlation metrics on long-horizon tasks. Moreover, high-quality samples can be generated with as few as 20 sampling steps, offering significant efficiency gains without sacrificing accuracy.

title: Black-Box Optimization of the Storage Location Assignment Problem in Logistics Centers Using an Annealing Algorithm
authors: Hiromitsu Kigure, Takeshi Baba, Makoto Taniguchi, Hirotaka Kaji
publish: IEEE Transactions on Quantum Engineering
abstract: The manufacturing industry encounters numerous optimization problems, one of which is the optimization of storage location assignment (OSLA) problem in logistics. OSLA is a combinatorial optimization problem focused on improving the efficiency of picking operations in logistics centers. We explore quantum annealing (QA) as a potential solution to combinatorial optimization problems and investigate its applicability to the OSLA. The objective function for this optimization is the average travel distance of workers to their assigned destinations. However, this value is derived by solving the Traveling Salesman Problem for multiple orders, which is itself a combinatorial optimization problem. Therefore, it cannot be analytically represented in a quadratic unconstrained binary optimization form. To address this limitation, we employed black-box optimization with annealing (BBO-Annealing), which combines a surrogate model with an annealing algorithm, an approach that has recently gained attention in applied research involving QA. To evaluate the effectiveness of quantum computing, we compared results obtained using simulated annealing (SA) with those obtained using QA. Additionally, to assess the optimization performance of our proposed method, we compared it with a genetic algorithm (GA) that did not utilize a surrogate model of the objective function. QA demonstrated a higher probability of finding the optimal solution (33.3% vs 26.7% with SA). However, the optimization performance of GA surpassed that of the proposed method. Our analysis suggests that the relatively lower performance of our method was primarily attributable to the strong influence of constraints. The optimization performance can be improved by incorporating methods that consider the uncertainty of surrogate model predictions such as the lower confidence bound.
