title: Design and Implementation of Multi-Parameter Weighted Scheduling Circuit Based on DTN Mechanism in Ad Hoc Networks
authors: Rongjian Li, Lufeng Qiao, Zhanyou Du, Xue Qin, Jinxu Wang, Qinghua Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Network Communication and Information Security (ICNCIS)
abstract: A multi-parameter weighted scheduling algorithm that applies Delay-Tolerant Networks (DTN) technology to Ad Hoc networks has been designed, and the key circuit has been implemented. This algorithm can calculate the forwarding weights and screen the messages to be sent based on five-dimensional parameters, including DTN message priority, remaining lifespan, local waiting time, number of forwarding hops, and routing type, in a full-hardware manner. The forwarding weight values of all parameters can be configured by the upper-layer software according to different network states. When there is a direct route to the destination node for the message to be sent, the message is forwarded according to the route; when there is no direct route to the destination node, the Multi-Path Cooperative Transmission (MPCT) mode is supported for forwarding. The entire design is coded in Verilog HDL, implemented on the Xilinx xc7z100ffg900 - 2 FPGA platform, and simulated and analyzed using ModelSim SE - 64 10.6d, which verifies the correctness of the multi-parameter weighted scheduling algorithm and the circuit design.

title: Curriculum Learning in Cyber-Physical Systems: Anomaly Detection Using Digital Twins
authors: Ram Reddy Jonnalagadda, Kiran Kumar Reddy Kalam, Kiruthika S, Buddaraju Manojna, Kannan Kunnathully, Haider Ali Rizvi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Cyber-physical Systems (CPSs) are crucial to achieving the goals of Industry 4.0. Numerous CPSs, including smart cities, self-driving cars, and water treatment facilities, are developing rapidly as a result of extensive research from both academia and business, as well as advancements in hardware and software. CPSs are now exposed to a variety of dangers since they have developed into complex, diverse, and integrated systems that offer broad functionality. Both academics and professionals must create new methods for CPSs because most conventional approaches become outdated when faced with new threats. To achieve this, we offer viewpoints on several topics related to the development of digital twins to feed CPSs, where the basic models can be utilized to boost the utility of the abilities they offer, increase the productivity of the digital twin creation process, and serve as a particular, fine-adjustedbasis framework that functions as a physical digital twins.

title: A Conceptual Framework to Assess and Mitigate Cyber Threats Through Anonymization and Risk Modelling
authors: Priyamvada Saxena, Raghavendra Sharma
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: As the automotive industry is using Advanced Driver Assistance System (ADAS) systems in their vehicles it is important to ensure the safety of the driver and built reliability in intelligent transport systems. However, as we are providing more comfort to users there are increasing cyber threats in vehicle, especially advanced persistent dangers (APTs), that can cause a great issue in the safety of the user. This paper proposes a structure to assess the severity, likelihood and impact of various attacks on the communication systems. This paper also provides an anonymization-based mitigation strategy to reduce the risk of APT.

title: AI-Driven Priority-Based Predictive Maintenance of Automotive Systems
authors: Manojith Bhat V, Aneesh Sai Grandhi, Aditya Ravi, Ganesh N Naik, Sujay Arun Kudtarkar, Anala M R
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The application of artificial intelligence (AI) has become very important in the rapidly evolving automotive sector for improving vehicle maintenance plans. The paper presents an AI-driven, priority-based predictive maintenance system designed to improve service schedules by classifying vehicle failures and providing guided troubleshooting. The system utilizes a Light Gradient Boosting (LightGBM) model to perform multiclass classification on data collected from OnBoard Diagnostics (OBD). The model predicts one of four states: Heat Dissipation Failure, Overstrain Failure, Power Failure, or No Failure. The system also integrates a Large Language Model (LLM) with a Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) framework that uses the model's predicted failure type as a query to the vehicle's technical manual, generating contextually relevant troubleshooting steps and providing actionable guidance for maintenance personnel. The classification model demonstrates high performance, achieving an overall accuracy of 98%. This integrated solution provides a practical end to end workflow, from data-driven prediction to guided repair, enhancing the efficiency of automotive maintenance.

title: Impact of climate change on energy need and cost of sustainable electrified irrigation
authors: Nathalie Pettersson, Alida Nilsson, Amelia Bergum, Pierre Damien Uwitije, Jimmy Ehnberg
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: This study investigates the impact of climate change on the energy requirements and installation costs of electrified irrigation systems in the small village of Tabagwe, Rwanda. With global temperatures projected to rise by $1.6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $2.4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ by 2050, the study examines how these changes affect water needs and energy consumption for irrigation. Using a combination of the FAO model for water requirements and a linear optimisation model for energy systems, the research evaluates three temperature scenarios and their implications. Results indicate that water requirements could increase by up to 13% during peak months, leading to a corresponding rise in energy demand and system costs of 6% for the highest temperature scenario. The study also explores the viability of solar/battery and solar/biodiesel hybrid systems, highlighting the benefits and challenges of each. The findings underscore the necessity for adaptive strategies in designing sustainable irrigation systems to enhance agricultural productivity and resilience to climate change.

title: High-Performance Optimized Implementation of Kyber Algorithm Based on ARM NEON
authors: Bao Yuqiao, Zhong Junjie, Cui Yijun, Wang Chenghua, Liu Weiqiang
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: The rapid advancements in quantum computing technologies present a significant challenge to traditional cryptosystems. To mitigate the potential collapse of existing cryptosystems, the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) initiated the standardization of post-quantum cryptography in 2016. During the NIST post-quantum cryptography standardization process, CRYSTALS-KYBER was selected as the sole standardized public key encryption algorithm in July 2022. Following the determination of standardization, deploying lattice-based cryptographic schemes for Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) capable of resisting quantum attacks in resource-constrained embedded devices, such as smartphones and ARM-based Internet of Things (IoT) devices, is of great significance. ARM NEON is an extension of the Single Instruction Multiple Data (SIMD) instruction set, widely employed in ARM-based processors to perform parallel vectorization operations on data. This paper analyzes NEON coprocessor instructions based on the Phytium-FT-2000 processor. ARM NEON technology is employed to optimize the Montgomery reduction, NTT transformation, and other algorithms within the Kyber algorithm. Furthermore, the hardware platform's accelerator is invoked to perform global vector optimization of the algorithm, fully utilizing register storage space and leveraging the parallel computing capabilities of the NEON instruction set. Experimental results demonstrate a significant improvement in algorithm efficiency through the optimization provided by ARM NEON technology, based on the Phytium-FT-2000 processor. It is approximately 6 times faster than the version without NEON technology, and compared to the pure C implementation of the Kyber algorithm, the operation speed improves by approximately 39 times.

title: Corporate Legal Liability in Environmental Crimes: An Analytical Study in the Context of Climate Change
authors: Husein Bani Issa, Nasiem Khalid Alshawawreh, Qais Maaitah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The growing climate crisis has placed corporate environmental accountability under increasing legal and ethical scrutiny. This study examines the concept of corporate legal liability in environmental crimes, with a particular focus on the context of climate change and its global implications. Existing legal mechanisms often fall short in attributing direct responsibility to corporate entities due to limitations in evidence linking emissions to specific environmental damages and the fragmentation of legal standards across jurisdictions. To address these issues, this study proposes the Climate Forensics-Based Legal Attribution Framework (CF-LAF), which integrates scientific climate forensics with legal attribution models to identify and quantify a corporation's contribution to environmental degradation. By tracing specific greenhouse gas emissions to corporate activities and linking them to climate-related harms, CF-LAF offers a robust, evidence-backed approach to establishing legal liability. The framework is applied to hypothetical and real-world corporate scenarios, demonstrating its potential for use in national litigation and international tribunals. Findings suggest that CF-LAF significantly enhances the evidentiary strength of environmental claims, aids in shaping policy reforms, and supports the development of enforceable legal precedents for corporate climate accountability. The proposed method gradually improves the emission volume by 98.45%, the legal emission threshold by 97.42%, the climate impact evidence by 96.38%, and the causation and attribution index by 97.92%.

title: Integrating Transfer Learning and XAI for Trustworthy Malaria Diagnosis in Clinical Decision Support
authors: A N Ramya Shree, Nithya N, Sajitha N, Lavanya Kamaraju, Hrithwika, Supriya, Sahana M B
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The transfer learning based classification of the red blood smear images as malaria-infected or not is proposed with the Intermediate Feature Analysis. The AlexNet convolutional neural network (CNN) is used based on learning strategy and model is trained and tested which results in a high binary classification accuracy. Explainable AI techniques are used for convolutional filter visualization, class activation maps (CAMs), and intermediate feature map analysis. XAI techniques helps to enhance the model interpretability, further builds trust in AI based malaria disease diagnosis. The feature visualizations reveal how the proposed system detects crucial traits associated with malaria infection. The efficacy of integrating transfer learning and XAI visual analytics to support in automated malaria disease diagnosis and clinical decision making.

title: How Artificial Intelligence Leads to Excellence in the Human Resource Department?
authors: Dirar Abdelaziz Al-Maaitah, Tamara Adel Al-Maaitah, Murtadha Bilal Yousuf Al Bahrani, Rasha Mohammad Rath’An Alraqqad
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This paper focuses on developing Human Resource Management (HRM) prospects by assessing the current situation of integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI) into HRM and understanding the general concerns about AI professionals accepting their value in modern HRM. Contemporary HR professionals, in the context of Workplace 4.0, are integrating AI into organizational HRM practices and can create insight into the current practices of AI in HRM workplaces. Furthermore, the paper also aims to understand how AI can influence recruitment and selection, training and development, and performance appraisal processes within an organization. Through the integration of AI within HRM, these practices could take on a different and more efficient form based on various sub-components within each of these areas, and it also provides a brief summary of AI researchers about its impact on making day-to-day general HRM decisions.AI, which is today's contribution, is the process of making machines think like humans. Though humans do this with inference and learning from the past, AI is also the process of developing human intelligence systems and working on arguments, characteristics, competition, and perception by learning from the past. Within the context of 'Workplace 4.0', professors or creators are encouraged by AI inductors who develop HRM functions such as recruitment, performance appraisal, training, or any other process that can increase performance optimization in any organization’s performance and create some time efficiency. AI has some basic properties that concern HR managers to adopt this. Some of the properties used in AI and questions are as follows: the attributes are Big Data, Machine Learning Systems, Neural Networks, Natural Language Processing, Cloud Platforms, Robotic Process Automation, Chatbots, and Predictive Analytics.

authors: Alborz Aghamaleki Sarvestani, Adithya Ravindran, Jianye Shi, Ole Granhaug
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The transition to SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf>-free switchgear creates an urgent demand for energy-efficient actuation systems capable of high-speed, reliable, and precise switching. The ban on SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> necessitates alternative arc extinguishing techniques, each requiring distinct energy and speed profiles-challenges that conventional single spring-based actuators cannot meet. This paper presents a novel deformable beam-based actuation system customized for each switching mode with separate energy storage sources. The proposed design enables optimized energy delivery and switching speed. System performance was validated with a physical demonstrator, achieving target speeds with less than 1% error with multibody dynamics (MBD) simulation. The results highlight the deformable beam actuator as a lightweight, scalable, and sustainable solution for next-generation SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf>-free switchgear.

title: Dissociating Cognitive Load and Stress Responses Using Single-Channel EEG: Behavioral and Neural Correlates of Anxiety Across Cognitive States
authors: Neta Batya Maimon, Lior Molcho, Talya Zaimer, Ofir Chibotero, Nathan Intrator, Eliezer Yahalom
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Identifying neural markers of stress and cognitive load is key to developing scalable tools for mental state assessment. This study evaluated whether a single-channel high-density EEG (hdrEEG) system could dissociate cognitive and stress-related activity during a brief auditory task-based protocol. Sixty-eight healthy adults completed resting-state recordings, cognitively demanding auditory tasks, and exposure to unpredictable lateralized startle stimuli. Participants also rated their stress and anxiety using a modified State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI). EEG analysis focused on frequency bands (Theta, Gamma, Delta) and machine-learning-derived features (A0, ST4, VC9, T2). A double dissociation emerged: Theta and VC9 increased under cognitive load but not startle, supporting their sensitivity to executive function; in contrast, Gamma and A0 were elevated by the startle stimulus, consistent with stress reactivity. ST4 tracked cognitive effort and worry, while T2 negatively correlated with self-reported calmness, indicating relevance to emotional regulation. These results demonstrate that a short, uniform assessment using portable EEG can yield multiple reliable biomarkers of cognitive and affective states. The findings have implications for clinical, occupational, and educational settings, and may inform future neurofeedback protocols targeting simultaneous regulation of attention and stress.

title: Auxiliary Power and Electrical Losses for PV and BESS Power Plants
authors: Christian Sanchez, Julie Matarweh, Eklas Hossain
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Understanding auxiliary power requirements and electrical losses in solar PV (Photovoltaic) and Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) power plants is essential for accurate system design and financial modeling. These values, often underestimated during development, can lead to lower-than-expected power capacity or energy production and unforeseen grid consumption, impacting both operational efficiency and profitability. This paper seeks to help engineers and developers differentiate between auxiliary loads and system losses, demonstrating how each affects the overall design and, thus performance, of solar PV and BESS projects. To explore these impacts, we will compile typical losses and auxiliary power demands in a grid-connected, utility-scale, solar PV, and BESS system. We will incorporate critical components, including medium-voltage (MV) and high-voltage (HV) transformers, substation auxiliary loads, thermal management auxiliary loads, underground cables, and overhead lines by examining performance at a specific temperature profile to reflect real-world environmental conditions and their effect on system efficiency.

title: AI-Based Subscriber Classification in Power Distribution Networks Using Load Profiles
authors: Gaye Tülgen Kale, Ömer Adıgüzel, Cem Haydaroğlu, Özal Yıldırım, Heybet Kılıç
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Accurate classification of electricity consumers is vital for demand forecasting, anomaly detection, and tariff optimization in modern power systems. This study investigates the effectiveness of various machine learning and deep learning models in classifying electricity subscribers based on their active power consumption profiles. Using a real-world dataset containing over 21 million hourly consumption records from 25,476 subscribers in Southeastern Turkey, four consumer types were defined: General Subscriber, Lighting, Transformer, and Industrial Facility. Two modeling approaches were explored: (i) traditional machine learning models (e.g., LightGBM, Random Forest) using statistical and temporal feature extraction, and (ii) deep learning models (1D-CNN, CNN-LSTM, LSTM, ROCKET) trained directly on raw time series data. The 1D-CNN and ROCKET models outperformed others with a classification accuracy of 98%, while LightGBM achieved 96% accuracy among classical models. Evaluation metrics, including confusion matrices and F1 scores, indicated that 1D-CNN was particularly effective in learning temporal patterns from imbalanced data, especially in minority classes. Unlike most prior studies focusing on load forecasting, this work demonstrates how time series can be utilized for direct consumer classification. The results provide a practical and scalable framework for electricity distribution companies to enhance operational efficiency, consumer profiling, and energy management strategies.

title: Overseas Gliding UAV Parachute-Free Airdrop Development Status and Trend Research
authors: Jie Guo, Yanpeng Guo, Zhenwei Wang, Runze Gao
publish: 2025 Low-Altitude Economy Forum &amp; International Conference on Low-Altitude Flight Technology and Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Application (LEF &amp; ICLU)
abstract: The development of glider UAV parachute-less airdrop has brought about a fundamental change in airdrop resupply, realizing the right time, right place, and right amount of resupply of equipment and munitions, and comprehensively enhancing the deployment and guarantee capability of troops at the strategic and tactical levels. In order to promote the research and application of parachute-free airdrop in China, this paper reviews the development status of foreign glider UAV parachute-free airdrop, compares the advantages and limitations of various glider UAVs, and looks forward to the future development trend of glider UAVs, which will be developed in the direction of improving autonomy, intelligence, low cost, stealth, clustering, environmental adaptability, and autonomous takeoff and landing in order to provide a reference for the development of glider UAV parachute-free airdrop technology in China. in order to provide reference for the development of China’s glider UAV parachute-less airdrop technology.

title: The Burden Beyond Reproduction: Characterizing Comorbid Conditions in PCOS and PCOD
authors: Suvika K V, D G Jyothi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) which is a complex endocrine condition is commonly linked to metabolic, hormonal, and reproductive issues. Comorbid disorders must be identified early for prompt intervention and better results. The co-occurrence and prevalence of obesity, hypothyroidism, hypertension, hyperprolactinemia, diabetes, vitamin D deficiency, and reproductive problems were investigated in this study using patient data collected from Kaggle open repository. According to the results, over 40% of the group had obesity and 70% of obese people had hypertension, which displayed the highest co-occurrence pattern. Vitamin D insufficiency and hyperprolactinemia were also very common, with the former often associated with reproductive problems. Diabetes was less common than the other conditions. These results show the significance of thorough screening and multidisciplinary care for women with PCOS, as well as the complex interactions between PCOS and several systemic illnesses.

title: Regulatory Frameworks Based International Standards for Secure FinTech and Payment Operations
authors: Orhan M. Albayati, Labeeb Saadoon Alyassri, Mustafa M. Abd Zaid, Kawther Al-Fatlawi, Aqeel H. Al-Fatlawi, Ali Abdulkareem Hadi Al-Magsoosi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: With the emergence of FinTech and digital payment systems, facilitating regulatory compliance and ensuring security in three or more international jurisdictions is becoming increasingly important. The inconsistency of regulatory frameworks that rely on internationally recognized standards including ISO/IEC 27001, PCI DSS, and PSD2 lack iteratively evolving standards on secure financial transactions and overall compliance standards. Existing compliance practices are static, region-focused, and not tailored for sustained compliance, leading to inefficient compliance processes and insecure financial transactions. Propose the RegTech-Driven Adaptive Compliance Framework (RDACF), a name for the proposed framework. RDACF integrates regulatory technology (RegTech) and artificial intelligence (AI) to provide a mechanism of dynamic compliance capability within multi-jurisdictional fintech environments that leverage real-time compliance technology. RDACF uses a context-adaptive AI policy engine to programmatically map transactions against relevant international standards, and jurisdiction standards. This is achieved using the Cross-Border Smart Transaction Monitor (CSTM) secure transaction compliance system, which allows for the modification of its rules based on the classification type of the transaction, classification geography, and risk profile associated with the particular transaction. It is proposed that the framework will deliver increased compliance accuracy and reduced operational risks as well as mitigate the scalability problems encountered in global fintech firms. The results from the tests indicated that RDACF has improved regulatory responsiveness, decreased compliance costs, and enhanced transaction security while being a secure framework for strong digital finance ecosystems. The framework's results, as proposed based on RDACFs methodology can in future research lead to an improved compliance accuracy rate of 98.43%, regulatory responsiveness rate improved to 97.68%, transactional security rate improved to 96.51%, and scalability by 98.70%.

title: Techno-Economic Analysis of a Grid-tied Solar Hybrid Energy System for a TVET College
authors: S.M. Ncikazi, A.A. Adebiyi, M.L.T. Zulu, T.F. Mazibuko
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: South African educational institutions face mounting challenges due to persistent electrical energy shortages and grid instability, largely stemming from the country’s dependence on coal power generation. This introduces critical drawbacks, including environmental pollution, escalating fuel costs, and frequent load shedding by ESKOM. Such disruptions adversely affect the consistent use of electrical and electronic resources essential for effective teaching and learning, particularly in technical and vocational education and training colleges. This study investigates the deployment of hybrid renewable energy systems as a sustainable alternative to reduce dependency on the conventional grid and lower electrification costs for a TVET campus. Using the Homer Grid simulation tool, various system configurations are analysed to determine the optimal techno-economic setup. Key performance indicators assessed include the renewable energy penetration ratio, distributed generation potential, grid stability, and contribution of renewables to overall energy demand. The study evaluates life cycle cost, capital investment, cost of energy (COE), total annual energy production, and monthly average output to compare system efficiencies. The net present cost (NPC) is employed as the primary metric for conducting the techno-economic analysis. Findings support the feasibility of adopting a hybrid renewable energy approach to enhance energy reliability, reduce operational costs, and promote environmental sustainability in educational infrastructures.

title: Robust Control of a Dual Star Permanent Magnet Synchronous Generator in Normal and Fault Conditions
authors: Mouhamed Mbengue, Abdoulaye Dieng
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This paper presents a robust vector control strategy based on field oriented control for a dual star permanent magnet synchronous generator. The system is modeled in a synchronous rotating reference frame with dynamic decoupling. Independent proportional-integral controllers regulate the direct and quadrature current components, with an outer speed loop. Numerical simulations under disturbances such as phase imbalance and sensor faults show improved power tracking stability and reliable operation in degraded conditions.

title: Federated Learning-Based Cotton Crop Diseases Detection Using Internet of Drones
authors: Md Benozir Hossain, Tim Leonhardt, Ticauris Stokes, Partha Sengupta, Ahmed Sherif, Mohamed Elsersy, Rabab Abdelfattah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become a vital tool for agricultural farming. AI-based image processing models utilizing different machine learning (ML) algorithms and deep learning (DL) offer advanced functionalities in disease detection, yield estimation, land use, etc. This paper examines AI-driven techniques utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) with the addition of Federated Learning to analyze satellite and drone images for agricultural insights, especially in detecting Cotton diseases. The AI models improve agricultural farming in many ways, such as using data to make critical decisions, reducing labor costs, pest infestations, etc. Moreover, these models allow farmers to minimize yield losses by making early interventions. AI models can also efficiently use land by analyzing soil conditions and crop performance. This paper utilizes various ML models for classifying cotton plant diseases. We received accuracy scores of over 90%. The results are promising; however, ensuring good results on unseen or new data remains one of our future work directions.

title: AI-Powered Solutions for Legal Compliance in Industrial Workspaces a Psychological and Labour Law Perspective
authors: E. Venugopal, Rikimi, Lakshmi Priya Vinjamuri, Vivek Singh Sachan, Stephen Samuel, Ismoilov Shukhratjon
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The complicated issue of the ways to ensure the workplaces in the industries meet the legal standards brings together the psychology of the workplaces, the labour law, and the convolution of the AI design. In this dissertation, the author investigates the use of AI-mediated options to deal with regulatory compliance and psychological and legal issues. The risk associated with the fair labour, discrimination, and safety issues can be addressed with the help of predictive analytics, automated compliance, and AI-compliance monitoring. The use of AI can also be expanded to support worker well-being and mental health through the identification of work stressors, burnout prevention, and creation of a physiologically safe workplace. But in the case of AI, there are ethical or legal considerations around the agency of workers, bias in algorithms, as well as privacy or confidentiality of data. Due to these reasons, it is necessary to adopt the strategy approach, where AI and human observation are used to determine the work decisions trade-offs in an observable and just manner to employers and employees alike. This dissertation also added to the contribution of how AI can benefit the responsible design of industrial workplaces that do not fail to achieve ethical standards, hold to psychological sustainability, and adhere to labour laws, evaluating the psychological effects of labour law actors as well as effects on the workplace.

title: Self-Similarity Feature Extraction Using the Hurst Parameter in Transformer Architectures for IoT Anomaly Identification
authors: Roya Morshedi, S. Mojtaba Matinkhah
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: The increasing deployment of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has amplified the importance of effective anomaly detection to ensure network security and reliable operation. Traditional methods often struggle to accurately identify complex and subtle abnormal patterns within high-volume, multidimensional traffic data. In this study, we introduce a novel framework that combines Transformer-based deep learning models with self-similarity features derived from the Hurst exponent to enhance anomaly detection performance. By extracting fractal-based features and employing attention mechanisms within the Transformer architecture, our approach effectively captures long-range dependencies and dynamic traffic behaviors. Experimental results on a benchmark IoT dataset demonstrate a high detection accuracy of 95.64%, outperforming many existing methods. The proposed model not only improves detection effectiveness but also provides interpretability and robustness against noisy data. Visualizations of confusion matrices and anomaly frequency analyses further validate the effectiveness of our approach. This work highlights the potential of integrating fractal features with advanced neural architectures for real-time, reliable IoT network security.

title: Lightweight Hybrid CNN Model with Explainable AI for Skin Lesion Classification
authors: Mahshid Benchari, Magdy Bayoumi, Michael W. Totaro
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Skin cancer, a potentially fatal condition, results from abnormal skin cell growth due to excessive ultraviolet (UV) exposure. Early and accurate differentiation of malignant and benign lesions is essential for effective treatment. This paper presents a new hybrid deep learning model to improve skin cancer classification by integrating the feature extraction ability of MobileNetV3Large and EfficientNetB0, two of the most recent lightweight convolutional neural networks (CNNs). To tackle common challenges in medical imaging, including class imbalance and visual artifacts, we employ a robust preprocessing pipeline that includes inpainting, adding image resampling, and hair artifact removal. All these approaches enhance data quality significantly and support better model generalization. Moreover, extensive data augmentation is also applied in an effort to boost the training set and avoid overfitting. Our system also involves an Explainable AI (XAI) module that runs on the LIME platform offering understandable visual explanations of model output, thereby making it easy to close the gap between black-box AI and clinical credibility. On the ISIC dataset, our dual-CNN model performs very well with accuracy of 96.7%, recall of 94.85%, precision of 92.4%, and F 1 -score of 91.6%. In this paper, we demonstrate the benefits of combining lightweight CNNs with explainability tools to develop interpretable, robust, and clinically useful skin lesion classification solutions.

title: Generative Artificial Intelligence for code generation based on CodeT5 algorithm
authors: Amna U. Hamed, Safwan O. Hasoon
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research proposes a generative AI-based framework that uses the CodeT5 Transformer model to automate the translation of structured pseudocode into C++ source code. The system was trained and evaluated on a curated dataset and achieved promising results: 80% exact match accuracy, precision of 79.58%, recall of 78.83%, and an F1-score of 78.80%. These results highlight CodeT5’s capability to understand logic and generate syntactically valid code, making it a viable tool for enhancing productivity in software development.

title: Edge embedding based on meta-path subgraphs for link prediction in heterogeneous networks
authors: Jiaxin Yan, Linlan Liu, Jian Shu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Heterogeneous networks are a special type of network that contains different types of nodes and edges. Link prediction in heterogeneous networks can reveal hidden interaction patterns among diverse entities, serving as a key task in handling the associations within complex information structures. Existing research mostly relies on various similarities between node pairs to measure the likelihood of links, thereby predicting connections between nodes. However, this approach misses edge information when capturing node details. To address the aforementioned issues, we proposes a edge embedding based on meta-path subgraphs for link prediction model (EMSLP). EMSLP extracts subgraphs through meta-paths, converts meta-path subgraphs to line graphs, utilizes graph convolutional networks to process line graphs, reduces redundant noise and extracts edge information, and performs link prediction through MLP. Experiments on the generalizability and effectiveness of the model were conducted on three real heterogeneous network datasets: ACM, IMDB, and Amazon. The results demonstrate that EMSLP outperforms other baseline models in terms of AUC and AP metrics on all three datasets. This model exhibits excellent link prediction performance.

title: Design and Optimization of the Florian Shared FPU Architecture
authors: Sree Vidya J, Deepika P
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The proliferation of computation-intensive tasks in embedded System-on-Chip (SoC) environments has amplified the necessity for optimized floating-point arithmetic units that exhibit minimal power dissipation and silicon footprint. This study introduces a centralized and power-efficient Floating-Point Unit (FPU) architecture intended for concurrent access by multiple lightweight processing cores. Unlike conventional percore FPU replication, the proposed model incorporates a shared computation paradigm governed by FIFO queuing and arbiterbased control mechanisms to facilitate equitable and conflict-free access. To further enhance energy efficiency, the design integrates operand reuse detection, dynamic precision scaling, and clock gating–techniques that collectively curtail redundant switching and lower dynamic power consumption. The Xilinx Artix-7 FPGA is used to realize the proposed architecture, which is implemented using Verilog HDL via the Vivado 2024.2 toolchain. Simulation and functional validation are performed using ModelSim, affirming IEEE-754 compliance and timing correctness. Empirical synthesis results reveal a significant reduction in area and power metrics: 52.9% fewer Lookup Tables (LUTs), 53.8% reduction in flip-flop usage, and 45% lower total power compared to traditional FPU deployments. The system achieves a sustained clock frequency of 150 MHz while maintaining computational integrity. The findings underscore the suitability of the proposed centralized FPU for integration in resource-constrained, power-aware embedded computing platforms.

title: Edge AI-Driven Vision Systems for Zero-Defect Manufacturing in 6G-Enabled Industry 5.0: The Factory of the Future
authors: Yuvaraja Boovanahalli Kariyappagowda, Manjunatha G, Mahjabeen, Sabin T T, Pramod, Prabhavathi K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: In the era of Industry 5.0, achieving zero-defect manufacturing is essential for enhancing production quality, minimizing waste, and ensuring operational efficiency. Traditional quality control systems—whether manual or cloud-based—face challenges such as high latency, limited scalability, and data security risks. This paper presents a novel Edge AIdriven vision system that leverages 6G connectivity to enable real-time defect detection on the manufacturing floor. The proposed solution integrates lightweight deep learning models and high-speed edge inference to eliminate the need for centralized processing, thereby reducing response times and energy consumption. Experimental validation using NVIDIA Jetson AGX Xavier demonstrates significant performance gains, including 99.2% defect detection accuracy, a 70% reduction in latency, and 40% lower energy consumption compared to conventional cloud-based approaches. These results underscore the system's potential to facilitate predictive maintenance, seamless human-AI collaboration, and real-time defect elimination—core principles of Industry 5.0. Despite these advancements, challenges such as model optimization for edge hardware, secure federated learning, and widespread 6G infrastructure adoption remain open research problems. Future work will focus on integrating neuromorphic computing and blockchain-enhanced AI for improved adaptability, security, and scalability. This research lays a strong foundation for intelligent, autonomous, and defect-free manufacturing in nextgeneration smart factories.

title: Fuzzy Logic-Based Algorithm for Decision Support in Secure Healthcare Diagnosis Systems
authors: Sudarshan Goswami, A. Buckshumiyan, Ammar Hameed, M. Anjaneyulu, M.S. Gowtham
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: To keep up with clinical data's expanding complexity and ambiguity, intelligent decision support systems that mirror human reasoning are essential. Increased clinical data complexity explains this. Additionally, both factors are predicted to rise. MedFuzz is a new fuzzy logic-based system for medical diagnosis. MedFuzz is described in this article. The research project follows this investigation. Due to the flexibility of fuzzy logic, MedFuzz may examine many patient symptoms, test data, and clinical concerns. Fuzzy logic enables this.In contrast to the above situation, long-standing rule-based systems suffer from imprecise or erroneous data. System diagnoses are accurate and easy to understand. This is done via a multilayered fuzzy inference model. This model integrates medical experts' expertise, experience, and dynamic input weighting. MedFuzz was evaluated using anonymized patient data from many ailment categories. The assessment included this. After comparing previous approaches, MedFuzz demonstrated higher diagnostic accuracy and decreased false-positive rates. This showed that MedFuzz outperformed established approaches. The study found that the system may give doctors timely, data-backed recommendations, improving patient outcomes. The study's results demonstrate this possibility. This study advances healthcare diagnostics by enabling more intuitive, personalized decision-help tools.

title: Design of Meandered Line Dual Band Patch Antenna
authors: Neetu Agrawal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: In the present study, a patch antenna with dual band that resonates at 2.06 GHz and 3.29 GHz is designed and investigated, and it suitable for communication applications. The proposed antenna utilizes a meandered line patch structure with optimized dimensions to achieve the desired resonant frequencies. The proposed antenna design with FR4 substrate, having a loss tangent, 0.025 and a relative permittivity, 4.3. This substrate is easily available and less costly. The antenna exhibits steady radiation patterns at both working frequencies, a wide bandwidth, and good impedance matching due to the accurate feed technique choice and integration of an appropriate substrate material. The antenna owing to its dualband features may support multiple communication technologies, including Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and 4G/5G networks. Simulations results show that the antenna offers desirable performance, including low return loss and high efficiency at both resonant frequencies and VSWR is less than 2 within two operating band. When efficient and small antenna designs are needed for a variety of frequency bands, such as in mobile networks, IoT devices, and communications systems, this dualband patch antenna is perfect.

title: Techno-Economic Analysis of Grid-Connected Rooftop Solar Power Plants for Residential and Commercial Sectors in Banyumas, Indonesia
authors: Itmi Hidayat Kurniawan, Sadham Arbian, Anna Nur Nazilah Chamim, Sheik Mohammed Sulthan, Latiful Hayat, Winarso Winarso
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: The transition to renewable energy resources is a strategic step in supporting the Indonesian government's policies on carbon emission reduction. A significant effort is the utilization of solar energy through grid-connected rooftop Solar Photovoltaic (PV) systems in the residential and commercial sectors. This study aims to analyze the techno-economic aspects of implementing grid-connected rooftop solar PV system. Simulation results A 900VA residential class with an installed capacity of 0.87 kWp generates 1299.95 kWh of electricity annually, while a 2200 VA commercial class with a capacity of 2.175 kWp produces 3175.68 kWh/year. Economic analysis, comparing two scenarios based on Ministerial Regulation of ESDM No. 26 of 2021 and No. 2 of 2024, indicates significant differences in energy savings. With a discount rate of 6.95%, the Net Present Value (NPV) is negative for the 900VA residential class and positive for the 2200VA commercial class. The Internal Rate of Return (IRR) for the 2200VA commercial class exceeds the discount rate, while the 900VA residential class falls below it. The Discounted Payback Period (DPP) for the 900VA residential class is longer, and for the 2200VA commercial class, it is shorter than the project lifespan under both 900VA regulation scenarios. The implementation of rooftop PLTS is currently financially unfeasible without supportive incentives or government policies promoting solar power plant adoption. Recommendations include system optimization to enhance energy efficiency, reducing initial investment costs through subsidy schemes, and evaluating energy policies to support the better adoption of rooftop PLTS in the residential and 2200VA commercial sectors.

title: Control of a Doubly-Fed Induction Generator for Wind Energy Conversion System
authors: Ibrahim Yaichi, Aoumri Mohammed, Ilhami Colak, Anissa Ticherahine
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This research undertakes an in-depth investigation into the modeling, control system design, and dynamic simulation of a Doubly Fed Induction Generator (DFIG) as part of a grid-connected wind energy conversion system. The central aim of the study is to develop and implement a robust vector control strategy that enables independent and precise regulation of both active (real) and reactive (imaginary) power flows between the wind turbine and the electrical grid. Such decoupled control is critical for enhancing grid stability, maintaining voltage levels, and improving the overall power quality, especially under fluctuating wind speeds and variable grid load conditions. The proposed control architecture is specifically tailored to ensure high performance and reliability during transient events, such as wind gusts or grid disturbances, while simultaneously meeting stringent grid code requirements related to power factor correction, fault ridethrough capabilities, and dynamic voltage support. To thoroughly evaluate the efficacy and resilience of the control strategy, a high-fidelity simulation platform is developed within the MATLAB/Simulink environment. This simulation framework incorporates detailed models of the wind turbine, DFIG, power electronic converters, and grid interface, allowing for comprehensive testing under a wide range of realistic operating scenarios. Quantitative metrics such as response time, steady-state error, harmonic distortion, and system stability margins are used to validate the control performance and ensure the system’s compliance with modern grid integration standards.

title: Semi Supervised Framework for Segmenting Remote Sensing Images
authors: S Eliza Femi Sherley, Boopathy C, Anand A, Varun Karthik B, Rubesh VC
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of remotely sensed images is mandatory for efficient environmental management and land use observation. Manual annotation of satellite images is inefficient and expensive. To address this issue, this research introduces a semi-supervised semantic segmentation network that employs both labeled and unlabeled samples to enhance segmentation accuracy while minimizing dependency on manual annotations. The architecture includes combining advanced deep learning models like DeepLabV3+ and attention mechanisms with Vision Transformer (ViT) in a teacherstudent setup. By utilizing both pseudo-labeling and attention modules like SCSE (Spatial and Channel Squeeze & Excitation), the proposed model improves overall accuracy of feature extraction and segmentation. The experimentation is been carried out using high-resolution remote sensing datasets such as DLRSD, WHDLD, and ISPRS Potsdam-each covering varied terrain and label distributions. Experimental results shows that DeepLabV3+ employing ResNet-101 and ResNet-50 backbones with attention mechanisms scored a mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) of 0.7237 on the DLRSD dataset. While, DeepLabV3+ model with ViT and SCSE attention achieved an mIoU of 0.7024 on WHDLD dataset. Moreover, the DeepLabV3 with ViT achieved a high mIoU of 0.8965 on the ISPRS Potsdam dataset. These findings show the effectiveness and strength of the proposed semi-supervised framework under different geographical conditions, which confirms its potential for real-world applications such as in remote sensing and land cover mapping.

title: Decentralized Finance Platforms for Promoting Secure Peer-to-Peer Lending Through Trustless Smart Contracts
authors: Mustafa M. Abd Zaid, Ali Abdulkareem Hadi Al-Magsoosi, Kawther Al-Fatlawi, Orhan M. Albayati, Labeeb Saadoon Alyassri, Aqeel H. Al-Fatlawi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Decentralized Finance (DeFi) platforms are reshaping the financial landscape by enabling secure, peer-to-peer (P2P) lending through blockchain technology and trustless smart contracts. These platforms eliminate the need for traditional intermediaries, offering transparency, automation, and reduced transactional friction. However, existing DeFi lending solutions face challenges such as smart contract vulnerabilities, poor user trust, limited risk management, and inefficient system design processes. These issues often result in security breaches, collateral mismanagement, and reduced adoption. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a framework using the Blockchain-Based System Development Life Cycle (BSDLC) methodology. BSDLC introduces structured phases—including requirement analysis, system design, smart contract development, testing, deployment, and maintenance—tailored to the unique needs of blockchain-based systems. These phases ensure systematic identification of risks, secure coding practices, and continuous verification of smart contract behavior through rigorous testing. The proposed BSDLC-based method is applied to develop a safe, trustless P2P lending application on the Ethereum blockchain. The platform enables users to borrow and lend digital assets using collateralized smart contracts, which are enforced by oracles for real-time asset valuation. The implementation ensures tamper-proof loan execution, automated liquidation, and complete transparency, all without requiring central oversight. The findings reveal that applying BSDLC significantly enhances the security, reliability, and usability of decentralized finance (DeFi) lending applications. It reduces vulnerabilities and ensures system integrity, making it a scalable and trustworthy solution for modern financial ecosystems.

title: High-Performance Computing in Browsers: An Empirical Study Evaluating the Computational Efficiency of JS, C++ WASM, and Java WASM in Matrix Operations
authors: Bin Wang, Haoliang Li, Jie Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: Despite the maturity of web technologies, compute-intensive tasks in browsers often underperform compared to native clients due to their reliance on JavaScript. This paper benchmarks the efficiency of JavaScript, C++ (WASM), and Java (WASM) in matrix operations. It provides data-driven guidance and scenario-specific recommendations for technology selection, offering practical insights for high-performance web computing and WASM ecosystem development.

title: A Quantitative Cybersecurity Risk Framework for Regional Development Banks: An OSINT-Based Analysis in Indonesia
authors: Indah Rizkiani Adha, Adityas Widjajarto, Umar Yunan Kurnia Septo Hediyanto
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: As digital infrastructures grow in developing economies, the associated cyber risks have also expanded in sophistication and frequency. Most existing frameworks focus on insider data, making them insufficient for assessing externally observable cyber risks. This paper introduces a novel quantitative cybersecurity risk framework for external assessment of financial institutions. The framework calculates risk scores as a product of externally observable vulnerability, threat, and asset indicators, with data collected through Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) techniques. Applied to Indonesian Regional Development Banks, the study revealed wide risk score disparities, demonstrating that technology governance significantly outweighs financial scale in determining external risk profiles. The framework identified critical patterns including attack surface complexity, technology sprawl, and common misconfigurations across institutions. This research contributes a practical, data-driven tool enabling financial institutions and regulators to objectively benchmark cyber risk, prioritize remediation efforts, and systematically improve cyber resilience through evidence-based resource allocation.

title: ECO-VVC: Energy-Aware Cognitive Orchestration of VVC for Real-Time Green IoT Video Streaming Over SDN
authors: Yaghoub Saberi, Mohammadreza Forghani, Sharifeh. S. Mirkhalaf
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: The rapid expansion of Internet of Things (IoT) devices and the growing demand for real-time video streaming highlight energy efficiency as a critical requirement alongside latency and Quality of Experience (QoE). While the Versatile Video Coding (VVC/H.266) standard achieves remarkable compression efficiency, its computational complexity often results in high energy consumption in resource-limited IoT environments. To address this, we present ECO-VVC, a novel framework for Energy-aware Cognitive Orchestration of VVC in SoftwareDefined Networking (SDN)-enabled IoT networks. ECO-VVC uniquely integrates VVC tool-level adaptation, energy-aware quantization parameter scheduling, and SDN-assisted edge orchestration into a unified optimization loop. A fuzzy multiobjective controller dynamically balances energy use, end-to-end latency, and QoE, leveraging telemetry data such as battery level, decoding load, stall events, and network state information. Comparative evaluation with state-of-the-art methods including SDN-assisted HAS, latency-aware encoding, and VVC energyquality tradeoff models demonstrates ECO-VVC's superiority in reducing decoding energy and transmission overhead while maintaining perceptual quality. Experiments show up to 45 % lower decoding energy and 28 % reduced transmission cost, with video quality preserved (VMAF <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\geq 92$</tex>). These results establish ECO-VVC as a sustainable and future-ready solution for real-time green IoT video streaming over SDN-based infrastructures.

title: Fast Pattern Matching Algorithm for DNA Sequence Alignment in Genomic Databases
authors: K.Sathya, J.Mythili, Mostafa Abdulsalam Alhayaly, M.Ramya, Bashar Yaser Almansour, Hameed Nida Hameed, P. Panneer Selvan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Appropriately matching DNA sequences about one another is one of bioinformatics' most essential difficulties. This is true because the quantity of genomic data will keep rising at an exponential rate. GenMatch-FastAlign, based on the findings of this study, is a game-changing method that precisely matches patterns in a brief period without sacrificing accuracy. This paper aims to increase the speed and accuracy of DNA sequence alignment in large genomic databases. This effort is being done to reach this goal. Matched subsequences may be found in a brief period by using the provided technique combining adaptive sliding window methods and hash-based indexing. This could be done using the technique. Using this method, one can identify subsequences congruent with the main sequence. Compared to the other alignment techniques already in use regularly, this approach significantly cuts the time needed for computation. Because it uses biological concepts as motivation for its optimization techniques, GenMatch-FastAlign may minimize the number of mismatches and maximize the alignment sensitivity. This lets it reach both of these objectives at once. Genomic data acquired from both short and longitudinal reads is therefore relevant.Comprehensive testing on benchmark datasets reveals GenMatch-FastAlign to be faster in data alignment and more memory-efficient than competing tools like BLAST and BWA. The method can also be parallelized, making it appropriate for usage in cloud-based settings and remote genomic analysis systems. It is also possible to parallelize. The GenMatch-FastAlign software's scalable solution has many applications, including real-time genetic analysis, variation discovery, and customized treatment. Here are a few uses that fit this description. Sequence alignment acceleration, which does not affect the precision of the process, is used to achieve this. The results of this work have significantly contributed to computational genomics through their discoveries. Eliminating the current performance restrictions allows them to explore complicated DNA sequence data more efficiently and effectively.

title: The role of the strategic mindset of the leader in enhancing the benefits of artificial intelligence applications in educational organizations
authors: Maan Waadallah Al Maadhedee, Baraa Sadeer Al Mahrooq
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The research seeks to test the relationship between the strategic mentality of the leader aus an independent variable, and the benefits of AI applications as a dependent. Built Model Theoretical based on how Using the strategic mindset of the leader in enhancing the benefits of AI applications in the world for educational organizations, Thus, a fundamental question had to be answered: Are there correlations and influence between the strategic mindset of the leader and the benefits of AI applications? To verify the contents of the answer, the College of Administration and Economics at the University of Mosul was chosen as a field of study, and one of the most prominent findings of the research was the existence of different levels of influence and correlation exerted by the independent variable in the approved variable.

title: Operational Cost Assessment Using IGDT Considering Uncertainty in Wind and Solar Power with Battery Integration
authors: Basim ALbaaj, Orhan Kaplan
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable energy sources has introduced significant uncertainty into modern power systems, creating challenges in maintaining reliable and economic operation. To address this issue, this study proposes an optimal power flow (OPF) framework based on Information-Gap Decision Theory (IGDT). The framework is designed to handle severe uncertainty in renewable power generation while ensuring robust and stable system performance. The IEEE 30-bus test system, integrated with 4 MW of wind generation and 1 MW of solar generation, is used as the test platform. To enhance flexibility and reliability, a Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) is incorporated, enabling the system to effectively mitigate fluctuations in renewable output. The optimization problem is solved using the Binary Differential Evolution (BDE) algorithm, which efficiently identifies the best compromise among conflicting objectives such as fuel cost, system losses, emissions, and voltage deviation. Simulation results demonstrate that the inclusion of BESS consistently improves performance across all metrics compared to the no-BESS case. The findings indicate substantial reductions in generation cost, system losses, and emissions, while simultaneously enhancing overall system stability. Furthermore, analysis of the percentage error between the BESS and non-BESS scenarios reveals that the most favorable outcome occurs at $\boldsymbol{\beta}= 0.2$, corresponding to a daily profit of ${\$}$139.2152. These results confirm that the integration of IGDT with BESS and BDE provides a resilient, efficient, and economically viable strategy for operating renewable-dominated power systems under uncertainty.

title: Low Power Implementation of RISC V Processor with Fine Grained Clock Gating/Power Gating
authors: Santhosh V, Abhay Deshpande
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: In modern low-power VLSI design, power efficiency has become a critical consideration, especially in processors intended for embedded and battery-powered systems. RISC-V, an open-source and modular instruction set architecture (ISA), provides an excellent platform for implementing customized low-power designs. Fine-grained clock gating and power gating are two effective techniques used to minimize dynamic and static power consumption, respectively. These methods allow selective disabling of the clock or power supply to idle functional units within the processor, thereby significantly reducing unnecessary energy usage without compromising performance. These techniques are particularly beneficial in pipelined RISC-V cores, where not all stages or submodules are active during every clock cycle. By integrating control logic that dynamically determines when a unit is idle, fine-grained gating ensures that only the required sections of the processor are active at any given time. This selective activation reduces switching activity, which directly lowers dynamic power. Similarly, power gating is applied to completely shut off leakage-prone blocks like caches or memory buffers during idle periods. The implementation of such power-saving mechanisms requires careful RTL design and synthesis strategies to ensure functional correctness and timing closure.

title: Challenges of electricity trading - Lessons from the Southern African Power Pool market
authors: Sydney Kadikula Zimba, Natasha Justina Kumwenda
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: The Southern African Power Pool has operated the competitive day-ahead electricity market since 2009. By 2025, other power pools in Africa were still in their infancy in developing competitive electricity markets. This paper presents challenges of electricity trading, categorized as technical, institutional, regulatory and commercial. It also discusses lessons learnt from the Southern African Power Pool in running competitive regional electricity markets.

title: AI-Driven Data Warehouse Solutions for Real-Time Retail Analytics and Optimization
authors: Srinivasa Sridhar Kavikondala, Saurabh Mittal, Achyutha Mohan, Shireesha Gorgilli, Tejasvini Alok Paralkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The maturity of omnichannel retailing, together with the huge scale of data being generated by both online retail and more traditional stores, has placed real-time data analytics as a key enabler in generating competitive advantage. Conventional data warehouses are faced with the volume, speed, and diversity of retail new data streams. The structure of an AI-powered data warehouse that is proposed in this paper includes the incorporation of machine learning, the data ingestion pipelines that operate in real-time, and the likes of dynamic optimisation engines to enable real-time retail analysis. The framework applied through literature synthesis and empirical examination of large-scale simulated data sets in retail outlets showed the best results in inventory management, dynamic pricing, sales forecasting, and customer segmentation. The model takes into account cloud-based storage, streaming platforms, AI-based analytics, and optimisation layers that enable scalable, low-latency analytics of the retail enterprise. Confirming these findings, it is visible that data warehouses with the application of artificial intelligence are a revolutionary solution capable of providing not only technical but also business scalability of retail analytics.

title: Image-Based Steganography for Hidden Text Application using the LSB Approach
authors: Mohamad Zahiran Zahari, Nazhatul Hafizah Kamarudin, Nur Hanis Sabrina Suhaimi, Azana Hafizah Mohamad, Norjihan Abdul Ghani, Mohammad Kamrul Hasan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: In an era of digital transformation, safeguarding sensitive data is more critical than ever. Traditional approaches to encrypting information protect data but can still draw attention to its existence. Steganography provides an alternative where secret information is hidden inside innocent-looking media, for example, images, in order to deny its very existence. This paper introduces Zahiran, a lightweight desktop application that employs image-based steganography and allows the embedding of secret text messages based on the Least Significant Bit (LSB) technique. Zahiran provides methods to embed and extract text from image files (PNG and JPGs) with no perceptible image degradation. Implemented using Python, the system uses multiple libraries like Tkinter, PIL, Stegano, and is designed using the Model-View-Controller to maintain tier-based modularity and clearity within the code. The tool has a user-friendly, easy-to-use and intuitive graphical user-interface which allows users with different technical expertise to use the software. OTP based access control, reset and multiplatform support are some of the key features. Functional testing indicated that the application has the ability to successfully conceal and extract the messages without loss of functionality and performance. In this work, we also compare Zahiran with various other steganography tools and show that it exhibits some of its distinctive advantages regarding accessibility and visual fidelity. While being a fundamentally insecure method since it is based on LSB substitution, Zahiran provides a practical tradeoff between usability and security for secure communication.

title: Decoupled Direct Power Compensators for a Dual-Inverter Based UPFC
authors: Joaquim Monteiro, J. Fernando Silva, Sónia Pinto, V. Fernão Pires
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: In recent decades, Unified Power Flow Controllers (UPFCs) have become essential devices for enhancing the flexibility and controllability of modern electrical transmission networks. These devices facilitate the simultaneous control of local bus voltage and the optimization of power flow within electrical power transmission systems. The multilevel converter capability to operate with high voltage levels while generating low-distortion AC voltages, makes multilevel topologies suitable for UPFCs. Within this framework, this paper presents a novel multilevel converter topology and control strategy specifically designed for UPFC applications. The proposed solution employs a dual inverter topology driven by sliding mode direct power controllers, which are controlled via decoupled Proportional-Integral (PI) compensators. The characteristics, capabilities, and resulting flexibility of the proposed UPFC and control subsystem is validated through a series of simulation tests.

title: A Two-Stage Nonlinear Model Predictive Control for Navigation and Resource Allocation of Autonomous Navy Ships
authors: Natalie Xu, Saskia Putri, Faegheh Moazeni, Javad Khazaei
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: This paper presents a two-stage nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) framework for integrated navigation and power management of autonomous navy ships. The proposed system incorporates a navigation-based propulsion power model into a direct-current naval shipboard microgrid (DC-NSMG), where the propulsion-induced constant power load is modeled as a dynamic disturbance to the microgrid controller. The navigation NMPC processes real-world automatic identification system (AIS) waypoints as a reference and updates optimal thruster power based on the ship’s trajectory. This integrated approach enables more accurate resource allocation under dynamic operating conditions and introduces a novel control architecture by coupling a navigation-based propeller model with microgrid power management. By simulating the integrated system in the baseline case and in the destroyer case, the control robustness is validated.
