title: Ant Colony Optimization Algorithm for Efficient Pathfinding in Autonomous Vehicle Navigation Systems
authors: Pradeep Kumar Muthukamatchi, M Kasiselvanathan, V Anupriya, T. G. Ramabharathi, Salam Ahmed Mahdi, Myasar Mundher Adnan, Duaa A. Majeed
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Autonomous automobiles need a real-time, consistent pathfinding system to appropriately and efficiently negotiate changing surroundings. Sometimes, traditional approaches fall short in multiple respects, including scalability, flexibility, or handling of difficult terrain. This paper presents an improved Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) method to help nav-assisted autonomous automobiles overcome obstacles. The enhanced ACO adds environmental feedback systems, dynamic heuristics, and adaptive pheromone updates to improve route selection under real-time restrictions. The key goals in urban and off-road settings are to lower calculation time, accident risk, and route distance, thus enhancing pathfinding efficiency. This work has been simulated using reasonable traffic models, and the method is compared to industry standards in navigation systems like A* and Dijkstra's to evaluate it. Comparatively to traditional methodologies, the results of trials show an increase in convergence time, an improvement in route optimality, and an increase in adaptability to barrier conditions. The suggested ACO variation provides next-generation intelligent transportation systems with scalability and outstanding performance and boosts the decision-making capability of autonomous systems. The following projects will concentrate on hardware implementation on actual autonomous systems to evaluate their viability and real-time responsiveness under different circumstances.

title: Medical Image Privacy Using GAN-Based De-Identification for Secure Diagnostics Sharing
authors: Vijay Dhote, Harsha Sharma, M. Mahima, R. P. Ram Kumar, Saif O. Husain
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The fast digitization of healthcare technology has led to more questions about patient privacy. It is exceptionally accurate when sharing medical images for research and diagnostic purposes. There are several situations in which conventional anonymization techniques fail to stop re-identification. This paper introduces a de-identification framework founded on a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN). This research effort aims to tackle the significant difficulty of safeguarding patient privacy in the medical imaging domain. The proposed approach can create synthetic facial features in medical images while preserving diagnostically necessary data. Extensive studies using benchmark datasets were done to assess the diagnostic usefulness and privacy preservation. It was discovered following a decision that large-scale studies had been conducted. While preserving high fidelity in clinically relevant areas, the results imply that the de-identified images significantly reduce the probability of re-identification. They also maintain an above ninety percent accuracy on diagnostic tasks. These results concluded that GAN-based de-identification is dependable and scalable, guaranteeing the safe distribution of medical images. By applying this method, data can be sent in a way that follows privacy criteria. They promote cooperation in medical research without compromising the patients’ privacy.

title: Automated Sleep Stage Classification Using Multi-Channel EEG Time-Frequency Features and CNN-BiLSTM Hybrid Networks
authors: Sulaiman M. Karim, Ameer Najy Obeed, Abdul Razzaq Oleiwi Jasim, Maytham T. Qasim, B.S. Veena, Hassan Rajih Ghazi, Mashael Taha Hamad, Rawezh Mohammed Hussein
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research presents a high-accuracy deep learning framework for automated sleep stage classification, leveraging a hybrid CNN-BiLSTM architecture combined with multi-channel EEG time-frequency feature encoding. By extracting spectral-spatial representations via STFT and CWT, and modeling temporal dependencies with BiLSTM, the proposed system effectively distinguishes all five sleep stages—Wake, N1, N2, N3, and REM—across subject-independent settings. Evaluated on benchmark datasets including Sleep-EDF and MASS, the model achieved classification accuracies up to 92.3%, with F1-scores exceeding 86.4%, particularly improving sensitivity for transitional stages like N1 and REM. Compared to baseline models using handcrafted or single-channel features, the proposed approach yields a 5.4% gain in accuracy and demonstrates enhanced generalization under leave-one-subject-out cross-validation. The integration of multi-lead EEG fusion and frequency-domain representations enables robust classification across varying signal morphologies and recording protocols. Designed for real-time deployment, the model maintains inference latency under 200ms per epoch, supporting its application in both clinical and wearable EEG monitoring systems. This architecture represents a scalable, explainable, and domain-adaptive solution for sleep disorder diagnostics and long-term physiological monitoring.

title: THz/FSO Hybrid Channel Propagation Loss Model for Space-Air-Ground Integrated Network
authors: Yutong Jiang, Zhuoxin Li, Jiao Zhang, Shuang Gao, Meng Liu, Wantong Hou, Ruizhe Xu, Min Zhu
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: This article proposes a THz/FSO hybrid channel model for Space-Air-Ground Integrated Network (SAGIN), comprehensively accounting for free-space path loss, atmospheric loss, and weather-induced loss. The propagation characteristics of both signals across atmospheric layers under diverse weather conditions are rigorously analyzed. Computational results verify the complementary transmission characteristics of THz and FSO technologies in varying meteorological scenarios.

title: Pap Smear Image-Based Cervical Cancer Severity Grading Using VGG16 Deep Convolutional Neural Network Classifiers
authors: Zainab Mohammed Jawad, Satar Jabbar Rahi Algraittee, Lubna Qassim Khader Al Sbehat, Hayder Abdulameer Yousif, Hawraa Karm Jouad, Zahraa M Hasan, Aras Ismail Khider
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research proposes a high-performance VGG16-based deep convolutional neural network framework for automated cervical cancer severity grading using Pap smear images. Leveraging transfer learning from ImageNet and incorporating domain-specific enhancements such as stain normalization, image augmentation, and fine-tuned dense layers, the system was evaluated on benchmark datasets including Herlev, SIPaKMeD, and LBC. The model consistently achieved classification accuracies above 96.9%, with F1-scores peaking at 0.911 and lesion-level sensitivity exceeding 93.7% for high-grade (CIN2/3) abnormalities. Compared to traditional image processing pipelines and handcrafted-feature-based classifiers, this framework achieved a 4.8–5.4% improvement in diagnostic accuracy, while reducing inter-class misclassification in low-grade lesions. Integration of dropout regularization and adaptive learning rates enabled fast convergence and strong generalization across diverse cytological patterns. With inference latency below 180ms per image and scalable architecture for real-time deployment, the proposed system demonstrates clinical-grade reliability for large-scale cervical screening applications. Its modular design supports future integration of ensemble models and domain adaptation pipelines across varied staining protocols and cytology platforms.

title: Cross-Border Digital Operations for Enforceable Legislative Sovereignty Mechanisms
authors: Mahmood Ahmed Hamdi, Rasha Saad Abdalwahid, Raya Majid Alsharfa, Maytham Manfy Kadhum, Raghad Ali Hassan, Zain Al Abdeen Khaled Atiya
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Global Digital Activities under Legislative Sovereignty Enforcement States have more and more need to manage cross-border digital activity, and systems exist to help with that. Given the growing globalization of data flows and computer services, safeguarding legislative autonomy raises significant ethical questions. Systems that would handle jurisdictional conflicts, data privacy violations, or enforcement gaps resulting from the incompatibility of national laws with international digital operations are not currently in place. A lack of coordination, responsibility, and adaptability makes current models unable to keep up with the ever-shifting character of digital ecosystems. The reason for this inquiry proposes a multi-layered strategy comprising legislative intent mapping, cross-border regulatory APIs, and real-time data localization audits, known as the SOV-DOME framework (Sovereign Oversight and Verification for Digital Operations and Multinational Enforcement). The objective of this framework is to enhance digital sphere sovereignty. SOV-DOME enables governments to enforce compliance, exercise their legal authority, and facilitate intergovernmental collaboration without interfering with legitimate Internet trade. Its accordance engine, which employs artificial intelligence to validate operations, and its blockchain technology verification system guarantee openness and flexibility to new rules. Without sacrificing international digital cooperation, the results reveal that SOV-DOME significantly reduces jurisdictional ambiguity, increases legislative sovereignty in digital ecosystems, and enhances enforcement efficiency by 45 percent.

title: Building a Context-Aware Language Model for Translating Historical Texts
authors: Sri Marmoah, Farida Nurhasanah, David Treagust, Hasanin Alshamri, Ali S. Haleem, Bashar Yaser Almansour, Enas R. Alwaily, Mohammed Abdulsalam Alhayaly
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The exponential growth of digital news material has called for the creation of smart algorithms able to offer brief summaries to enable the fast absorption of information. Presented in this study is DeepDigest, a creative text summary tool built on deep learning meant to automatically generate news digests. The proposed model for semantic understanding uses a hybrid architecture combining a Pointer-Generator Network with Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT). This enables both extractive and abstractive summarizing to be done. A large-scale dataset of news articles published in several languages was gathered and processed to train and assess the algorithm's performance. DeepDigest scores very well on ROUGE-1, ROUGE-2, and ROUGE-L, confirming its value in preserving coherence and contextual significance. Experimental findings show that DeepDigest outperforms current baselines like TextRank and LSTM-based algorithms. Qualitative studies have also demonstrated that DeepDigest can provide more interesting and readable summaries. The survey results show that DeepDigest offers a means for the automatic summary of real-time news that is both efficient and scalable. This is important for content recommendation systems, digital journalism, and tailored news feeds. Future studies aiming at greatly enhancing the quality of summarization and its adaptability throughout a broad spectrum of material domains will mainly rely on the inclusion of reinforcement learning.

title: Enhancing Virtual Private Network (VPN) Security via Dynamic Key Rotation: A Theoretical and Partial Simulation Study
authors: Doaa S. Salman, Amjed Abbas Ahmed, Alaa Sabree Awad, Zahraa Haimeed Rasool, Haneen Siraj Ibrahim, Inbithaq Ahmed Shakir, Azhaar A. Shalal, Wael Yahya Yaseen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) are the cornerstone technology for secure remote access, but their dependence on static or rarely updated keys makes them vulnerable to emerging cyber threats. This paper proposes a dynamic key refreshment approach for the VPN, in which encryption keys are automatically updated regularly and no service is interrupted during the refreshing period. Also provide a theoretical framework explaining its advantages in terms of the reduction of the key exposure window and increase in resistance against brute-force attacks. Simulated using Cisco Packet Tracer v8.2.2, it shows the network-level possibility of maintaining the connectivity and the concept of the tunnel recreating in the rekey operation. The results show that the dynamic key rotation greatly strengthens the security of VPNs against present attacks, thus supporting its incorporation into current VPN protocols.

title: Secure Multi-Object Detection and Tracking via YOLOv7 Integration with Particle Filter Algorithms
authors: Tholfiqar Z. Ismail, Qusai AL-Durrah, Bibin Vincent, Abdumutalliev Abdulakhad Abdusamad Ugli, Aswathy SU, Atul Dattatraya Ghate
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Multi-object detection and tracking are a fundamental task in computer vision, especially in surveillance, autonomous systems, and robotics. YOLOv7, a state-of-the-art real-time object detection model, offers high-speed performance and accuracy, which faces challenges in maintaining object identity over time. Existing tracking methods often suffer from drift, occlusion, and identity switching due to noise, dynamic environments, and lack of temporal consistency. To address these issues, here is the proposed SMODT-Y7PF (Secure Multi-Object Detection and Tracking via YOLOv7 with Particle Filter), a hybrid framework integrating YOLOv7 for robust detection and Particle Filter algorithms for probabilistic tracking and motion estimation. This combination improves identity preservation and resilience against occlusion and noise. The proposed method uses YOLOv7 to detect multiple objects in each frame and employs Particle Filters to maintain object trajectories by estimating the posterior distribution over time. This integration ensures secure and consistent tracking in real-time applications. Experimental results show that SMODT-Y7PF significantly improves tracking accuracy, reduces identity switches, and enhances robustness in dynamic and cluttered environments, making it ideal for smart surveillance and autonomous navigation systems.

title: 3D Cardiac MRI Segmentation Using Spatio-Temporal Convolutional Neural Networks with Shape-Aware Loss Functions
authors: Nusaibah Khalid Abdulmajeed Alsalihi, Ayad Jawad Kadaim, Abdul Razzaq Oleiwi Jasim, Maytham T. Qasim, Sazan Kamal Sulaiman, Mashael Taha Hamad, Zahraa Najah Salman, Abdulnaser M. Fashakh, Mays Qasim Jebur
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research proposes a high-precision spatio-temporal deep learning framework for 3D cardiac MRI segmentation, integrating dynamic feature encoding with anatomically guided supervision. Leveraging a hybrid architecture based on 3D convolutional layers and ConvLSTM modules, the model captures both spatial structures and temporal motion patterns across full cardiac cycles. Shape-aware loss functions—including signed distance function (SDF) loss and boundary-based constraints—are incorporated to ensure anatomical fidelity, reducing segmentation artifacts and improving topological correctness. Evaluated across benchmark datasets such as ACDC, M&Ms, and UK Biobank, the model consistently achieved Dice scores above 92.1% and reduced Hausdorff distances to 5.2mm. Compared to conventional 2D/3D CNNs, this framework showed a 3.7–4.5% increase in segmentation accuracy and an 18–25% reduction in boundary leakage, particularly in complex regions such as the apex and basal slices. The suggested technique accomodates strong generalization over pathological cases, ensuring temporal coherence and clinical applicability. Its encoder-decoder framework is still flexible to different sequence lengths and resolutions to facilitate scalable deployment in real-time diagnostic and surgical planning applications.

title: Longformer-Powered Sop Assessment and University Admission Likelihood Predictor
authors: Dhruv Nariani, Dhruv Kothari, Atharva Narvekar, Divya Shah, Monika Mangla, Khushbu Trehan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Admission to post graduation courses across reputed universities is a challenging and cumbersome task. The traditional SOP evaluation is subjective and may be biased also. Hence, authors in this work, aim to propose an automated AI- based SOP evaluation framework using a finetuned Longformer based deep-learning model for multicriteria assessment of SOP. Further, the work also presents a University Likelihood Predictor, an extension to predict the probability of an applicant being admitted to a university. Experimental results show that the proposed model achieves promising performance metrics in distinguishing strong and weak SOPs. The obtained results strengthen the belief regarding employment of proposed model in real life.

title: Automated Identification of Grapevine Leaf Diseases Using Supervised Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Kuldeep Bhimsingh Thakur, Ravindra Sugdeo Sonavane, Siddharth Shravan Kumar Singh, Anaya Prasad Chitnis, Bhoomi Jitendra Maurya, Ajeet Ayodhya Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Plant diseases are essential to crop production, resulting in worldwide economic losses. Detection of plant leaf diseases promptly and accurately is crucial to mitigating their impact and ensuring crop well-being. The proposed research presents a grape plant leaf disease classification technique using supervised machine learning algorithms. The database includes grape leaf images categorized into healthy and disease classes, and preprocessing techniques are used to enhance the quality of the photos and detect key features. Texture-based features from the Gray-Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM) & Stationary Wavelet Transform SWT are essential in separating disease patterns. Experimental results prove that Gradient Boosting performs better than other classifiers at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex> accuracy, followed by Support Vector Machine (SVM) using an RBF kernel with 88 % accuracy. The research emphasizes the benefits of ensemble learning in enhancing classification performance while overcoming issues like overfitting and computational complexity. The proposed method offers an efficient and scalable automated vineyard disease detection solution, enabling timely intervention and precision agriculture. Future research can investigate deep learning-based architectures and IoT-based real-time disease monitoring systems for higher accuracy and feasible deployment in agricultural environments.

title: AI-Powered Adaptive Firewall Using Suricata and Large Language Models
authors: N Ragavenderan, Saara Unnathi R, Ramakanth Kumar P
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: With the proliferation of connected devices and constantly evolving attack techniques, modern networks require security systems that can see the threat landscape, understand what the events mean and respond autonomously. This paper presents an AI-powered adaptive firewall that combines deep packet inspection via the open-source Suricata IDS/IPS with large-language-model (LLM) reasoning and the FreeBSD/macOS PF firewall. Suricata inspects network traffic in real time, logs suspicious events and supplies structured alerts in JSON form. These alerts are parsed, summarized using an LLM and then translated into precise firewall table commands. The adaptive firewall dynamically blocks or unblocks IP addresses without manual intervention, generates periodic PDF reports for administrators and exposes a web dashboard and CLI for naturallanguage commands. As evaluated in Section VI, by leveraging LLM-based summarization and dynamic PF tables, the system reduces time to mitigation and lowers false positives compared with static rule sets.

title: Realization of Optimized TSPC Prescaler Circuit
authors: Pranav Sharma N, Rathan C, Tarun Prasanna, Tulasi Prasad H, Shylashree N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The demand for high-speed, low-power clocking in digital integrated circuits has made True Single-Phase Clocking (TSPC) a preferred design choice for its simplicity and efficiency. This paper presents the design and optimization of a 2/3 frequency prescaler using TSPC logic. The methodology involves schematic design, transistor-level tuning, and performance optimization using the Cadence Virtuoso platform. Critical paths were identified and optimized through improved layout and timing analysis. The proposed design consumes 32 transistors without compromising performance. It also improves timing efficiency, with setup delay of 1.002 ns and hold delay of 0.279 ns. Although power consumption increases slightly to 0.085 W it remains within acceptable limits for high-speed systems. The use of NAND and AND logic supports modular TSPC-based frequency division, making the design a strong fit for next-generation clock distribution networks.

title: Advanced Threat Analysis and Cyber Defense Using Intelligent Systems
authors: Yashvanth P S, Poornima Kulkarni
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The escalating complexity of modern cyber threats targeting networks, systems, and software ecosystems necessitates the development of unified, intelligent defense mechanisms. This research proposes a comprehensive framework for Advanced Threat Analysis and Cyber Defense Using Intelligent Systems, integrating multi-domain data sources such as intrusion detection logs, malware binaries, and vulnerability feeds to strengthen cybersecurity resilience. Utilizing deep learning models CNNs for malware analysis, LSTMs for network data, and Transformer-based architectures for vulnerability assessment the system employs a unified pipeline to enhance accuracy and efficiency in identifying and mitigating cyber threats. The project leverages benchmark datasets (CIC-IDS2017, EMBER, NVD) alongside Python, PyTorch, FastAPI, and Streamlit for implementation. SHAP is integrated for explainability. Evaluations demonstrate improved accuracy, robustness, and interpretability across metrics such as Precision, Recall, F1-Score, and AUC-ROC. The proposed framework shows promising applications in enterprise security, government defense, and intelligent security platforms.

title: LoRa-Enabled Edge-IoT with Attentional Bi-LSTM for Predictive Gas, Environmental, and Health Monitoring
authors: Mona Saghafi Binabaj, Seyed Amirhossein Farjadi, Sara Ershadi-Nasab
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: This paper presents a low-cost and intelligent Internet of Things (IoT) system for gas, environmental, and health monitoring in hazardous industrial environments. The proposed system integrates low-power sensing modules with LoRa communication and an Attentional Bi-LSTM model deployed at the edge. Distributed sensor nodes, built on Arduino microcontrollers, collect temperature, humidity, and gas concentration data using DHT and MQ-series sensors. These readings are transmitted via LoRa to a NanoPi Neo Plus2 gateway, where the Attentional Bi-LSTM model performs multivariate time-series forecasting for early hazard prediction by capturing temporal dependencies and dynamically focusing on critical features. Local edge processing eliminates cloud dependency, reduces latency, and enables immediate visual and auditory alerts through reverse LoRa communication in case of potential risks. Experimental evaluation demonstrates stable LoRa transmission exceeding 1 km in obstructed environments at a baud rate of 9600 bps, along with high predictive accuracy and robust system performance. By combining LoRa-based wireless sensing with edge-deployed deep learning, the proposed system provides a scalable, energy- efficient, and practical solution for proactive gas detection and environmental and health monitoring in safety-critical industrial applications.

title: Hybrid Transformer-GNN Model for Multi-Document Summarization
authors: Krishna Dheeravath, Pallati Narsimhulu, Premkumar Chithaluru, Md. Aleem Pasha, Sunil Reddy Goli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Multi-document summarization (MDS) remains a challenging task due to the complexity of extracting, synthesizing, and generating coherent and non-redundant summaries from multiple related documents. While Deep Learning (DL) techniques, particularly Transformer-based models, have shown significant advancements, they often struggle with redundancy elimination, coherence preservation, and contextual relevance. In this research, we propose a novel Hybrid Transformer-GNN Framework (HTGF) that integrates Transformer networks with Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to capture document relationships, semantic dependencies, and content importance effectively. Additionally, we incorporate a Reinforcement Learning (RL)-based reward mechanism to optimize summary fluency, coherence, and informativeness. Our framework employs hierarchical attention mechanisms to prioritize key sentences and a novel redundancy-aware contrastive loss function to improve abstraction. We evaluate our model on benchmark datasets and compare its performance against state-of-the-art methods using widely accepted evaluation metrics. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing models in terms of ROUGE scores, coherence, and factual consistency. This research provides a robust and scalable solution to MDS, offering new insights into DL-driven text summarization.

title: Comparative Analysis of Genetic Algorithms and Multi-Variant PSO Approaches for Fuzzy-Guided Portfolio Management
authors: Cemal Öztürk, Fatmana Şentürk
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: This study conducts an extensive evaluation of metaheuristic optimization algorithms that employ fuzzy logic to solve portfolio optimization problems. The research evaluates DJIA 30 component stocks through five optimization methods which include Genetic Algorithm (GA), Standard Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Adaptive PSO, Parallel PSO and Island Model PSO. The methodology implements a fuzzy inference system that uses risk and Sharpe ratio inputs to generate unified fitness values for portfolio evaluation. The experimental results demonstrate that Adaptive PSO achieves the optimal balance between computational speed and solution quality through its maximum Sharpe ratio (1.088) and Sortino ratio (1.075) in out-of-sample testing. The parallel implementation methods led to high computational expenses without producing superior results. The optimization methods of Markowitz and Maximum Sharpe performed exceptionally well during in-sample testing but produced unstable results when tested out-of-sample. The research demonstrates that adaptive parameter adjustment provides superior benefits than increased computational complexity for medium-sized portfolio optimization problems and fuzzy logic enables successful management of multiple portfolio objectives.

title: Design a Mobile PM2.5 Sensor Device and Calibration Using Machine Learning Models
authors: Anita Karim Ghassabpour, Hatam Abdoli, Mohammad Amin Kamali
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: Air pollution is an important threat to the environment and public health. Raising awareness of air pollution among city managers and citizens can help to mitigate the problem. However, data acquired from stationary sensors frequently fails to give complete coverage of the metropolis. Furthermore, the expensive cost of the equipment associated with these stations restricts their deployment to all sections of the city. To address this constraint, this study describes the design and construction of a transportable sensing device equipped with low-cost sensors that can collect air pollutants from a variety of metropolitan areas. A fundamental issue with low-cost sensors is their limited accuracy, which necessitates calibration and improvement. In this study, after designing and building a mobile sensing device, it was deployed. Machine learning models, such as linear regression, KernelRidge, XGBoost, LightGBM, and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), were used to calibrate the PM2.5 data from the PMS5003 sensor. The results show that the XGBoost model had the highest accuracy and best performance for PM2.5 calibration, with mean squared error (MSE) and root mean squared error (RMSE) values of 2.83 and 1.68, respectively. The built mobile device was then used for six days to monitor pollution in numerous streets in Hamedan, allowing for a field evaluation.

title: Fault tolerant multi-stack hydrogen fuel cell system for maritime applications
authors: Jihane Ait El Mahjoub, Jean-Christophe Olivier, Mohamed Machmoum, Salah Laghrouche
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: With the growing demand for clean energy, hydrogen fuel cells have emerged as a viable solution. This paper explores the implementation of a multi-stack hydrogen fuel cell system applied to maritime transports. The proposed configuration employs parallelized three-level boost converters. It allows the increase of the voltage ratio between the fuel cell stacks and the 1 kV DC-bus voltage. It also enables the system to meet the 1 MW power demand imposed by the naval application. The first part is focused on the system’s behavior in normal conditions. The second section evaluates the natural reliability and robustness of the power converter by considering fault scenarios.

title: Technology for Building a Maritime Knowledge Large Language Knowledge Model Based on Efficient Parameter Fine-tuning
authors: Miaozang Zhang, Yazhen Du, Yi Wei, Yang Cao, Fanbin Meng, Chunyan Hou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: In response to the complex and irregular knowledge acquisition requirements of an intelligent navigation assistance decision-making system during ship operations across various scenarios, this study investigates the construction of a maritime knowledge large language model (LLM) based on efficient parameter fine-tuning. The research aims to overcome challenges in building maritime knowledge fine-tuning datasets and constructing LLMs using efficient parameter adjustment techniques. By integrating current scenario information with maritime expertise, the system provides professional support for intelligent navigation assistance decision-making across different waterways, navigation scenarios, and operational tasks in coastal and inland river environments.This study developed a custom dataset of typical maritime knowledge for fine-tuning purposes. Leveraging pre-trained models such as Qwen and Deepseek, along with LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) fine-tuning technology, multiple maritime knowledge LLMs were constructed. A comprehensive evaluation framework combining both subjective and objective metrics was established to assess the performance of these models. Evaluation criteria included ROUGE scores, BLEU scores, and response times for knowledge-based question answering.The results demonstrated that the maritime knowledge LLMs are capable of providing accurate answers to users' inquiries across various scenarios, thereby effectively supporting navigation assistance decision-making processes.

title: Digital Twins in Manufacturing: Analysis of Challenges, Successes, and Future Advances
authors: Adam Dooley, William O’Brien, Mihai Penica, Fiona Boyle, Sean McGrath, Eoin O’Connell
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: Digital twins (DTs) are transforming the manufacturing sector by enabling real-time monitoring, predictive maintenance, and process optimization. This paper systematically reviews the ten most cited research papers on digital twins in manufacturing, identifying key themes, successes, challenges, and future research directions. While rooted in the manufacturing domain, the findings reveal insights highly transferable to renewable energy and power systems—particularly in areas such as data-driven decision-making, AIdriven predictive modelling, and cyber-physical system integration. Notably, the technologies and methodologies explored—such as real-time data synchronization, simulation-based planning, and AI-enhanced analytics—can support smart grid optimization, renewable energy forecasting, and infrastructure resilience. The paper advocates for greater crosssector adoption of digital twin frameworks, particularly in energy system planning, energy efficiency strategies, and sustainability-driven innovation. This positions digital twins as not only pivotal for Industry 4.0 but also as enablers of the global transition toward secure, efficient, and intelligent energy ecosystems.

title: Efficient and Secure Data Sharing With Mobile Crowdsensing in Internet of Vehicles
authors: Songnian Zhang, Rongxing Lu, Hui Zhu, Yandong Zheng, Fengwei Wang, Jun Shao, Hui Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Promoting data sharing is one of the critical strategies for thriving in the digital age, and enormous demand for location-based services propels data sharing in the Internet of Vehicles (IoV), particularly in the case of integrating mobile crowdsensing (MCS). However, data security and privacy concerns are increasingly posing serious challenges to the development of data sharing. Although a slew of works have been designed to achieve secure data sharing in IoV, they are inadequate for addressing the privacy issues identified in the data sharing model and often suffer from performance limitations. In this work, we propose an efficient and secure data sharing scheme under the MCS-integrated IoV. Specifically, motivated by the distributed point function (DPF), we design a double-output DPF and leverage it to construct a secure updating scheme that protects full privacy while ensuring high efficiency. Then, based on the XOR filter and a series of subtle transformations, we carefully design a secure spatial test protocol to determine whether a point falls within an arbitrary spatial range efficiently. Afterward, we propose a secure retrieving protocol by using the idea of shared shuffling, in which the offline sub-protocol is presented to generate random masks, and the online sub-protocol is designed to quickly retrieve the desired data items. After formally proving the security of our proposed schemes, we experimentally evaluate their efficiency by comparing them with the alternative solutions, and the results indicate that our proposed schemes offer superior performance, particularly in terms of communication overheads.

title: A Low-Power Single-Ended SAR ADC With Energy-Efficient Differential Switching for Ultrafast X-Ray Imagers
authors: A. Pena-Perez, H. Hernandez-Herrera, L. Fanals-i-Batllori, L. Rota, H. Kim, A. Gupta, B. Markovic, G. Liu, F. Mele, P. King, C. Bakalis, D. Doering, N. Mishra, A. Dragone
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Circuits and Systems
abstract: This work presents a SAR ADC architecture designed for single-ended-to-differential conversion with low-energy switching and area efficiency. By incorporating top and bottom sampling techniques, the architecture achieves seamless conversion without the need for extra DAC hardware. It offers configurable fully-differential or single-ended modes by means of Vcm-based switching. With 75% reduced total capacitance compared to the conventional method, consistent energy savings are achieved across configurations. Implemented in 130nm CMOS, this design features an array of 48 ADCs and custom on-chip voltage references integrated within the SparkPix-S ASIC, a device tailored for X-ray imagers. With a nominal sampling rate of 5 MSps and 1.2V supply voltage, the achieved SNDR is 54.5dB, with +0.98/-0.86 LSB of DNL and +0.83/-1.26 LSB of INL. The core SAR ADC average power consumption is 96μW, resulting in a FOM of 40.1 fj/conv-step, all within a compact active area of 0.0212mm2.

title: Deep Learning-Based Decoding and Feature Visualization of Motor Imagery Speeds from EEG Signals_supp1-3645617.pdf
authors: Mitsuhiro Hayashibe
publish: N/A
abstract: Objective: This study investigates the neurodynamics of motor imagery speed decoding using deep learning. Methods: The EEGConformer model was employed to analyze EEG signals and decode different speeds of imagined movements. Explainable artificial intelligence techniques were used to identify the temporal and spatial patterns within the EEG data related to imagined speeds, focusing on the role of specific frequency bands and cortical regions. Results: The model successfully decoded and extracted EEG patterns associated with different motor imagery speeds; however, the classification accuracy was limited and high only for a few participants. The analysis highlighted the importance of alpha and beta oscillations and identified key cortical areas, including the frontal, motor, and occipital cortices, in speed decoding. Additionally, repeated motor imagery elicited steady-state movement-related potentials at the fundamental frequency, with the strongest responses observed at the second harmonic. Conclusions: Motor imagery speed is decodable, though classification performance remains limited. The results highlight the involvement of specific frequency bands and cortical regions, as well as steady-state responses, in encoding MI speed.

title: Traversability-Aware Legged Navigation by Learning From Real-World Visual Data_supp1-3645885.mp4
authors: Hongbo Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: The enhanced mobility brought by legged locomotion empowers quadrupedal robots to navigate through complex and unstructured environments. However, optimizing agile locomotion while accounting for the varying energy costs of traversing different terrains remains an open challenge. Most previous work focuses on planning trajectories with traversability cost estimation based on human-labeled environmental features. This human-centric approach is insufficient because it does not account for the varying capabilities of the robot locomotion controllers over challenging terrains. To address this, we introduce a novel real-world learning pipeline that unifies offline demonstrations, online reinforcement learning, and multi-modal perception to achieve robust legged navigation. The framework employs multiple training stages to develop a planner that guides the robot in avoiding obstacles and hardto- traverse terrains while reaching its goals. We first develop a novel traversability estimator in a robot-centric manner. The training of the navigation planner is directly performed in the real world using a sample efficient reinforcement learning method. With the proposed method, a quadrupedal robot learns to perform traversability-aware navigation through realworld interactions in diverse offroad and unstructured environments. Moreover, the robot demonstrates the ability to generalize the learned navigation skills to unseen scenarios.

title: Coordinated Restoration Strategy for High- and Extra High-Voltage Transmission Networks Considering HVDC Integration and Emergency Repair Scheduling
authors: Changming Chen, Tianhan Zhang, Feixiong Chen, Changxu Jiang, Zhenguo Shao, Chutong Wang, Yucui Wang, Jianwei Wu, Yuxuan Huang, Zhenzhi Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems
abstract: With the increasing frequency of large-scale black-start events in recent years, the rapid restoration of high-voltage transmission networks has become a critical technical challenge. This paper proposes a coordinated restoration strategy for 500 kV extra-high-voltage transmission networks (EHVTNs) and 220 kV high-voltage transmission networks (HVTNs), incorporating HVDC integration and emergency repair crew (ERC) scheduling. First, an integration and operational model for HVDCs is developed using the adjoint network method, which transforms complex self-impedance constraints into a mixed-integer linear programming formulation, enabling accurate and efficient HVDC integration. Second, fault repair priority indicators—derived from topological connectivity, reachability, and power flow betweenness—are introduced. Based on these indicators, an ERC scheduling optimization model is formulated to prioritize critical fault repairs and minimize overall restoration time. Then, by incorporating the synergistic effects of HVDC integration and ERC scheduling, a bi-level restoration optimization framework based on model predictive control is proposed to coordinate the restoration of EHVTNs and HVTNs. Finally, case studies on an actual 379-bus power system in China are conducted, and simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method reduces restoration time and improves restoration performance compared to conventional approaches, thereby providing effective technical support for rapid grid restoration following large-scale blackout events.

title: Large AI Model Enabled Asynchronous Service Provisioning for Future Wireless Networks
authors: Xiaoxu Ren, Qixin Li, Haipeng Yao, Hongyang Du, Chao Qiu, Xiaofei Wang, Dusit Niyato
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Future wireless networks, such as 6G, are envisioned to deliver ultra-reliable, high-quality services with ultra-low latency and dynamic connectivity across heterogeneous environments, driving the adoption of edge–cloud collaborative architectures. Within this paradigm, container-based microservices, with their lightweight, modular, and portable characteristics, offer an effective foundation for scalable and adaptive service provisioning in heterogeneous wireless networks. The layered architecture of microservices facilitates efficient resource management through layer scheduling and caching. However, dynamic service requests and diverse container layers pose major challenges for layer-aware service provisioning in future wireless environments. These include time-exceeded offline service provisioning, tangled microservice orchestration, and layer cache redundancy. To address these challenges, we propose Tri-Ring, an asynchronous online provisioning framework for future wireless networks, empowered by large AI models (LAMs). The framework optimizes request dispatching, orchestration, and layer updates across three timescales. At the small timescale, we formulate request dispatching as a linear programming (LP) subproblem. At the medium timescale, the estimator-assessor algorithm manages microservice orchestration, where a diffusion-enhanced prediction model serves as the estimator to predict layer caching strategies. Moreover, submodular optimization serves as the assessor to determine deployment and scheduling. At the large timescale, we introduce the age of layer (AoL) to guide the pruning of infrequently accessed cached layers to reduce storage overhead. Comprehensive evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrates that Tri-Ring outperforms existing baselines, increasing utility by 44.78%, reducing microservice startup time by 78.64%, and optimizing storage resources by 36.38%.

title: Cyber Resilience in Islanded AC Microgrid: A Cryptography-Based Approach
authors: Saurabh Prabhakar, Suman Rath, Bijaya Ketan Panigrahi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: The incorporation of information and communication technologies (ICT) into microgrid systems has considerably improved their control and operational efficiency. However, this integration has exposed the microgrid systems to cyber threats that can potentially compromise the security and reliability of this critical infrastructure. To address these challenges, this article proposes a robust algorithm incorporating hash-based message authentication code (HMAC) in microgrid systems for cyberattack detection. The HMAC-based detection algorithm ensures the integrity and authenticity of all transmitted messages by embedding cryptographic tags in communication protocols. Our framework assigns a unique symmetric key to the sender and receiver module, which it uses to generate and verify HMAC tags, enabling it to easily identify any anomalies indicative of cyberattacks. For mitigation of attacks, a Communication Error Counter (CEC) is calculated and embedded in the secondary control equation to reduce the communication weights. The analysis is done on an islanded cyber-physical microgrid embedded with a controller area network (CAN) protocol for real-time communication. The performance of the proposed algorithm is verified in MATLAB simulation, and real-time evaluation is done in the OPALRT simulator, which shows our approach achieves high detection accuracy and robustness against various types of cyberattacks.

title: A Super-Resolution Forward-Looking Imaging Technique and FPGA Implementation for FMCW Radar
authors: Yanjun Zhang, Yan Huang, Jun Tao, Ciyuan Zheng, Xutao Yu, Xinqi Hu, Zhanye Chen, Hui Zhang, Wei Hong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: With the development of frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) radar, its forward-looking imaging capability has gained prominence. However, traditional super-resolution methods based on direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation often fail to deliver satisfactory results in complex scenarios with many targets occupying multiple bins. This is because many DOA methods process individual range bins independently, ignoring target correlations and resulting in significant information loss. Additionally, some DOA estimation methods generate outputs that do not reflect the spatial spectrum of target intensity, thereby making them unsuitable for imaging tasks. Furthermore, these methods typically involve high computational complexity, limiting their applicability to scenarios with simple processing devices. In this study, we introduce a novel low-rank and sparse recovery forward-looking imaging (LSFI) approach for FMCW radar, establishing a new forward-looking imaging model. This method formulates an optimization problem that integrates both target and background features within an overall image perspective and resolves it using the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM), replacing the iterative operations along the range dimension required by most methods with matrix operations and thereby significantly reducing computational complexity. Moreover, the proposed method has been successfully implemented on field programmable gate array (FPGA) platform and has demonstrated excellent super-resolution imaging performance in extensive experiments, including complex intelligent driving scenarios.

title: Dynamic Equivalency Model for Inter-Connected Systems
authors: Paul Muia Musyoka, Cosmas Mutugi Kiruki, Peter Musau Moses
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: Identifying coherent machines using online measurement data, where multi-area configurations are prioritized for the external network models can provide a breakthrough for modeling dynamic equivalents in multi-area environments. Dynamic equivalents that consider high penetration levels of Renewable Sources (RES) and integration of Flexible AC Transmission System (FACTS) simultaneously, possess high probabilities of correlating the dynamic equivalent behavior to the real multi-machine network in key performance indicators such as clearing times, and computational efficiency. Simulated annealing algorithm blends well in solving the grouping of the coherent machines based on Metropolis Criterion indicated in this modeling of the equivalence process, thus guaranteeing optimal solution for arbitrary systems, especially, if slow cooling is achieved to enforce regularity. The test results demonstrate computational efficiency, faster, simple and ease of carrying out simulations based on the dynamic equivalents, when planning large network expansions.
