title: A Novel Procedure to Forecast Annual RES Curtailments in the Spanish Power System
authors: E Lobato, F. M Echavarren, L. Rouco, M. Duvison, L. Díez-Maroto
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: Renewable energy sources (RES) curtailment in continental Spain occurs when RES generation causes overloads incompatible with Spanish security criteria. Forecasting annual RES spillage becomes critical for promoters. This paper proposes a novel procedure to forecast annual RES curtailments of a future plant to be deployed at a certain location of the Spanish peninsular real-life power system where real-life limited information is available. The procedure comprises three steps: (a) selection of a most critical reference scenario representative of both high demand and RES production, (b) detection and solution of overloads with minimum RES curtailment, and (c) intersection of computed maximum RES injection with load-duration curve. The computation of the short-term annual energy spillage of a future 300 MW solar photovoltaic (PV) power plant to be deployed in Aragon autonomous region (northeast of Spain) is provided as case study to illustrate the simplicity and adequacy of the method.

title: Federated Learning for Secure Multi-Vendor E-Commerce Recommendations with Privacy-Preserving User Data
authors: Dayal Pyari, A. Vini Infanta, S. Suma Christal Mary, Nusrat Hamid Shah, Sajiv G, B Kiran Bala
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Recommendation systems play a key role in creating engagement on e-commerce platforms and improving sales, although such solutions are compromised due to security and data risks created by centralized architectures. In this paper, a type of privacy-preserving multi-horn collaboration capable of handling millions of vendors is presented, BlockFed, a Federated Learning framework designed to fit in large multivendor e-commerce scenarios. BlockFed uses Differential Privacy and Homomorphic Encryption to protect user data when training a model using a decentralized mechanism. To guarantee clarity and confidence between rival sales personnel, a Blockchain-based safe gathering is utilised. Experimental findings show that BlockFed records a high F1- score of 98.8 percent and zero privacy leakage, which provides a great privacy performance tradeoff. It is also modular and decentralized, which allows scaling easily with the participation of more vendors without either affecting performance. The suggested framework enables various vendors to jointly train a cross-domain recommendation model without sharing sensitive data, and as such, it has the potential to be implemented in a way to enable e-commerce personalization across platforms to be efficient, secure, and compliant with regulations.

title: Challenges of Artificial Intelligence in Tax Administrations and its Impact on Government Revenues
authors: Abbas Moufarrej Fahel Yacob, Raed Theyab Ahmed, Shamil S. Awad, Mutaz Ali Sabbr, Saeed Hameed Aldulaimi, Marwan Abdeldayem
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The world witnessed rapid development following the industrial revolution, especially within the arena of data and communications technology, as well as within the data innovation and data collection, and counterfeit insights speaks to one of the foremost critical shapes of these advancements within the area of information technology and technology. It should be noted here that artificial intelligence is a broad field of study in various scientific, technical, and even humanitarian disciplines because it seeks to build intelligent systems that rely on specific algorithms that mimic human behavior and ways of thinking in a way that is able to analyze and scrutinize information and data according to the need envisioned from them. As part of our research, we aim to demonstrate the impact of tax administrations’ use of artificial intelligence in tax operations, with the hope that it will reduce reliance on human effort in investigating and collecting tax data or preparing tax reports, or verifying the reduction or reassurance of taxpayers (taxpayers) of the concerns they experience as a result of its use. Artificial intelligence techniques within the framework of the tax relationship. The use of artificial intelligence also has potential effects on tax systems that tax policy makers should take into account from the legal, technical, and economic aspects. The research dealt with explaining that impact as a result of the use of artificial intelligence by tax administrations, as well as the areas in which it can be used, and the stages that the use of intelligence has reached. The research also addressed the principles that should be taken into account when using artificial intelligence in tax affairs, in addition to explaining the benefits of its use.

title: Cloud Computing Framework based on Quantum-Neuromorphic Technology
authors: Surya Bhushan Kumar, Kuntal Mukherjee, Swapan Dey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Based on the Pay-As-You-Use model, Cloud Computing has opened a new era of shared-based web services for the end users. This cutting-edge technology comprises three important layers, namely, SaaS (Software as a Service), PaaS (Platform as a Service), and IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service). The SaaS layer provides different types of software applications for the end users, such as Google Workspace and Microsoft 365. The PaaS layer offers the development platform and tools, libraries, etc., for designing, developing, running, and managing applications on the cloud server, for instance, Google App Engine, Heroku, Microsoft Azure App Service, etc. The IaaS layer provides customizable infrastructure on demand. This layer manages the actual infrastructure using Infrastructure Management Software, which is called the Virtualization technique. It is observed that “Infrastructure” actually means a collection of the classical computers. Hence, the existing cloud computing applications finally run on the classical computers. The major limitations of the classical computers are that they can follow scaling style only horizontally and cannot significantly have upgraded the scaling style vertically. Due to its horizontal scale, it is more costly, the higher bandwidth rate consumes more energy, and has become complex in nature. To address this issue, this endeavor has proposed a new framework for cloud computing, where the IaaS will have only Quantum Computers and Neuromorphic Computers. Quantum and neuromorphic computers can easily scale-up vertically using their unique property, namely, superposition, entanglement, increasing the density of neural networks, Wafer-scale integration techniques, etc. In this way, the proposed framework for cloud computing will be more efficient in the context of energy consumption, bandwidth rate and computational power.

title: AI-Driven Beamforming for 5G Networks Using Intelligent Antenna Arrays
authors: Manvith K C, Bhagya R, Bharathi R, Usha Padma, S G Shivaprasad Yadav
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Hybrid beamforming has emerged as an effective solution for high-frequency multi-antenna communication systems, enabling high spectral efficiency with reduced hardware cost. This work presents an AI-assisted hybrid beamforming framework that integrates traditional signal processing with deep learning for multi-user MIMO scenarios. The proposed system models a patch antenna array, enhanced channel conditions, and realistic line-of-sight/non-line-of-sight propagation to generate training datasets via optimal precoder computation. A neural network is designed to predict complex beamforming weights from estimated angles of arrival, using a correlation-based loss to align with optimal solutions. The framework also incorporates a direction-of-arrival estimator based on the MUSIC algorithm, enabling a hybrid approach where AI-predicted and classical beamforming weights can be compared or combined. Numerical simulations demonstrate that the proposed method achieves high beamforming accuracy and robustness to noise while significantly reducing the computational burden compared to purely optimization-based designs.

title: Early-Stage Detection of ICMPv6 Flooding Using Decision Trees in Smart Home Systems (Work in Progress)
authors: Adi Hermansyah, Deris Stiawan, Ahmad Heryanto, Nurul Afifah, Dhani Saputra, Ferry Astika Saputra, Adi Wibowo, Didi Rosiyadi, Rahmad Budiarto
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: The ICMPv6 "Packet Too Big" flooding attack is a significant threat to IPv6 network security, particularly when exploiting vulnerabilities in the automatic address configuration mechanism based on EUI-64 and the Privacy Extension feature. In this scenario, the attacker uses a fixed source address to send a large volume of malicious ICMPv6 packets to various destination addresses derived from the same address structure. This technique takes advantage of weaknesses in the handling of "Packet Too Big" messages and the deterministic nature of the EUI-64 format, potentially causing the target system to become overwhelmed and suffer from degraded network performance. This study utilizes a simulated dataset based on the described scenario to detect the attack using the decision tree algorithm. The evaluation results demonstrate that the algorithm effectively identifies attack patterns, achieving a test accuracy of 92.37%, with a precision of 100% for the Normal class and 86.76% for the Flood class. The recall for the Normal class is 84.73%, while the Flood class reaches 100%. The F1-score is 91.73% for the Normal class and 92.93% for the Flood class, indicating the model's strong ability to balance precision and recall across both classes.

title: Secured Routing System Combining Stop-and-Wait Protocol, OSPF, Encryption Techniques, and TCP Reno for Error-Free Data Transmission
authors: Viraj Bhat B, Yadunandan. V, Vrushank M Hosamath, Kiran V
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents a simulation framework for secure and reliable data transmission in dynamic networks. It integrates OSPF routing using Dijkstra's algorithm, AESRSA hybrid encryption for confidentiality, Stop-and-Wait ARQ for reliable delivery, and TCP Reno for congestion control. The system models a packet-switched network under variable conditions and we see that average throughput is 395.5 bytes and average RTT is 0.0070 seconds when packet loss is low, making it suitable for industrial IoT and mission-critical applications.

title: LLM-Powered Synthetic Data Modeling for Self-Emulsifying Drug Delivery Systems
authors: Samiul Islam Niloy, Md Rahat Kader Khan, Nourhan Mostafa, Eman A. Ashour, Kasem Khalil
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: The formulation of self-emulsifying drug delivery systems (SEDDS) represents a pivotal advancement in improving the oral bioavailability of poorly water-soluble pharmaceutical compounds. Although traditional SEDDS development has predominantly relied on empirical methodologies, modern formulation science faces critical challenges, including limited experimental datasets, intricate formulation constraints, and the need for accurate predictive modeling of key quality attributes. In response to these limitations, this study proposes a novel Drug Formulation Agent (DFA) that integrates the generative capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) to synthesize realistic data, alongside a dual-task machine learning framework designed to concurrently predict nanoparticle size classification and drug release profiles. The proposed approach emphasizes both the quantitative evaluation of synthetic data quality and the predictive reliability of the machine learning models. Experimental results across three distinct testing scenarios reveal that Support Vector Machine (SVM) consistently outperforms other models, achieving the highest accuracy across all evaluated performance metrics. This study demonstrates the potential of LLM-guided synthetic data generation and predictive modeling to significantly enhance the efficiency and reliability of SEDDS development.

title: Leveraging Generative AI for Proactive Customer Churn Management in the Telecommunications Sector
authors: Agus Laksono, Mohd Yazid Idris, Farhan Muhamed, Deris Stiawan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Customer churn creates a significant threat to the profit and continued existence of telecommunication firms; however, my research focuses on Customers. When using traditional churn prediction models, customers are typically identified as having churned after they have had longer opportunities to take action. This research introduces a new GAN-based model specialized in GenAI for optimizing management of customer churn processing, where it is possible to proactively recognize churn predictors, create adaptive retention schemes, and adjust indicators during shifts in customer behavior. Specifically, we present a novel framework that combines Large Language Models (LLMs) in Textual Feature Engineering (TFE) with Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) to manipulate various customer data, model churn scenarios, and enhance intervention strategies. For our study, we utilized telecommunication data from Indonesia, comprising 1 million instances and 68 features. The results highlight the potential of ensemble learning models, specifically LightGBM-TFE (Textual Feature Engineering), which outperformed all other churn prediction machine learning models. This model achieved an F1 score of 95%, a ROC AUC of 97%, and a Precision of 99%, resulting in the best performance across various evaluation metrics. After the new predictive churn model was run for several months, it was observed that the churn rate decreased by 32%, from 1.86% to 1.26%.

title: BW-YOLO: small target vehicle detection based on improved YOLOv8
authors: Wen Naining, Lu Qi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Systems (ICCS)
abstract: In the context of complex traffic scenarios, existing vehicle target detection algorithms encounter several challenges when dealing with small targets, including low detection accuracy, missed detections, and high computational complexity. To tackle these issues, this study presents an improved vehicle target detection algorithm, BW-YOLO, which is based on YOLOv8. The Star Block in the lightweight network StarNet is incorporated into the C2f module. This integration aims to enhance the model's capacity for extracting features of small targets amidst complex backgrounds. Introduce the bidirectional feature pyramid network in Neck to enhance the model's multi-scale feature fusion capability. Introducing WIoU as a new bounding box loss function to enhance the convergence speed and regression accuracy of the model for small objects. The experimental results show that compared with the YOLOv8n model, the improved BW-YOLO model has achieved mAP50 and mAP50~95 indicators of 91.4% and 65.3% respectively, which are 3.0 and 3.6 percentage points higher. Moreover, it demonstrates higher accuracy and stability in detection tasks under complex backgrounds. The research results provide new ideas for vehicle target detection and have good practical application prospects.

title: Cross-Jurisdictional Ethical Governance and Legal Accountability Architecture for Autonomous AI-Powered Legal Advisory Systems
authors: Ali Hamza Nimrud, Sawsan Hussein Abed Al-Rubay, Zaid Abd Al Wahab Ali, Mohammed Sameer Hasan, Adnan Abass Hamza, Sara Amir Read, Ahmed Abdullah Madi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research introduces a scalable, modular governance architecture for autonomous AI-powered legal advisory systems that function across multi-jurisdictional environments. The framework synergistically combines jurisdiction-aware LegalBERT embedding’s, ethical reasoning modules, and constraint logic enforcement mechanisms to ensure regulatory conformance, ethical integrity, and decision traceability in AI-generated legal guidance. Evaluated on over 10,000 advisory cases spanning civil, common, and hybrid legal domains, the system achieved compliance accuracies above 94.6%, with F1-scores reaching 0.94 and conformance robustness peaking at 0.95. Compared to baseline models, the architecture enhanced policy alignment by 5.0–5.9% and significantly improved explainability via integrated SHAP visualizations and rule attribution mapping. The inclusion of legal knowledge graphs and smart contract-enabled audit layers facilitates real-time accountability and immutable logging, while sustaining inference latencies under 1.2 seconds per advisory. Designed for interoperability, ethics-awareness, and jurisdictional adaptability, the framework offers a robust foundation for the deployment of next-generation legal AI platforms focused on transparency, compliance, and cross-border legal scalability.

title: Brain Tumor Classification Based on Optimized Jump-Gain Integral Recurrent Neural Network Using MRI Images
authors: Sanjaykumar Hamilpure, Mohan Ramasundaram
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: At the most advanced stage, brain tumors are among the most fatal diseases, and resulting in a very short life expectancy. When brain tumors are misdiagnosed, patients get bad medical care that lowers their chances of surviving. Accurate classification of brain tumors is critical for planning treatment and improving the survival of people with brain tumors. In this manuscript, Brain Tumor Classification based on Optimized Jump-Gain Integral Recurrent Neural Network using MRI Images (BTC-JGIRNN- MRI) is proposed. Intially; input images are collected from Brain Tumor MRI Dataset. Then, the input data are preprocessed using Trainable SelfGuided Filter (TSGF) to remove noise and to improve image quality. Subsequently, the images that have been preprocessed are provided for feature extraction using SET to extract the statistical feature such as mean, standard division and variance. Then, the extracted features are provided to Sparse Reconstructive Multi-View Evidential Clustering Algorithm (SRMECA) for segmenting the regions of interest (ROI) from the pre-processed images. Then, the Jump-Gain Integral Recurrent Neural Network classifies the input as glioma, meningioma, no tumor and pituitary. Then it is given in to Federated Multi-Output Gaussian Processes (FMOGP) for post processing. The proposed BTC-JGIRNN-MRI method is implemented and assessed utilizing performance metrics like accuracy and recall. The suggested method attains 19.77%, 21.96% and 27.25% higher accuracy; 21.54%, 22.32% and 21.56% improved recall in comparison to current methods.

title: Improving Energy Efficiency During State-of-Charge Balancing in Battery Energy Storage Systems through Enhanced Use of Circulating Current
authors: Tsuyoshi Omi, Tomoyuki Hatakeyama
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Grid-scale battery energy storage systems (BESSs) must keep state-of-charge (SOC) of battery cells uniform to preserve usable capacity. Active balancing transfers charge through converters with high energy efficiency, but its cost and complexity escalate in multi-thousand-cell system. Passive balancing relies on inexpensive resistors but dissipates substantial energy as heat. Therefore, energy consumption is high. This study proposes novel passive balancing method which enhances use of circulating current that naturally flows between parallel-connected strings with different SOC. The proposed method estimates the circulating currents using equivalent circuit, and an exhaustive search selects the string-disconnect switch pattern that produces the largest charging current into the string containing the battery with minimum SOC. Experiments on ninety batteries demonstrate that the proposed method dissipates 8.03 Wh-an energy-loss reduction of $39.6 \%$ compared to a conventional method without considering circulating current. The proposed algorithm therefore enhances round-trip efficiency of battery system without adding any power-conversion hardware.

title: Graph Attention Networks for Fraud Detection and Risk Assessment in Banking and Financial Technology Using Graph-Based Customer Relationship Analysis
authors: Akshay Varkale, Ammar Hameed Shnain, R. Revathi, Md Afzal, Pideka Kundil Abhilash, Zainb Hussain Ali, Sajjad M Al-Hakeem, Sajad Ali Zearah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: A dramatic uptick in the use of financial cards is attributable to how the digital revolution has altered monetary transactions. However, the trade-off for this convenience is a dramatic increase in illegal operations. Typical algorithms for machine learning struggle to identify fraud in financial data due to its fundamental interconnectedness. The study proposed Graph Attention Networks for Banking Fraud Analysis (GAT-BFA), a novel framework leveraging Graph-based Customer Relationship Analysis for fraud detection and risk assessment. The system creates a graph-based customer relationship network from transaction patterns, account activity, and customer interactions, protecting top-notch network data, including weighted adjacency matrices across multiple concealing relations in the recommended solution. To identify anomalous and high-risk entities, GAT-BFA dynamically learns connection relevance. The model offers a secure and effective alternative to current financial fraud detection methods while protecting top-notch network data.

title: Comparative Analysis of A* and Dijkstra's Algorithms for Efficient Non-Planar 3D Printing Toolpath Optimization
authors: Khushi Choudki, Prarthana Kulkarni, Rutvik Hegde, Varenya Thaker
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of Di-jkstra's algorithm with multi-source A* algorithm for optimizing non-planar 3D printing toolpath on tetrahedral meshes. It implements the multi-source A* algorithm, using an admissible Euclidean distance heuristic, which significantly outperforms Dijkstra's in computational efficiency. A paired t-test confirms the statistical significance of the A* algorithm's superior performance, which achieved a 2.41% average speedup in pathfinding. This study discusses the practical implications of these findings, highlighting the potential for faster slicing iterations, improved scalability, and more responsive digital fabrication workflows. This research provides a validated, efficient pathfinding method-ology that addresses a key computational bottleneck in non- planar additive manufacturing, paving the way for wider adoption of these advanced printing techniques.

title: Ensemble Learning-Based Mental Analysis and Prediction of Mental Disorder
authors: L. Sudha Rani, Pogula Sreedevi, Dhomala Aswani, K. V. Panduranga Rao, C. Dastagiraiah, K Pushpa Rani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Given the increasing prevalence of mental health disorders, the use of evidence-based prediction tools to support early intervention is paramount, which can reduce stigma through sustainability. Because of the importance of using the Super Learner algorithm to improve prediction accuracy, this chapter presents on a new framework for predicting mental disorders using ensemble machine learning methods. The new framework collects survey responses from a participant across varying levels that each have a different set of questions when they participate in a study over multiple sessions. The algorithm analyzes the data and predicts an individual's mental health status on the survey data from only a few levels, for the purpose of providing targeted intervention recommendations. We applied the Super Learner method to combine different machine learning Models, and the model uses a large data set to train and optimize the prediction system. The modified survey used for assessment increases accuracy adapted to the individual's questionnaire by asking about multiple sessions. The initial results provide an indication that there is a high level of accuracy predicting mental state, and the method has the potential for identifying early intervention needed and reducing limitations related to stigma for mental health.

title: Recent Advances in Analog Front-End Architectures for ECG Signal Acquisition
authors: Riccardo Olivieri, Giuseppe Ferri
publish: IEEE Sensors Reviews
abstract: This review provides a comprehensive and structured analysis of electronic interface systems for electrocardiogram (ECG) signal acquisition, with a particular emphasis on the design of analog front-end circuits. These front-end systems represent the first and most critical stage in any ECG acquisition chain, as they must handle biopotential signals that are extremely low in amplitude, bandwidth-limited, and highly susceptible to environmental interference. After the description of general and innovative principles of ECG acquisition, some examples of sensor electrodes, as well as proposed solutions of ECG signal acquisition are given. Starting from electrode technologies, including wet, dry, and textile-based solutions, their impact on interface design is discussed in terms of impedance, motion artifacts, and patient comfort. The fundamental building blocks of ECG front-ends—instrumentation amplifiers, driven-right-leg (DRL) circuits, and filtering stages—are then investigated, highlighting design strategies and innovative proposals. In particular, the fundamental design requirements for amplifiers have been examined: the discussion will be centered on traditional voltage-mode architectures as well as emerging current-mode approaches, analyzing their advantages and limitations in terms of power efficiency, gain stability, and integration capability, as presented in recent literature for ECG interface design. Future perspectives are outlined, covering the role of advanced CMOS technologies in the development and design of analog systems for biosignal monitoring, as well as the needs of electrodes based on nanostructured and biocompatible maerials. Through an in-depth examination of recent literature, we have compared some state-of-the-art solutions and outlined future trends for the development of high-performance, low-power ECG analog acquisition systems, particularly in the context of portable and wearable medical devices.

title: Towards Intelligent Structural Health Monitoring: Comparative Evaluation of ML Models
authors: Shankar Gowda B. N, Tejashwini P S, Pranav Gupta, Vaibhav Kumar, Gourav Chahar, Nishant Bhardwaj
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Structural damage detection is the methodology used to find cracks and surface flaws on concrete structures, and critical helps us to ensure durability and safety of infrastructure. If left unattended, such damages can result into severe structural failures, leading to costly repairs, economic disruption, and potential hazards to human life. To address these challenges, this study employs deep learning techniques by integrating Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and VGG architectures, combining them into a hybrid model that leverages CNN's strength in spatial feature extraction and VGG's depth in hierarchical learning. The dataset employed for training and evaluation consisted of 17,470 labeled images (227×227 pixels, ~12.6 KB each), nearly balanced across damaged and undamaged samples. A hybrid CNN-VGG model was developed, outperforming solo CNN, VGG19, and SVM models, with an accuracy of 83.7%. This model was made possible by optimizing and cross-validating the previous models. This proves that hybrid deep learning models are beneficial for improving and automating structural monitoring.

title: AI-Driven Behavioral Anomaly and Fraud Detection Models for Real-Time High-Frequency Financial Transactions in FinTech Systems
authors: Haidar Ali Al Dulaimi, Hussein Basim Furaijl, Leena Sameer Baddour, Abed Alnasser Ramada, Faez Hlail Srayyih, Sinan Raheem Jasim, Sinan Abdullah Harjan, Mohammed A Mahdi, Doha K Ibrahem
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research introduces a real-time behavioral anomaly and fraud detection architecture tailored for FinTech systems by integrating temporal deep learning with federated and explainable AI (XAI) pipelines. Utilizing LSTM Autoencoders, Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), and reinforcement-based feedback loops, the system was evaluated on over 220 million transactions from mobile wallets, algorithmic trading, and cross-border remittance platforms. The framework attained classification accuracy surpassing 97.85%, F1-scores of 0.947, and latency below 110 milliseconds per transaction stream. Compared to static threshold and non-temporal baselines, it reduced false positives by 41.3% and improved interpretability via SHAP, DeepLIFT, and counterfactual XAI layers. Behavioral embeddings, transaction graph profiling, and anomaly temporal vectors facilitated granular detection across adversarial and high-frequency patterns. Unlike traditional resource-intensive systems, model training remains under 1.9 seconds per adaptive window, supporting real-time retraining under concept drift. The architecture is modular, privacy-aware, and deployable across diverse FinTech infrastructures without retraining core layers.

title: AI-Powered Detection of Microbial Threats in Digital Health Systems: A Cybersecurity Perspective
authors: Mohammad A.Alfaham, Araf H Wahab, Amer Ibrahim, Maher Khanafer, Darin Shafek
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The digitization of healthcare systems has amplified their vulnerability to each microbial threats and cyberattacks, necessitating integrated answers that balance diagnostic accuracy with security. This looks at proposes a novel framework combining AI-pushed microbial detection and adaptive cybersecurity mechanisms to deal with those dual challenges. Utilizing a hybrid CNN-BiLSTM architecture, the model analyzes genomic sequences and microscopy pix, reaching an F1-rating of 0.93 and AUC-ROC of 0.98 in figuring out antibiotic-resistant pathogens and emerging viruses. Concurrently, the framework embeds stop-to-give up encryption, graph neural community (GNN)-primarily based anomaly detection, and antagonistic education, demonstrating a 94% assault detection price in opposition to facts poisoning, ransomware, and version evasion assaults. Results screen crucial trade-offs: federated gaining knowledge of reduces statistics switch charges by 73% but will increase schooling time, while hostile training preserves model accuracy beneath perturbations (82% at ε=0.05) at the fee of larger education datasets. The have a look at highlights the imperative of co-optimizing AI and cybersecurity in healthcare, mainly for crucial programs like sepsis detection and outbreak prediction. Practical suggestions are proposed for developers, emphasizing HIPAA/GDPR-compliant federated learning and obligatory antagonistic checking out for regulatory approval. By validating a unified technique to microbial and cyber threats, this study advances the development of secure, AI-augmented fitness structures, offering a pathway to mitigate risks in a technology of escalating virtual and biological threats.

title: Employee Behavior Prediction in Government Networks Using Long Short-Term Memory Networks
authors: Raz A. Jalal
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Employee behavior prediction in government networks is crucial for maintaining security, ensuring compliance, and preventing insider threats. Accurately modeling employee actions over time helps organizations detect anomalies and safeguard sensitive information. Existing methods often rely on static or rule-based approaches that fail to capture the dynamic and sequential nature of employee behavior, leading to poor prediction accuracy and delayed threat detection. To address these limitations, this study proposes a framework called Sequential Behavioral Data Modeling with Long Short-Term Memory Networks (SBDM-LSTM). This approach leverages the power of LSTM networks to analyze time-series employee activity data, such as access logs and system usage patterns. By learning temporal dependencies within behavioral sequences, the SBDM-LSTM model effectively predicts future actions and identifies deviations from standard patterns. The proposed method enhances real-time monitoring capabilities in government networks, enabling proactive detection of suspicious activities and insider threats. Experimental results demonstrate that the SBDM-LSTM framework outperforms traditional models in terms of prediction accuracy by 97.83%, early anomaly detection by 98.31%, precision by 97.64%, and latency by 98.27%, providing a robust solution for secure government network management.

title: SmartBioBin: An Automated Waste Classification and Methane Monitoring System Using Embedded Sensors
authors: P Sai Lekhya, P Sai Abhirishi, Mallikarjun Neelappagol, Sai Hasini Pothamsetti, Swetha S M, Vanishree K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Efficient waste segregation is a critical component of sustainable waste management in modern urban environments. The SmartBioBin is an automated system designed to classify and separate biodegradable and non-biodegradable waste at the source using embedded sensors and a microcontroller. The system employs an infrared (IR) sensor for object detection, a moisture sensor to identify organic content, and an inductive proximity sensor to detect metallic items. Based on sensor input, a servo motor directs the waste into the appropriate compartment, with LEDs providing visual indication. A 16x2 LCD displays real-time information, while a load cell measures the weight of deposited waste for capacity monitoring. By automating segregation, the SmartBioBin minimizes human intervention, improves sorting accuracy, and supports the generation of energy-rich by products from biodegradable waste. The novelty of SmartBioBin is that it not only segregates waste but also provides a simple user interface. LEDs indicate the type of waste, while the LCD shows methane levels and weight in real time. Unlike regular smart bins that stop at segregation, this system adds an extra layer of verification by detecting methane from decomposing organic matter, linking waste management with potential energy generation. Bringing segregation, monitoring, and feedback together in one compact unit makes SmartBioBin a practical and sustainable solution.

title: Building and Hosting AI Locally with Ollama, Open WebUI, and Stable Diffusion
authors: Amitesh Srinivas, Vinay Hegde, Aditya G S, Avneesh Singh, Fayaz
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The rapid evolution of artificial intelligence (AI) has intensified the need for efficient local deployment of advanced models. This paper presents a practical framework for configuring and operating a local AI server that supports models such as Ollama, Open WebUI, and Stable Diffusion. The proposed setup encompasses both hardware and software integration, beginning with system installation, GPU configuration, and containerized deployment using Docker. It further explores model management through Open WebUI, performance tuning via GPU optimization, and local image generation using Stable Diffusion. Advanced functionalities, including document processing and integration with productivity tools like Obsidian, are also examined. By enabling users to host AI models locally, this work emphasizes enhanced data privacy, reduced dependency on cloud infrastructure, and improved computational performance. Overall, this study delivers a comprehensive guide to establishing a reliable, scalable, and cost-effective local AI environment.

title: Business Email Compromise Detection Using Random Forest Classifier with Email Header Embeddings
authors: Guttumukkala Prasanthi, Muntather Muhsin Hassan, S.Ananthi, Dhablia Dharmesh Kirit, C. Mukuntharaj, Myasar Mundher Adnan, Mohammed Abdul Malek Al Saadi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Attacks on business email compromise (BEC) are becoming more complex and are causing primary data and financial losses. These attacks aim to affect users by sending them emails with incorrect information. Conventional rule-based detection systems fail to spot these attacks.BEC emails are identified in this paper using a machine learning-based approach, a Random Forest Classifier, and email header embeddings. The email headers are preprocessed and converted into vector embeddings to find hidden patterns unique to fraudulent emails. The model is trained on a labeled dataset, including authentic and BEC emails. The proposed method exhibited minimal false-positive outcomes and achieved a detection accuracy of 96.3%. Similar to other baseline machine learning models, it performs much better than rule-based models. It generalizes effectively to various assault variations overlooked previously, supporting the model's longevity. Utilizing embeddings in email header metadata greatly improves the identification of BEC attacks. The Random Forest-based approach provides a real-time, interpretable, scalable solution. This approach proves suitable for strengthening the email security systems of corporate enterprises.

publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Precise mapping of forest vegetation, including both dominant tree species and other vegetation types, is essential for forest management and biodiversity conservation, yet traditional high-resolution imagery is limited in spatial coverage. The high revisit frequency of Sentinel-2 provides dense time-series observa tions that capture phenological differences among species across broad areas. In this study, we compiled all cloud-free Sentinel 2 images from 2023 for the Eastern Qilian Mountains, China. Twelve thematic classes were defined in this study, including six dominant tree taxa (five tree species and one Picea genus group), five vegetation-type classes (mixed forests, shrubland, and grassland), and one non-vegetation class. Vegetation phenology metrics were derived using two methods: a curve-fitting approach (TIMESAT) and a harmonic analysis of time series (HANTS). We integrated these phenological features with the original spectral bands, Sentinel-1 SAR backscatter, texture metrics, and topo graphic variables as inputs to multiple classifiers (Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, Convolutional Neural Network, Vision Transformer, and Extreme Gradient Boosting). We also applied Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) to interpret model feature importance. Without phenological inputs, the best model achieved 92.5% overall accuracy. Incorporating phenological variables from TIMESAT increased accuracy to 96.1%—slightly higher than using HANTS-derived features (95.5%). SHAP analysis revealed that time-series phenological and spectral variables con tribute most to species discrimination, while SAR backscatter and topographic metrics provide crucial complementary information. These findings demonstrate that exploiting Sentinel-2's temporal dynamics alongside multi-source data markedly improves tree species classification in complex mountainous forests, and high light the added value of advanced phenology extraction methods and explainable machine learning techniques.

title: STERN: Simultaneous Trajectory Estimation and Relative Navigation for Autonomous Underwater Proximity Operations
authors: Aldo Terán Espinoza, Antonio Terán Espinoza, John Folkesson, Clemens Deutsch, Niklas Rolleberg, Peter Sigray, Jakob Kuttenkeuler
publish: IEEE Journal of Oceanic Engineering
abstract: Due to the challenges regarding the limits of their endurance and autonomous capabilities, underwater docking for autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) has become a topic of interest for many academic and commercial applications. Herein, we take on the problem of relative navigation for the generalized version of the docking operation, which we address as proximity operations. Proximity operations typically involve only two actors, a chaser and a target. We leverage the similarities to proximity operations (prox-ops) from spacecraft robotic missions to frame the diverse docking scenarios with a set of phases the chaser undergoes on the way to its target. We emphasize the versatility on the use of factor graphs as a generalized representation to model the underlying simultaneous trajectory estimation and relative navigation problem that arises with any prox-ops scenario, regardless of the sensor suite or the agents’ dynamic constraints. To emphasize the flexibility of factor graphs as the modeling foundation for arbitrary underwater prox-ops, we compile a list of state-of-the-art research in the field and represent the different scenario using the same factor graph representation. We detail the procedure required to model, design, and implement factor graph-based estimators by addressing a long-distance acoustic homing scenario of an AUV to a moving mothership using data sets from simulated and real-world deployments; an analysis of these results is provided to shed light on the flexibility and limitations of the dynamic assumptions of the moving target. A description of our front- and back-end is also presented together with a timing breakdown of all processes to show its potential deployment on a real-time system.

title: Exploring 3D Unsteady Flow Using 6D Observer Space Interactions_supp1-3642506.pdf
authors: Xingdi Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Visualizing and analyzing 3D unsteady flow fields is a very challenging task. We approach this problem by leveraging the mathematical foundations of 3D observer fields to explore and analyze 3D flows in reference frames that are more suitable to visual analysis than the input reference frame. We design novel interactive tools for determining, filtering, and combining reference frames for observer-aware 3D unsteady flow visualization. We represent the space of reference frame motions in a 3D spatial domain via a 6Dparameter space, in which every observer is a time-dependent curve. Our framework supports operations in this 6D observer space by separately focusing on two 3D subspaces, for 3D translations, and 3D rotations, respectively. We show that this approach facilitates a variety of interactions with 3D flow fields. Building on the interactive selection of observers, we furthermore introduce novel techniques such as observer-aware streamline- and pathline-filtering as well as observer-aware iso surface animations of scalar fluid properties for the enhanced visualization and analysis of 3D unsteady flows. We discuss the theoretical underpinnings as well as practical implementation considerations of our approach, and demonstrate the benefits of its 6+1D observer-based methodology on several 3D unsteady flow datasets.

title: Understanding the Performance Behaviors of End-to-End Protein Design Pipelines on GPUs
authors: Jinwoo Hwang, Yeongmin Hwang, Tadiwos Meaza, Hyeonbin Bae, Jongse Park
publish: IEEE Computer Architecture Letters
abstract: Recent computational advances enable protein design pipelines to run end-to-end on GPUs, yet their heterogeneous computational behaviors remain undercharacterized at the system level. We implement and profile a representative pipeline at both component and full-pipeline granularities across varying inputs and hyperparameters. Our characterization identifies generally low GPU utilization and high sensitivity to sequence length and sampling strategies. We outline future research directions based on these insights and release an open-source pipeline and profiling scripts to facilitate further studies.

title: Comparative Analysis of Drift-Based and RL-Based Designs for Synchronized and Fresh Downlink Communication
authors: Xujin Zhou, Irem Koprulu, Atilla Eryilmaz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: Synchronized and fresh communication of common information is vitally important in numerous multi-user network scenarios, whereby end-users must perform coordinated real-time action with the available information. However, developing efficient policies with performance guarantees is greatly complicated by the abruptly changing nature of related age and synchronization metrics. In particular, powerful approaches that are based on so-called drift-plus-penalty (DPP) methods could not be employed due to the non-traditional multiplicative update dynamics of age and synchronization. In this paper, we overcome these limitations by designing and analyzing a Lyapunov-drift-based algorithm under the non-traditional age and synchronization dynamics that is not only low-complexity and analyzable, but also performs better than all the prior designs in numerical investigations. By comparing our design with two alternatives using the DPP approach, we also shed some light on the key aspect of our design that enables the performance analysis, which may be useful in future studies in multiplicative update dynamics. Furthermore, we implement Feature-based Reinforcement Learning (RL) methods with reduced state spaces and RL with full-state observations. Fresh-Async performs very closely to feature-based RL method using a feature space consisting of average age, age asynchrony, and maximum age, and both algorithms exhibit competitive performance compared to full-state RL while maintaining superior computational efficiency. These investigations clarify the contrast between drift-based and RL-based designs, and also reveal how drift-based design can be beneficial for feature selection for RL operation.

title: Optimal Access Structure Partition Methods for Image Secret Sharing
authors: Xiaotian Wu, Li Tang, Zhihua Xia, Ching-Nung Yang, Weiqi Yan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Visual cryptography scheme (VCS) and polynomial-based secret image sharing (PSIS) are two primary types of secret sharing for protecting images. VCS and PSIS have their respective pros and cons. For VCS, the benefits of perfect security and easy decoding are provided. But it suffers from the limitations of lossy secret recovery and binary image-oriented. PSIS can deal with grayscale/color images and offers lossless secret reconstruction. Whereas, the secret decoding is computationally intensive (i.e., O(k log2 k) for (k, n) threshold) and the residual-image problem in PSIS compromises the security. In this paper, we are motivated to investigate a sharing technique that can preserve the advantages of both VCS and PSIS. Differing from existing VCS and PSIS, the proposed sharing method is accomplished based on the access structure partition (ASP) result. Essentially, an ASP guided image secret sharing approach is developed and three optimal ASP algorithms are designed. When compared with existing partition method, significant improvement is offered by our partition techniques especially for the (k, n) threshold with a larger n. Take the (2; 15), (2; 18), and (4; 12) thresholds for example, the numbers of involved sub-access structures by our method are 4, 5, and 19, while the quantities by existing approach are 8, 10, and 45. The percentages of improvement are 100%, 100%, and 137%. Further, based on the partition result from ASP algorithms, we can employ (k, k) probabilistic VCS (PVCS) to constitute a (k, n) sharing method for encoding gray-level/color images. Experiments are demonstrated to confirm the effectiveness of the sharing method and ASP algorithms. Meanwhile, comparisons are included to show that the merits of perfect security, low decoding complexity (i.e., O(d)), lossless secret recovery (i.e., PSNR= ∞, SSIM= 1), and grayscale/color image-oriented are provided by our sharing method.

title: Automated hierarchical block decomposition of biochemical networks
authors: Manvel Gasparyan, Satya Tamby, G.V. HarshaRani, Upinder S. Bhalla, Ovidiu Radulescu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Biochemical networks are models of biological functions and processes in biomedicine. Hierarchical decomposition simplifies complex biochemical networks by partitioning them into smaller blocks (modules), facilitating computationally intensive analyses and providing deeper insights into cellular processes and regulatory mechanisms. We introduce a novel algorithm for the hierarchical decomposition of large-scale biochemical systems. By using causality and information flow as organizing principles, our approach combines strongly connected components with <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$r$</tex-math></inline-formula>-causality to identify and structure manageable network blocks. Benchmarking against a comprehensive database of biochemical reaction networks demonstrates the computational efficiency and scalability of our algorithm. To ensure broad applicability, we integrate our algorithm into tools that support standardized Systems Biology Markup Language (SBML) formats, facilitating its use in biochemical modeling workflows.

title: Effects of DC Magnetron Sputtering Parameters on The Topography and Magnetic Properties of Galfenol/SiC Films
authors: Yu Tang, Barry Gallacher, Zimeng Yu, Sarah Olsen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Magnetics
abstract: Galfenol thin films demonstrate significant potential for MicroElectroMechanical System (MEMS) applications due to their notable magnetostrictive properties and favorable mechanical characteristics. In this study, we report an investigation into the modifications in both the amorphous and crystalline structures of galfenol thin films subjected to various direct current (DC) magnetron sputtering parameters, employing atomic force microscopy (AFM), magnetic force microscopy (MFM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques. Our results indicate that coercivity force increases with higher sputtering power but decreases as the Ar working pressure rises. Furthermore, the effects of film thickness, root mean square (RMS) surface roughness, and sputtering parameters on magnetostriction were systematically investigated.

title: Distributed Optimal Load Frequency Control in Multi-microgrids Under Transmission Losses and Operational Constraints
authors: Xiao Qi, Jizhen Liu, Wenguang Zhang, Hui Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The integration of high-penetration renewable energy sources into multi-microgrids (MMGs) exacerbates the inherent limitations of the conventional frequency regulation framework, where decoupled load frequency control (LFC) and economic dispatch lead to suboptimal economic efficiency. To address this issue, this article formulates a real-time economic LFC problem for nonlinear MMGs and proposes a distributed optimal disturbance rejection control (DODRC) method. First, a comprehensive dynamic model of nonlinear MMGs is established, explicitly incorporating transmission losses-a critical yet often neglected factor in low/middle-voltage networks-along with operational constraints such as tie-line thermal limits and generation capacities. Second, the DODRC method is designed for nonlinear MMGs by deriving a supplementary compensating control loop that realizes the integration of the cascade extended state observer-based active disturbance rejection control with the partial primal–dual gradient algorithm. This development not only enables simultaneous real-time frequency regulation and economic optimization but also significantly enhances the antidisturbance capability against internal parameter uncertainties, external supply-demand imbalances, and measurement noises. Third, the stability of the proposed DODRC is rigorously proven from both theoretical and experimental perspectives. Experimental validation via an industrial control platform confirms its effectiveness and superiority. Comparative results demonstrate substantial improvements in disturbance rejection, noise suppression, and robustness to critical parameter variations, outperforming existing distributed optimal control methods.

title: Precise Model-Based Predictive Motion Control for Electric Vehicles Using Limited Offline Data and Real-Time Online Adaptation
authors: Haoqi Hu, Wei Pan, Lin Zhang, Yiding Hua, Chunlai Zhao, Xiaoyan Liu, Hong Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The pronounced nonlinearity of vehicle dynamics under extreme conditions presents a substantial challenge for motion control. The complexity of nonlinear modeling, parameter inaccuracies, and the high computational cost associated with high-order nonlinear control systems significantly hinder improvements in control stability and performance. To address these challenges, this article proposes an innovative data-driven model predictive control (DMPC) approach. A data-driven modeling (DM) technique is first introduced to construct a linear model based on step response input/output (I/O) data, with real-time compensation for model deviations using online data to more accurately capture the vehicle’s lateral and longitudinal dynamics. The stability of the model estimation error is rigorously analyzed, and a data-driven vehicle model with theoretical guarantees is established. A hierarchical stability control framework based on DM is then developed. The upper-level controller evaluates vehicle maneuverability and lateral stability to determine the required additional yaw moment, while the lower-level controller assesses longitudinal stability and traction, and incorporates lateral–longitudinal coupling to optimize motor torque distribution across the wheels. DM is validated using more than 25 000 s of low-adhesion road data, demonstrating significantly higher modeling accuracy than traditional nonlinear models (NLMs). Compared with the NLM-based controller, DMPC improves vehicle handling and lateral stability by 28.98% and 66.92%, respectively, while reducing driver workload by 33.72% in lateral tests. In longitudinal tests, the strategy increases vehicle acceleration by 58.65% and reduces yaw fluctuation by 79.5%. Finally, the robustness of DMPC is evaluated through parameter sensitivity analysis and variations in tire pressure.

title: Online Energy-Optimal Trajectory Planning for Servomotor Systems With Nonlinear Dynamics
authors: Kuan Wang, Le Sun, Longmiao Chen, Jingqi Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Online computation of energy-optimal trajectories is critically important for single-axis servo systems performing point-to-point positioning tasks. Indirect methods are widely adopted for this purpose due to their computational efficiency. However, existing methods are generally limited to systems with linear dynamics, while practical servo systems often exhibit nonlinear load torques that vary with load position. To address this, a novel online energy-optimal trajectory planning method is proposed to handle nonlinear load torques that is continuously differentiable and bounded. The method of variation of extremals is introduced to efficiently solve the resulting nonlinear two-point boundary value problems. Additionally, constraints on jerk, acceleration, and speed can also be considered. To verify its online computation performance, an orthogonal method is employed to design various positioning tasks. Numerical results show that the proposed method achieves computation times ranging from 7.2 to 55 ms on a Raspberry Pi and from 0.8 to 7.1 ms on a personal computer, outperforming MATLAB’s bvp4c solver by 11 to 29 times. Finally, the experimental results confirm that the energy-optimal trajectories significantly reduce energy consumption while maintaining comparable tracking performance to that of conventional trapezoidal speed trajectories and S-curve trajectories.

title: Efficient Video Summarization Using Deep Summarization Network: A Deep Learning Approach
authors: Kakarla Ramana Reddy, Jangam Subbarayudu, N Kireeti, Panuganti Shravani, Mohammed Mukhtar, Davuluri Koushik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Exponential video production in various fields demands proper summarization of the films in such a way that the contents can be accessed in a short time. The traditional methods are not able to identify the most suitable segments with contextual integrity. Deep Summarization Networks (DSN) are explored in the study for their capability of producing short but informative video summaries. Deep learning techniques are used in the new approach for important events and key frame extraction, thus generating a coherent and meaningful summary. DSN uses feature abstraction, attention, and sequence modeling to effectively eliminate redundancy without losing representational fidelity. Our approach's summaries have been demonstrated to be of better quality and usefulness compared to existing approaches through exhaustive testing on benchmark corpora. Deep learning is shown in this study to be very efficient in video summarization and the applications within media analysis, surveillance, and video indexing.

title: Damping and Sensitivity Analysis of Parallel Resonance for PV-VSC Systems in Distribution Lines
authors: Igor Oliani, Alfeu J. Sguarezi Filho, Renato M. Monaro, Luís F. Normandia Lourenço
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Background: The increasing integration of distributed energy resources (DERs) in low- and medium-voltage networks poses challenges to maintaining power quality. The DERs reduce grid inertia and increase harmonic distortion, which may interact with nonlinear loads and passive compensation elements. Objective: This paper investigates parallel resonance phenomena in shunt capacitor banks within feeders connected to photovoltaic (PV) converters and proposes a control-based damping solution. Method: The proposed strategy replaces the conventional current reference generation in the converter control with a theory-based approach to synthesize a resistive load, thereby emulating passive damping behavior. The technique is evaluated under both voltage-oriented control (VOC-PI) and finite control set (FCS) predictive control frameworks. Sensitivity analyses are carried out to examine the influence of grid and control parameters on the stability of shunt resonance. Results: Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed resistive-load synthesis method effectively mitigates resonance peaks without any hardware modification. The results indicate that the stability and safety of PV-VSC systems can be enhanced through minor adjustments in the converter control structure, offering a low-cost and easily implementable alternative to conventional passive or active filtering techniques.

title: Edge-Native IoT Data Architectures for Practitioners: A Glass Manufacturing Use Case
authors: Mattia Antonini, Anna Rubini, Damiano Dallapiccola, Massimo Vecchio, Nicola Peghini, Fabio Antonelli
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Magazine
abstract: Glass manufacturing plants, as in many other heavy industries, run legacy equipment under strict latency, security, and network isolation constraints that make cloud-centric IoT architectures unsuitable. In this article, we present an edge-native IoT data architecture tailored to this environment, detail its design and implementation and validate it with an on-premises deployment. This architectural solution enables near-real-time data acquisition, analytics, and control while preserving data sovereignty, system autonomy, and offline-first continuity at site level. Built with modular, industry-grade technologies aligned with current best practices, the architecture delivers scalable stream processing, schema governance, long-term auditability, and supports deploying AI models near data sources and equipment. We conclude by discussing system challenges and future work to guide practitioners and researchers in pursuing similar industrial IoT scenarios.

title: Dual-Polarization Modulated Optically Transparent Metasurface Based on Graphene-Ionogel
authors: Fulong Yang, Yongxia Zhang, Zhe Feng, Yuqing Qi, Yurui Wang, Mengyao Cui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents a graphene-ionogel-based transparent metasurface that can dynamically adjust the reflection amplitude of x-polarized waves and the resonance frequency of y-polarized waves. This design addresses the issue of ionic liquid leakage in traditional graphene sandwich structures by integrating ionogel with graphene. By changing the resistance of the graphene sheet, the amplitude of the x-polarized wave can be modulated within the range of -3.9 dB to -40 dB, and the resonant frequency of the absorption spectrum of the y-polarized wave can be shifted from 13.8 GHz to 8.27 GHz. The equivalent transmission line model is constructed based on the induced electric field and surface current, and the dual-polarization tunable characteristics of the metasurface are analyzed. The results show that the experiments are in excellent agreement with the simulations, thereby validating the accuracy and feasibility of the proposed metasurface and enhancing the practicality and adaptability of tunable graphene-based metasurface.

title: QHR-V2X: A Quantum-Heuristic Routing Framework for Efficient V2X Path Discovery
authors: Zahid Khan, Sultan Almogbil, Muhammad Babar, Adel Ammar, Wadii Boulila
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) networks face significant challenges in achieving optimal, reliable routing due to their large scale, high mobility, and rapidly changing topologies. Traditional routing approaches have been applied to address this highly dynamic behavior, but they often fail to deliver steady performance in dynamic environments. In this study, we introduce Quantum-Heuristic Routing for V2X (QHR-V2X), a novel paradigm that integrates the heuristic efficiency of the A* algorithm with quantum-inspired amplitude amplification. The proposed scheme is designed to enable rapid and optimal route discovery while reducing redundant exploration. This makes it particularly suitable for latency-sensitive vehicular environments. To validate its effectiveness, QHR-V2X was evaluated against two classical baselines, Dijkstra and A*, within grid-based simulation environments of increasing size and obstacle density. Experimental results show that QHR-V2X achieves significantly lower route-discovery time and reduced message overhead compared to classical algorithms, while maintaining path lengths nearly identical to those of the optimal routes produced by Dijkstra. These findings demonstrate the potential of QHR-V2X to improve scalability and responsiveness in next-generation V2X communications.

title: Decoupled and Closed-Loop Motion and Stiffness Control for Articulated Soft Robots Driven by a Class of Electromechanical Variable Stiffness Actuators
authors: Maja Trumić, Franco Angelini, Kosta Jovanović, Adriano Fagiolini
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
abstract: Controlling articulated soft robots (ASRs) driven by variable stiffness actuators (VSAs) remains an open challenge from the model-based control perspective, where the key difficulties are due to: 1) the coupling between motion and stiffness dynamics; 2) highly nonlinear dynamics; and 3) sensitivity to the model accuracy. Herein, we contribute to: 1) by achieving decoupling through shifting the eigenvalues of the actuator matrix to avoid singularity, followed by the compensation of such shift through the integral action. To address; 2) we design a cascade-based control that formally proves convergence of the motion and stiffness tracking errors to zero. Finally, our contribution resolves; and 3) by ensuring robustness to uncertain dynamics parameters through adaptive approach. Notably, this methodology enables independent motion and stiffness control design, allowing the application of diverse control strategies. The proposed solution is validated in simulation and on an ASR hardware setup. The results prove that the method is capable of controlling motion and stiffness in a decoupled manner, while the adaptive strategy ensures improved tracking performance.

title: DESTinE Block: Private Blockchain Based Data Storage Framework for Power System
authors: Khandaker Akramul Haque, Katherine R. Davis
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper presents Discrete Event Simulator in Energy (DESTinE) Block, a blockchain-based data storage framework designed for power systems and optimized for resource-constrained environments, including grid-edge devices such as single-board computers. The proposed architecture leverages the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) for storing large files while maintaining secure and traceable metadata on a custom blockchain named DESTinE Block. The metadata, comprising the IPFS Content Identifier (CID), uploader identity, administrator verification, and timestamp; is immutably recorded on-chain to ensure authenticity and integrity. DESTinE Block adopts a dual-blockchain abstraction, where the blockchain remains unaware of the IPFS storage layer to enhance security and limit the exposure of sensitive file data. The consensus mechanism is based on Proof of Authority (PoA), where both an administrator and an uploader with distinct cryptographic key pairs are required to create a block collaboratively. Each block contains verified signatures of both parties and is designed to be computationally efficient, enabling deployment on devices like the Raspberry Pi 5. The framework was tested on both an x86-based device and an ARM64-based Raspberry Pi, demonstrating its potential for secure, decentralized logging and measurement storage in smart grid applications. Moreover, DESTinE Block is compared with a similar framework based on Multichain. The results indicate that DESTinE Block provides a promising solution for tamper-evident data retention in distributed power system infrastructure while maintaining minimal hardware requirements.

title: Guest Editorial Special Section on Edge AI Strategies for Fortifying Security and Privacy in Healthcare Devices
authors: Md. Jalil Piran, Paolo Napoletano, Mechelle Gittens
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: As the healthcare sector undergoes rapid digital transformation; a new era of personalized healthcare services has begun. Wearable electronics, ubiquitous sensing, and intelligent data-driven analytics accelerate this process. In this transformation, Edge Artificial Intelligence (Edge AI) and the Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) work together to enable real-time diagnostics, continuous patient monitoring, and intelligent decision-making at the network edge. However, as these devices become more interconnected and autonomous, they also present significant vulnerabilities related to data privacy, cyber-security, model robustness, and system resilience.

title: A High-Gain, Low-Voltage Operational Amplifier With Bias-Stress and PVT Robustness for Large-Area Temperature Sensing on LTPS Substrates
authors: Chen Wang, Xiaonan Xing, Seyed Mojtaba Sadati Faramarzi, Aris Siskos, Qiuyang Lin, Yannick Baines, Chutham Sawigun, Mauricio Velazquez Lopez, Florian De Roose, Jan Genoe, Nikolas Papadopoulos, Kris Myny
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Circuits and Systems
abstract: This paper analyzes the temperature coefficients of low temperature polysilicon (LTPS) devices and investigates critical blocks of a system architecture for large-area temperature sensing, which integrates sensors and readout circuits monolithically. As part of this system, a low-voltage folded-cascode (LV-FC) operational amplifier (OpAmp) with a class-AB output stage was designed and implemented using an LTPS thin film transistor (TFT) process on a 15μm-thick polyimide flexible substrate. The performance of 20 amplifier samples was thoroughly characterized under DC, AC, long-term bias-stress (up to 40,000 seconds), and temperature conditions (0∘C to 80∘C). The amplifier achieves a maximum DC gain of 64.2 dB and a gain-bandwidth product of 400 kHz, while operating reliably under a 6 V supply with a peak power consumption of 0.6 mW in a compact area of 1.38 mm2. Under bias stress, the gain degraded by only 2.5 dB and the offset shifted by 1.5 mV. Over the full temperature range, the average gain varied by less than 2 dB and the offset by under 6 mV. These results demonstrate strong robustness against PVT variations and prolonged stress, confirming the suitability of the proposed LV-FC amplifier for flexible, long-term, and large-area temperature sensing applications.

title: Jointly Optimizing Task Offloading and Resource Allocation in MEC with Secure Data Transmission: A Multi-DNNs Approach
authors: Shubin Zhang, Xun Tong, Kaikai Chi, Zhiguo Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Edge computing has emerged as a promising paradigm to enable low-latency and high-bandwidth Internet of Things (IoT) applications. However, owing to the intrinsic characteristics of IoT devices, this emerging paradigm still faces bottlenecks such as energy shortages and security vulnerabilities. In this paper, we consider a physical layer security empowered wireless powered mobile edge computing (WP-MEC) system where wireless devices (WDs) can harvest energy from radio frequency signals, and the delivered data is protected against eavesdropping by using the well-known Wyner's wiretap encoding scheme. We focus on maximizing the secure computation rate by jointly optimizing artificial noise power, resource allocation, and offloading decisions for a multi-antenna scenario with wireless devices and a potential eavesdropper. We formulate this sum secure computation rate (SSCR) maximization problem as a mixed-integer programming problem and design an integrated deep reinforcement learning framework consisting of a discrete policy network module, a continuous policy network module, and an optimization module to derive binary offloading decisions, continuous time allocation, and an artificial noise covariance matrix. We evaluate the proposed approach through extensive simulations, and the results demonstrate that our approach can significantly enhance the security, energy efficiency, and computing capacity of wireless edge computing compared with existing works.

title: Time-to-Go Polynomial Guidance Laws Under Off-Axis Seeker Constraints
authors: Ohryeung Kang, Boseok Kim, Chang-Hun Lee, Sang-Wook Shim
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper investigates the guidance problem of missiles equipped with an off-axis seeker, focusing on satisfying non-standard field-of-view (FOV) constraints. The engagement scenario is reformulated in a relative coordinate frame, and a guidance law is derived based on a time-to-go polynomial approach without requiring any linearization assumptions. This approach yields closed-form solutions for the state variables, enabling the derivation of a capturability condition that remains valid even under large initial heading errors. In addition, a set of performance metrics and the impact angle are investigated to determine the appropriate initial missile attitudes. Extensive simulations are conducted to validate the performance and practical applicability of the proposed method.
