title: Enhancing Game Development Efficiency: A Reusable AI Pathfinding Framework for 2D Platformer Games
authors: Brian Akbar Wicaksana, Darlis Herumurti, Imam Kuswardayan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Informatics (EECSI)
abstract: Navigating between platforms in the development of 2D platformer games is a significant challenge for developers. This complexity arises from determining the path of a character between platforms while considering various variables such as movement speed, gravity, and obstacles. To address these challenges, this study proposes the development of a pathfinding package specifically designed to address these issues. The package implements two main features: platform graph creation and platform navigation. The platform graph maps the game level in detail, while the platform navigation feature allows characters to move efficiently between platforms. The testing was carried out using two methods: execution time testing for the creation of the platform graph and prototype testing on two different platformer games. The results demonstrate that the package effectively provides a reliable navigation solution for platformer games, with platform graph creation execution times varying depending on the level size. Furthermore, the experiment results indicate that the pathfinding package has been successfully implemented and applied to other platformer games, showcasing its reusability. This package can help game developers create better character navigation and improve gameplay quality in platformer games.

title: Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning for Secure Cloud Scheduling with Digital Twin Validation
authors: Naimil Navnit Gadani, Rupenkumar Anjaria
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Cloud-based time-critical smart grid applications need to be able to efficiently schedule resources to maintain their performance and robustness in the presence of time varying loads and cyber intrusions. In fact, we find that simple heuristics as Round-Robin (RR) and Least-Loaded (LL) are not viable choices in adversarial settings and that single-layer DRL architectures cannot scale well and are not stable. To enable attack-aware and efficient performance scheduling, this work introduces a Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning (HDRL) based structure along with a digital twin (DT) validation environment. In the HDRL model, local and global PPO agents work in sync to allocate resources at various levels and DT orchestrates redundancy of workloads and cyberattacks injection for resilience purposes. The assessment was performed on actual building load traces with normal, low attack, and high attack profiles. The results indicate that HDRL outperforms the baselines in terms of throughput, SLA violations and recovery time. Under high attack, HDRL also exhibited a reduction in SLA violations of more than 50% relative to LL and RR as well as $50 \%$ decrease in the time needed for recovery. Using Wilcoxon signed-rank test, we statistically validate that the improvements by HDRL are indeed significant with adversarial workloads. These results conclude HDRL with DT validation to be a novel and viable approach to secure, resilient, and flexible scheduling in the cloud for smart grid applications.

title: Load Scheduling With Integration of Solar Energy
authors: Theresa Merlin, K Narayanan, Ankur Singh Rana, Gulshan Sharma, Pitshou N. Bokoro, Tomonobu Senjyu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: The uneven distribution of loads throughout the day in an active distribution system often results in increased operational costs and power losses. These challenges can be addressed through optimal load scheduling, which not only ensures balanced energy distribution but also reduces daily energy expenses. This study proposes an analytical approach to load scheduling that achieves significant cost savings while promoting long-term sustainability. Moreover, the integration of solar energy plays a pivotal role in further reducing energy costs, easing grid stress, and enhancing system efficiency. The findings demonstrate that incorporating solar energy reduces overall grid loading, improves system reliability, and prolongs the lifespan of grid infrastructure. By increasing solar energy utilization, the dependence on traditional energy sources is diminished, leading to a reduced carbon footprint and a more environmentally sustainable energy distribution system.

title: Blockchain-Based Carbon Credit Trading
authors: Chitra BT, Amitesh Srinivas, Avneesh Singh, Aditya GS, Aditya Sharma
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The growing impact of climate change has made carbon credit trading an essential strategy for controlling industrial emissions. Traditional systems face issues such as fraud, inefficiency, and limited transparency. This paper presents a blockchain-based platform for carbon credit trading that supports the minting, exchange, and burning of digital credits. Organizations can retire (burn) credits to offset emissions and obtain a non-fungible token (NFT) certificate as verified proof of compliance. Through decentralization, immutability, and transparency, the framework removes intermediaries and builds trust. The proposed system offers a secure, scalable, and tamper-resistant solution for verifiable carbon offsetting, advancing sustainable blockchain innovation.

title: Development of a Cost-Effective Internet-Based Home Energy Management System with Appliance Prioritization
authors: Motaz Amer
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: A key element of smart grids that improves energy control and lowers overall consumption is demand side management, or DSM. By intelligently automating appliance usage, Home Energy Management Systems (HEMS) enable residential Demand Response (DR), which is a critical component of DSM. The internet-based smart home energy management system presented in this paper gives end users the ability to automatically regulate their smart loads through utility-driven programs. To efficiently reduce electricity costs, the system uses an optimized energy source allocation strategy in conjunction with a priority-based appliance switching algorithm. A specially made smart meter with an Arduino Mega 2560 controller and a Wi-Fi shield for smooth communication is used for experimental validation. The results show that, while preserving user comfort, the suggested solution effectively lowers peak power consumption, the Peak-to-Average Ratio (PAR), and generates significant cost savings. The strategy supports both consumers and utility companies in reaching more intelligent energy management goals by offering a low-cost, readily implementable platform for realtime monitoring and control of residential energy consumption.

title: Predicting Student Academic Performance Via Deep Learning: PyTorch-Based Study on UCI Dataset
authors: Aimina Ali Eli, Abdur Rahman, Naresh Kshetri
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Predicting student academic performance is crucial for early intervention and improved educational outcomes. This study introduces a deep learning framework using a feedforward neural network built with PyTorch to predict students’ final grades based on demographic, behavioral, and academic features from the UCI Student Performance dataset. Preprocessing involved categorical encoding and feature scaling. Despite the dataset’s limited size (395 samples), the model achieved a Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of approximately 2.5 on a $0-20$ grade scale. To benchmark its effectiveness, the model’s performance was compared with traditional machine learning algorithms including Random Forest and SVM. Basic explainability using SHAP was also incorporated to interpret feature contributions. Security features such as encrypted model parameters and secure deployment protocols were implemented to ensure responsible handling of student data. The study highlights the promise of deep learning in educational analytics, offering an interpretable, secure, and effective method to support proactive academic interventions.

title: Technological Interventions To Improve Novice Driver Safety: A Review of Current Technologies and Future Directions
authors: Ahmad Abutahoun, Mohammed Elhenawy, Natalie Watson-Brown, Sebastien Glaser, Andry Rakotonirainy, Taqwa I. Alhadidi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, and Internet of Things (AIBThings)
abstract: Novice drivers are overrepresented in road traffic fatalities, particularly during the early stages of independent driving. While traditional interventions such as the Graduated Licensing System (GLS) have made strides in mitigating this risk, substantial gaps remain in preparing novice drivers with the skills required for safe and independent driving. In response to these gaps, recent research has focused on developing more targeted and adaptive driver performance evaluation and advice systems. This review examines these developments, categorizing them into simulation-based, motion-based, and AIdriven approaches, including the emerging use of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs). Our analysis underscores several critical limitations in existing research, including the absence of real-world validation, a predominant reliance on single-modality data in field studies, inadequate emphasis on delivering explanatory and prioritized guidance in real-time systems, and a notable scarcity of efforts to adapt emerging AI models. MLLMs offer promising capabilities in multimodal perception and reasoning. Future research should focus on integrating lightweight, edge-compatible models, enhancing contextual advice through conversational AI, and developing robust prioritization frameworks for providing real-time advice. Addressing these gaps can contribute to the development of comprehensive systems that support novice drivers in improving their skills and reducing crash risks.

title: Randomness And Avalanche Effect Evaluation of the Encryption Algorithm for HF Applications
authors: Dilmukhanbet Dyusenbayev, Nursulu Kapalova, Oleg Lizunov, Ardabek Khompysh
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: The employees of the Information Security Laboratory have developed the AL04 cryptographic algorithm based on nonlinear substitution blocks and a round key scheduling mechanism. This symmetric block encryption algorithm is designed to achieve an optimal balance between security, computational efficiency and low resource consumption, with the aim of using it to protect voice information transmitted over high-frequency (HF) radio channels.To evaluate the cryptographic strength of the AL04 algorithm, well-known cryptanalysis methods were used. In addition, the output data of the algorithm were evaluated for randomness using NIST and Donald Knuth statistical tests. The results showed that the encrypted data generated by AL04 correspond to random data. The AL04 algorithm and its S-boxes were analyzed for the avalanche effect. As a result, the obtained data demonstrate a strong avalanche effect, which indicates high sensitivity to changes in input data and ensuring cryptographic strength.

title: Secure and Energy-Efficient Clustering in WBANs for Extended Network Lifetime
authors: Annapurnanand Tiwari, Saif Obayd Husayn, R. Ahila, S Govinda Rao, D. Anandhasilambarasan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: An aspect that affects both the dependability and lifetime of wireless body area networks (WBANs), which are fundamental to modern continuous health monitoring systems, is the degree to which they use energy efficiently. Given that sensor nodes have limited battery capacity, improving energy use remains a significant issue of debate. This research examines a new method called Energy-Efficient and Enhanced Clustering with Routing (E3-CR), which is designed to make wireless body area networks (WBANs) last longer. Using factors such as remaining energy, communication distance, and density, the dynamic cluster head selection algorithm of E3-CR can maximize the energy efficiency of the whole network. On top of that, hybrid routing strategies improve connection inside and across clusters while lowering the amount of communication overhead and unnecessary transmissions. Research using simulated benchmark WBAN datasets showed that E3-CR is better than the best clustering algorithms in extending network life and reducing total energy use, cutting it by up to 28 percent. This approach guarantees a more consistent network connection and causes packets to be delivered more quickly. The study indicates that E3-CR is a great choice for long-term medical monitoring as it employs a more efficient and long-term strategy to lower the energy WBAN consumes.

title: Secure Blockchain-Powered Health Record Management for Telemedicine and Remote Patient Monitoring Using Decentralized Encryption
authors: Padakanti Shirisha, Sandeep Soni, V. Hemamalini, Manish Agarwal, Zaid Ajzan Balassem, Ali Usama Al-Hayaly, Mohammed Abdulsalam Alhayaly
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The fast development of telemedicine and remote patient monitoring has increased the need for secure and reliable management of health records. This study shows how blockchain technology combined with decentralized encryption techniques, can enhance the security, privacy and access to health information. The paper formulates a blockchain-based architecture in which patients are stored securely and retrieved by encrypted smart contracts, keeping the data intact and private. A decentralized consensus mechanism is used to avoid unauthorized access and tampering. Machine learning models are also incorporated for discrepancy and data recovery. Experimental results indicate that the proposed system enhances data protection, minimizes the risk of cyber attacks, and permitted the patient’s information to the patient’s information from the authorized healthcare providers. Key results indicate that blockchain technology is capable of providing a tamper-evident and transparent medical data environment, addressing telemedicine’s privacy issue. Through the support of distributed encryption, the research facilitates pursuing safe healthcare approaches and thus boosts trust and efficacy in distance-affected individual care. Future visions must emphasize scalability and compliance to support commonly applied blockchain in medicine.

title: Scalable Blockchain-Based Smart Contract Enforcement Framework for Cross-Border Protection and Verification of Intellectual Property
authors: Ammar Abbas Al Husseini, Ahmed Y. Alasadi, Aqeel M. Alsadi, Marwah Hamad Hasan, Muhanad Tareq Jehad, Ali Musa Hussein, Mahdi Nooruldeen Muhamad
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: This research introduces a jurisdiction-aware, zk-SNARK-enhanced smart contract framework for scalable, cross-border intellectual property (IP) enforcement using blockchain infrastructure. By integrating Solidity-based contract logic, decentralized identifiers (DIDs), Layer-2 scaling, and real-time policy-aware oracles, the system supports legally compliant automation of patent licensing, copyright validation, and trademark dispute resolution. The framework consistently achieved enforcement accuracy above 97.6%, compliance robustness of 0.94, and throughput gains up to 3.4× relative to baseline architectures. It reduced contract execution latency by over 45%, and zk-SNARK proofs allowed secure, privacy-preserving ownership validation within 3.6 seconds proving time and sub-2 second verification. Formal verification and multichain interoperability further ensure logical integrity and cross-jurisdictional adaptability without centralized arbitration. Unlike high-latency or siloed systems, the proposed architecture maintains contract execution below 6.2 seconds and scales across 30+ jurisdictions, demonstrating readiness for deployment in next-generation, global IP management infrastructures.

title: Automated Fault Diagnosis in IoT Systems Through Semantic Analysis of Long-Form Textual Data
authors: Ali Mamanpoosh, Hossein Karshenas
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) systems has led to an exponential growth of operational data, much of which exists as unstructured, long-form text such as system logs and maintenance reports. This “textual exhaust” contains critical information for fault diagnosis, yet it remains largely untapped by traditional monitoring tools. Furthermore, standard Large Language Models (LLMs) are constrained by limited context windows, making them unsuitable for directly analyzing the lengthy data corpora from system-wide IoT incidents. This paper introduces a multi-stage NLP pipeline designed to overcome this limitation. Our method systematically segments vast streams of textual data, employs domain-specific summarization on each chunk, and aggregates these summaries to construct a coherent, human-readable narrative of system behavior. By applying this framework to a 350 MB simulated incident log, we demonstrate two key outcomes: a data reduction ratio of 85.8%, and an average quality score of 3.72 out of 5.0 as assessed by an LLM-as-a-Judge protocol. The generated summary accurately identifies the incident's root cause, indicating a clear path to reducing Mean Time To Resolution (MTTR) by transforming millions of log lines into actionable insights.

title: Using Vibro-Acoustic Measurement Method for Transformer’s Onload Tap Changer Diagnostics—Case Study
authors: Sofiane Bakkay
publish: 2025 IEEE PES/IAS PowerAfrica
abstract: Vibro-Acoustic Measurement is considered as the latest state-of-the-art method used for diagnosing Onload Tap Charger in Power transformers. The measurement is based on analyzing the vibrations patterns captured during the switching process of the OLTC and comparing them to footprint patterns obtained after the manufacturing of the same transformer. This analyzing principle based on fingerprint measurements comparison constitutes a challenge for the users since there are thousands of transformers equipped with OLTC in the field without any previous VAM traces data. This paper will describe the various aspects of practical use of this method and will demonstrate, through a case study, how signals obtained from sister transformers are comparable and could be taken as a comparison base method in case of non-availability of fingerprints measurements. By validating this approach, reliable OLTC’s online monitoring systems could be implemented based on direct real-time comparison between similar transformers on the same grid.

title: Accelerating Drug Discovery Using GenFold-AI for Protein Structure Prediction in Genetic Disease Research
authors: Sardor Kamolov, Yokubjon Khursanov, Orzu Sokhibnazarov, Shuhrat Akhmedov, Zilola Djurayeva, Zahraa N, Abdulkareem A. Jasim Abushraida, Sajad Ali Zearah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: Accelerating drug development depends on accurate prediction of protein structure, especially in relation to genetic illness studies. Although AlphaFold2 has greatly improved wild-type protein modelling, structural change prediction from genetic mutations still presents a difficulty. To introduce proposed technique named as GenFold-AI, an advanced sophisticated framework enhancing mutant protein structure predictions by combining AlphaFold2 with Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations. MD simulations improve the stability evaluation of mutant proteins by including dynamic conformational changes and atomic-level interactions. Additionally investigate, using a yeast-based complementing sensor, the effects of insertions and deletions (indels) on protein folds. Experimental validation shows that GenFold-AI beats AlphaFold2 in forecasting structural changes caused by mutations, hence producing more consistent therapeutic target identification. By enhancing the accuracy of disease-associated mutation modelling and refining protein function analysis, this method speeds up drug development and thereby advances treatments for genetic conditions.

title: Explainable AI Using SHAP for Transparent and Interpretable Decision-Making in Financial Risk Assessment and Credit Scoring
authors: Deepak Patidar, Mohammed Hussein Fallah, Thamizhkani.B, Karri Hemalatha, C. Karthikeyan, Zahraa N. Salaman, Zeyad Taha Yaseen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: In recent years, financial institutions have increasingly relied on artificial intelligence (AI) to evaluate credit ratings and economic risk. In the meantime, Many artificial intelligence-oriented models operate as black boxes, making decision-making difficult to understand. Lack of transparency raises doubts regarding regulatory compliance, justice, and responsibility. Explainable artificial intelligence (Xai) solves these challenges when one understands model predictions. The popular Xai method used to help grasp complex artificial intelligence models to ensure that their results are more dependable and understandable is Shapley's (SAPL) additive explanations. This paper investigates the application of the SHAP in evaluating financial risks and credit scores. Real-world financial data sets to train machine learning models, including gradient reinforcement techniques, neural networks, and decision-making trees. After that, the artificial intelligence decision-making process is investigated using the SHAP concerning several factors like income, credit history, and job status. This work evaluates SHAP's performance in improving interpretability and justice. Initial findings suggest that the SHAP provides unambiguous justifications for resource value and significantly increases the transparency of the model. Improved interpretability helps financial companies identify likely biases, enhancing ratings and regulatory compliance. According to the studies, AI financial models increase accountability and confidence. Including artificial intelligence-oriented credit scores into their operations would help most open financial companies improve decision-making processes, follow policies, and increase customer confidence.

title: Mitigating Cyber Threats Through Artificial Intelligence with a Deep Dive into Machine Learning Applications in Cyber Security
authors: Shilpa Choudhary, Kodi Srinivas, Rupesh Kumar Mishra, Bhavana Majji, Tadaboina Ramya, B Ramana Reddy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: In the digital era, cyber threats are evolving day by day and traditional solutions become ineffective. To overcome this problem, we need adaptive, intelligent protection mechanisms in cybersecurity. This research paper presents a hybrid machine learning method that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), Random Forest (RF) classifiers, and the DBSCAN clustering algorithm to detect malware, intrusion attempts, and anomalous activities in real time scenario. The CNN algorithm achieved 92.5% accuracy in malware classification, while the RF classifier achieved 89.7% accuracy in intrusion detection. Additionally, the DBSCAN algorithm outperformed traditional statistical techniques in anomaly detection with an F1-score of 90.3%. The proposed work improves the detection accuracy and reduces false positives, while adapting to both known and unknown threats. Proposed work outcomes highlight the potential of hybrid approaches to reinforce cybersecurity infrastructure and lay a foundation for developing intelligent and self-adaptive defense systems.

title: Emerging Trends in Hybrid Neural Network- Based Techniques for PSP MOSFET Parameter Extraction
authors: Abinaya S M, Sheejin N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of technology, modeling and simulating MOSFETs is more complex at nanoscale levels. This paper discusses a different type of engineering design development of neural network based hybrid frameworks for the extraction of parameters of PSP MOSFETs and scalability problems. The integration of deep learning models with engineering optimization techniques such as genetic algorithms or particle swarm optimization in this way exudes the effective control of sophisticated parameter interactions and variability. Some of the document also attends to pre and post analysis of the parameter extraction using hybrid methodologies with neural network assisted compact models and adaptive learning techniques that improve accuracy and performance metrics. In addition, the capabilities of hybrid frameworks are assessed to meet the demands imposed by the complexity of modern circuits. This paper uses the applications of AI technologies and enhances different use cases in PSP MOSFET parameter extraction.

title: Anomaly Detection in Encrypted Network Traffic Using Deep Learning
authors: Chandrani Chakravorty, Prajwal S D, Punith S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: The use of encrypted traffic to protect user privacy has surged in response to the network security threats posed by the rapid advances in IoT, data science, and online services. Encryption provides better security, but it poses a significant challenge in identifying malicious behavior since conventional inspection methods do not allow for efficient analysis of encrypted data. This has led to the use of machine learning and particularly deep learning to provide solution to these multiple domains-as well as providing valuable methods for anomaly detection and analysis of encrypted traffic. The assertion is being made that when machine learning and deep learning are used without decrypting private information, these applications can provide security with intelligent recognition of patterns based on multiple analytic intersections without exposing sensitive private data during any possible learn process. However, challenges still exist such as the lack of data and adversarial attacks. Various techniques for anomaly detection in encrypted traffic using deep learning are presented in this paper. Limitations and future research directions are also discussed.

title: AI-Driven Performance Analytics in Sports: Enhancing Athlete Training and Injury Prevention
authors: Tushar Dhar Shukla, Aakash Dhiman, Neelam Sharma, Malik Bader Alazzam, Al-Hussein Maysir Majid, A. Balakumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: AI is intensifying in sports performance analytics, with which athlete training is being replaced and revolution is being done through real-time monitoring, personal response and prevention of injuries. For example, these functions – machine learning, deep reinforcement learning, computer vision, wearable sensors, and this research - are examined in this research for what role they play in adaptation to training. Using the huge dataset and algorithm thinking found, AI enables better decisions, which leads to standard training paradigms to catch tracking and performance. Results for DQL and PPO, smart, data-powered athlete training to balance exploration and exploitation on hybrid reinforcement learning approaches. AI comparison displays its major effects on speed, endurance, agility and recovery efficiency, which can lead to infallible, efficient training, less susceptibility to low injuries and dedication at the same time.

title: Green IoT-Enabled Intelligent Scheduling Framework for Electric Vehicle Charging Stations Using Hybrid Deep Learning
authors: Hossein Shahinzadeh, Farshad Ebrahimi, Amirafshin Zamani, Mahtab Bagheri, Saiedeh Mehrabani-Najafabadi, S. Mohammadali Zanjani
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Internet of Things and Applications (IoT)
abstract: The rapid adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) has reshaped the energy landscape by offering an environmentally friendly alternative to conventional fossil-fuel-based transportation. Nevertheless, the massive and uncoordinated charging demand of EVs poses significant challenges to charging infrastructure, especially under dynamic electricity pricing and spatial constraints. To address this, we present a Green IoT-integrated intelligent scheduling framework that optimizes charging station (CS) allocation by incorporating the state of charge (SoC), distance, and pricing factors. Unlike conventional neural network-based approaches, our method leverages a hybrid deep learning architecture combining temporal sequence modeling with attention mechanisms, which enhances the accuracy of SoC prediction and facilitates more reliable scheduling decisions. Furthermore, we formulate multi-objective CS selection strategies that prioritize trade-offs among price, distance, and user preferences to ensure efficient utilization of resources. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate the robustness of the proposed framework across multiple performance metrics, including prediction error (MAE), convergence efficiency, and SoC estimation accuracy. Results indicate that the integration of advanced optimization strategies significantly improves scheduling effectiveness compared to traditional AI models.

title: Energy Efficient Precoding Scheme for Multiuser MISO Symbiotic Radio Communications
authors: Mohan Wang, Liang Wu, Zaichen Zhang
publish: 2025 6th Information Communication Technologies Conference (ICTC)
abstract: Symbiotic radio (SR) communication emerges as a pivotal technology for the realization of spectrum- and energy-efficient wireless networks. This paradigm empowers passive backscatter devices (BDs) to harness both the spectral resources and the transmitted energy of active primary transmitters (PTs). In this paper, we are dedicated to improving the energy-efficiency (EE) in multiuser multiple-input single-output (MISO) SR systems where the users access the system using a time division multiple access (TDMA) approach, catering to a diverse array of users and antenna configurations. The maximum individual EE for both the primary communication and backscatter communication is derived, and convex optimization problems are formulated. Through rigorous simulation, we substantiate the efficiency of the proposed precoding scheme.

title: An Integrated Network Routing Solution Using RIP Protocol, Prim's Algorithm, CRC and TCP Tahoe
authors: Sujatha Badiger, Gagandeep S Cholaki, Gaurav R, K S Baradvaj
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Modern computer networks require sophisticated protocol integration for reliable communication. Current implementations often operate in isolation, limiting effectiveness in real-world scenarios. This research develops a simulation frame-work combining Routing Information Protocol (RIP), Prim's algorithm, TCP Tahoe congestion control, and CRC-16-CCITT error detection. The goal is to design an integrated protocol stack coordinating routing, transport, and error detection lay-ers. The work evaluates performance under realistic conditions and demonstrates cross-layer optimization effectiveness. The framework provides end-to-end communication with dynamic routing and robust error detection. Experimental evaluation using “Computer Network Protocol PBL” data shows 94.7% packet delivery success rate, validating the framework's real-world potential.

title: Control Strategy Based Sliding Mode Control of DC Microgrid in Islanded Mode Operations
authors: Burak Onar, Şevki Demirbaş, Kenan Ünal
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: With the widespread adoption of renewable energy sources, the utilization of low-power microgrids has also increased. In this context, photovoltaic (PV) panels have become an integral part of our energy systems, owing to their ease of deployment, availability, and scalability from small low-power systems to large-scale solar farms. However, due to the inherently variable nature of PV systems throughout the day, ensuring stability and continuity of power supply has become a critical challenge. To address this issue, the integration of battery energy storage systems (BESS) with PV generation has emerged as a preferred solution. Two different control strategies have been implemented for the proposed study. Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) was employed to extract maximum power, while an Sliding Mode Control (SMC) control strategy was used to limit PV generation when necessary. Through the proposed control method, the islanded system can supply the target load continuously and without interruption. The effectiveness and performance of the proposed microgrid design and its control strategies have been validated through simulations conducted in the MATLAB & Simulink environment

title: Enhancing UAV Small Target Detection via SPD-Conv and Hybrid Attention in YOLOv8
authors: Ying Chen, Xiaochun Shen, Yuelei Xu, Jun Che
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Human-Computer Interaction (ICHCI)
abstract: This paper proposes an improved model based on YOLOv8-SPD that integrates a hybrid attention mechanism to address the key challenges of low accuracy and high false detection rates in UAV small target detection under complex backgrounds. The method designs a triple attention mechanism tailored for complex scenarios, combining channel attention, window self- attention, and overlapping cross-attention, which significantly enhances the model's capability to discriminate small UAV targets in challenging environments. Experimental results on the DUT UAV dataset demonstrate that the improved SPDHA-UAV-YOLOv8 (SHUY) model achieves a 1.38% increase in mAP50 compared to the baseline YOLOv8-SPD model.

title: Design of an Improved Model Using Adaptive Homomorphic Encryption and Multi-Level Access Control for Secure Cloud Computations
authors: Shubhangi S. Shambharkar, Latesh G. Malik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) theories are good for privacy-preserving computing but computationally costly and lack adaptive access constraints. Due to these constraints, this work proposes Adaptive Homomorphic Encryption with Multi-Level Access Control, an integrated system. It computes encrypted data efficiently and has 40% less encryption delay than normal-FHE utilizing Levelled Homomorphic Encryption. The practice-relevant LHE trade-off between efficiency and deep homomorphic calculations was chosen. For safe data access, a Multi-Level Access Control (MLAC) system can dynamically adjust access privileges based on time, geolocation, device integrity, and behavioral trust score. This policy-driven module examines user credentials and environment context to authorize or prohibit access. AHE/MLAC computation against encrypted data inside adaptive security constraints. Preliminary results indicate a 92 percent decrease in unauthorized access and promising results for encryption efficiency sets.

title: Reinforcement Learning Approach to Mitigate Cyber Threats in Algorithmic Trading Platforms
authors: Ali Abbas Hadi, Haider Mahdi Rammoo, Mustafa Radif, Muqdad Zaki Hammed Banana, Ali Fakhri Abbas, Salah Mahdi Saleh Alkhafaji
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: For algorithmic trading systems, automatic decision making and dynamic system monitoring through Reinforcement Learning (RL) is highly important because they must remain safe against complex cyber threats. As for algorithmic trading, the systems liberally place static, ruledetection models expecting intrusions. This model-crafted suppression works slowly, adapts poorly to shifting attack patterns, and belligerently invokes security alarms that drown systems in meaningless alerts. The gaps in the proposed method are filled with D-ARIN - Deep Q Learning for Anomaly Response in Intrusion Networks. This framework employs responsive and dynamic deal-based anomaly detection and response through reinforcement learning powered Deep Q Learning. Trade decision processes using D-ARIN can interact and optimize, learns from algorithms actively using the environment for entrusted trade and activity, which automates optimal choices, reduction of cyber defense, and mechanics. Based on simulation verifications done using benchmark datasets of trading systems, the battling system simulated cyber attacks, D-ARIN outperformed existing systems by 95.26% in responsiveness, granting minimal false positives. The results from this study illustrate that algorithms drafted with deep mechanics powerfully enhance stability in algorithms used within systems in algorithmic trading, dealing with intense engineered spirit monitoring without compromising service efficiency.

title: A Critical Benchmark of Hybrid Quantum-Classical Graph Neural Networks for Molecular Property Prediction: Revealing Performance Bottlenecks in Current Architectures
authors: Rakesh Kalshetty, Manish S M, Shashank Kotagi, Vishwas Desai
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Hybrid quantum-classical neural networks (HQCNNs) represent a promising but largely unproven paradigm for enhancing molecular property prediction in drug discovery. Despite growing interest and optimistic claims in recent literature, rigorous benchmarks comparing these hybrid architectures against strong classical baselines remain scarce. This work implements and systematically evaluates a representative HQCNN architecture against its classical equivalent using standardized molecular datasets (QM9 and ZINC-250K) within a reproducible, multi-seed experimental framework. Contrary to optimistic expectations, our results reveal that the hybrid model consistently underperforms the classical baseline, showing a 49% increase in MAE on QM9 (1.0834 vs 0.7256) and a devastating 107% degradation on ZINC (1.4006 vs 0.6755), with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values dropping by over 80% on both datasets. Through detailed analysis, we identify fundamental challenges including information bottlenecks during quantum encoding and difficult optimization landscapes in variational quantum circuits as primary causes of performance degradation. This work provides a crucial, datadriven reality check for the field, demonstrating that current “plug-and-play” quantum layer approaches may be insufficient for practical quantum advantages. All experimental code and data are publicly released to enable community replication and investigation of more sophisticated quantum-native architectures.

title: Social Media Fake News Detection Using Transformer Model
authors: Paavani Komarla, Nagaraja G.S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Fake news's extensive proliferation on social media has become a major worldwide concern, undermining public trust in digital information and influencing elections, social movements, and health-related decisions. With the increasing reliance on online platforms for news consumption, studies reveal that false information spreads substantially faster-up to six times more quickly-than factual news on platforms like Twitter. This rapid propagation intensifies the need for robust, real-time misinformation detection mechanisms. Conventional methods for machine learning, like Logistic Regression and Random Forest has been used in this challenge but often struggle to understand the deeper contextual meanings embedded in short or ambiguous headlines. These models typically rely on surface-level features and are limited in capturing semantic nuances. The research offers a BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers)based method for detecting bogus news, a cutting-edge large language model (LLM) designed for deep Natural Language Processing (NLP) applications, for the purpose of overcoming these limitations. Leveraging BERT's bidirectional encoding capabilities, the model captures complex linguistic patterns and contextual relationships, offering a more accurate classification of news headlines. In this work, a BERT-base-uncased model is finetuned using a labeled dataset of real and fake news headlines. After applying preprocessing techniques like normalization and subword tokenization, the dataset is strategically split into training, validation, and test sets. Model will be processed or trained over 5 epochs using the AdamW optimizer. The learning rate is found to be <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mathrm{e}-5$</tex>. Accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and confusion matrix are used to assess performance. Accuracy, precision, recall, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score, and confusion matrix are used to assess performance. The model achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 8. 0 8 \%}$</tex> accuracy and an F1- score of 88.31 %, clearly outperforming traditional models and demonstrating clear potential for integration into social media moderation tools and automated news validation systems.

title: Research on Malicious C2 Regression and Prediction
authors: Lu Gao, Menglei Xu, Li Sun, Xiaoling Bai
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Network Communication and Information Security (ICNCIS)
abstract: This paper focuses on the regression and prediction of malicious code in information and network security, primarily covering cryptography, regression prediction models, static configuration, configuration decryption, malicious code analysis, artificial intelligence, and computer applications. The research focuses on C2 samples found in backdoor malware. For prevalent C2 samples, the research method utilizes regression prediction methods based on static configuration decryption and symbolic regression. The experimental data for this paper is sourced from the multi-engine scanning and analysis platform VT. 139,998,761 VT samples were collected from June 2024 to June 2025, of which 22,153,930 had domain name hits. Based on the family classification criteria of the antivirus vendor ESET-NOD32, the analysis targets were selected by comprehensively considering the top backdoor malware rankings and C2 linking behavior. Based on VT dynamic data and manual analysis, a regression and prediction model for malicious C2s was developed based on static configuration decryption. Based on the model established above, a static configuration decryption engine is implemented on a computer using C and Lua programming languages to achieve regression of malicious C2 and output of related IOC information; and corresponding predictions are made based on the decrypted data stream generated by the engine using methods such as symbolic regression, ultimately realizing the application of cryptography and artificial intelligence in computer, information and network security.

title: Investigation of Adaptive Beamforming Techniques for Enhancing Spectral Efficiency in 6G mmWave Networks Utilizing Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Deepak Upadhyay, Nookala Venu, Anshu Sharma, Himanshu Sharma, Lokesh Kumar, Neha Jain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: In this paper, we study the employment of machine learning (ML), especially the RL, in the adaptive beamforming in 6G mmWave networks. Key emphasis is put on improving the spectral efficiency, user mobility support and interference suppression through optimizing beamforming. The traditional, rule-based, and ML-based beamforming schemes are evaluated by spectral efficiency, energy efficiency, and SINR performance of the systems over different channels. Python and MATLAB-based simulations illustrate the benefits of ML-based beamforming for high-mobility and dense scenarios. The achievement indicates the capability of ML in real-time beamforming optimization, which may provide a promissory future direction for 6G networks. The results are useful for the development of future wireless communication systems.

title: CodeSketch: A Real-Time Multi-Language Code Visualization Tool with UML and Animation Support - A Comparative Study
authors: Harsda Shrivastava, Lohitha Kanisettypalli, Jiya Borikar, Adhikari Bhavishya, Aiswariya Milan K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative code visualization tool that simplifies code comprehension and improves conceptual clarity for students and educators, while significantly enhancing software development workflows and educational outcomes by converting source code into interactive graphical representations. It automatically generates flowcharts, UML diagrams, and animations for Python, Java, and C++. The accuracy of parsing is ensured through the Python AST module and regular expressions, while user interaction is streamlined via the Tkinter framework. A key contribution of this work is a comparative study that rigorously evaluates the proposed tool against existing visualization solutions across multiple dimensions such as language support, usability, feature richness, and educational applicability. This study demonstrates the superior functionality and user experience offered by the tool, reinforcing its impact in both academic and professional environments.

title: Photovoltaic Generation Prediction using a Weather-Forecast-Aware Autoformer
authors: Sergio Vanegas, Lasse Lensu, Samuli Honkapuro, Fredy Ruiz
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Renewable Energy Research and Applications (ICRERA)
abstract: Effective management of Distributed Energy Resources is essential for a green-energy transition, ensuring sustainable and reliable power. This requires accurately forecasting complex renewable energy production, a task well-suited for deep neural networks due to their ability to model intricate temporal and spatial dynamics with low computational overhead compared to physics-based simulation. This work leverages a domain-specific normalization strategy and a modified Autoformer, a Transformer-like neural network architecture that uses the Cross-Correlation function for calculating time dependencies, to better capture signal periodicities and leverage future information. The resulting scheme was benchmarked against established forecasting architectures using real-world photovoltaic generation data, resulting in comparable accuracy with the added benefit of interpretable internal coefficients, which are shown to be a useful analytical tool.

title: The Future of Smart Homes with Bluetooth and Microcontroller Integration
authors: Akkarapaka Chiranjeevi Manikantan, Akshika Munshi, Amal Ajith, Allen Sony, Abhiram K, Jayasree K R, Shankar Nalinakshan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: This paper presents a novel Arduino-based smart home automation system designed to enhance energy efficiency and user convenience. Motivated by the increasing demand for IoT-driven smart home solutions, this work demonstrates the integration of Arduino microcontroller with sensors and communication modules, including Bluetooth Technology, to implement key automation functions such as lighting control and appliance management. The proposed system demonstrates the potential for energy conservation, convenience, and security improvements. Future Development recommendations include refining the user interface and expanding compatibility with other smart devices, and optimizing energy efficiency. This project showcases the effectiveness and versatility of Arduino-based home automation systems, paving the way for modernizing living spaces and improving residential comfort and sustainability.

title: Application of Convolutional Neural Network Based on Multi-Scale Feature Fusion and Data Augmentation in Transmission Tower Defect Recognition
authors: Jinjiao Hou, Rui Hu, Fan Yang, Wenjin She
publish: 2025 Low-Altitude Economy Forum &amp; International Conference on Low-Altitude Flight Technology and Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Application (LEF &amp; ICLU)
abstract: Transmission line towers are critical components of power transmission networks, and their structural health directly impacts the safe and stable operation of the power grid. Traditional manual inspection methods suffer from strong subjectivity, low efficiency, and high misjudgment rates, making them inadequate for large-scale and fine-grained maintenance tasks. To address these issues, an intelligent defect detection model for towers based on multi-scale feature fusion is proposed. First, 300 defect images collected by UAVs were annotated and augmented. Then, a feature pyramid network (FPN) structure was employed for feature extraction, with Convolutional Block Attention module incorporated to enhance defect recognition accuracy. Experimental results show that, compared to the baseline model, the proposed method improves accuracy, recall, and mAP@0.5 by 3.1%, 4.5%, and 3.3%, respectively. It also performs better in detecting small defects and in complex scenes, offering a practical solution for intelligent inspection of power facilities.

title: AI-Enhanced Phishing Defense & Real-Time Malicious URL Detection
authors: Mangala H S, Keerthana Shankar, K Deepa Shree, Divya H N, Swathi A, Amrutgouda M Patil
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainability, Innovation &amp; Technology (ICSIT)
abstract: The goal of this project is an AI-based development of the phishing defense and malicious URL recognition system that operates in real time. The purpose of this system employing machine learning and natural language processing techniques is to discriminate phishing web pages and URL links as harmful based on the domain name, content on the web page and users' expectations and patterns. The approach combines deep learning models that self-update based on new phishing approaches and thus are able to provide high performance and protection at scale. It supports real-time detection and alerting and can be integrated with other security tools, which improves the security of users and businesses. The objective of the project is to combat phishing and improve safety on the net.

title: Comparative Assessment and Prediction of Weather Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Sowmya DN, Kapilan N, Vijay Kumar S, Jose de Jusus Agustin Flores Cuautle
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Computational System and Information Technology for Sustainable Solutions (CSITSS)
abstract: Accurate weather forecasting is a complex task because atmospheric variables interact in highly nonlinear ways. In this study, the focus is on evaluating and comparing four machine learning algorithms for short-term weather prediction; namely, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Gradient Boosting (GB), and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGB). The researchers used a publicly available dataset that has a record of 3000 weather readings (on a daily basis) including temperature, humidity, rainfall, and wind speed, to train and assess each of the four algorithms. In order to ensure that an accurate evaluation occurs, the researcher clean the dataset, conducted feature scaling, and split the data into respective training and testing datasets. The performance is evaluated with respect to Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Mean Average Error (MAE), and the coefficient of determination (R2). Those experiments show that the XGB algorithm achieves the lowest RMSE (7.9), and has the lowest MAE (6.0), the XGB algorithm also achieved the highest R2 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0.92)$</tex> compared to other algorithms. This suggests that ensemble-based boosting techniques are effective in predicting weather relative to distance- and margin-based methods. The study highlights XGB's potential for practical deployment in meteorological forecasting systems, while acknowledging dataset size and regional coverage as limitations for broader generalization.

title: Political Regimes based Critical Infrastructure Strategies Across International Digital Sovereignty Frameworks
authors: Ammar Abdulhassan Muhammed, Mustafa Abdulirees Jebur, Mohammed Saeb Nahi, Estabraq Rasheed Ibrahim, Ihsan Alwan Muhsin, Hayder Rageh Abdulsada
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Cyber Resilience (ICCR)
abstract: The global change toward digital governance has amplified the strategic importance of critical infrastructure (CI) and its regulation under various international digital sovereignty frameworks. Political regimes, including democratic, authoritarian, and hybrid ones, play a decisive role in shaping these infrastructure strategies based on ideological, security, and economic priorities. However, existing methods often adopt binary or linear models that fail to account for the complex, multi-causal nature of regime behavior and policy outcomes in digital sovereignty. These limitations restrict a nuanced understanding of how diverse political and contextual factors interact to shape CI governance. This paper proposes the use of Fuzzy Set Qualitative Comparative Analysis (fsQCA) to overcome these issues by enabling the examination of causal configurations across multiple cases. fsQCA enables partial membership and assesses the interplay of political, economic, and technological factors that shape state strategies. Applying fsQCA to a cross-national sample, this research identifies multiple causal pathways through which different regime types adopt either high or low-intensity digital sovereignty strategies for CI protection. The findings reveal that no single factor determines strategy intensity; instead, regime type, cybersecurity threats, and foreign technology dependency interact in complex ways.
